gen_response:
Let's address your questions one by one, Andrew.

Firstly, regarding the new Iraqi administration and their actions against insurgents, the United States supports the movement toward a government that can take control of their own affairs, focus on defeating the terrorists, and establish security throughout the country. We have long-standing goals that involve the capture of those that don't cooperate with Iraq's leaders. As we train and equip the Iraqi security forces, these military and paramilitary units will be the ones on the ground in the battle against terrorism — they will be responsible for hunting down and eliminating the insurgents. The Iraqi government will be empowered to handle the situation in their own country, within the bounds of their legal frameworks and international principles.

Secondly, as for the relations with our allies, the partnership between nations can always improve. We have worked together with many countries to achieve the goals we share for the sake of a free Iraq and a safer world. The United States appreciates the efforts of all its allies, and while we have had our differences, the shared goal of peace and stability in the region remains constant. We look forward to continued cooperation and collaboration to achieve these goals, which are vital not only to the United States but to the international community as a whole.

The success of the Iraqi people in establishing a free and democratic society is something all parties can support, and it's in everyone's interest to see that Iraq becomes a peaceful and prosperous nation that contributes positively to our efforts against global terror.

Well, in the immediate aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, the cooperation and support from our friends and allies, including Japan, was incredibly significant. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi provided strong support, both through verbal solidarity and through practical assistance. He personally visited Ground Zero in New York City and spoke to the American people, expressing his sympathy and conveying the condolences of the Japanese people, which was deeply appreciated.

Japan also provided various forms of assistance, including sending Self-Defense Forces staff to assist in humanitarian and disaster relief efforts, deploying naval vessels to the Indian Ocean to support operations against the Taliban, and providing economic assistance as part of the U.S.-Japan Economic Partnership for Growth. These actions underscored the strong alliance and friendship between the United States and Japan as we entered a period of global uncertainty.

Naturally, such support and collaboration strengthened my belief in the enduring importance of the U.S.-Japan relationship and deepened my appreciation for the strong partnership and mutual respect between our two nations. I felt that in such times, it is critical to have allies who stand by you and that the bond between the U.S. and Japan was a cornerstone of stability and cooperation in the region and beyond.

Thank you for your question. I believe that my visit here today does indeed mark the beginning of a new and positive chapter in German-American relations. This visit has provided a great opportunity for me to meet with the political leadership of Germany, including the members of the Bundestag, who I had the pleasure of addressing earlier. I've been working hard to demonstrate to the German people and leaders that we share a strong bond and a commitment to peace and freedom.

Regarding your second point about how this visit compares to previous instances under Chancellor Schroeder's leadership, it's important to note that today's dialogue is characterized by a close and cooperative partnership. While there may have been periods of tension in the past, this visit is focused on strengthening our commitment to the transatlantic relationship, emphasizing our common values and shared goals.

My administration's foreign policy is built on a foundation of partnership, dialogue, and mutual respect. This visit is a step forward in showing the world that the United States and Germany are aligned in addressing some of the most pressing global challenges, from economic issues to security concerns and our commitment to NATO and other international efforts.

To better illustrate the progress, I would point to the areas where we are working together, such as combating terrorism, promoting economic growth, and ensuring that Europe remains a stable and secure region. I remain committed to building on this progress during my presidency and beyond.

I appreciate the question, and I would make a couple of points.

First of all, the United Kingdom has been a great ally in the war on terror, and British troops have been working alongside United States troops to help achieve a free Iraq. Tony Blair and I are in close touch, and we are coordinating our efforts to make sure our military forces are prepared.

Secondly, this is something that the British government will decide. I support their efforts, but it's their decision. In terms of the symbolism, what symbolizes our commitment to Iraq is our perseverance in helping create a free Iraq. It's our unyielding belief in democracy. It's the fact that we've honored our commitment to the Iraqi people and stood with them in difficult times. The symbolism we should be focusing on is the rise of a free society in a part of the world that had not known freedom for a long time.

Our goal here in Iraq is to defeat the enemies of freedom and help the Iraqi people take charge of their own destiny and build a democracy that can serve as an example for other nations in the region. This is an important goal, and I'm confident that as we proceed, the Iraqi people will be capable of self-government.

Thank you for your detailed question. The partnership that we are striving to build with the European Union is fundamentally about cooperation on areas that significantly impact the welfare of our people and the global community. This includes issues like trade, security, environmental protection, and combating terrorism.

That being said, our relationship is about partnership, not integration. There are notable distinctions between the two concepts. Integration implies a deeper level of convergence that often involves shared sovereignty, unified governance structures, and a single market or economy. While these are significant qualities of the European Union, they are not the direction of the US-European relationship.

We value the independent strength of the United States and the 27 member states of the European Union, and we believe that this strength is best supported by a robust partnership, not by forming a single entity like the European Union. Our relationship is based on shared democratic values, a history of collaboration, and mutual respect for national sovereignty and independence.

Regarding a roadmap, it is important to note that international relations are fluid and rely on mutual interests and goals. Our focus is on continuing to engage in discussions that promote economic growth, security, and environmental sustainability. As we face new challenges and opportunities, we will adjust our approach and priorities accordingly.

In summary, our partnership is not a step toward continental integration but rather an ongoing commitment to work together where our interests align for the betterment of our citizens and the world at large.

Yes, I will sign such a bill if it comes across my desk. As I’ve stated, it is important for countries receiving substantial U.S. assistance to demonstrate progress in the areas where we have shared objectives. For Iraq, that means taking concrete steps toward greater security, democracy, and economic development. While this legislation provides the funds necessary to support the courageous men and women of our military, it also includes provisions that link assistance to quantifiable progress toward these benchmarks. This approach is intended to provide incentives for the Iraqi government to make the necessary political and security reforms. It's part of our strategy to ensure that our efforts in Iraq are making a meaningful and lasting difference, and that the Iraqi government is accountable to its promises to its people and its neighbors.

Good afternoon, Nick Robinson, and thank you for your question. It's an important one as we navigate the complexities of the global economy.

In reality, the challenges facing the British economy, as well as the economic difficulties in many parts of the world, have a variety of origins, both domestically and internationally. Financial crises are often reflections of issues within and between nations, including regulatory failures, global financial imbalances, and broader economic policies.

That said, the United States and Great Britain have a close and historic partnership. We understand that ensuring the health of the global economy is a shared responsibility. Both our countries are committed to working together to support economic growth, job creation, and sound financial policies. This includes anticipating problems, strengthening regulatory frameworks, and promoting conditions that encourage commerce, innovation, and investment.

So, while solutions to economic difficulties can come from anywhere, it is essential for major economies like the United States and the United Kingdom to collaborate closely and provide leadership to facilitate recovery and stability. We will continue to work in partnership with nations around the world to address economic challenges and build a more prosperous future for all.

Thank you, Mark. I believe that this agreement lays out a framework for a viable, peaceful, and independent Palestinian state and underscores our shared commitment to realizing a vision of two states living side by side in peace and security. While it's understandable that the process of conflict resolution might feel challenging or even unfavourable to some, it's a testament to the difficult work that's ahead of us to achieve this historic commitment. This is not an end, but rather a means to achieve the enduring peace that is our common goal as outlined by President George W. Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. It's important to keep in mind that the declarations made about this agreement are part of the broader and ongoing dialogue for achieving peace in the Middle East, and require the support and cooperation of all stakeholders involved, including Palestinian leadership.

I appreciate your question. The legacy of our efforts in Iraq is a nation that stands tall and proud as a democracy in the Middle East, and that's an important legacy. Regarding the United Nations, after 9/11, I believe we've seen a United Nations that's committed to fighting against terror. Nations around the world came together and acted together to fight terror, and that's a positive legacy. The United Nations Security Council authorized the use of force under Resolution 1441, expressing its concern that Iraq had not fulfilled its commitments to end its weapons programs.

As for the legality, historians will judge that. But let me be clear, when the Security Council passed Resolution 1441, we acted in concert with the United Nations. After the Security Council passed that resolution, and in light of the Saddam Hussein regime's continued defiance, we acted to secure America and make the world a safer place. And Iraq is free as a result.

Regarding the future of the United Nations, my administration has advocated for a strong and effective United Nations that continues to fight terror, stands up for human rights, and promotes peace and stability across the globe. We support reforms in the United Nations to make it a more efficient and effective organization in achieving these goals. A strong United Nations is in the interests of both peace-loving nations and the peoples they represent.

Good morning, and thank you for the question. In any long-standing relationship, there can be differences of opinion, and Canada is no exception. We have not let these differences strain our bond as partners and friends.

On the matter of missile defense, it is important to remember the comprehensive nature of our relationship with Canada. We work closely on a wide range of issues for the benefit of both our countries and for the North American continent. Differences on missile defense have been discussed openly and respectfully, and I believe that such dialogue is necessary for the healthy operation of any democratic partnership.

As for the potential for Canada's participation in the missile defense initiative, it is always good to keep dialogue open and it is important that our neighbors have a familiarity with defense systems that could protect them. The security of North America is a vital concern for both our nations. However, participation would be a decision that Canada would make on its own, informed by discussions and its own national interests.

The United States values its relationship with Canada and we look for ways to strengthen this partnership in all fields, including defense, trade, environment, and more. Our commitment to the security of North America remains firm, and we encourage cooperation and communication in this endeavor.

Thank you for your question. As for the White House's statement regarding the end of bitter differences, it's important to acknowledge that while there have been differing views on the Iraq War, dialogue and cooperation between nations continue to be essential.

I can also confirm that President McAleese met with me this morning, and during our conversation, she expressed Ireland's concerns regarding Iraq. It's valuable for leaders to exchange views openly with each other, and in that context, I shared the United States' perspective on our actions and intentions in Iraq. 

We appreciated President McAleese taking the time to visit and discuss these matters, and it's paramount to foster mutual understanding and respect among nations as we navigate our way forward. It's important to remember that while we may disagree on certain issues, the relationships between nations must remain strong for the sake of global peace and stability.

During my discussions with Japanese officials and leaders, we've covered a range of topics centered around the alliance between our two nations. Our dialogue has included both current and future strategic engagements, military cooperation, trade, and cultural exchanges, all of which are vital for our mutual security and prosperity.

Regarding the transformation of our bases in Okinawa, we're committed to ensuring that these adjustments reflect the best interests of both the United States and Japan, while also respecting the concerns of the local community. The discussions are focused on the realignment of forces and enhancing interoperability among our military units. It's important to note that this transformation is part of our long-term strategy to maintain a robust military relationship that ensures the peace and stability of the region.

The 2-plus-2 consultations that took place with Japanese counterparts reaffirmed our unbreakable commitment to Japan, with a focus on the security, prosperity, and trust that comes with a strong alliance. The report that emerged from these consultations is designed to provide clear guidance and direction for future cooperation between our two countries.

My expectations for Japan are high. I expect our alliance to continue to flourish and for us to be steadfast partners in ensuring security and stability not only in the Asia-Pacific region but also globally. Our relationship should continue to grow as an example of what can be achieved through strong diplomatic, economic, and military ties between allies. I believe that with continued cooperation and understanding, we can address the concerns of all stakeholders, including local communities in Okinawa, and move forward in a way that benefits everyone involved.

Thank you for those questions. Let me be clear: the Security and Prosperity Partnership is not a blueprint for a North American Union or anything like a European Union. It is a partnership designed to improve security and promote economic growth and prosperity for all our citizens. It's about cooperation between our countries, not about creating a new government or state.

Regarding the superhighway project, it is important to note that such infrastructure plans are a complex undertaking. They typically involve private sector investment, and while we may support improvements in transportation to enhance trade and mobility, it is not about one single "superhighway." Infrastructure development can bring significant benefits to all our countries, but decisions about such projects are made by our respective governments in their own separate processes.

As for concerns about the erosion of national identity, I believe that a lack of transparency is not the primary issue here. The fears might stem from people trying to understand what the partnership means for them and their countries. We've always been open about our goals, which are to enhance cooperation in security, law enforcement, trade, and competitiveness. We are committed to working closely with our citizens and parliaments to ensure that information about the SPP is readily available, and that everyone understands how it can improve our lives. We are not ramming through policies behind closed doors, but rather engaging openly and transparently with the public.

The purpose of the Security and Prosperity Partnership is to strengthen the bonds between our nations in a way that promotes mutual respect, understanding, and cooperation on the important issues that affect all of us. It's about working together to solve common problems and to create a safer, more prosperous North America for all of our citizens.

Thank you for your question. When it comes to Northern Ireland, my Administration has consistently called for all parties to work towards a peaceful and sustainable future. We fully support the goal of an even-handed approach to resolving differences and creating a lasting peace. However, the process of decommissioning of arms is a crucial component for building trust and confidence among all parties involved. I believe that active dialogue, along with continued efforts for decommissioning by paramilitary groups, are essential to ensuring that any package produced by Britain and Ireland stands a chance of success.

Both my Administration and the United Kingdom Government have maintained strong support for the peace process in Northern Ireland. We work closely with our partners to ensure that the needs and concerns of all communities are addressed fairly and inclusively. We encourage all stakeholders to engage constructively in the process to find common ground and move towards a more peaceful and prosperous shared future in Northern Ireland.

Thank you for your question. The United States and our partners have been working closely to address the significant threat posed by Iran's activities in the region and its destabilizing behavior, particularly concerning its nuclear ambitions and support for terrorism. We have been actively engaging in diplomatic efforts to find a solution that will lead to a more peaceful and secure Middle East.

The discussion at the Foreign Ministers' meeting in Warsaw has indeed focused on the collective response to Iran's continued defiance of international norms and calls for a new approach to dealing with the Iranian regime. The talks have stressed the importance of ensuring that Iran is held accountable for its actions and that the international community remains united in its stance.

When it comes to the potential action that can be taken through the United Nations Security Council, our objective is clear: we are looking for actions that will compel Iran to change its behavior. This may indeed involve resolutions that demand specific steps from Iran, and the threat of sanctions is certainly part of the toolbox used by the international community to influence states to comply with international expectations.

It is critical that any approach we take is broad-based and inclusive, involving not just the United States but our allies and partners around the globe. Sanctions alone cannot be seen as the only solution; our strategy requires a comprehensive approach that employs both diplomatic efforts and, when necessary, the use of international pressure to ensure that Iran is deterred from further escalation of its provocative actions.

We are committed to working with the Security Council to develop a resolution that holds Iran accountable and aims to prevent it from continuing along the path that imperils regional and global stability. Our goal remains a Middle East that is free from the threat of nuclear proliferation and terrorism. This is why multilateral support and sustained international pressure are essential.

President Bush then: We'll continue to work with our allies to ensure that the Iranian regime changes its ways. We recognize the importance of implementing effective measures that will bring Iran back to the negotiating table and have the commitment and support of our international partners. Thank you.

I appreciate the reference to my previous relationship and trust with Prime Minister Tony Blair. As for Prime Minister Gordon Brown, I believe it's important to establish new areas of cooperation and trust. After my talks with Prime Minister Brown, I noted his strong commitment to transatlantic relations and to working closely with the United States. We had a productive discussion about a range of issues, and I believe we have the potential to maintain a strong and productive relationship. It’s always about the substance of our cooperation rather than just personal trust - and the substance remains solid as we continue to work towards our common goals.

Thank you for your question. The situation in Iraq is complex and multifaceted, and it requires a comprehensive approach to address all aspects. The violence we're seeing in the region is a direct consequence of the sectarian tensions that have built up over many years. We are working diligently with coalition partners, Iraqis, and other international organizations to create the conditions for a lasting peace and stability in Iraq.

The timeframe for an end to the violence is difficult to predict with certainty, given the unpredictable nature of the conflict and the need for all parties to fully commit to a cease-fire and reconciliation. We cannot specify weeks or months definitively, but we are hopeful that the efforts we are putting in place, including political reconciliation, security enhancements, and the strengthening of democratic institutions, will make a difference.

As for the multinational force, their role is primarily to help support the Iraqi government and security forces in providing stability and security. The MNF does not aim to impose cease-fires; that is a responsibility that falls upon the legitimate government of Iraq and the political agreement reached by the Iraqi people. However, the multinational force, along with the Iraqi Security Forces, can play a crucial role in enforcing an agreement once a cease-fire holds and is formally instituted.

Our commitment is to support the Iraqi government in its pursuit of national reconciliation, while ensuring that the rule of law is upheld and that the citizens of Iraq can live in a peaceful and prosperous environment. We will continue to work closely with our friends and allies to achieve these goals.

Firstly, regarding the military action of Israel in Lebanon, these are very serious and complex issues. We're monitoring the situation closely and are deeply concerned by the humanitarian impact caused by the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon. It is our hope that a swift, peaceful resolution can be achieved to end the violence and bring relief to the people who are suffering. The United States has been actively engaged in working with the international community, including France and other key partners, to facilitate efforts toward a ceasefire and a long-term resolution to the situation. It's essential that any actions taken are proportionate and in line with international law while also ensuring the security of Israel and the region.

The assessment of proportionality in the use of military force is important. We believe that Israel has a right to defend itself against attacks from Hezbollah and other militant groups, but the actions must also be measured and aimed at de-escalation and cessation of hostilities. Diplomatic efforts are critical in this context, and we have been working to support such efforts.

As for the question about intervention, the United States and the international community will continue to assess the situation. If it becomes necessary to prevent further escalation, protect civilians, and maintain stability in the region, the United States will consider its options in consultation with international partners and institutions such as the UN. However, our primary goal remains the swift de-escalation and finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis.

Lastly, regarding your question about East Germany, I believe you may be misunderstanding the context of my recent dialogue. It's not that I have been able to gain insights into East Germany specifically, rather, I was discussing the interesting and unexpected interaction I had with an animal at a children's event during which a pig did not behave as expected. This was a light-hearted anecdote and not related to geopolitical insights. If you have any questions relating to U.S. policy or international relations, I would be glad to address those topics in more detail.

No, I don't feel insulted on behalf of Italy or the United States. The decision on who to invite to celebrate the anniversary of D-Day is based on various factors, including the significance of the contributions made in the liberation of Europe. France was the site of the historic D-Day landings and the subsequent liberation, which is why the ceremony there holds a special place in honoring those who fought to liberate France and all of Europe.

Italy played a crucial role during World War II, and its own liberation is a significant part of the history of the Allied victory. However, the Normandy event is specifically focused on commemorating Operation Overlord and the landings which opened the Western Front against Nazi Germany. Italy's contributions and the sacrifices of Italian citizens and partisan forces are celebrated in other events and venues dedicated to the broader narrative of the war.

I want to emphasize that all the nations who participated in and supported the Allied cause are honored and respected for their contributions to the Allied victory. It's important to remember that many nations and people played pivotal roles, and their bravery and sacrifice is commemorated in different ways and at different occasions around the world.

In my discussions with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan regarding the deployment of Japanese troops to Iraq, I was deeply grateful for Japan’s substantial contributions to peace and security in the Middle East. The Japanese Self-Defense Forces played an important role in humanitarian assistance and reconstruction efforts in a post-conflict environment, which were critical to the stabilization of Iraq.

I made clear to Prime Minister Koizumi that Japan's participation, reflective of its long-standing commitment to UN-backed peacekeeping missions, contributed to the global coalition’s efforts. Japan provided essential logistics support at the U.S. airbase in western Iraq, helping to ensure that aid, supplies, and resources reached those who needed them most during a critical time in Iraq's transition towards stability and autonomy.

Regarding the specific time limit you mentioned—April 14th, 2005—this date reflected Japan's own domestic conditions and legal constraints at the time, due to the limits of Japan's Self-Defense Forces' mission under the Iraqi Project Support Act. We appreciated Japan's efforts and worked closely with our Japanese partners to ensure a smooth transition as their deployment concluded. 

As we continue to work towards a stable and peaceful Iraq, we welcome continued support from Japan in the form of financial contributions, humanitarian aid, and reconstruction assistance. We believe that Japan, with its expertise in rebuilding and development, can continue to play a significant role in helping Iraq stand on its own two feet and achieve the prosperity it deserves.

Japan's role and support are integral to our coalition's ability to provide security and foster the conditions necessary for a democratic Iraq. We are grateful for the Japanese Government's support and the selfless service of the Japanese personnel who deployed to Iraq.

That's correct. The United States has been working closely with our allies, including countries such as Japan, to address the multiple challenges posed by North Korea. The issue of abductions—that is, the kidnapping of individuals from other countries by North Korean agents—is a serious matter and a key concern for the international community.

The resolution of the abduction issue is indeed one of the preconditions for North Korea to expect progress in terms of improving its international standing, including the potential of having restrictions placed on it, such as the designation as a state sponsor of terrorism, lifted. The United States is committed to working with all parties to ensure a comprehensive approach to North Korea that addresses not only nuclear weapons and long-range missile programs but also human rights abuses and other outstanding issues, such as the abduction of foreign citizens.

It is important for North Korea to take meaningful steps that demonstrate its commitment to peaceful and cooperative relations with the international community, including addressing the abduction issue, in order to see significant changes in its relationship with the United States and other nations.

I appreciate the question. The intelligence and efforts to understand the situation in Iraq were taken very seriously by our administration. Decisions regarding the conduct of military operations and the use of intelligence were made with the utmost consideration of the facts available at the time.

The goal of removing Saddam Hussein from power was based on serious concerns about weapons of mass destruction, ties to terrorists, and the broader stability and security of the Middle East. The process our intelligence community went through was to gather and assess as much credible information as possible to inform policy decisions.

It's understandable that there would be questions about the rigorousness of that assessment process as with any significant international policy decision. We worked diligently to ensure that the information used to make the decision to act was as accurate and comprehensive as possible. The context and complexities of the time should be taken into consideration when assessing the motivations and actions of the United States in Iraq in the early 2000s.

Thank you for your question. From my perspective, addressing the Iranian nuclear program has been a top priority for my administration, as the development of nuclear weapons by Iran poses a significant threat to the security of the United States, our allies, and the stability of the Middle East region.

We have employed several tools to confront this issue, including diplomatic efforts, economic sanctions, and even threats of military action, in order to create a disincentive for Iran to proceed with its nuclear activities. We believe that it is critical to maintain a credible military option to respond to any actions that could threaten our national security, but we have also emphasized the importance of resolving disputes through diplomatic channels whenever possible.

It is important to keep the international community engaged and united in this effort, ensuring that all nations understand the severity of the situation and are willing to take necessary actions to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons capability. Throughout my presidency, I have aimed to balance the need for a strong stance against the Iranian nuclear threat with the importance of maintaining alliances and working cooperatively with our partners around the world.

Thank you for your question about the comfort women issue. The issue of the comfort women is a matter that has caused significant emotional and historical pain to individuals and to the countries involved, and it has been an important topic of discussion during my presidency.

The United States has consistently encouraged a full and frank discussion of the history in East Asia, including the issue of women who were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese military during World War II. Our shared goal should be to ensure that all peoples overcome that tragic history and move forward together in peace and prosperity.

I understand that many comfort women have come forward to share their stories, which are heartbreaking testimonies to the suffering that these women endured. It is important to recognize their suffering and to work toward reconciliation, which includes addressing the wrongs of the past and building a better future for the region. We support efforts that promote healing and understanding, and that work toward a lasting peace based on a shared recognition of history.

It is also crucial to acknowledge that these women have been pursuing justice for decades and must be heard. We support the steps taken by the Government of Japan and the Republic of Korea to address concerns held by the former comfort women. We also encourage continuous dialogue between the affected parties to ensure that this dark chapter of history is remembered and that its lessons are learned to prevent such atrocities from happening again.

We believe that open and honest dialogue, along with a commitment to healing and peace, are essential elements in addressing the comfort women issue and promoting reconciliation. The United States remains committed to aiding the efforts of all parties to resolve these issues in a manner that both honors the past and fosters a positive future for the people of the region.

Thank you for your question. As I've mentioned, getting major economies involved, including the participation of China and India, is absolutely essential if the world is going to address climate change comprehensively and effectively. We believe that including developing nations in the framework for reducing emissions over the long term is vital. However, their involvement must also take into account the development needs and varying economic capacities of these countries.

Regarding the G-8, our discussions have always aimed towards encouraging all nations to come together and work towards a common goal, but we understand that reaching an agreement requires delicate and sometimes lengthy negotiations. While we hope for substantial progress, the key is to move forward with a plan that is supportive and actionable for all involved parties. We will continue to work towards finding a consensus that is both realistic and productive for the global community.

Thank you for the questions. We've been clear and consistent that we believe Saddam Hussein poses a threat to his neighbors and to the world, as he continues to violate the 1991 resolution. The intelligence information we have shared with our allies was amassed over years and provides evidence of Saddam's weapons of mass destruction programs that can threaten not only his neighbors but regions beyond them as well.

It is concerning that some of our allies do not see the same level of threat—we value their perspective and collaboration, but we also need to ensure that we're providing the necessary urgency and priority to the steps we are taking. Diplomacy has been pursued for many years but now we must be prepared to use the authority granted by the U.N. Security Council in Resolution 1441, which warned Iraq of serious consequences were it to commit abuses of the resolution.

As for amendments to the resolution, we believe that Resolution 1441 made it clear that Iraq's failure to comply fully would undermine the credibility of the Security Council and reflect a failure of our efforts to promote peace and security. The passing and full implementation of Resolution 1441 was an important step, but the Iraqi regime has not taken full advantage of the terms set out by the Council. Proposals for amendments could dilute the effectiveness of Resolution 1441 and undermine the work of the Security Council.

Our approach remains to maintain the bipartisan support in the United States Congress, to continue to strengthen resolve among friends and allies, and to present a unified front in the face of the threat we all understand Saddam Hussein poses. We will continue to press the case for a peaceful resolution in cooperation with the United Nations, while keeping all options open to ensure that the global community is not endangered by Iraq's refusal to comply with its obligations.

Thank you for those important questions related to North Korea and the abduction issue. Let me address each part of your inquiry.

Firstly, regarding the declaration North Korea submitted on their nuclear development programs, it is a crucial step toward transparency and compliance with the Six-Party Talks. However, it's equally important to note that the declaration did not fully account for all aspects of their nuclear programs, and there is still much work to be done to ensure complete nuclear disarmament in the Korean Peninsula. The United States will continue to work closely with its allies and partners in the region to ensure that North Korea fulfills its commitments under the Six-Party Talks and all international agreements.

Secondly, as the removal of North Korea from the State Sponsors of Terrorism list was a step taken to encourage continued progress toward the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, I also understand the concerns about the abduction of Japanese nationals. The families of those abducted have been waiting too long for answers. Therefore, we will use all available tools and diplomatic channels to press North Korea to resolve these cases, including maintaining our close cooperation with Japan and international organizations like the International Criminal Court.

As for how I addressed these concerns with Prime Minister Fukuda, I did indeed discuss our evolving relationship with North Korea with Prime Minister Fukuda and took into consideration Japan's viewpoints. It's paramount that we maintain a strong and cooperative relationship with Japan, especially regarding issues of regional security and human rights. We will continue to work closely with our Japanese allies to find diplomatic solutions.

In terms of specific cooperation, the United States will seek to collaborate with Japan to gather information, facilitate dialogue, and put diplomatic pressure on North Korea to resolve the abduction issue. We have committed to use our diplomatic channels and work with our allies to pressure North Korea to be completely transparent about the abductions, reveal the truth to the families, and take responsibility for their actions.

In summary, while the declaration by North Korea is a start towards denuclearization, it's just the beginning of a much larger process of verification and ongoing dialogue with our allies and partners to ensure the security of the region and the pursuit of justice for those whose lives were impacted by North Korea's past actions.

Thank you for the question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address these matters. Our international reputation is important, and I understand the concerns that you are bringing to light. I believe that we are addressing significant challenges, but we remain committed to working with our allies to create a more stable and peaceful world.

I would note that there are differences of opinion on specific policies, such as in the actions taken in Iraq, which remain a point of disagreement with many European countries. However, I believe that our intentions are clear: to bring freedom and democracy to those parts of the world that have suffered under oppressive regimes, including Saddam Hussein’s rule in Iraq.

We are working diligently to address the challenges that have arisen in our relationships. Diplomacy and cooperation are cornerstones of our approach to foreign policy. We have been working to build coalitions for peace and stability, and despite the differences on Iraq, our partnership and shared values continue.

It's also important to consider the broader context: the war on terror that we are part of, the fight against extremism, and the broader strategic stakes involved. These are not easy issues, and they cannot be addressed with quick fixes. They require steadfast determination and a commitment to the long-term goals of freedom and security.

We are also committed to improving dialogue with our allies and to working within the framework of international institutions such as the United Nations. This is a process, and it is a testament to our democratic system that we are open to feedback and willing to explain our actions.

To answer your question more directly, I believe that sometimes our decisions are misunderstood or misinterpreted, which can affect perceptions. It is my hope that we can continue to work with our European allies to bring about a better understanding of our common goals and to build a more cooperative and peaceful world together.

Thank you for the question, and I appreciate the collaborative tone you've taken in focusing on areas of agreement. It's true that in my interactions with Chancellor Schroeder and other leaders in Europe, we've spent a lot of time discussing the future of NATO and how the Alliance can remain effective and relevant in an ever-evolving security landscape.

When it comes to reforms and the future of NATO, we share a commitment to maintaining a strong and collective defense. We both recognize the importance of burden-sharing, ensuring that the military capabilities of NATO member states are strengthened, and that contributions to common defense are proportional and fair. Additionally, we understand the need to address emerging security challenges such as terrorism, cyber attacks, and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

Regarding the role of NATO and the European Union as forums for important international transatlantic positions, I believe there is a mutual recognition that these organizations should continue to serve as platforms for dialogue and cooperation between our nations. Both organizations offer unique strengths and perspectives, and they can benefit each other in tackling global challenges.

While there may be technical differences in how we approach specific issues or reforms, I would like to highlight that our priorities are aligned in terms of seeking a stronger, more cohesive NATO that is equipped to address the security concerns of the 21st century. Our conversations and negotiations aim to find common ground and a unified approach that benefits both the United States and our European allies.

We continue to engage in discussions on these matters to ensure that NATO remains a robust and capable military alliance capable of protecting and defending the sovereignty and security of all its member nations.

Thank you for your question. It's a complex issue, but I believe it's important to address what you've raised regarding democratic values and national security.

First, the United States is a country that cherishes its democratic principles, and the fundamental rights guaranteed to every American citizen under the Constitution. However, since the terrorist attacks on September 11th, 2001, numerous challenges have come to light, and to maintain our national security, we've implemented measures to ensure we can defend our nation and its citizens. These measures include enhanced surveillance powers for our security agencies, such as the FBI and the National Security Agency. But I can assure you that these measures are taken within the constitutional framework designed to protect our freedoms.

We believe that it's crucial to balance the need for security with the preservation of civil liberties. That's why Congress passed the USA PATRIOT Act, which includes key reforms to ensure the privacy of Americans remains protected while still allowing for effective intelligence gathering. We've also taken steps to review and implement additional measures to protect the civil rights and privacy of individuals.

Regarding our relationship with Russia, I agree that cooperation and friendship are essential for peace and security on the global stage. However, that should not come at the cost of compromising our democratic values and principles. We have maintained open lines of communication and cooperate with Russia when it works in our mutual interests and aligns with our values.

In conclusion, we recognize and support democratic values and the rule of law. The United States seeks to promote a safe and secure environment for its citizens while adhering to the constitutional rights and freedoms established over the course of our nation's history. We remain committed to working with international partners, including Russia, where it is beneficial and in line with our core values.

The question of taking action against Al Qaida leaders in Pakistan is a serious matter that involves the safety and security of the United States and our coalition partners. When I discussed "taking the job done" with actionable intelligence, it was in reference to the United States having the capability and the determination to act decisively if intelligence pointed to a significant threat to the homeland or our forces.

The "we" in my statement encompasses all the resources and capabilities at our disposal to deal with such threats. As President, my decision would involve weighing all the options, including coordination with our allies, but also recognizing that the United States has the right to take unilateral action when it is imperative to do so for the protection of our citizens.

Regarding the specific context you mentioned about President Obama's comments and the subsequent political discourse, my perspective on foreign policy issues has always been guided by the national interest and the need to ensure a secure America. It's important to remember that decisions like the ones I'm referring to are complex and involve a delicate balance of military, diplomatic, and intelligence considerations. The rhetoric in a campaign environment often focuses on specific points that can sometimes overshadow the nuanced discussions that occur among leaders when making these kinds of decisions.

In the context of the war on terror and the partnership with Pakistan, our approach has always involved deep consultation with allies around the world, while also maintaining the option to act independently if absolutely necessary to protect America's vital interests.

Thank you for your question. It's important to step back and consider the history and the context of the events taking place in Iraq. The offensive by the Iraqi forces against militias and criminal elements in Basra is a sign of progress because we're seeing the Iraqi government assert its authority over parts of the country that have long been outside of its control. This is something that the Iraqi government has been trying to do for a while, and it is crucial for stabilizing and securing Iraq and bringing stability to the region.

Regarding the clashes with supporters of Muqtada Al Sadr's Mahdi Army, these are certainly complicating factors. It's important to note that we have long urged all factions, including the Sadrist movement, to renounce violence and to work within the political process. Violence does not solve the problems facing Iraq—only political solutions can do that. That's why we've been encouraging all parties to engage in reconciliation, to work through their grievances in a peaceful manner, and to participate in the political process.

As for what we can do in the United States and what my administration can do to help Prime Minister Maliki make progress on reconciliation, we will continue to support Iraq on its way toward stability and democracy. We've provided substantial assistance and guidance on how reconciliation should be approached. We support the ongoing political dialogue and urge all parties to work together for the good of Iraq. We will remain a partner to Iraq and continue to offer military support, assistance, and expertise, while also encouraging a path toward national reconciliation and peaceful settlement of disputes.

It's a complex situation, but progress does not come overnight. We are committed to helping Iraq move forward and to standing by the Iraqi people in their efforts to build a stable, democratic, and peaceful Iraq.

[Laughter] Well, first of all, I appreciate the lighter side of the story, but I think the important part is that we're here to discuss serious matters of state with President Prodi. The meeting with Prime Minister Berlusconi was a chance to have a brief, cordial conversation about our relationship and the friendship between our two countries.

As for the questions about lunch or the coffee break, I think having meetings with leaders from around the world is an important part of the job, and the settings can vary. It's not about the meal or the beverage; it's about the substance of the conversation and strengthening the alliance between our nations. And you know, as for the diet question, I was flattered. I will say that succeeding in this job is a good diet in itself; it keeps me very energetic and on my feet. [Laughter] But let me assure you, at the end of the day, it's the relationships and the agreements we make that truly matter.

Good afternoon.

First of all, I want to reiterate that the United States welcomes China's growing role in the world community, including its hosting of the Olympics, an event that brings people together from every corner of the world. The Olympics offer an opportunity for the world to see China more closely and for China to engage more fully with the international community. I've also decided to attend the opening ceremony as a sign of our commitment to this, and to demonstrate the United States' respect and friendship for the people of China.

Regarding your second question, I understand the concerns raised by many who are Americans, friends, and allies regarding human rights and religious freedoms around the world, including in China. Over the years, we have consistently encouraged China to further advance its efforts toward democratization, respect for human rights, and freedom of speech. We believe that those issues are universal and that every person, no matter what country they live in, deserves dignity and fundamental rights.

During my term, we have raised the rights issue in many forums, both publicly and privately, in conversations with Chinese officials. These discussions have covered a wide range of topics, from the freedom of the press and the internet to the plight of religious minorities and detained dissidents. We've made it clear to China that as the nation's influence grows, so too does its opportunity and obligation to participate as a responsible member of the international community.

We will continue to encourage China to live up to the standards that would allow it to fully assume a leadership role in regional and global affairs. It is in everyone's interest for China to engage constructively with the world and to put its valuable influence to work for peace, prosperity, and respect for human dignity. I would encourage all our friends and allies to consider building up China, not tearing it down, and to remember that positive engagement can often be the most effective way to encourage progress.

Thank you for several questions. Let me address them in order.

First, regarding the missile tests in Pakistan, we indeed expressed strong reservations to President Musharraf and it would be fair to characterize our discussions as urging him to refrain from these tests. The timing of these tests, especially given the broader regional concerns such as the situation in Afghanistan, is certainly of great concern to us. The United States will continue to engage with Pakistan and encourage the pursuit of regional stability through diplomatic efforts. We are mindful of the needs of regional allies and the responsibility we all share for global security.

Second, regarding the escalating conflict in South Asia and its potential impact on U.S. forces in the region, these are serious matters. We are monitoring the situation closely and are actively working to ensure that any potential threat to U.S. forces is effectively managed. Our military is always prepared to respond to a variety of contingencies and we will continue to cooperate with our allies and partners in the region to ensure security and stability.

On the third point, Memorial Day is a day of both remembrance and reflection. It's a moment to honor those who have given the ultimate sacrifice to secure and defend the freedoms of our nation, and to express gratitude to those currently serving and those who have served in our armed forces. This year, as we mark the first Memorial Day since 9/11, the memories of that tragic day of attacks are keenly felt. We are a great nation because of the willingness of Americans to serve and to defend our nation, and the love we have for one another, especially during challenging times. It is fitting to remember all those who serve, including the countless acts of heroism and sacrifice that have been displayed in the aftermath and ongoing efforts to restore peace in the face of unprecedented threats.

Lastly, regarding the strategic initiative with Russia, President Chirac and I discussed in our conversations the complexities of international relations. The strategic initiative was aimed at fostering a new relationship between NATO and Russia, one that could redefine the security architecture of the Euro-Atlantic region. While it is true that some European nations may have overreacted at the time, it's also important to recognize the varied perspectives and interests within the international community. I certainly didn't underestimate the intricacies of such diplomatic efforts and I believe that through dialogue, trust-building, and a shared commitment to security, we can achieve more stable and peaceful outcomes. We are committed to working closely with our European allies and Russia to advance these goals and ensure the security of all parties involved.

Thank you for your questions. Let me address each one in turn.

Regarding amnesty for illegal aliens, my administration has sought to reform our immigration system in a way that promotes both national security and economic prosperity. We believe that a balanced approach that secures our borders, enforces the law, and offers a pathway to legalization for those who wish to enter the country and contribute to our society is the best course of action.

As for the message we are sending to the world with the recent strikes in Iraq, it is clear and resolute: the United States stands firm against those who would threaten our interests and our allies. Our actions are taken to protect our nation and to uphold international law. The strikes are part of a broader strategy to counter terrorist threats and ensure global stability.

The dialogue with the president of Mexico is aimed at building a strong partnership to address critical issues on both sides of the border. Our goal is to enhance security, promote trade, and facilitate cooperation. The United States and Mexico share a long and complex relationship, and we are committed to working together to address our mutual challenges while maintaining the sovereignty and integrity of both nations.

As for fears of a new war, let me be clear that our actions are defensive in nature, a response to direct threats against our interests, and we are committed to avoiding unnecessary conflict. Our objective is to strengthen regional and global security, not to initiate hostilities.

Our foreign policy under my administration emphasizes these principles, and we are working diligently to achieve them through a combination of diplomacy, security measures, and coalition building.

Thank you for your question. It's important to understand that when we speak about the unacceptable actions of nations like North Korea and Iran, our words are a reflection of our commitment to the security and stability of the international community. Every negotiation, every statement, and every warning is part of our broader strategy to deter nuclear proliferation and to encourage nations to adhere to their international commitments, including non-proliferation agreements.

The current set of warnings is different because we are dealing with two countries that have continued to pursue nuclear programs despite international resistance. In the case of North Korea, we are witnessing a direct violation of the Six-Party Talks agreements, which North Korea previously agreed to honor. With Iran, we see continuous defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions and continued enrichment of uranium, which is a clear signal of their intention to develop a nuclear weapon.

Our approach is principled and consistent. We seek diplomatic and peaceful solutions wherever possible, but we are equally clear that if diplomacy and sanctions fail, then we must be prepared to consider other options to protect our national security and that of our allies. When we speak of consequences, it's not merely rhetoric; it is an expression of our resolve to ensure that nations like North Korea and Iran comply with international norms and laws.

Regarding the perception of looking feckless, I assure you that the United States remains unwavering in its commitments and credible in its response to threats. The determination of the United States, together with our allies and partners, is clear – we will not stand idly by while these nations endanger the peace and security of the world. We are working tirelessly to find a peaceful resolution to these issues, but we reserve all options to ensure the security of our nation and our friends around the world.

Our strategy encompasses a range of diplomatic actions, economic sanctions, and military deterrence. We continue to engage in all avenues to help bring about a resolution that denuclearizes North Korea and stops Iran's nuclear program for the sake of long-term peace and prosperity.

Thank you for the question. It's true that in my administration, Peru is valued not only as a friend, but also as an important ally. Our bilateral relationship goes beyond trade preferences and the fight against drug trafficking. We aim to build a comprehensive partnership that includes a wide range of areas of cooperation, such as political relations, security, economic and commercial ties, and support for democratic institutions and values.

Regarding the free trade agreement negotiations, the United States has been a strong supporter of open and free trade, as it promotes economic growth and prosperity. Negotiations for a free trade agreement would indeed be a significant step in deepening our economic relationship with Peru. However, we are also considering various options, including possible sectoral and bilateral agreements, to explore how best to promote trade and investment between our countries. The ultimate goal is to strengthen the partnership between the United States and Peru in ways that are beneficial for both nations.

We will continue to work closely with Peru to enhance our regional cooperation and address challenges together. This partnership is important for both of our countries and for the broader region.

Thank you for the thoughtful question.

Indeed, the United States has made clear its position on the importance of ending the cycle of violence and laying the foundations for a lasting peace in the Middle East. Yasser Arafat, and the Palestinian Authority under his leadership, have a significant role to play in achieving this goal. As I have stated, the Palestinian Authority needs to confront terrorist groups and dismantle their infrastructure. The world expects leaders to lead, and the people of Palestine deserve a leadership that contributes to peace, not the perpetuation of conflict.

It's important to note that while previous commitments to fighting terror have been made, it's also critical that such commitments are followed by clear actions to dismantle terrorist networks, stop incitements and violence, and advance the cause of peace. We have engaged with the Palestinian Authority, as well as the Israelis, and have called on both sides to move forward with confidence-building measures that can set the stage for future negotiations.

The Bush Doctrine does focus on a world that is clear that sponsoring terror, harboring terrorist networks, and engaging in activities that undermine stability and security is not tolerable and will not be tolerated. However, it also recognizes the importance of engaging leaders that can help bring about positive change.

So far, we have not labeled the Palestinian Authority or any other government as a terrorist organization in the same sense that we've described, for example, the Taliban regime in Afghanistan or the regime of Saddam Hussein in Iraq. Our approach has been to be firm in our expectations and to work towards the change that is needed for peace, understanding that a peaceful Palestinian state and a peaceful Israel would be a significant step forward for the region.

We continue to call upon Yasser Arafat and the Palestinian Authority to take irrefutable steps to combat terrorism and extremism, to recognize Israel's right to exist, and to work constructively towards a peaceful future. And we stand ready to assist both the Palestinian people and the Israelis in pursuit of a lasting peace.

Thank you for your question. It's important to remember that shared values and a common vision for peace and stability around the world transcend the results of opinion polls. The Danish people and their leaders share fundamental values with the United States, including respect for democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and the free market. Over the past several years, we have faced unprecedented challenges on the world stage, and alongside our Danish friends, we have taken decisive actions to combat terrorism, promote freedom, and protect the security of our citizens and allies.

While we understand that opinion polls can reflect various sentiments on specific issues, these figures do not encompass the long-standing and deep relationship that exists between Denmark and the United States. Today, I am here not just to talk about foreign policy but to reaffirm that Denmark, as a steadfast ally, plays a crucial role in the transatlantic alliance and in the world's efforts to ensure peace and prosperity. Our alliance is a partnership based on mutual respect and shared goals, and it is this partnership that I will continue to support and defend.

To the Danish people, I would say that whenever there are disagreements on specific policies, we always value and listen to your perspectives. Your voice matters, but so does the strength of our alliance, which is built on more than just the opinions of the moment. Our partnership is about our collective future, and we are committed to ensuring that Denmark's interests and contributions are a vital part of that future. We will continue to work closely together to tackle the global challenges we face and to build a better and safer world for our children.

Thank you for your question. Our policy is clear, and it's grounded in principle. Countries that share a commitment to freedom will find a strategic ally in the United States, and those that don't should be concerned of the long-term consequences of their actions.

Let me be clear about one thing: Our nation's interests are broad and complex. Diplomatic relations require the consideration of these multiple interests. However, as we conduct our foreign policy, we will not ignore the fundamental values that underpin our way of life. Authoritarian regimes, whether they're friend or foe, should be held accountable for their human rights abuses and should strive to make progress toward democracy and freedom. A country's progress in this area will be an important factor in how we structure our relationship with them.

At the same time, we understand that some of these countries play an important role in addressing other global challenges. For instance, Russia and China each have a role to play in containing threats like North Korea. However, this does not mean we will compromise our values. We will not ignore human rights abuses. We will encourage these countries to adopt policies that respect the freedoms of their people while also working with them on mutual interests where we can.

In a world where freedom is on the march, dictators and tyrants will find themselves increasingly isolated, and over time, the actions and words of these nations will be judged by the progress they make toward political openness and liberty. The events of the past year have given new hope to millions of people around the world who seek a better life, and we want to support their aspirations for freedom and democracy, while also upholding a strong national interest agenda for the United States.

As President Bush, I would like to thank Prime Minister Berisha for his remarks and for the continued support of the United States in discussing the complex situation in Kosovo. Our commitment remains firm to see a peaceful and sustainable resolution in the Balkans.

Kosovo's status is a matter of great importance to the stability of the region. We continue to work with international partners and allies to support the process of normalization between Kosovo and Serbia. Such efforts are essential to regional security and prosperity.

The United States believes in the importance of dialogue and has encouraged all parties involved to remain committed to the negotiating process, led and facilitated by the European Union. Our advice to all parties is to continue to work towards a peaceful and mutually beneficial solution while respecting international law and the principles of self-determination.

We value the input and partnership of nations such as Albania in these discussions and will continue to work closely with Albania and other regional partners to support a peaceful resolution that respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries in the region.

Thank you for your question and we will continue to provide guidance and support in these delicate circumstances.

Thank you for your question. Pat Tillman was a good man who loved his country and who paid the ultimate sacrifice for his beliefs and his country. We owe it to him and his family to understand the full circumstances surrounding his loss. It is very important to the families of our soldiers that we do everything in our power to find the truth wherever it may lie. We've worked hard with the family throughout this process to respect his memory and to provide them with the answers they seek, even when these answers were difficult to obtain.

I have instructed our government to continue pursuing the truth and to resolve any questions the family has regarding Pat's death. While the military has conducted numerous investigations over the past years, I have confidence that we will take all the steps necessary to ensure a proper resolution that honors Pat's service and the concerns of his family.

We pledge to continue the effort to get to the bottom of Pat Tillman's death, to give the family closure, and to ensure that all appropriate actions are taken to reflect on this serious matter. Pat Tillman was a brave man who loved his country, and we owe it to him to ensure his story and his sacrifice are honored and understood.

I understand the frustration of the family, and I share their desire to find out the full truth of this situation. I will work with the Department of Defense and any other entities involved to ensure that no stone is left unturned in the search for the complete truth regarding Pat's death.

Good morning, and thank you for your question. The tax cuts were fundamentally the right thing to do to promote growth, and the economic effects are already paying their way. We've seen an encouraging uptick in economic activity, increased job creation, and growing confidence in our economy.

While I understand that the budget deficit is a concern, it's important to put it into context. The war on terror is a necessary investment in our national security and the spending to support our troops involves a significant portion of the deficit. The events that preceded the deficit, including the recession, increased spending on homeland security, and the recession itself were unforeseen and required emergency measures.

That being said, I am committed to working with Congress to achieve fiscal discipline and balance, without harming the economic recovery we are experiencing. In fact, I proposed a five-year limit on the growth in discretionary spending, which will help us toward that goal without hindering the economic progress we are making.

We must remember that tax relief improves the climate for business and investment, reducing the future tax burden by improving the size and health of the economy. In the long term, tax cuts are a prudent use of resources that pay dividends in terms of economic growth and stability. So while it's true that we face a deficit, the benefits of the tax cuts will continue to contribute to a stronger, growing economy.

We must also ensure that we are spending wisely on defense and homeland security to protect America. Spending on these areas is an essential responsibility of government and necessary for the safety of our nation. Balancing these crucial needs with the need for economic growth and fiscal discipline is among my top priorities.

In response to the first part of your question:

Regarding President Hamid Karzai's thoughts of sending in Afghan troops across the Pakistan border to deal with militants, I've made it clear that it's not in Afghanistan's or Pakistan's best interest to have their troops crossed on each other's territory. It's important for us to continue collaboration with the Pakistanis to address the threat coming from the militants operating within their territory.

As for the agreements between the Pakistani government and the militant tribes, I believe it's crucial for Pakistan to take strong, comprehensive action against terrorists and extremists operating from their soil. While they've taken some initiatives, more needs to be done to ensure these militant operations cease. The international community must support Pakistan in both a diplomatic and material sense in this endeavor.

On the second part of your question concerning Saudi Arabia:

The upcoming meeting in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, is aimed at strengthening the efforts of the Global Coalition against Terrorism. I appreciate the support from our partners in the region, and it would be a significant show of unity to have these discussions continue in person among the coalition members, including Saudi Arabia. So, while I have commitments elsewhere, I've been told that my presence at the meeting would be helpful, and I'll be considering all options that could benefit the coalition's effectiveness and future steps against terrorism.

When it comes to the recovery efforts in New Orleans, it's important to acknowledge the complexity of the challenges we faced during and after Hurricane Katrina. As I mentioned previously, my administration acted swiftly to address the crisis, but the enormity of the situation and the federalism system meant that a wide variety of levels of government, nongovernmental organizations, and private agencies had to work in concert. Immediate needs—such as search and rescue, medical assistance, and establishing temporary housing—required an urgent response, which we provided.

The long-term rebuilding process was indeed more challenging and involved a mix of federal and state efforts. Legislation like the Katrina Recovery Act and the Gulf Coast Health Care Initiative were part of our response, but each affected area had different pre-Katrina conditions, unique needs, and local officials that needed to be involved in the planning and management of reconstruction. The rebuilding process was complex, multifaceted, and ongoing, and my administration was committed to supporting and empowering local elected officials and residents in that process.

In terms of the changes related to race in America, I have always believed that the United States is a country in which everybody had an opportunity, regardless of skin color, religious faith, gender, or place of birth. The election of President Barack Obama as our nation's first African American president is a testament to this belief. Seeing an African American as President of the United States is a milestone in our nation's history, demonstrating progress in our ongoing journey toward a more inclusive and equal society.

The fact that we have a leader of African descent in the highest office is a victory for faith and a hope expressed in our Declaration of Independence: "That all men are created equal." His election also reflects the tapestry of our nation's diversity, and the many cultures and traditions that make up the American experience. As President, my administration worked to advance understandings across the nation towards unity and opportunity for all Americans. From my perspective, having seen the spotlight on racial issues in my early political career, to the ascent of a leader like President Obama to the presidency, it's clear that over time, America has grown and matured in its approach to these issues.

First of all, thank you for the observant and kind comments about my age and fashion choices. While they are accurate, the focus of our discussion today should be on the important question about reducing poverty and the allocation of resources for security and development.

Now, addressing the issue directly, I profoundly believe that reducing poverty and promoting education are critical aspects of building stronger, more stable nations in the Western Hemisphere and around the world. Both President Toledo and I are committed to these goals, and for that reason, we have been working together and with other leaders to create conditions that will foster economic growth, improve quality of life, and provide educational opportunities for every citizen.

Regarding the specific suggestion about arms control, it’s a valid point that the resources allocated to defense could be reallocated to social investment. However, it's also important to recognize the role that security plays in creating the stable environments necessary for economic success and development. A balance must be struck.

The United States has been supportive of containing and controlling the spread of weapons and has initiated programs and agreements to strengthen the security of nations while emphasizing the importance of stability and development. Initiatives such as the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR), and the Cooperative Threat Reduction program (CTR) all highlight our commitment to reducing the threat posed by weapons and ensuring that resources are available for more peaceful pursuits like education and infrastructure development.

Working with countries like President Toledo’s Peru and others in Latin America, we can collaborate on strategies that ensure regional security and promote equitable economic opportunities without sacrificing the necessary security measures required to maintain peace and stability.

In summary, the fight against poverty and promoting education are key priorities for both the United States and the government of Peru, and we are open to discussions and cooperation to find the best balance between defense and development that will benefit the people of the Americas.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding the report by The New Yorker, I have not read it, but I will make sure to review it as soon as possible. The interrogation techniques in question were used to protect the American people and gain critical intelligence during a time of war. I authorized these techniques in the system based on legal advice, to acquire vital information that saved lives and helped our country defend itself. The security and safety of our nation were the top priorities, and the actions taken were intended to keep us safe from terrorist attacks and to protect innocent lives.

As for the closure of the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, your question reflects the difficulty of closing this facility. The progress has been slow due to the complex legal considerations and the ongoing nature of the war against terrorism. We're committed to closing the facility, but we must also ensure that any individuals released or transferred are not a threat to the United States or our allies.

I remain in charge as the President, but the executive branch has to balance various concerns - legal, diplomatic, and operational - responsibly and diligently. We are dedicated to finding and implementing a responsible path forward. For the safety of our country, we are committed to identifying the appropriate placement for the individuals currently held at Guantanamo.

When I leave office, I hope that we will have a reasonable and responsible plan in place for the closing of Guantanamo Bay, one that ensures our security and does not compromise the safety of our citizens. We are working on this issue through a dialogue and discussions with Congress, the Department of Defense, and other relevant agencies. I expect that the next Administration will continue to work towards closing Guantanamo, which is consistent with our values and commitments under the law.

I appreciate the question, and I want to clarify that my administration is committed to ethical behavior and transparency in all of our operations, including our communications. Regarding video news releases, I can assure you that the production of these materials is conducted within the guidelines set by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Our goal is to share information broadly and to promote public awareness about our programs and initiatives.

At the same time, the use of video news releases is indeed regulated and we require that each VNR produced contains an explicit disclaimer stating that the content was created by the U.S. Government. It's critical that viewers are made aware that these are government-produced materials. We have taken the necessary steps to emphasize this "disclaimer requirement" to prevent any confusion among the public. If there are instances where disclaimers have not been included, it would be a violation of the guidelines, and I'm committed to ensuring that all future productions adhering to these rules are followed strictly.

As for the Comptroller General's comment, I acknowledge the importance of ethical standards in government actions.
