We shall continue to monitor the usage of VNRs closely to ensure they are handled in a transparent and compliant manner. If any issues with these disclaimers arise, my administration will take action to correct them and prevent future occurrences.

In this era of complex communications, it's crucial for the Government to provide accurate and clear information to the public, while simultaneously respecting the integrity of the press. We will continue to safeguard the line between the Government and the news media, ensuring that any material produced by the Government is properly identified as such.

Thank you for your question. We are committed to a layered missile defense system that will protect the American people, as well as our deployed forces and our friends and allies around the world. Discussions about radar upgrades or station locations involve classified and sensitive information, and any decisions on such matters are part of a comprehensive assessment of our overall defense strategy.

Our missile defense plans are designed to be adaptable and responsive to the evolving threat environment. As we continue to develop and enhance our missile defense capabilities, we will work closely with our allies to ensure that our approach is both effective and in their best interest. We value our transatlantic partnership and will continue to consult with our UK allies on these important matters.

Throughout my presidency, I had many discussions with leaders from around the world, including European leaders like Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany. Engagement with other leaders is part of how we navigate the complexities of the international community and formulate policies that are in the best interest of the United States.

While it is true that my administration made many decisions independently, I always valued the perspectives we received during our conversations and from our allies. We often found common ground and areas for cooperation, particularly in the Middle East, despite differences on some issues.

Regarding your specific question, I can say that our approach was guided by a comprehensive review of our strategy and the input we received from many allies, including those in Europe. For example, as we worked on the Middle East peace process, we sought the input and partnership of European allies to strengthen the support for the vision of two states living side by side in peace. While an individual change of mind based on a single conversation may not be the norm, the cumulative effect of these conversations shaped our overall approach to various initiatives.

The relationship between the United States and European allies is one of partnership and mutual respect for each other's perspectives, even when we do not agree on everything. Working together, we strive to achieve our common goals and address global challenges.

Good afternoon. Thank you for your question. As you mentioned, the issue of hostages held by FARC has been a source of great concern for both the Colombian people and the international community. Our administration has been actively engaged in discussions to address this humanitarian crisis.

Regarding the humanitarian agreement, we believe it is important to pursue all avenues that can lead to the release of the hostages in a peaceful and secure manner. This includes the possibility of exploring humanitarian agreements that could facilitate the release of these individuals. We have been working closely with the Colombian government and other partners to find a solution that respects the human rights of the hostages and upholds justice.

As for military actions, we support the efforts of the Colombian government to fight against illegal armed groups and bring stability to the country. We believe a comprehensive approach that combines military action, diplomacy, and humanitarian efforts is necessary to achieve a lasting resolution.

The issue of extraditions is another component of our relationship with Colombia. This is indeed an important topic of discussion, and we have expressed our support for the rule of law and the Colombian judiciary system. We understand the complexities of the situation and continue to work with the Colombian government on these matters.

Our administration remains committed to working with all relevant parties to achieve a peaceful resolution and the safe release of hostages while also supporting Colombia in its long-term efforts to build peace and prosperity throughout the nation.

Thank you for your questions. First of all, the security of our nation is a top priority for our administration, and we take every warning from our law enforcement and intelligence agencies very seriously. When there is credible information received, we work closely with our federal agencies to assess the situation, and determine the appropriate response.

In the case of concrete, actionable intelligence that there is a specific threat against a piece of infrastructure or a type of venue, we do not hesitate to take steps to secure that location, and we have done just that. For example, we have taken preemptive measures to secure key buildings, transportation hubs, and public facilities. Our armed services, federal agencies, and local partners are working around the clock to ensure the security of our nation.

Regarding the sentiment of being helpless, I would say this: while we understand that individuals may feel concerned about the safety of themselves and their families, it is essential that we stay vigilant but not paralyzed by fear. As a nation, we have heightened vigilance and have engaged in increased security measures in cooperation with local, state, and federal authorities. We have also enhanced our homeland defense, which includes increasing security screenings at airports, and other critical infrastructure.

To all Americans, I advise the following to help protect yourselves and your families:

1. Stay informed and follow reliable news sources.
2. Continue to adhere to any guidance issued by law enforcement.
3. Report suspicious activity.
4. Keep in mind that community resilience is our first line of defense. Being aware, engaged, and prepared can make a difference.
5. Support one another, and foster a sense of unity and resolve as we go through these challenging times.

I also urge everyone to stay calm and to trust that our government and its agencies are working tirelessly to protect our citizens and prevent future threats.

I appreciate your questions, and thank you for your service to your communities as members of the press.

Good afternoon. Thank you for your question. And I appreciate the opportunity to address it.

We remain committed to helping Central American countries and others to grow their economies and provide greater opportunities for their citizens. That’s why we're supportive of the Free Trade Agreement with the countries of Central America, including the Dominican Republic, as well as the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act aimed at boosting commercial ties and economic growth in that region.

You're right that fostering open markets is key to achieving those goals. We recognize that trade agreements need to be balanced and fair, and we're working to level the playing field for all parties involved. This includes our willingness to address issues like subsidies, which can affect competitiveness in the agricultural sector and impact small producers.

Regarding subsidies specifically, the United States has made strides over the years to reform our farm safety-net programs. While ensuring our farmers can compete in global markets, we've sought to do so in a manner that doesn't unfairly disadvantage producers in other countries. We've already taken significant steps to reduce subsidies, and we are committed to continuing that effort.

On the issue of Senate approval for negotiations, it's important to note that members of Congress play a crucial role in this process. We are working closely with them to ensure that discussions with our partners in Central America are reflective of our mutual interests and objectives. The goal is to see that these negotiations progress in a bipartisan manner, so that such agreements can be beneficial for all parties involved.

In summary, we are taking the necessary steps to ensure that our trade policies are both aggressive in opening up markets and responsible in how they support our domestic producers while respecting the rights of other nations to develop and thrive economically.

Thank you for your question. In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, the federal government acted swiftly to provide aid and assistance to all the people affected in the Gulf Coast region. Our commitment to the people of New Orleans and the state of Louisiana has been unwavering, and our approach to rebuilding has been guided by the needs and conditions on the ground.

The decision to prioritize certain areas for federal funding is not about betraying a promise to the people of New Orleans; on the contrary, it's about making practical, strategic decisions that ensure the safety and resilience of the city for the future. We must be mindful of the long-term viability of the city and the risks associated with rebuilding in flood-prone areas without proper protections. It’s essential that we approach this recovery in a way that respects the realities of our geography and promotes sustainable long-term growth.

Our commitment to ensure that New Orleans would rise again was not empty rhetoric; it was and is a pledge we are dedicated to keeping. However, the approach to rebuilding must take into consideration the lessons learned from Katrina and the necessity of implementing infrastructure improvements that protect the entire city from the dangers presented by extreme weather events.

We will continue to work closely with local, state, and federal partners to develop comprehensive recovery plans that take into account all the communities within New Orleans and throughout the Gulf Coast region. This includes ensuring that the most vulnerable populations are provided for and that every effort is made to address their unique needs. The goal is not to set limits on the extent of rebuilding, but to do so in a way that maximizes the safety, resilience, and prosperity of all residents.

The concern for the American people and the security of our nation is always at the forefront of my mind. The strategy in Iraq continues to evolve based on the needs on the ground and the progress we are achieving. When I say we're adapting to win, I mean that our administration is working to change strategies to ensure success for our operational mission.

The term "stay the course" reflects a steadfast commitment to the original mission in Iraq—to bring freedom and democracy to a nation controlled by a dictator—and to ensure that the country does not become a safe haven for terrorists to plan attacks against the United States and our interests. We remain committed to this overarching mission.

As for the benchmarks and timetables, these are tools we are using as part of the political strategy within Iraq to alleviate sectarian violence and to encourage the Iraqi government to take on greater responsibility for the security and governance of their country. This is something I have been calling for since early in my presidency. It is critical for the success of the mission that the Iraqis take the lead in their nation's security.

The American people understand the gravity of the situation. The designation of "defeatocrats" in the past was a response to suggestions that would have undermined our progress and compromised our security. It was never about playing games or politics; it was about being clear that the path of withdrawal without achieving essential goals would be detrimental not just for Iraq but also for our national security interests.

Our actions in Iraq are about winning the war on terror, helping an oppressed people to live in freedom, and protecting the United States. The adaptation we're making is part of an ever-evolving strategy aimed at securing victory. We remain dedicated to the mission and will do whatever it takes to achieve a successful outcome for our troops and for the Iraqi people.

Good morning. The Justice Department's role as an independent, impartial entity is critically important. I have the utmost respect for the men and women who serve in the Department of Justice, and I am confident in its ability to carry out its duties independently.

Regrettably, allegations of misconduct always give rise to concern, and that is why the Attorney General has moved decisively to appoint a special counsel and to initiate an independent review to address these matters. The Department of Justice is already operating with independent oversight, and I have full confidence that it will reach a fair and just conclusion.

Regarding the specific situations you have mentioned, I've discussed these concerns with Attorney General Gonzales and he has assured me that every allegation will be thoroughly investigated to ensure that the integrity of the Department and the rule of law are upheld.

For the American people, I offer this assurance: the most fundamental principle of any democracy is the rule of law. Our government must be accountable for our actions, and I believe that even when mistakes are made by individuals, the institutional strength of our government will endure. I'm committed to ensuring that the Justice Department upholds its constitutional obligations faithfully, and I'm assured by the actions taken thus far to address these issues.

Transparency and accountability are key, and I am fully supportive of the investigation to ensure that the rule of law is not only observed but respected by all members of the Justice Department.

Thank you for your question. The events of September 11th shocked our nation, and we've taken swift and appropriate actions to protect the American public. Our government understands the importance of the First Amendment and the freedoms it guarantees. Our approach to counterterrorism is careful to respect these freedoms.

Regarding Osama bin Laden, it's important to note that he's not an individual who seeks to present his views in a way that aligns with democratic principles. He's a person who seeks to spread fear and destruction, and denying him the platform to broadcast his hateful message is a prudent step.

As for your concerns about the new climate at home and around the world, I can assure you that while we remain focused on the critical task of keeping our nation safe, we do so within the legal and constitutional framework that defines our nation. We're working hard to balance security needs with the fundamental freedoms and rights that are central to American democracy.

With respect to Hollywood, I'm not aware of any members of my administration briefing filmmakers or any other industry about specifics related to anti-terrorism. However, I do believe it's vital for individuals involved in media and entertainment to be mindful of the full breadth of information available when they create content, particularly when such content may have an impact on national security or the safety of the American people.

We must continue to strike a balance between necessary security measures and the freedoms that we cherish. Our administration is committed to doing so, ensuring that we uphold the freedoms we defend from those who would take them away while simultaneously protecting America from further acts of terror.

Good afternoon. Let me address each part of your question as it has been asked.

Firstly, regarding the resumption of U.S. drug interdiction flights in Peruvian airspace, I want to reaffirm our commitment to work closely with our Peruvian allies in the fight against illegal drug trafficking. We are currently reviewing the situation rigorously with all the relevant stakeholders to understand the context, contingencies, and consequences of resuming these flights. It is our ultimate goal to support effective counter-drug operations that dismantle the drug trade and protect the safety and security of our citizens. However, we must ensure that any actions taken are conducted under the appropriate legal, diplomatic, and operational frameworks. We will consider all necessary preconditions to ensure that these missions can be carried out safely and with the full cooperation of the Peruvian government.

Secondly, President Alejandro Toledo and his administration have made significant statements and efforts toward the reduction of drug trafficking. While the United States expects maximum effort and partnership in the war on drugs, it is important to approach each country's unique challenges and capabilities. Our discussions with President Toledo focus on achieving results through various strategies, whether they be crop eradication, alternative development, demand reduction, or other initiatives that can be tailored to the specific requirements of Peru.

We understand the complexity of this issue and recognize the role coca production plays in the larger drug problem. However, it is also crucial to emphasize comprehensive and balanced approaches, which may vary from one nation to another. We are committed to working with all nations to find common ground and solutions that can effectively combat drug trafficking and achieve stability in the region.

Our partnership with Peru in the war on drugs is a vital aspect of our broader efforts to create a hemisphere free of illegal drugs. We value the relationship we have built with Peruvian authorities and look forward to continuing to work together to achieve our shared goals of disrupting the drug trade and enhancing regional security.

Thank you for your questions and I look forward to further dialogue on this important subject.

I want to thank you for the question. I understand the concerns you're raising, and I share the unease and frustrations many Americans feel. I am very mindful that there are very real costs of this war, and there are those who have lost loved ones, and others who worry about their own service members.

When I made the decision to go to war, it was based on the best advice I had from our intelligence community and military leaders. At the time, we were united as a nation with a clear and compelling mission to remove a threat to our nation posed by Saddam Hussein's regime, which had shown a willingness to use weapons of mass destruction and to support terrorist organizations, including al-Qaeda.

The Iraqi people are now free from the brutal rule of Saddam Hussein. A democratic government is being established in Iraq. Over time, more Iraqis will be able to take responsibility for their own security. And we will have won a great victory against an enemy of America.

I understand that our troops and military families bear the burden of prolonged service, which puts a strain on everyone involved. And I also recognize that the path we're on is difficult and challenging. The next phase of the plan is to hand over responsibility for security from coalition forces to the Iraqi people as they continue to build their capacity to handle their own affairs and to establish a responsible, representative, and accountable government.

In terms of the costs of this war, I am working closely with Congress to address the needs of our military, our veterans, and our troops' families, and to ensure we are providing the support that is necessary and appropriate for the mission in Iraq.

To the American people, including those who supported the war effort from the beginning and those who have doubts today, I would say that I know a path ahead may not be clean or easy. But the stakes are high, and I believe the Iraqi people deserve their freedom and the chance to live in a country that respects human rights and upholds the rule of law. We will remain committed to the success of a free and democratic Iraq, for the good of the Iraqi people and the world.

Thank you for your question. The agreement that we have reached with President Putin yesterday was based on the understanding that the United States reserves its rights to defend itself against ballistic missile threats. We discussed the need for new strategic frameworks and cooperation that would enhance both our nations' security while also addressing the changing global security environment.

The agreement does not obligate the United States to slow down or delay the development of missile defense technologies. The U.S. will continue to invest in those technologies to fulfill its commitment to protect its people and allies.

Regarding the ABM Treaty, I believe it is important to understand that the framework of that treaty has outlived its usefulness, as the world is different today than it was during the Cold War, and the threats we face are different as well. The United States plans to withdraw from the ABM Treaty when necessary to address these new security challenges.

Our approach to missile defense and strategic stability remains focused on working with Russia, but also ensuring that we can address the emerging threats, whether from rogue states, terrorists, or potential adversaries. We will continue to consult with Russia and other allies on these matters, but ultimately, the security of the American people is our primary concern, and we must be prepared to act accordingly.

I hope that clarifies our position. We are committed to transparency and cooperation with Russia as we move forward, but we must also be vigilant in addressing the new realities of the 21st century.

The United States supports the Quartet's roadmap for peace, which is a plan aimed at achieving a lasting and comprehensive Middle East peace. As I discussed with His Majesty King Abdullah II of Jordan, our commitment to this process remains strong, and we are committed to working with the parties involved to advance the cause of peace. The implementation of the roadmap involves steps from all parties and our role includes encouraging all sides to fulfill their obligations, to ensure a just, and a lasting peace in the region.

Good evening, and thank you for your questions.

To address your first question about Iraq, as we have seen progress in Iraq — with the establishment of a unity government, reduction in attacks on our troops, and steps toward economic recovery and political stability — the United States has a responsibility to help the new Iraqi government stand on their own feet. That's why we are looking at a transition strategy that could involve a residual force of U.S. troops to continue training Iraqi forces and providing support for stability operations. However, the specifics of when and how many troops we would withdraw would be contingent upon the success of these transitions and the security situation on the ground. There's no precise timeline, but we are committed to seeing the Iraqis step up and take responsibility for their own security while we move accordingly.

Regarding your second question for Prime Minister Berlusconi, I believe that Italy's dedication to the development and security of Iraq is an essential part of the broader coalition effort. The improvement of the Iraq situation offers the potential for constructive dialogue among the political forces in Italy, as it does among our friends and allies around the world. The Prime Minister will be better suited to provide a detailed response, but based on the progress and dialogue presently underway, it does seem that we are in an environment conducive to more unified approaches to international challenges, including Iraq. Italy, along with its allies, has been a strong supporter of a free and stable Iraq, and that commitment remains as important as ever.

Prime Minister Berlusconi, perhaps you can provide more insight on the political situation in Italy regarding this issue and the dialogue with the opposition.

Thank you for your questions. First, let me begin by confirming the strong support of the United States for Mexico in its efforts to combat the serious challenges of drug trafficking and organized crime. It's critically important for the United States and Mexico to work together on this issue, given our shared border and close ties.

I understand that there is a lot of attention and expectation surrounding the details of Plan Mexico, which is part of our broader efforts to support Mexico. The delays in the release of certain elements of the plan have been due to a combination of factors, including the level of detail that needs to be worked out, ensuring that the coordination between our two governments is effective, and making sure that strategies and resources are aligned to achieve the most significant impact.

The United States absolutely remains committed to supporting Mexico in its fight against drug trafficking and other related crimes. We believe it's essential to provide Mexico with the tools it needs to address these challenges, not only through security assistance but also through training, intelligence sharing, and other forms of support.

The emphasis on cooperation and mutual efforts is a key aspect of our relationship. We want to make sure that the support is understood and appreciated by the people of Mexico, and we will continue to communicate the roles and responsibilities of both sides in achieving our shared objectives.

It's important to note that efforts in Mexico are part of a larger strategy to disrupt the flow of drugs into the United States and to dismantle the criminal cartels that profit from the drug trade. Our support to Mexico is significant and we will continue to work closely with President Calderón and his government to coordinate efforts effectively.

We recognize that the situation is serious, but we also recognize the determination of the Government of Mexico to address these issues. We will continue to support their efforts to create a safer environment for the citizens of both our countries.

Spain is a valued ally, and the United States is committed to working closely with Spain to combat terrorism and promote global security. We recognize and respect the legal and ethical differences between our nations, and any cooperation between our countries would be conducted in a manner consistent with both Spain's laws and principles and the international norms governing the treatment of detainees.

In terms of assistance, the United States can work with Spain through a variety of means, including intelligence sharing, counterterrorism training for law enforcement and security forces, technical assistance, and the exchange of best practices in the field of counterterrorism. We can also assist with the prevention of terrorist financing and work to disrupt terrorist networks.

It's important to note that while there are differences in our approaches to the death penalty, our commitment to fighting terrorism aligns us in our broader goals of protecting our citizens and our democratic values. The United States is prepared to provide any support that does not violate Spanish law or ethical standards, and will always respect the sovereignty of Spain in its treatment of individuals involved in terrorist activities.

Thank you for the question. When we discussed the AIDS initiative for Africa, we committed to a robust, comprehensive program that would be a beacon of hope for those suffering from HIV/AIDS. The commitment to provide $15 billion over five years was made, with the goal being to save millions of lives and make a significant impact on the epidemic.

I want to be clear that this initiative, known as the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), is truly an emergency plan, thus the $15 billion is broken down by its execution over the five-year span. It's a long-term commitment that does not mean an outlay of all $15 billion in just the first three years. It reflects a structured way to deliver resources and aid effectively, ensuring accountability and impact.

Regarding the first year's funding, the commitment covered an initial investment to jump-start the program, providing necessary infrastructure and support to begin the critical work with our partners around the world. The $15 billion over five years has been a bipartisan effort, with strong support from both parties, as doctors from all backgrounds have come together to advocate for an effective response to the AIDS pandemic.

I want to make sure that everyone understands that this initiative is about more than just the money—it's about lives being saved. We have been working closely with our partners in Congress to ensure that the funding is appropriate for the scope of the mission. I assure you, we will be diligent in meeting this commitment and making sure that aid reaches those who need it most.

Thank you for raising this important topic, and I hope we can continue to work together to save lives and combat this terrible virus.

Thank you for your question. The Doha Development Round is different from the FTAA negotiations in that its scope and focus are on global trade issues rather than just hemispheric ones. It aims to address the needs of developing countries, with a strong focus on reducing trade barriers and improving market access for goods and services from all countries, particularly those from the developing world.

The FTAA negotiations, while laudable in their goal to create a free trade area among the Americas, faced significant challenges, including varying levels of development and concerns about equity and competitiveness among the participating countries. However, the Doha Round has a more inclusive approach designed to foster growth and development across the board.

Regarding language and communication, we understand the importance of clear, concise, and understandable dialogue in trade negotiations. We aim to ensure that all voices are heard, and all concerns are addressed during the discussions.

As for deadlines and commitments, it's important to establish realistic timelines that allow for thorough and robust negotiations. While setting ambitious targets can provide momentum, the ultimate goal is to achieve a balanced and fair agreement. We are committed to working diligently with all stakeholders to reach a deal in the Doha Round, maintaining a spirit of cooperation and mutual understanding.

Leaders from various countries will meet in Washington to further these discussions, and these meetings will be critical in advancing the Doha Round negotiations. We will continue to seek common ground and build consensus, recognizing that effective trade agreements require the goodwill and dedication of all participating nations.

I want to reaffirm our commitment to the principles of the Doha Round and the betterment it can bring to the global economy and the well-being of all people, regardless of borders.

Thank you for your insightful questions. Indeed, Africa is on the cusp of significant change, and I believe that the continent is well-poised to emerge as a critical player in the global economy and international affairs. To achieve sustainable progress, I believe that Africa must focus on several critical areas. First and foremost, good governance and accountable leadership are paramount. Leaders must be committed to transparency, the rule of law, and the welfare of their citizens. This means promoting political stability, investing in institutions that can support democratic practices, and combating corruption.

Secondly, economic growth must be inclusive and equitable. This requires a concerted effort to diversify economies away from reliance on commodities and to leverage technology to create opportunities for entrepreneurship and innovation. Investment in infrastructure, such as transportation, energy, and information technology, is also essential for economic growth.

Thirdly, education and healthcare are cornerstones of human development. Africa must invest in its people to ensure they have the skills and health needed to harness the continent's potential. This includes improving access to quality education and healthcare services.

The United States is committed to being a partner in this journey. We will continue to support programs that promote good governance, economic development, education, and healthcare. We will also continue to engage in dialogue with African leaders to encourage positive change and cooperation.

Regarding my African tour, it is an opportunity to reaffirm our commitment to Africa and to discuss how we can work together to address the continent's challenges and seize its opportunities. Specifically, we will focus on themes such as entrepreneurship, healthcare, and security. The overarching goal is to help create an Africa that is secure, prosperous, and thriving.

As for my visit being near the end of my presidency, I see it as a testament to the enduring partnership between the United States and Africa. My administration has consistently prioritized Africa, and my hope is that this visit will continue to foster a positive trajectory of engagement between our countries.

To ensure continuity in these efforts, it is crucial to institutionalize our relationships and initiatives. This means building strong, bipartisan support for U.S.-African partnerships, focusing on areas where both parties can work effectively together, and fostering the next generation of leaders in both our countries. I am confident that with continued dedication and cooperation, we can achieve meaningful and lasting progress for the people of Africa.

I appreciate the question, and I will try to address it in a series of points.

First of all, regarding my own situation, I want to ensure we're all clear: I was investigated by the SEC and I fully cooperated. In legal proceedings, I made the decision to waive attorney-client privilege because I believed it would help resolve the issue more efficiently and fairly. This was a voluntary action I took, provided under legal parameters involved at the time.

Regarding executives invoking the Fifth Amendment, it's a defensible constitutional right. However, I understand your concern that it can cause uncertainty and lack of transparency, especially during a time when investors might be feeling nervous. I recognize the importance of fostering integrity and accountability in corporate leadership, and I share the Senate's concerns about ensuring that our actions to reform corporate governance actually help restore trust in the markets. It's important for senior officers to step up and cooperate with transparent and thorough investigations.

Regarding the Sarbanes proposal, our administration supports robust reforms aimed at restoring trust in our markets. We are committed to ensuring that public companies' financial statements are accurate and that corporations and their executives adhere to the highest standards of ethical behavior. It's also important to ensure that any new regulatory bodies are necessary, effective, and appropriately balanced to minimize potential bureaucratic overreach. I remain open to discussions on how to best achieve these goals while also ensuring the continued competitiveness and resilience of our financial markets.

I believe that we can work together to create a sensible approach to corporate governance that protects investors while safeguarding the innovative and dynamic spirit of American enterprise. It is my hope that we can achieve truly meaningful reforms that will help foster trust and transparency in the corporate world.

Thank you for your question. As I've emphasized, one of our key priorities is to address the challenges posed by North Korea's nuclear weapons program. We have sought to engage diplomatically to resolve this issue, recognizing the risk and instability that come from a nuclear-armed North Korea. Over the last year, we've worked to seek out a diplomatic resolution while also strengthening our alliances in the region and reinforcing American military presence to show strength and resolve.

Our approach is multifaceted. We have engaged in direct diplomatic talks, worked with our allies, and implemented targeted sanctions where appropriate to put pressure on North Korea to choose dialogue over the continued pursuit of nuclear weapons.

It's important to remember that dealing with a nuclear threat as complex and as dangerous as that posed by North Korea requires patience, strategy, and perseverance. We continue to work diplomatically and with international partners to achieve a peaceful and stable resolution.

The challenge is significant, but we remain committed to a comprehensive approach that combines our efforts diplomatically, economically, and strategically to produce the best outcome for the American people and the security and stability of the region.

Thank you for your question. The United States has consistently supported Russia's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), and we have recognized the economic reforms and the effort made toward improving its trade policies. However, there have been concerns within our country regarding certain issues that need to be addressed before we can fully support Russia's accession.

One of the principal concerns has been the protection of intellectual property rights, which are critical for a market-driven economy. We have worked closely with Russia to address these concerns, and progress has been made as a result of our engagement. Additionally, there are issues related to transparency and legal predictability in the business climate which Russia has been working to resolve.

Under President Putin's leadership, Russia has made significant strides toward WTO accession, and we recognize the ambition to integrate the Russian economy into the global trading system. The United States is committed to working with Russia to resolve the remaining issues, and I am confident that we can find a way to move forward on this important matter that benefits the global trade community and helps create a more prosperous environment for all involved.

It is important to emphasize that the U.S. position is not standing in the way of Russia's membership solely for the sake of impeding progress; rather, it is about ensuring that all WTO members adhere to the principles of fair and equitable trade. The United States will continue to engage constructively with Russia and other WTO members to ensure a smooth and robust accession process.

Thank you for your questions.

First, I can understand that some of my statements, including those regarding the axis of evil, could be seen as causing some concern among South Koreans. My intent was to express the seriousness of the threats posed by certain regimes, chief among them being North Korea. I deeply respect the commitment of the South Korean people and their leaders to peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula.

Regarding the axis of evil, I believe it is important for the U.S. to make clear the challenges that we face with nations that threaten the security of their neighbors and the broader global community. However, I want to stress that my administration is committed to working with allies, including my good friend, President Kim, in South Korea, to achieve peace and security.

In terms of the Sunshine Policy, I believe our approach is complementary to the broad goals of engagement and peaceful coexistence. While I am clear about the challenges posed by North Korea, I also support efforts to constructively engage with North Korea through dialogue and cooperation to achieve the goal of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and improved relations between North and South Korea.

I spoke with President Kim Dae-jung, and he expressed his perspective on the situation. Regarding the sincerity of North Korea's intentions to open up, President Kim and I both share the view that careful and cautious steps must be taken. We understand that North Korea's actions have raised doubts, as evidenced by the issues with reunification processes, infrastructure development, and willingness to engage in direct dialogue with the U.S.

Despite these concerns, it's important to keep the lines of communication open. Sovereign nations can change their policies, and the prospect of normalization and engagement can encourage positive steps. The verification of North Korea's stated intentions through concrete actions is key, and both our countries will continue to work towards a peaceful resolution to the tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

Again, my thanks to President Kim and all South Koreans for the warm reception I've received. We are committed to maintaining a strong alliance and working together to ensure a peaceful and prosperous future for the Korean people.

Thank you for your question regarding Italy's role in the 5-plus-1 group regarding the Iranian crisis. The 5-plus-1 group, composed of the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Russia, and China along with Germany or another European representative, has been an important platform for addressing the Iranian nuclear issue. Italy, and indeed other European countries, have a significant interest in the stability and security of the region and have often been strong partners in working with us on this matter.

Regarding comments from Secretary of State Stephen Hadley or any other member of my administration, it's worth noting that the approach of engaging with Iran on the nuclear issue while maintaining pressure through sanctions and diplomatic efforts has been a consistent policy from my administration. The way such engagement will unfold can indeed depend on the ongoing dialogue and developments at the time.

If Italy or any other country is invited to participate in or contribute to the 5-plus-1 discussions, it reflects the value we place on their perspectives and their commitment to non-proliferation. The United States seeks to coordinate our efforts with our allies and partners to ensure a coherent and effective approach to addressing the Iranian nuclear issue.

We are always open to dialogue, but we are also steadfast in our commitment to preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. Our policy of engagement and pressure remains firm, and our decisions will be based on what is in the best interest of ensuring regional and global stability and security. Thank you for your question, and we will continue to work closely with our international partners on this vital issue.

Thank you for your question. As we continue to seek a resolution through international efforts, the United States is committed to working with our allies and friends around the world. The situation continues to be discussed within the United Nations, but we remain steadfast in our commitment to addressing the serious threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

Regarding coalition support, we recognize the importance of having a broad coalition in this effort, and we have received support from several nations. While the UK, Spain, and other countries have been very supportive and have committed troops and resources to the operation, the exact details and the extent of participation from each country are matters that need to be worked out with each respective government. 

Prime Minister Blair has been a strong ally in this endeavor, and we've discussed the importance of a post-conflict Iraq and stabilization efforts, which will require international cooperation. We will work through the United Nations and other international bodies to facilitate the reconstruction and rebuilding of Iraq once Saddam Hussein's regime has been removed. But let me be clear, our immediate focus is on the danger posed by Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction and his support for terrorism.

President Aznar has been a steadfast supporter of the US and a partner in our discussions. Spain's role will be determined by the coordination with the Spanish government, and I would direct that you speak directly with President Aznar for the specifics of Spain's participation. Our goal remains to ensure the security of ourselves, our friends, and allies around the world by dealing effectively with the threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

Thank you for your interest in this matter. We will keep the world informed as the situation develops and as we work towards our shared goals of a safer, more secure world.

Thank you for your questions. Let me address the context and the concerns expressed in your inquiry regarding the investments of Petrobras in Iran.

Firstly, President Bush to the media: It's important to understand that while the United Nations may have passed sanctions on Iran, the U.S. and other world powers maintain their own independent policies toward Tehran, beyond those established by the UN Security Council. The Iranian regime supports terrorism, works on weapons of mass destruction, and has hostile intentions toward the United States and its allies. These assessments and concerns are key in guiding the U.S. government's and its allies' policies regarding investments in Iran.

Regarding Petrobras' investments, the concern is not merely about fulfilling UN sanctions. We are deeply concerned about the broader implications of such investments in a country known for its state-sponsored terrorism and defiance of international norms. We strongly encourage our partners and allies around the world to think twice before participating in ventures that support or prop up such a regime.

I would recommend that Brazil and Petrobras consider the strategic implications of their investments in Iran, not only in terms of sanctions but also because the Iranian regime continues to pose significant threats to regional stability and global peace. Our diplomatic efforts are focused on maintaining international pressure on Iran and preventing it from advancing damaging policies that destabilize the world.

To President Lula or the Brazilian government, I would advise discretion and carefully weigh the benefits and risks of continuing such investments into Iran. The stakes are high, and the consequences could be significant not only for Petrobras but for the global economy and the fight against terrorism.

Thank you for your question. When it comes to North Korea and Iran, the situations are certainly serious, given the proliferation of nuclear weapons and programs that threaten international peace and security. The United States has been very clear in its stance against the spread of weapons of mass destruction and their use. 

In the case of North Korea, our approach has been to work through multilateral efforts, like the Six-Party Talks, to achieve the complete, verifiable, and irreversible dismantlement of their nuclear program. In addition, we have taken a comprehensive approach that includes diplomatic, economic, and strategic efforts to address the North Korean threat.

Regarding Iran, we have also emphasized the need for full transparency and accountability regarding their nuclear program. The administration worked hard to support the Iran deal, formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, which was designed to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. While it has been criticized for its effectiveness, the deal was meant to provide strict limits and inspections to curtail Iran's nuclear ambitions.

The doctrine of regime change is a complex issue. It depends on the specific context and the likelihood of success. In the case of Iraq, the decision to act was based on the intelligence available and the assessment that the threat justifiably warranted a decisive response to ensure the safety of the United States and our allies.

For North Korea and Iran, the international community has not reached a consensus on the degree or type of regime change that might be necessary. Instead, we focus on containing and de-escalating the nuclear threats these countries pose. We have not ruled out all options, but we believe that diplomacy, alliances, and international pressure are important tools to address the situation.

Ultimately, the decisions about how to address ongoing challenges with rogue regimes will be made with a careful consideration of national security interests, potential outcomes, and the safety and well-being of the American people. It is crucial that any actions taken are part of a broader strategy that considers regional stability, humanitarian concerns, and the long-term vision for peace and security in those regions.

I understand the concern about human rights and the importance of freedom of expression around the world. It is important for the United States to speak up when we see issues of human rights being violated, because we believe strongly in fundamental human rights being accessible to everyone. I have, in fact, raised concerns about human rights with President Hu during our discussions.

When it comes to the relationship between the United States and China, it's crucial to approach these issues in a manner that facilitates constructive dialogue and cooperation. We work with the Chinese on a range of issues from economic relations to security matters, but that doesn't mean we ignore the legitimate concerns of the American people and the international community about human rights. We will continue to advocate for the expansion of freedoms and the protection of human rights, while also engaging China on areas of mutual interest.

Thank you for your question. Let's address each part of it carefully.

First, regarding the treatment of prisoners, the United States works hard to make sure that the individuals detained are treated humanely and with dignity, consistent with our values and the law. It’s important to communicate to the world, and especially to the Muslim world, that incidents of misconduct, while unacceptable, are not reflective of our policies or the values by which we operate.

We condemn the actions of individuals who abuse prisoners, and we take aggressive measures to prevent such conduct, to investigate it thoroughly, and to hold those responsible accountable. Ensuring that the actions at Bagram and other detention facilities are isolated incidents is not just about the rhetoric; it is about implementing rigorous policies and oversight to make sure that our service members understand and respect the rights and treatment of those in their custody.

We must also continually remind the world that the majority of our personnel are dedicated men and women who are engaged in a difficult but necessary mission – to ensure the safety of the United States and its allies, and to eliminate terrorism.

On the matter of casualties in Iraq and the challenge it presents, it's true that there have been incidents of high casualties in recent days, and the insurgency has shown resilience. The ongoing struggle against extremists in Iraq is complex and evolving, but it's not insurmountable. We must remain steadfast in our commitment to the mission while working towards a political and security solution that can bring stability and unity to Iraq.

Our strategy involves not only the military effort but also supporting political, economic, and social reconstruction which are vital ingredients for long-term security and success. Defeating the insurgency militarily is important, but equally critical is the establishment of a government that respects the rule of law and the rights of its citizens. This contributes to the overall framework of a peaceful and democratic Iraq, which helps counter the appeal of insurgency and extremism in the region.

We stand with the Iraqi people and our coalition partners, and we will continue to adapt and employ all necessary means to ensure the success of the mission. The challenges ahead are significant, but so is the resolve of our troops and our allies. We cannot let the insurgency's brutality undermine the legitimacy and effectiveness of our efforts to bring peace and security to the region.

I appreciate those questions. First, concerning the remarks from General John Abizaid: He has been a valuable source of advice, and his assessment of the challenges facing Iraq reflects the complex security situation the nation is currently experiencing. The religious differences contributing to violence in Iraq are a challenge, but it's important to note that the situation is multifaceted. We are working closely with Iraqi leaders from all communities to combat terrorism and build a peaceful Iraq that respects all its citizens. We are committed to supporting the Iraqi government and people as they work to establish a stable and democratic society that addresses the underlying causes of conflict, including the thorny issue of religious and ethnic tensions.

Regarding the security plan to counter religious violence, we have been working closely with the Iraqi government to develop effective strategies. These strategies include strengthening the capabilities of the Iraqi security forces and supporting their efforts to restore security, as well as working with community leaders to de-escalate tensions and promote dialogue.

Now, turning to the question about humanitarian aid and the military assistance to Israel: Our objective is to support the security of Israel as well as the humanitarian needs of the Lebanese people, which is not contradictory. We support Israel's right to defend itself and we are providing humanitarian assistance to Lebanon as per our commitments to the international community and the United Nations. We are trying to help Lebanon rebuild after the destruction caused by the conflict, separate from our response to Israel's security concerns. Our actions are guided by a desire to ensure regional stability and security while also addressing humanitarian needs.

These are difficult and complex issues, but our goal is clear: to support our friends, promote peace and security in the region, and assist those in need. We are committed to working with all affected parties to achieve these important objectives.

Thank you for your question. The situation in the Middle East is indeed complex, and it's important to keep the perspective of the progress we've made and where we need to go.

First, our commitment to transforming the Middle East has focused not just on the removal of Saddam Hussein but also on the long-term prospects for peace in the region. By removing Saddam Hussein, we've eliminated a dangerous and destabilizing figure who was at odds with the United States, Israel, and many Arab states. The new government in Iraq aims to be a bulwark against the forces of extremism, and although there have been setbacks, we believe that Iraq is on the path toward becoming a democratic, peaceful, and prosperous member of the international community.

Regarding the criticism of Israel by the Iraqi Prime Minister and other actors, it's important to note that the encouragement of open debate and criticism is a hallmark of democracy. We support the Iraqi government maintaining sovereignty and its people having the freedom to make their voices heard. However, we also support our alliance with Israel and have worked to solidify its security and the security of its allies.

We've been working actively with allies and the international community to deal with Iran and Syria's support to Hezbollah. Their provocations and rhetoric are deeply concerning, and we've called for them to moderate their stance and to cease their support for terrorist organizations that threaten regional stability. While progress isn't always as quick as we'd like, our efforts are aimed at making sure that Middle Eastern countries move towards a more peaceful and productive relationship with one another and with the international community.

The challenges have certainly been significant, and the regional dynamics have changed since the initial phase of the Iraq War. However, we continue to believe that our efforts to promote democracy, liberty, and justice will be the key to transforming the Middle East into a region that respects human rights and promotes peace, security, and economic growth for all its citizens. We've stayed committed to our strategic goals despite challenges, and we will continue to work with our friends and allies in the region to achieve these objectives.

Thank you for your question.

During my visit, it has been clear that the United States values strong relationships with its neighbors in Latin America, and we seek mutual cooperation that promotes prosperity and security for all involved. President Calderon and I discussed the regional dynamics and challenges that include the efforts by President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela to exert influence in the region.

The United States does not wish to create or be associated with any kind of bloc or alliance system aimed specifically at opposing any one country. However, it is important for the United States to work closely with Mexico and other nations in the region to promote democratic values and economic stability, which in turn lead to stronger relationships and better outcomes for our people.

President Calderon and I agreed that one of the best ways to encourage cooperation and stability is to continue working together on issues such as security, economic opportunity, and regional integration. During my state visit, I had the opportunity to underscore our commitment to these goals and to express support for the Calderon administration's efforts to tackle serious challenges in Mexico.

Regarding the relationship with Venezuela, it is important to note that countries have a right to engage in diplomatic relationships with each other. The United States engages with a variety of countries, and we seek productive dialogue on a range of issues. However, this does not conflict with our efforts to foster cooperation and stability in the region.

The commitments made during this visit with the Calderon administration focus on mutual benefits through enhanced cooperation in various areas, including security and economic development, which contribute to a more stable and prosperous Western Hemisphere. We support our friends and allies in the region as they work to promote democratic governance and economic opportunity for their citizens.

Thank you for your question. Indeed, understanding the complexities of the Palestinian situation, including the issue of prisoners, is something that the administration continues to work diligently on. While I can't go into specific details of the meeting with President Abbas today, I can say that any discussions we have had with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and his administration have been focused on finding ways to move forward with the peace process.

One of the key goals is to unlock the potential for peace, and that means addressing all issues, including the release of prisoners and ensuring that all parties are committed to the conditions set forth for the continuation of dialogue. It's important to remember that these are complex issues that require thorough understanding and careful handling.

The United States remains committed to supporting the parties in the Middle East as they work towards a negotiated settlement that leads to two states living side by side, in peace and security. We continue to engage with all relevant parties to encourage progress and help facilitate agreements that meet the necessary conditions for lasting peace.

We have been working closely with the Palestinians and Israelis to address their concerns and find solutions that are acceptable to both sides. Our ultimate goal is to help build confidence and trust between the parties, which is crucial for the success of any peace process.

I appreciate the opportunity to address this important issue. It's true that trade is a complex and often contentious topic, but I am confident in the benefits of free trade agreements like the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and its successor, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

The free trade debate is critical, and I believe that the positive impacts of these agreements are clear: they create jobs and economic growth. NAFTA in particular has had a significant positive effect on our economy by expanding markets for American goods and opening up opportunities for businesses large and small.

I understand that some are concerned about the impacts on certain industries or regions, but it's important to have a comprehensive view that includes the significant benefits as well. Our administration will continue to make the case for trade policies that are in the best interest of the American people, and we will work to address the challenges that arise as part of the global economy.

We've also taken steps with domestic policies such as the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program and other initiatives to support workers as we pursue our protrade agenda, ensuring that the American workforce is strong, competitive, and adaptable to the changing global market.

Regarding the political discourse, I'm supportive of those advocating for policies they believe in, but as president, I will continue to advocate for trade policies that promote economic prosperity and a stronger America. It's essential that the American people understand the broader context and opportunities that these agreements present.

Thank you for your question, and I hope this clarifies our position on this vital issue.

I appreciate the question, but it seems there might be a slight confusion. I'm President George W. Bush, not "Your Majesty," and the U.S. certainly plays a prominent role in the Middle East peace process, but the situation you describe would more precisely align with the framework and terms relevant to the Quartet's participation, rather than a monarchical designation or direct rule.

The Roadmap for Peace, which I supported, did indeed call for a monitoring system to ensure that both the Israelis and Palestinians are fulfilling their obligations. It's important to note that the Quartet on the Middle East, which consists of the United States, Russia, the European Union, and the United Nations, has been actively involved in the peace process and can potentially be more deeply involved in monitoring mechanisms.

Regarding stricter monitoring, the involvement of the international community is crucial and we have had discussions on how to strengthen the framework's implementation. The U.S. has often worked closely with the Quartet to enforce the Roadmap and to encourage the parties to move forward constructively toward the goal of a peaceful resolution. This includes support for performance-based steps such as Palestinian reforms and security measures, as well as Israeli actions to facilitate the path to a viable Palestine. We support collaborative efforts that enhance the monitoring and enforcement of commitments from all parties to the conflict.

Thank you for your question and for bringing attention to the critical issue of drug trafficking and security concerns in Guatemala. As you rightly point out, drug trafficking and related criminal activities pose a grave threat to the safety and prosperity of Guatemala and the broader region. We recognize the importance of addressing this issue not only for Guatemala, but also for the security and stability of our hemisphere.

The United States has a long-standing commitment to supporting efforts to combat drug trafficking and organized crime through strategic regional cooperation. Our strategy aims to build a comprehensive and collaborative approach that addresses not only the flow of drugs but also the underlying factors that contribute to the problem, such as corruption, criminal violence, and underdevelopment. Through this regional strategy, we are working closely with Guatemala and other neighboring countries to enhance law enforcement capabilities, strengthen judicial systems, support civic governance, and promote economic opportunities for citizens.

The U.S. government has been an active participant in bilateral and multilateral efforts to address the security situation in Guatemala. This includes our commitment to the Mérida Initiative, which, although primarily focused on Mexico, has also aimed to support Central American countries in their fight against drug trafficking. We have provided assistance to support law enforcement, judicial reform, and the rule of law in Guatemala as part of our broader efforts.

Regarding the specific request for a mini-Colombia Plan for Guatemala, the U.S. is exploring ways to adapt our successful programs from other regions to the unique context of Guatemala. The Colombia Plan provided a model of how to integrate aid for security with programs to undercut drug trafficking and associated violence. We are engaging with the Guatemalan government to develop strategies that leverage lessons learned from these kind of initiatives while recognizing the distinct challenges and conditions in Guatemala.

The murder of the three Salvadoran Congress Members is a tragic event that underscores the need for the international community, including the United States, to work alongside national governments to combat the violence and illicit activities that threaten the safety of citizens and the democratic process.

Our cooperation with Guatemala on these issues will continue to be robust. We will continue to work through diplomatic channels, bilaterally and through regional bodies, to ensure that Guatemala has the assistance and tools it needs to address drug trafficking and related security issues effectively. Additionally, our cooperation will involve intelligence sharing, training for law enforcement and judicial officials, and supporting legal reforms aimed at curbing corruption and enhancing the ability of Guatemalan institutions to address organized crime.

In conclusion, the United States is committed to standing with Guatemala and the region in the fight against drug trafficking and related violent crime. We will continue to listen to the needs of our partners and adapt our approach to provide the most effective support for the complex challenges they face.

Thank you for your question. With regard to Cuba, my administration has made it clear that the stance on the embargo is tied to the progress towards democracy and respect for human rights in Cuba. The embargo is a comprehensive policy addressing a regime that does not respect the freedom of its citizens. We have supported the Cuban people in their quest for freedom and dignity, insisting that any change in policy must reflect a positive movement towards a democratic and free Cuba.

On the subject of Europe and other countries, it's important to understand that each country and situation is unique, and our policy towards them can vary based on a range of factors, including human rights records, economic relations, and strategic interests.

Regarding Plan Colombia, we are indeed committed to continuing and supporting anti-drug efforts in Colombia. Plan Colombia was a comprehensive strategy that aimed at promoting peace and stability in the country, while combating drug trafficking and terrorism. This is a significant issue not only for Colombia but also for the United States, given the impact of Colombian cocaine on our society. We have provided substantial support through the plan, and I anticipate that my administration will continue to support our allies in Colombia in their fight against illegal drug trade and associated violence.

Mr. President,

As the President of the United States, I want to express my confidence in the traditional definition of marriage and our nation's commitment to basic moral values. The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) recognizes that marriage in the United States is the union of one man and one woman. This is not a reflection of disrespect or discrimination toward our fellow Americans. 

We support all Americans in their pursuit of happiness, but when it comes to the public policy of marriage, the federal government recognizes the union of one man and one woman. The DOMA Act is one way we declare this stance, and as you know, California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger reaffirmed this stance regarding same-sex marriage when it was ruled against by the California courts.

While some may view the legal authorization of marriage for gay and lesbian couples as a positive step, as a nation, we have honored the union of one man and one woman as being the best environment to raise our children. The interests of those children extend beyond the legal status of their parents' union; it includes a loving and supportive home, which is best promoted by families built on the traditional understanding of marriage.

The pictures of thousands of families getting married sparked discussions and brought attention to the issue of same-sex relationships and their integration within society. However, the debate continues, reflecting the diverse views within our country. As a society, we uphold freedoms, including the freedom to support and advocate for differing views and beliefs. 

I believe that the well-being of all Americans' children, including those in gay and lesbian families, is of paramount importance. While we respect the rights of individuals to love whom they choose, we stand by the traditional understanding of marriage under federal law. There is ongoing dialogue about where the law falls, and various states have different positions on this issue, which is part of our democratic process.

If you have further questions on this topic, please feel free to ask.

Thank you for your questions. Regarding the situation in Iran, we are carefully monitoring the situation and are in close contact with our partners in the region and around the world. The British government would be well within their rights to consider all options as they see fit to ensure the safety of their personnel.

If the situation had involved U.S. sailors and marines, our response would clearly depend on the specifics of the incident. We always take the safety and well-being of our service members very seriously. The laws of armed conflict and international norms guide our actions, and we do not make public decisions on whether an action qualifies as an act of war without a thorough and careful evaluation.

Regarding the proposal to trade the five Iranians captured in Irbil back in January, we have been consistent in advocating for the release of our personnel in Iran and those taken from HMS Monmouth. Humanitarian considerations are critical, and we would evaluate any proposal that would help bring our members home safely. However, such decisions must be made with reverence for both our citizens' dignity and the principles of rule of law. We are exploring all options to safely resolve this crisis, while upholding justice and the interests of our nations involved.

We remain committed to a peaceful resolution of the crisis and will continue to engage all parties involved to secure the release of the captured individuals.

Thank you for your question, and I appreciate you bringing this up.

When the Democrats took control of Congress, we listened to their ideas and pursued meaningful dialogue with members of the opposition party through several initiatives, such as the surge in Iraq. Although our perspectives differed, both parties worked together to evaluate how to move forward effectively. I believe that listening to each other's views is crucial to finding common ground.

Regarding the recent approval of war funding, it's important to note that Congress has recognized the necessity of supporting our troops as they continue their vital work in Iraq. The bipartisan approach to this issue demonstrates that when it comes to national security, members of both parties can find areas to cooperate and ensure the success of the troops and the overall mission.

In terms of the relationship with the Democratic leadership, I can say that despite our ideological differences and disagreements on policy, I have always emphasized the importance of respect and working together for the good of the country. The legislative process is inherently collaborative, and while there may be challenges, we must remain focused on our shared objectives—particularly the safety and security of our nation.

Of course, my administration remains committed to pursuing its legislative priorities while respecting the role of the Congress. Our strong policy statements and the willingness to follow through with actions, such as veto threats, reflect our commitment to guiding the national agenda and ensuring that the decisions made reflect the best interests of all Americans.

Thank you for your question, and I'll be happy to answer further queries you or other members of the press may have.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding my discussions with His Holiness Pope John Paul II, I respect the moral and spiritual guidance he provides, and I value his input on matters of conscience and faith. As a Christian, I hold those principles in the highest regard. I'm deeply committed to ensuring that our policies reflect the sanctity of life and respect moral values, while also recognizing the importance of medical research that could lead to advancements in treating and curing serious diseases.

In our conversation, we touched upon the fundamental ethical considerations regarding human life and the responsibilities we have as leaders to promote policies that adhere to high moral standards. The Pope expressed his views about the sanctity of life, which begins at conception, and the moral implications of creating embryos specifically for research. He is clear in stating that such practices are morally unacceptable.

However, the executive order I signed establishes guidelines for stem cell research using existing lines. These lines were created before my administration, which is distinct from the moral issue associated with the creation of new embryos for research purposes. Many researchers argue that research using these lines is critical for scientific and medical advancements. Balancing these scientific opportunities with moral and ethical concerns is part of the broader dialogue we seek through the President's Council on Bioethics.

Central to the discussion we had is also the commitment to ensuring that any research is done in a manner that not only aims to find cures for devastating illnesses but also respects humanitarian values. It's important for us to consider how we can proceed in a way that is supportive of the underlying moral principles of not destroying human life in the pursuit of research, while still allowing researchers to develop life-saving treatments and therapies.

I am open to considering all options that respect both the sanctity of life and the value of medical research, and I'll be taking into account the recommendations and insights from the Council on Bioethics as well as other relevant experts in the field.

As for the specific compromise, I'm not divulging the exact measures I'm considering, but they are intended to walk a fine line between supporting necessary research and adhering to ethical guidelines. We are considering options that can provide hope and healing without requiring the destruction of embryos.

Thank you for your interest in this important matter. I continue to maintain and will weigh all advice that is given to me as I work to find the best way to promote life and medical progress in a manner that honors our values.

Good morning, and thank you for the questions. Since September 11th, our nation has faced far-reaching consequences that have reshaped international relations and cooperation. To address your questions directly:

Regarding the ABM Treaty, back in September, we were focused on building a missile defense system that would enhance our security and the security of our allies. While the events of September 11th have certainly redefined our security priorities, the notion of a missile defense system remains valid. No longer are we solely concerned with an adversarial state launching an attack that may take up to 30 minutes to reach us. Now, we must be prepared to confront immediate threats, whether they come from a terrorist group or a hostile nation-state harboring such groups.

Russia, as a key player in the international community, understands the urgency with which the United States is responding to these new challenges. While we value our partnership with Russia, we must work on our own terms in the interest of defending our nation and protecting our citizens. The decision to develop and deploy a missile defense system, which is intended to protect against limited missile attacks, remains a priority for us.

As for the international support, particularly from the Muslim and Arab world, it is understandable that statements of solidarity from these regions are still evolving. The tragic circumstances of September 11th have necessitated a clear distinction between the actions of the terrorists and the peaceful and lawful members of the Islamic faith. It is crucial that the global community underscores the importance of separating the reprehensible actions of extremists from the beliefs of Islam and its followers.

We have seen supportive responses from various Muslim countries, leaders, and the United Nations. Many have renounced terrorism and condemned the attacks in clear terms. The United States continues to work closely with these nations to ensure that the broader message is understood—that this conflict is against the threat of terrorism and seeks to protect the freedom and human rights that every nation must cherish.

This administration, in collaboration with these countries, will continue to communicate firmly and consistently that the fight against terrorism is one that respects and upholds the principles of all faiths and honors the diversity within the global community.

I appreciate your question, and I want to address the points you've raised as well as I can. First, let me clarify what I've meant by my statement concerning the British servicemen. When I referred to the situation as one where they were "executed," it was to emphasize the brutality and ruthlessness of the Saddam Hussein regime. It was not meant to suggest legal terms or to come off as insensitive to the bereaved families or the British government.

Regarding the support we've garnered for the war in Iraq, it is a multi-faceted issue. While it's true that we have not received the explicit support from some countries, such as France and Germany in the case of the UN Security Council, we have the strong support of a coalition of 48 countries, including many longstanding allies who stood with us as per their national security concerns and democratic principles. These countries recognize that Saddam Hussein posed a danger to the region and the world, that his brutal regime was oppressing the Iraqi people, and that it was strategic and morally imperative to act.

I believe there is a moral imperative to ensure Iraq is no longer a threat to its neighbors or the rest of the world. Saddam Hussein's regime had a proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and continued a pattern of aggression, which was a danger we could not afford to ignore. Furthermore, it is the commitment to freedom and human rights that drives not only the United States but other like-minded nations to work towards changing regimes that oppress their people and threaten international stability.

Ultimately, the lack of wholehearted support from some long-standing allies reflects differences in strategic assessments and interpretations of international laws and norms. However, we are and continue to strive for broad international support as we resolve this conflict in Iraq, both during and after the military operations.
