However, Saddam Hussein refused to disarm, he deceived the world about his weapons programs, and he employed brutal methods against his own people and even against neighboring countries. We had intelligence that suggested Iraq had an active weapons of mass destruction program, and that was based on the conduct of the regime, which had used chemical weapons against Iran and against its own Kurdish population.

The concern that going to war could create more terrorists is a valid one, but it was not a reason to turn a blind eye to a threat to our own security. When you face a dictator who is known to have used weapons of mass destruction and who is working to acquire even more dangerous weapons, tyranny is not going to be weakened by mere words or sanctions alone.

Regarding the criticism that we'd create more enemies by going to war, it's true that the war and the circumstances in Iraq afterwards were complex and not without difficulties. But the key point is that the United States and its coalition partners acted to rid the world of a dictator who posed a grave danger to the world, and to set in motion a process towards democracy in the Middle East, which we believed was consistent with our values and would lead to peace and stability in the long term.

We acted not out of aggression, but out of a desire to prevent a future conflict that would be far more perilous and deadly than the one we took on. The responsibility of leadership is to take action when words and diplomacy have not been enough to safeguard our nation and our allies.

It must also be remembered that the global coalition against terrorism, which includes many nations, stands on a foundation of shared values and a common purpose in the face of extremism. Our job is to protect freedom and democracy, and sometimes that means tough decisions. We have a moral responsibility to stand against tyranny and fear, and to promote democracy and self-determination.

Well, thank you for that question. I must say, in this campaign, I heard people's concerns about the role of faith in our society. I believe in the separation of church and state, and I think it's absolutely vital that we have a wall of separation there. But I also believe that freedom to worship without government interference is a vital part of the legacy that our founders left for us.

One of the things that concerns me is when people dismiss people of faith. When Senator Kerry talked about the role of faith in the campaign and why people mobilized, I think he viewed them with a degree of condescension. I don't think it's fair to view believers in our country as if they have an agenda or if they're anything less than patriotic citizens.

Now, what I did hear during the campaign was people expressing the desire to have their values engaged. They don't want a candidate or official looking for the middle point on an issue but rather to actually have their voice heard. And I understood that. Part of the reason why I felt so strongly about a constitutional amendment to protect marriage was that there was such a heightened debate around the definition of marriage. People expressed a desire to preserve the sanctity of that concept.

In terms of my policies, I have always tried to balance the traditional role of separation between church and state with the recognition of the rights of the individuals to worship as freely as they choose to. I have surrounded myself with people who can provide advice from different points of view, even if they don't agree with my own. And I respect the opinion of others who don't share my viewpoint or whose viewpoints are outside my own.

So, this call that there's a division -- or reality, if you will -- of faith-based communities turning into a perceived political divide is just that: a perception. Good, decent people can disagree on issues, and they ought to be able to speak openly and freely about their differences in an environment that encourages respect and honors the act of voting itself.

To those who are concerned about the role of faith and how it impacts our public life and policy, my message would be to continue to act on your conscience. People of faith have a place in our government, and they're part of the fabric of our society. We should welcome their contributions and encourage an open dialogue on all issues. At the same time, we must ensure that no one is discriminated against based on their religious beliefs or lack thereof.

Thank you for your question. Our strategy in Iraq is focused on helping Iraq become a stable and peaceful democracy that respects the rights of its citizens and fulfills its commitments to the international community. Our troops are working with the Iraqi security forces to provide them with the training, equipment, and support necessary for them to take the lead in the fight against terrorism and to maintain security throughout the country.

We have been in close consultation with the Government of Iraq, and they understand the need for a responsible drawdown timeline that ensures that security is handed over to the capable Iraqi security forces, who are making significant progress. We are committed to supporting Iraq as they develop their security capacity and prepare for the full transition of security responsibilities.

Regarding the suggestion of pressure from the U.S. or any undue influence, this is not accurate. The discussions that have taken place reflect a partnership between our two nations. Ambassador Rice's visit, as well as other high-level visits, are aimed at strengthening our cooperation and ensuring that both nations are aligned in our shared goals for a stable and sovereign Iraq.

Thank you for also asking the question to Mr. Jafari. It would be appropriate for him to comment further on the situation and the engagement between our two governments. The Iraqi leadership has been a key partner in this process and they have a significant voice in the decisions regarding the future of their country.

Thank you for your question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address these important matters. President Musharraf has indeed made a strong call for dialogue and understanding, and I have repeatedly stated that it is a fundamental part of our strategy for fighting terrorism. Building bridges between the West and Islamic world is essential in this effort to find common ground and mutual respect.

It's true that over the years, I have used the term "Islamic fascists" to describe some of the extremist elements that we face. These are terrible people who commit acts of violence in the name of a faith that I respect and admire. We must remind ourselves and the world that the vast majority of Muslims reject the terrorists and their hateful ideology.

Regarding the Pope's remarks, I believe Pope Benedict has acknowledged the expressions in his speech about Islam were offensive to many people across the world, and we have to respect that. We have to work together to foster mutual respect, understanding, and dialogue. Misinterpretations and inflammatory commentary can create misunderstanding, and we need to ensure that leaders at all levels clearly condemn violence and extremism in the strongest terms.

To your question, I do believe leadership on promoting interfaith harmony can come from leaders in every area. As for our role in the United States, we must continue our efforts to support reform and modernization in the Islamic world, encourage open societies where the voice of moderates can be heard, and create economic opportunities that can lift millions out of poverty and despair. This is all part of the long-term solution to addressing extremism.

We also support interfaith dialogue through programs like the United States Institute of Peace and other efforts here at home and around the world to bring people together and to create forums for discussion.

Building bridges and supporting interfaith harmony requires a strong and sustained commitment from leaders across the globe, and I commit to working alongside President Musharraf and others towards this vital goal.

Thank you for your questions. As we work to promote peace in the Middle East and address the challenges in Iraq, it is indeed important to consider the interconnectedness of these issues. Two years ago, I expressed my commitment to working towards a vision of two states - Israel and Palestine - living side by side in peace and security. Since then, we have been engaged in various initiatives aimed at fostering dialogue and progress toward that goal.

The situation in the Palestinian territories and the broader region remains complex, and we have continued to encourage both parties to engage in meaningful negotiations. The efforts to achieve peace in the Middle East are ongoing, and we will continue to support the parties involved as they seek a sustainable solution.

Now, turning to the connection between these issues and the efforts in Iraq, it's undeniable that there is a link. Stability in the region is crucial for our overall goals in the Middle East and the broader War on Terror. A peaceful resolution to the Israel-Palestinian conflict could have a positive ripple effect, potentially influencing attitudes and dynamics across the Middle East.

Regarding Prime Minister Sharon's upcoming trip, he will be engaging in discussions with regional leaders, including those in Israel, to further these efforts. He will focus on how we can continue to build on the progress made and to address the ongoing challenges that obstruct a peaceful resolution. It is our hope that through these engagements, we can see a clear path towards a peaceful and prosperous Middle East.

I want to stress that achieving these goals is not a one-time effort, but a long-term commitment that requires the dedicated work of many parties, including the international community, the governments involved, and, most importantly, the people living with the daily consequences of these conflicts. We remain steadfast in our commitment to lasting peace in the Middle East.

Thank you for the question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address the concerns raised.

First, let me say that the situation in Iraq is complex and challenging, and it is understandable that people are concerned about the progress we are making. It's important to remember that building a stable and democratic Iraq cannot happen overnight. The strategy we put in place, with the surge, included clear goals and the expectation that Iraqi leaders would also take steps to bring stability to their country. Over time, we have seen significant progress on security and political reconciliation, although more work remains.

One of the key benchmarks we have watched closely is the progress in reducing violence in Iraq. With the surge, we've seen a substantial decrease in attacks and violence in Baghdad. The Iraqi Security Forces have demonstrated improved capabilities and are taking the lead in many areas across the country. There has been progress made in some areas, but indeed, some benchmarks have not yet been fully met. The Iraqi government continues to push forward with difficult decisions for national reconciliation, and the pace of progress can be uneven.

Regarding concerns about the sacrifice of our troops and their families, let me be clear: the safety of our military personnel is always our highest priority. The temporary uptick in troop numbers was a crucial shift in strategy that allowed our forces to create the conditions for Iraqis to take responsibility for their own security. The surge has provided us the opportunity to degrade the enemy's capabilities and for Iraqi security forces to gain invaluable experience through training and combat operations. These factors contribute to reducing the risk for our men and women in uniform in the long-term.

In addition, we must support our troops and their families, and we are working to provide our military personnel with the resources, benefits, and care they need and deserve. They have been extraordinary in their service to our country, and they must know their nation appreciates their sacrifice.

It's also important for the American people and Congress to stay the course with patience and resolve. The situation in Iraq is not a sprint; it's a marathon. We must continue to support the Iraqi people as they work towards a safe, free, and united country. We will continue to reassess the situation, but the evidence is that the surge has made a significant difference, and we are making tangible progress.

We will remain vigilant and will continue to work with our allies to bring about peace and stability. Our commitment to Iraq and to the men and women serving there will not waver.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this important matter with you and the global community.

First and foremost, it is absolutely true that progress has been made in our understanding of climate change and the need for practical solutions to tackle this global challenge. However, as you rightly pointed out, there is still much work to be done, and the international community must continue to come together to strengthen our efforts.

In the United States, we have implemented a wide range of policies and initiatives that are aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions while benefiting economic growth and consumer choice. For example, we have worked with the states and local partners to increase funding, improve technology, and develop new alternatives to gasoline in order to provide the American people with more transportation options and to reduce our dependence on foreign sources of oil.

The EPA's Clear Skies Initiative is another example of a major step forward in environmental protection. It makes a more than 70 percent cut in sulfur dioxide emissions, a 67 percent cut in nitrogen oxides, and a 73 percent cut in mercury emissions from power plants by 2018. Those reductions are equivalent to the total output of 244 million cars -- compared to 210 million cars on the road today.

It's also worth noting that the administration has done much to support alternative energy sources. We've set a goal of increasing renewable energy production fourfold by 2012. This will help create jobs, support domestic business, and reduce our emissions.

Regarding the approach to addressing emissions, I believe there is a place for both government-led and voluntary efforts. Our government has the ability to provide frameworks and incentives that lead to positive outcomes. At the same time, businesses and individuals must be part of the solution, embracing cleaner technologies and making environmentally-friendly choices.

Europe's focus on imposing national limits and targets has also played an important role in advocating for climate action globally, and I appreciate their leadership in some areas. However, I strongly believe that a balanced approach that combines government standards with consumer choice and innovation is the most effective way to reduce harmful emissions while preserving economic growth and prosperity.

While it may indeed feel as if we are facing an eleventh-hour challenge, it is crucial that we do not lose sight of the progress we have made. Continued dialogue, collaboration, and consensus-building between nations will be key to achieving our shared goal of combating climate change effectively. Thank you for your question, and I look forward to further collaboration with the European Union and all of our international partners in the years ahead.

Thank you for your question. The actions of individuals who leak information improperly are a grave matter that can undermine confidence in government and threaten national security. These actions are taken very seriously, and I exercised my clemency powers with the utmost seriousness during the consideration of the commutation of Ms. Lewis' sentence as well.

With respect to the behavior of my senior advisers, I believe that it's important for all of us to reflect on our actions and ensure that they are consistent with the high standards of integrity expected of those in positions of leadership and responsibility. While I cannot delve into specific conversations or private matters, I can say that throughout my time in office, I emphasized the importance of maintaining the trust of the American people and operating with the highest ethical standards.

In this instance, I expect my staff to uphold and model the principles of honesty, confidentiality, and responsible use of authority. Those principles are the bedrock on which we must maintain public trust and confidence in the government. If any individuals did not meet these standards during their time of service, they have personally and publicly acknowledged their mistakes, as Mr. Libby did through his plea and sentencing. As for any personal communications with my senior advisers on this issue, privacy and respect are important considerations, and I will not comment further on internal discussions.

Thank you for your question.

Firstly, the signing of the historic energy bill was a landmark moment for our nation. This bill will reduce our nation’s demand for oil and help to protect our environment by increasing our production of clean, renewable energy. It creates a clear national renewable fuels standard, which is an important element in reducing our dependence on foreign oil and combating greenhouse gases. It also includes provisions related to energy efficiency, alternative fuels, and other initiatives to enhance our environment.

Regarding greenhouse gas emissions, my commitment to addressing them is坚定不移的。我相信我们需要负责任地解决这个问题，但是我也认为，我们必须这么做时不能牺牲我们的经济增长或置我们的工人于不利地位。我们必须寻求一个平衡的方法。我认为国家行动是必要的，这就是为什么我们在2002年推出了Clear Skies Initiative，并且在最近签署的能源法案中采取了措施。

有关加州和其他州实施自己的排放计划的问题，确保全国汽车排放标准的一致性对我们联邦政府来说非常重要。我们的方针是维护联邦在国家环境规则制定中的领导作用，同时鼓励国内外创新和技术进步，这有助于减少温室气体排放。我们有信心支持创新和技术，这两者可以由国家和地方层面合作推动。

至于与戈尔先生关于气候变化的对话，按照惯例，总统与总统候选人之间的私人讨论细节通常不会披露。但是，我想说的是，我们政府致力于解决气候变化问题，也与全球其他国家密切合作，寻求国际共识。我要强调我们采取行动的方式应当维持经济的正常运转，而不是妨碍经济增长的关键动力。

总的来说，我们坚决致力于追求平衡的方法来解决环境问题，同时确保强大的经济增长并保护美国的工作岗位。

Well, thank you for your question. I appreciate you acknowledging the long-standing relationship between the United States and Benin. The visit here certainly represents a significant moment in that history and is a reflection of the strengthening ties between our two countries. As President, I believe it's important to lead by example and to emphasize the collaborative efforts that we share. Diplomacy is about building relationships and trust, and my visit here today is a sign of my commitment to the friendship between the US and Benin. It's about more than just a visit; it's about partnership, shared values, and working together to solve global challenges. So, while my visit might be seen as a milestone, my hope is that it contributes to a sustained and growing partnership, rather than being a one-off event.

Thank you for your question, and it's important to acknowledge the complexity of the issues we face in Africa. As we engage with the continent, our efforts are guided by a few key principles. We aim to support countries that are making progress, like Benin, which has made impressive strides in democracy and economic reform. We want to build on successes, share best practices, and encourage other nations to follow suit.

At the same time, it's crucial for us to also address the challenges that arise in places like Kenya. The crisis there is troubling, and it's essential for the international community, along with regional partners, to support efforts that promote peace, stability, and democratic governance.

In terms of deciding how best to spend my time here, we consider multiple factors. First and foremost, we focus on the areas where U.S. engagement can make the greatest impact. This means working closely with leaders who are committed to reforms and collaborating with regional organizations to constructively support those in need of assistance.

We also engage bilaterally, multilaterally, and through regional initiatives to address various issues, including security, democracy, and economic growth. It is a delicate balance, but one that we must manage with diligence and foresight.

Our presence in Africa is about more than just visiting; it’s about making a commitment to long-term strategic partnerships that help build a safer, more prosperous, and more democratic region. We must be mindful of both the successes and challenges and tailor our support accordingly to foster a positive environment for growth and stability for all.

Thank you for your question from Mexico. Let me address the aspect concerning our hemisphere and our views on energy cooperation, and I'll be happy to let my colleague, Prime Minister Jean Chrétien, also address his perspective.

Energy security is a crucial issue for our nations, and we are all part of the same interconnected global market. In a hemispheric context, cooperation is key to ensuring stability and development for all countries, regardless of whether they are producers or consumers.

The United States, as a major consumer and market participant, recognizes the importance of collaborating with Mexico, Canada, and other countries that are both producers and consumers. We have been working in many ways to ensure energy diversification, market competition, and environmental sustainability. Initiatives such as the North American Energy Working Group and the National Energy Policy emphasize issues like infrastructure development, energy efficiency, and the promotion of alternative and renewable energy sources.

To achieve a hemispheric-wide energy plan, equitable cooperation requires mutual respect and recognition of the different roles and capacities that each country has. There must be a commitment to dialogue and collaboration on issues of regulation, investment, and technology sharing. Transparency and stability in regulations and trade policies are also essential to diminish risks and enhance investor confidence.

Both the United States and Canada have commitments to free and fair trade, and we are eager to extend cooperative efforts to our neighbors in the Western Hemisphere. I would encourage Mexico and other countries to bring their views forward as we work together to address the many challenges and opportunities associated with energy.

Now, I would like to give the floor to Prime Minister Jean Chrétien, so he may share his thoughts on this important topic as well.

Thank you for your questions. Regarding the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, as President, my duty is to uphold the law and protect the innocent. This bill specifically addresses a procedure called partial-birth abortion, which is an incredibly brutal and inhumane practice. Congress has determined that this procedure cannot go unchallenged, and I can say without hesitation that I support this legislation. Abortion is a difficult and divisive issue in our country, but moral clarity must sometimes lead the way, and this ban is consistent with the values of the pro-life movement.

As for the broader question about all abortions, I believe that every life is precious and that every child is a blessing. My view is that we must continue to protect life at every stage of development. Over the past few years, we've seen increasing support for the best interests of unborn children. Countries around the world are recognizing the dignity of every human being and are taking steps to protect the rights of those who can’t protect themselves. This does not discount the complexity of the issue; rather, it reflects a principled position to uphold the sanctity of life.

Now, with regards to my brother's involvement in the Florida end-of-life care situation, that was a private decision made at the family's request, not a public policy matter for me as President. My brother Jeb Bush acted as a family member would in a private matter, supporting a loved one in a difficult personal decision.

These are deeply personal and challenging issues, but my commitment as leader of this nation is to uphold the rule of law and to advocate for every life, born and unborn.

Good morning. Let me address the first part of your question regarding negotiation. Saddam Hussein's actions and words speak for themselves. He's a vicious, murderous dictator who has consistently violated the conduct of civilized nations and brought suffering and death to the Iraqi people. The fact that he may now be open to negotiation doesn't change the need to confront him and remove the threat that he poses. We took the right steps by removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq, and our work there is not yet complete.

Addressing my greeting to Saddam Hussein: The United States of America has made clear that Saddam Hussein is a man who attacked his neighbors, used weapons of mass destruction against his own people, and harbored and supported terrorists. As such, he is a man who has no place in a free Iraq, and I hope the Iraqi people will soon be able to live in a fully free society.

Thank you for your question. I understand these statements have been the topic of significant debate, and it's essential that we address any confusion that may have been caused.

First, let me emphasis that the assessment of our efforts in Iraq is a vital matter, and it's crucial to ensure clear communication on all fronts. The Vice President's comments about the insurgency being in its last throes were made in the context of our overarching strategy and the progress we have seen. It is not to downplay the ongoing challenges and struggles that we face every day but rather to affirm the long-term progress being made.

The statements made by our commanders on the ground provide a detailed, periodic perspective of the ongoing security situation in Iraq. General Abizaid's comment about no significant change over the last six months is to communicate the hard work and persistence required to address the day-to-day reality of the conflict, which has been intense and persistent.

It is important to note that these statements are not in conflict; rather, they reflect different aspects of the overall picture. The Vice President's assessment speaks to the larger strategic progress and confidence in the ultimate outcome of our efforts, ensuring that Iraq can sustain its progress and enjoy a stable and free government. Meanwhile, the statements from our military commanders provide a more granular look at the current security environment on the ground.

Our commanders and I remain deeply in contact to ensure that we are making the best decisions for the security and stability of Iraq. It is critical to maintain a focus on the long-term goals while continuing to address the short-term challenges that inevitably come with any significant transitional period, especially in a place like Iraq, experiencing the transition from dictatorship to democracy.

Furthermore, I continue to consult regularly with my national security team, military leaders, and our Iraqi partners, and I will continue to rely on the best information and advice available to ensure we succeed in our mission to help the Iraqi people enjoy peace, security, and freedom.

Thank you for your understanding, and please continue to support the brave men and women who are working hard for a free and democratic Iraq.

Thank you for your question. In my presidency, there were always a variety of steps taken to address energy issues, including encouraging oil production, promoting conservation, and pushing for increased investment in alternative fuels. During my first term, my administration did address energy needs through policies such as tax incentives for renewable energy and automobile technology, as well as efforts to reduce the environmental impact of traditional fuels.

Regarding CAFE standards, or Corporate Average Fuel Economy, it's important to note that the administration worked with Congress and the EPA to increase these standards. The policy decision on how to balance fuel economy with vehicle safety and consumer choice is a complex one that takes into consideration various economic and social factors. Though some critics felt CAFE standards could have been pushed higher, it was my belief that we needed to strike a balance that also protected the safety and choice of American drivers.

I understand the concerns about gas prices and the economic impact they can have on families and businesses. That's why we also supported measures to increase domestic oil production, as well as initiatives to further research and develop alternative fuels and technologies.

We pushed alternative fuels and technology, investing in hydrogen and ethanol, among others. Despite these efforts, as well as a multi-billion dollar research and development effort to create new and cleaner sources of energy, the global market dynamics and supply led to higher crude oil prices, which in turn raised gasoline prices.

So, while we can always look back and question whether more could have been done, I believe we took significant steps to try and address the energy needs of the country. The challenge we face with energy is multifaceted, and continuing to address it with comprehensive and balanced policies is vital.

Thank you for your question. When I visit New York next week, it will be an opportunity for me to continue to emphasize the importance of addressing the threat posed by Iran's ambitions in the region and its support for terrorism. It's true that the international community has various perspectives on the war in Iraq, but our focus on Iran is not solely for that reason; it is about the broader threat that Iran poses to global security, particularly its nuclear ambitions, its sponsorship of terrorism, and its attempts to destabilize other governments in the Middle East.

Regarding the visit of the Iraqi Prime Minister to Iran, I believe the support of the Iraqi government is crucial in dealing with Iran, and we have been working closely with them to address these issues. It's important to note that the Iranian government's support for militants and its interference in Iraq's internal affairs are significant concerns that cannot be ignored. Our goal remains to work with our international partners to ensure that Iran does not develop a nuclear weapon, which could pose an even greater danger to regional and global stability.

We continue to seek international support and the broad strategy includes diplomacy, economic sanctions, and ensuring that all options, including military action, are available to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. The stakes are too high for the world to ignore the challenge posed by Iran, and we must continue to work together to address it.

Thank you for the question. Let me be clear: the consequences of failure in Iraq are real, and the cost is measured not only in dollars and in the sacrifices of our brave men and women in uniform but also in the loss of life and in the damage to our nation's standing in the world.

The strategy in Iraq, which includes the surge of additional American troops, the training of Iraqi security forces, and the partnerships we've built with leaders on the ground, is working to achieve our goal of a stable, secure, and unified Iraq. We are making progress in helping Iraq establish a democracy that can stand on its own.

It's important to understand that the complexities of Iraq went beyond just the military mission. The fall of Saddam Hussein's regime was followed by a period of uncertainty and violence due to long-simmering sectarian tensions. The insurgency and Al Qaida's opportunistic presence in Iraq required a multifaceted approach that included not only military engagement but also building up Iraqi security institutions, transitioning political power to Iraqis, and pressing the Iraqi government for reconciliation and political reform.

I know that many have their doubts about the Iraq war and our strategy. But the decision to defend America and to remove Saddam Hussein was not made lightly. Saddam Hussein posed a danger to his neighbors and to the United States. By removing him we have lessened risks to our country and set Iraq on a path to democracy.

I understand that the American people want to know how the surge and our broader strategy will lead to stability and freedom for Iraqis and for us as well. This won't be easy – it never is when attempting to position a young democracy after a period of tyranny. But we are committed to this course because we believe that a free and democratic Iraq will be a source of hope, stability, and progress in a tumultuous region.

I remain convinced of the rightness of our cause, and I believe that the steps we are taking now will lead not to merely a temporary respite, but to a lasting change for Iraq and for the world.

Thank you for your question. Tony Blair is a good friend and I respect his service and commitment to advancing our security and the freedoms of the world. We share a common view that countries must stand together to prevent threats before they materialize. We took action in Iraq and Afghanistan to confront the greatest threats of our time and to keep the peace.

As for reflecting on our decisions, leaders must be willing to make tough choices that are in the best interest of their country and the international community. We entered Iraq to disarm Saddam Hussein of weapons of mass destruction, to free the Iraqi people, and to prevent the spread of terrorism. This was a decision made with careful deliberation and the support of the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1441. While the situation was more complex than anticipated, America has always acted on the side of freedom and we believe in the power of democracy to overcome tyranny.

In terms of Afghanistan, it remains a significant front in the war against terror and we have been deeply committed to the mission there, focusing on the defeat of al-Qaeda and the establishment of a stable democratic government. We have worked closely with our allies, including the United Kingdom, to achieve these objectives.

Regarding the Prime Minister's question on the Lisbon Treaty, I would direct you to ask the Prime Minister or the appropriate officials from his government for a formal response. However, the challenges and the future directions for Europe are certainly topics for internal discussion among the European Union members. It's important for the EU to continue to work together on common goals and address the aspirations of its citizens.

I would encourage further dialogue on these matters and remain focused on our common commitment to promoting freedom and democracy around the world.

First of all, let me state clearly that this issue is an important one for the American people and for the world. The decision to withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol was based on an assessment of the best interests of the United States of America, taking into account a variety of factors. As with any policy decision, it is informed by scientific data as well as broader economic and geopolitical considerations. 

Regarding the specific mention of emotion versus science, my administration is committed to a balanced approach that takes science seriously, but it is also imperative to consider practical outcomes and the well-being of our citizens and economy. The decision to withdraw from Kyoto was preceded by a thorough review, and we stand by it as a decision that reflects America's desire to address environmental challenges in a way that supports the prosperity of its people.

As for whether European views are more emotional or whether there's posturing going on, it would be unfair to characterize the positions of other nations in such a simplistic manner. Each country has its own unique circumstances and priorities when it comes to climate change policies. We respect the diverse approaches taken by various countries around the world, but we also believe that our nation's interests must be prioritized in any global environmental agreement.

My administration's goal is to find a balanced and effective way forward, one that promotes environmental stewardship while ensuring that the U.S. can continue to grow and lead economically. That's the path we're on, and we appreciate the continued dialogue on this complex and important issue.

Good afternoon. I appreciate the questions and the concerns about the situation we face. Regarding the anthrax attacks, we are conducting extensive investigations to determine the origins of these acts. While we are looking at all potential sources, including foreign interests, it is important to note that we must gather concrete evidence before drawing any definitive conclusions.

Concerning the presence of special forces in Afghanistan, I can confirm that our military has taken key actions on the ground. However, this is part of a broader operation that includes air strikes and support to the Afghan resistance. I want to be clear that we are focused on the Al Qaeda network, and we are working with the Afghan opposition to degrade the Taliban's ability to provide sanctuary for terrorists.

As for the duration of military action, our focus is on the mission at hand, which is to bring the perpetrators of the 9/11 attacks to justice and eliminate the threat of terrorism. I understand that this is a serious endeavor that could take time and require perseverance. We will continue to take necessary actions to protect our nation and defend our citizens.

With respect to your host's question, we appreciate the support of all Americans and our allies in this critical effort. We are confident in the resolve and capabilities of our military and intelligence communities to see this through to the end. We will keep the American people informed of our progress and the measures we are taking to ensure the security of our nation.

First off, it's important to address your concerns about the visa approvals for Atta and Al-Shehhi carefully and seriously. When I heard about the disconcerting information regarding their visa approvals, my initial reaction was one of concern and determination to understand fully what had occurred and how we could strengthen our processes to prevent this from happening again.

The American people rightly demand unwavering vigilance from our government agencies, particularly when it comes to national security. As such, the credibility of the INS, now operating under a restructured framework through the Department of Homeland Security, is of utmost importance.

To restore and maintain public trust, several immediate actions are being taken and are imperative for the future:

1. Immediate Review: We are conducting a thorough review of visa issuance procedures, with a particular focus on ensuring that applications are thoroughly vetted against known terrorist lists and other intelligence community information.

2. Strengthening Intelligence Sharing: We are enhancing the sharing of intelligence between agencies so that the most up-to-date information is available to those responsible for making critical decisions on who is allowed to enter the United States.

3. Safeguarding the Entry System: We are improving our computer systems and databases to ensure that visa applications are processed accurately and securely.

4. Law Enforcement Coordination: Coordination between law enforcement and immigration officials is being heightened to prevent misuse of visas and to identify and apprehend individuals who seek to harm our nation.

5. Long-term Policy Reforms: Over the long term, we will continue to implement comprehensive reforms aimed at creating an immigration system that is both secure and humane, addressing the root causes of illegal immigration and strengthening our borders.

In the aftermath of tragedies like the September 11th attacks, it's crucial that we as a nation learn from past mistakes and work tirelessly to prevent them from recurring. We must balance our need for security with the rightful freedom and liberty of our people, both at home and abroad. This administration is committed to making these necessary changes to protect our country from future threats.

Thank you for your question. This matter was long ago resolved, and the Securities and Exchange Commission confirmed that Harken made its required filings in accordance with the law. During my time on the board of Harken Energy Corporation, I was focused on serving the best interests of the company and shareholders. The divestitures were part of the company's effort to refocus on its core operations.

In terms of the restatements required by the SEC, it's important to note that the restating of financials can occur for a variety of reasons and does not necessarily imply misconduct or wrongdoing. It reflects a process to ensure that financial statements accurately reflect a company's financial situation and position.

The transaction in question did not present any ethics or legislative issue for me. It was consistent with what I believed was the right direction for the company at the time, and I had the approval of the audit committee and the board of directors to proceed with the transaction as I saw fit.

As for whether this affects my credibility on corporate responsibility, I believe in holding leaders and corporations accountable for their actions and ensuring that they operate with transparency and honesty. The experience at Harken was an important one for me and contributed to my understanding of business operations and the importance of corporate governance.

Throughout my career, from the early days in the oil industry through the business turnaround that I was a part of, to my eventual position as President and then President of the United States, I have worked to set a standard of accountability and have encouraged those around me to uphold the highest ethical standards in all our endeavors.

Thank you for your question, and it's a good one to place the upcoming speech in historical context. I deeply appreciate your reference to President Theodore Roosevelt, who was a leader of determination and clear vision regarding the responsibilities of business and government.

While the challenges we face today are certainly different from those of the early 20th century, it's true that we continue to grapple with the critical need for balance between ensuring the vibrancy of our economy and maintaining a level of oversight to protect the American people. The tone of our times may not call for the same aggressive rhetoric that was needed a century ago, but it does require a steadfast commitment to transparency, accountability, and ethical standards in the corporate world.

My administration supports policies that promote fair play, like the Corporate Responsibility Act, which is aimed at enhancing corporate disclosure and reducing the potential for abuse and deception. It's a comprehensive approach that looks to strengthen investor confidence and protect the public from fraudulent practices. This legislation is a testament to our commitment to address the serious matters of corporate governance and transparency.

The work of reforming corporate governance isn't just the responsibility of government; it must involve the boards of directors, corporate executives, and shareholders who must each play a part in ensuring that their organizations operate with integrity. Together, we can and will create an environment where the benefits of a free market system are realized without compromising the interests of consumers, shareholders, or the public at large.

I look forward to discussing these issues further at the State of the Union address and working collaboratively to secure a fair and prosperous economic future for all Americans.

Thank you for that question. As President, my priority is to ensure that I work in a way that reflects the will of the American people and unites our great country. While I respect the enthusiasm and dedication of my conservative supporters, I also believe in a measured and collaborative approach to governance.

Regarding the suggestions you've outlined, I'll address each point:

1. Social Security: While the issue of Social Security reform is crucial for securing the future of those who depend on it, I would advocate for a thoughtful and bipartisan approach that carefully considers all options, including private accounts. I want to ensure that any changes made will preserve the promise of Social Security for today's seniors and tomorrow's workers.

2. Abortion: I support the right to life and have always been a strong proponent of that belief. However, I recognize that the issue of abortion is deeply personal and complex, and that many Americans hold differing views. In proposing new restrictions, I would seek to address the issue in a way that reflects the values of those who support life while also engaging in constructive dialogue with those who may not share the same views.

3. Judicial nominations: I understand the importance of filling vacancies on the federal bench with judges who not only follow the law but also interpret it faithfully. I will continue to nominate judges who I believe are qualified and will serve the American people faithfully. I am committed to working with the Senate to ensure that the confirmation process is both fair and thorough.

4. Tax Code: I agree that our tax code is in need of an overhaul. I will work with Congress to achieve comprehensive reform that boosts our economy, encourages job creation, and provides tax relief for the hardworking American families. Any plan should be fair, simple, and promote economic growth for all Americans.

In summary, while I appreciate the sense of urgency and the support of my conservative base, I will prioritize a deliberate, bipartisan approach to these issues to help achieve lasting and positive change for our country. Thank you for your understanding and support.

The United States supports a two-state solution where Israel and a viable, peaceful Palestine live side by side in peace and security. We believe that bilateral talks between Israeli and Palestinian leaders are critical, as they are the best forum to reach a lasting agreement. The United States has raised concerns about settlement construction and related activities, and we've made it clear that we believe such actions make it more difficult to reach common ground on an eventual final-status agreement.

While we understand and respect the concerns you raise, we believe that all parties should work towards a comprehensive peace agreement and that all sides need to take steps in good faith to move forward. The United States will continue to work with both sides to achieve a lasting peace and will continue to encourage all parties to take actions that can help resume and advance the peace process.

Thank you for your question. Let me start by saying that the economy is a key priority for our administration, and we've made significant progress during my time as President. Over the course of the last few years, we've seen steady job creation with over 3.5 million new jobs created since August 2003, the continuation of a growing economy, and most recently, decreases in inflation and mortgage rates. This progress demonstrates that the economic stimulus package we passed is working.

Regarding the long-term strategy to ensure sustained economic growth, the structural reforms we've initiated, such as healthcare policy improvements and education reform, as well as further efforts to reduce the tax burden on all Americans, including economic incentives for small businesses and incentives for energy exploration, are integral to our plans.

As for avoiding the historical precedent you mentioned about President George H.W. Bush, it's important to note that every situation is unique, and economic conditions change from year to year. Our Administration is focused on continuing responsible fiscal management and ensuring that the steps we take now will have a lasting positive impact on the economy into the future.

We also need to recognize that economic conditions are influenced by an array of factors, some of which are beyond the immediate control of government policy. What we can control is our commitment to sound economic policies that will provide a stable and favorable environment for businesses to thrive and for individuals to find jobs and build lives for themselves and their families.

It's crucial that the American people understand that while the economy can be volatile in the short term, our consistent focus on economic growth, job creation, and fiscal responsibility is what will benefit the long-term health of our economy and ensure the prosperity of future generations.

Well, first of all, I believe the best way to secure the peace is to encourage democracy. Democracies do not war with each other; they respect each other's sovereignty and they respect each other's independence. And so, I strongly believe that if we can encourage democracy, encourage free institutions -- independent media, independent judiciary, political parties -- that the people will be able to govern themselves. They will be able to say what they believe and be free.

Now, to directly address your point about a peaceful dictator: Peace through process is the answer. If we believe an individual or a group is going to be peaceful -- that's a good start. And we will work very hard to provide incentives for peace. We will work with international organizations, with NGOs, with non-governmental groups. And through the trade process, we'll encourage peace through trade.

But my belief is that the future of the Middle East and the world is one in which people are free to make their own decisions and are free to say what they wish to say. I want a world where freedom flourishes and that's what I'm going to work for.

Regarding Iraq specifically, the determination of a future leader of Iraq would depend on how they respect the will of the Iraqi people and whether they uphold the universal rights that we believe are foundational to a peaceful and constructive society. But ultimately, the Iraqi people must decide their own future and who leads them.

Mr. President,

The aftermath of September 11th was a moment of shared national grief and solidarity, not just between the United States and Canada but among nations around the world. The outpouring of support we received from all our friends, including Canada, was incredibly moving, and I want to thank you for it again on behalf of the American people.

It's important to recognize that our bilateral relationship with Canada is strong and remains a priority for the United States. Both our nations are bound by deep ties of history, culture, and mutual economic interests. We have worked closely on issues ranging from security to the economy, and Canada has been a consistent partner in our efforts to enhance homeland security and counter terrorism in the aftermath of the attacks.

However, it's also important to acknowledge that the world has changed since September 11th. The challenges, both new and old, that our nations face today may sometimes bring to surface underlying concerns about our respective roles and approaches. It's true that differing views on policies as varied as climate change, the war on terrorism, or trade policies can influence public opinion.

The American people and the Canadian people have a lot in common, and we share a common future. Differences in perspective should not be seen as a drift apart, but rather an opportunity for dialogue and understanding based on friendship and mutual respect. Diplomacy is about listening and taking the time to understand the other's point of view.

As for our responsibility, both the United States and Canada have a responsibility to ensure that we continue to engage in open and constructive dialogue, to work together in the global arena, and to reaffirm our commitment to shared values and common goals.

I hope we can continue to build on the strong relationship between our countries, and I welcome ongoing communication between our peoples to address any concerns and to ensure we continue to be good neighbors and strong allies.

Thank you, and I'd now like to ask the Prime Minister to provide his response to this important question.

Thank you, Nick. Let me address the issues of African poverty and climate change.

First, the "Make Poverty History" campaign is an important initiative that brings attention to the challenges people face around the world. I support any effort to eliminate poverty and improve lives in developing countries. My administration has worked hard to help Africa, including providing debt relief, promoting trade, and improving agriculture. I believe that through dedicated effort and partnerships among governments, international organizations, and the private sector, we can make significant progress in the fight against poverty.

I do believe that this is a time of great potential to achieve real change. My administration has doubled funding for HIV/AIDS programs and committed to initiatives such as malaria prevention and anti-malaria bed nets. We have also supported programs by empowering local communities and leaders to fight poverty effectively. Our greatest ally in this fight is the spirit of generosity that the American people have always shown toward those in need.

As for climate change, the U.S. has taken significant steps to address environmental issues. I support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to encourage clean energy technology. The U.S. is the world's largest donor of development assistance for global environmental purposes. The Bush Administration developed an Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate, which strategically targets key economic sectors for major greenhouse gas reductions. Further collaboration and innovative approaches to this complex issue are needed globally, and the U.S. has a role to play in leading these efforts and providing solutions that balance economic growth with environmental stewardship. We also want to ensure that any actions taken respond to the science and address the complexities of the issue while promoting economic growth and prosperity for all nations.

Firstly, I want to express my condolences to the families of the 17 police officers who tragically lost their lives in the insurgent attack in Baghdad. This is a stark reminder of the ongoing difficulty and sacrifice involved in our mission to bring stability and security to Iraq.

Regarding the woman from Cleveland whom you mentioned, I understand that when such horrific attacks happen, people become frustrated and disheartened. It is natural and important for Americans to question the progress and direction of the war effort. However, I also maintain that our goals in Iraq are essential to the security and future well-being of our country. We are dealing with an adversary who intends to harm the American people and our position in the world.

What I would say to that woman -- and what I would say to all Americans -- is that the actions we are taking in Iraq are for a just and peaceful future. The removal of Saddam Hussein was a necessary step for the safety of not only Iraqis but also for Americans. The continuation of our efforts is not an endeavor to win a popularity contest, but rather to ensure that the sacrifices made by our troops, the wounded, and the families of the fallen have meaning. We are working towards a goal where Iraq can stand on its own, a goal that may be lengthy but necessary to maintain a safer and freer world for our children and grandchildren. We will stay determined and focused on that objective.

To address the question about the violations of human rights and the steps taken to ensure accountability, I can say that the American government is deeply committed to human rights and upholding the rule of law. In the meetings with Prime Minister Maliki, we discussed the need for robust oversight, training, and discipline to prevent such violations from occurring.

For the United States military and its civilian agencies, we have taken significant steps to investigate, prosecute, and correct any abuses that have taken place. The Department of Defense has assigned inspectors general to investigate allegations of abuse, and we have made efforts to increase awareness and training to ensure that our troops understand and adhere to the laws of war and international human rights standards. Any U.S. military personnel directly involved in the violations have been subject to court-martial and prosecution when sufficient evidence is available.

For the Prime Minister:

You as a Prime Minister of Iraq face similar challenges and have a critical role in ensuring the rule of law and upholding human rights within your country. We have been working closely with your government to improve the capacity of Iraqi security forces, providing training and mentorship to build a responsible and accountable defense and interior ministry structure that respects human rights. It is important for the Iraqi government, under your leadership, to make it clear that such violations will not be tolerated and that every effort must be taken to ensure that justice is served for victims and that those responsible are held accountable. The progress in human rights and civil rights can help solidify Iraq's future as a democratic nation. 

By continuing to address the issues in a transparent and punitive way, both the United States and the Iraqi government can send a strong message to those who violate human rights that such actions will not be accepted and will lead to severe consequences. Together, we can work to prevent these violations, and foster a climate of respect and equality for all Iraqis.

Thank you for the question and for the opportunity to clarify our intentions regarding comprehensive immigration reform. We take the issue very seriously and believe that it's crucial to address it in a manner that respects the rule of law and the human dignity of all people.

Congressional opposition can be a significant hurdle when addressing a complex issue like immigration reform. It's essential to remember that both sides of the aisle have varying viewpoints on immigration policy. Some concerns include border security, the path to citizenship, the protection of American jobs, and how to balance the economy's need for labor with concerns about public safety.

In order to tackle the challenge of overcoming this opposition, my administration has been engaging with bipartisan groups of Senators, advocating for comprehensive reform that includes the following key components:

1. **Secure Borders:** Our first priority is to secure our borders and restore the integrity of our immigration laws. This means modernizing technology to detect threats, increasing the number of law enforcement personnel along the borders, and ensuring that we have the resources needed to manage our borders effectively.

2. **Legal Immigration System:** We want to create a legal immigration system that helps restore public confidence that our borders are enforceable and respects the rule of law. This includes enhancing the visa process, streamlining legal channels for family reunification, and businesses to hire foreign employees legally.

3. **Enforcement:** We aim to improve border patrol and interior enforcement, which includes ensuring the timely and effective removal of those who enter our country illegally and strengthening the enforcement of laws that hold employers accountable for not hiring unauthorized workers.

4. **Holding Line on Driver's Licenses and Benefits:** We want to make sure that any new program for existing unauthorized immigrants does not cause an unfair advantage over those who are in line for lawful residency and citizenship, and it must not reward illegal behavior.

5. **Future Flow of Workers:** Recognizing that our economy needs a consistent flow of workers, we're looking at creating a temporary worker program that meets demand while protecting workers’ rights. This program would allow those with temporary permits to change employers and move between industries to ensure they aren't trapped in abusive situations.

6. **Comprehensive Immigration Reform:** We're advocating for a comprehensive bill that will provide clear and achievable paths to citizenship for those who wish to become Americans, while also emphasizing accountability.

Our commitment with Senators and congressional leaders, both Republican and Democrat, is ongoing. We know that some may have concerns about specific aspects of the proposals, so we are working to address these concerns through dialogue and compromise. Our goal is to pass a bill that reflects the principles of respect for the rule of law and respect for the human dignity of immigrants, and gets through this important chamber.

We understand the need for a comprehensive approach and are committed to working diligently towards a solution that enjoys widespread support and effectively addresses the challenges faced by our nation in the realm of immigration.

Thank you for the question. First and foremost, accountability is indeed a critical value that we embrace in both the public and private sectors. When it comes to my Administration and decision-making in Iraq, I've applied accountability measures:

In Iraq, I've held leaders accountable for progress in establishing a democratic and stable government. We've seen significant achievements in that country, and while there have been setbacks and challenges, we've worked to secure the country and establish democratic institutions. The Iraqi interim government and later the elected government have faced requirements and benchmarks for implementation of policies, reform, and security enhancements, which we work with the respective administrations to establish along international lines and benchmarks.

As for the situation with Lewis Libby, the decision we made regarding his sentence was grounded in thorough review and a nuanced assessment of all the facts, including his unique role and circumstances in the context of the case. The Justice Department reviewed the case extensively, and the President, in line with judicial protocols and his discretionary authority regarding clemency, took this decision after full consideration of all recommendations and opinions. It was ultimately an exercise in justice and mercy, aiming to restore balance and fairness in the context presented.

Regrettably, Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld and Director of Central Intelligence George Tenet stepped down as we reflected on the challenges of Iraq and the broader war on terror. These were significant turnover decisions that I made based on my commitment to accountability and leadership stability amid the evolving complexities of our national security interests.

We also have regular reviews regarding performance and policy outcomes in various areas of governance and the economy, ensuring that we maintain high standards and hold ourselves to account for the results of the decisions we make. The American people should be assured that we remain vigilant in upholding accountability within the Administration.

In summary, accountability is a value that I take very seriously throughout my presidency, and we have implemented accountability measures across multiple areas, from the evolving landscape of Iraq to our federal leadership roles and legal matters.

First of all, I wanted to make it clear that I appreciate the sentiment. I'm here serving as your president, but the President-elect Barack Obama will be taking office soon, so let me address your question as a transition from this administration to the incoming one as best I can.

On the issue of Afghanistan and the broader strategy in the region, I believe it's crucial that we have a unified stance on terrorism. I supported an increase in troops to Afghanistan to combat the Taliban and al-Qaeda, and under my administration, we shifted a significant portion of attention and resources to the Afghan conflict. Once President-elect Obama takes office, it will be on him to evaluate the situation and determine the best course forward, which likely will include input from generals and military advisors as well as other allies and partners.

As for support from my Republican Party, I hope that members will come together and support efforts that safeguard America's interests. We have faced significant challenges in our ongoing operations against terrorist organizations, and it is in everyone's best interest to ensure that the new policies can build upon the work that has already been done.

Regarding Pakistan, this is undoubtedly a complex issue. The government of Pakistan faces a significant and pressing threat from elements within its borders that support international terrorism. The cooperation with Pakistan has been important, and I have made it clear in numerous statements and through diplomatic channels the necessity of addressing the issue of terrorism originating from the ungoverned territories.

President-elect Obama will have to carefully craft a message and a plan of engagement that achieves our goals. This may involve a mix of diplomatic measures, support for democratic reforms, encouraging economic development, and if absolutely necessary, targeted military actions that respect the sovereignty and dignity of the people and the government of Pakistan.

Ultimately, the aim would be to support Pakistan in becoming a responsible actor within the international community and a partner in the fight against terrorism. The incoming administration will have to continue the efforts at promoting security while also preserving relationships with Islamabad.

I appreciate the question, and I'll try to address it in parts.

First, on my own personal encounter with President Castro here: As the President of the United States, my interactions with world leaders reflect the broader interests of the United States and our approach to international diplomacy. We respect the sovereignty of other nations and their leadership, but it's also true that there are conversations that my administration may have had during discussions or private meetings that might not have been made public.

Fidel Castro did not attend the full summit, and it's been suggested that certain matters, including human rights, might have been points of discussion during our interactions. The United States has a long-standing position of advocating for human rights and the rule of law globally, which ties into our interactions with all international partners.

Regarding the relationship between Mexico and Cuba, I will let President Fox address that directly as he is best suited to speak on the bilateral relations between Mexico and Cuba. Our administration has diplomatic relations with Cuba as well, and we've engaged in various forums and discussions.

While our administrations have different stances on how to approach Cuba, we respect our alliance with Mexico and value their perspective in regional and global affairs. President Fox and I have a strong working relationship built on mutual respect and shared interests, which we have both emphasized throughout.

In summation, our engagements during the summit reflected a commitment to free trade and responsible governance, but recognized the spectrum of regional political and economic complexities.

Thank you for your question. The safety and security of Iraqi citizens and our coalition forces is our primary concern as we continue to support the Iraqi government in securing a free and fair election process. It's important to note that this election is a crucial step toward a more stable and democratic Iraq.

Regarding troop levels, our military advisors and leaders are constantly assessing the situation on the ground in Iraq. They take into account the needs for securing various critical points, ensuring the safety of polling places, and providing training to Iraqi security forces. As you mentioned, the Iraqi Security Forces are playing an increasingly important role, but their capacity and capabilities are still a work in progress.

Pentagon officials are indeed working on plans to ensure that there are sufficient forces available to provide security during the elections. This includes extending tours of duty for some troops and possibly deploying additional forces if required. The goal is to ensure that Iraqi citizens can vote freely and that we continue to support the Iraqi government as it works to establish itself and establish security in the region.

Please keep in mind that these decisions are made based on the latest intelligence and assessments of the security environment. Our military leaders will make adjustments as necessary to ensure that the elections can proceed in a safe and secure environment, allowing the Iraqi people to play a role in shaping their nation's future.

Thank you for your question. The potential for a pandemic flu remains one of my top national security concerns. We have learned a lot from the response to Hurricane Katrina and Rita, and while the experiences were challenging, they provided us with several valuable lessons, particularly in the areas of preparedness and response coordination at the federal, state, and local levels.

In terms of our readiness for a flu pandemic, it is certainly true that first-responders and local governments would play a critical role, but the current national response plan, along with state and local plans, must be strengthened to ensure a cohesive and effective response. I am concerned that the United States is not fully prepared at this point, and we have been working to address these gaps.

That is one of the reasons why we are considering options to utilize defense assets to support civilian agencies. The military has significant capabilities, such as strategic airlift, rapid deployment of medical and logistical support, national emergency communications, and mass prophylaxis equipment, which can be crucial in an emergency like a pandemic. Utilizing these resources could provide a robust and extended federal response capability that might be necessary for a prolonged pandemic scenario.

Furthermore, it is important to enhance our surveillance systems, strengthen our supply chain for antiviral medications and vaccines, and ensure that we have stockpiles available for distribution. We must also improve communication and coordination between all levels of government and with the private sector to ensure a unified and effective response.

This is not just a health issue; it's a matter of national security, and it is imperative that we are prepared to prevent, if possible, and respond effectively if a pandemic should occur.

I appreciate the question. This is a serious matter, and it's important to keep the American people informed about the challenges we face in Iraq.

We are committed to leaving in a way that will ensure the Iraqis can defend their freedom and fulfill their dreams of a secure and democratic society. To fail to achieve this objective, to leave before the job was done, would be contrary to our principles, and it would send a message around the world that if you use violence and terrorism against our coalition, you can get what you want.

However, it is vital that our forces not become involved in the internal affairs of Iraq, such as a conflict between two groups. The Iraqis have to take responsibility for their future and their security. We have been and will continue to be clear that the Iraqi government must demonstrate the capacity and willingness to take responsibility for the security of their people.

In the event that a full-scale civil war does break out, the United States will continue to work with our international partners and the Iraqi government to ensure that we protect our troops and avoid being pulled into an internal conflict. Our message is clear: Iraq must rise above sectarian divisions and build a strong, decentralized Iraqi state, where all Iraqis have a say in their future.

Our strategy involves supporting the Iraqi government in taking the necessary steps to reduce violence and to provide security while working toward economic stability, reconciliation between the different groups, and representative government. We will continue to support this strategy through the efforts of our military and civilian personnel on the ground while making it clear that leaving Iraq before the job is done is not an option.

We will stay committed to a safe and secure Iraq and to our values, and we will continue to work with our allies and partners to ensure that the Iraqi people can determine their own future. We will not allow our troops to be caught in the middle of a conflict that they did not start and do not need to resolve.

Thank you for your questions. Regarding Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, I have the utmost confidence in him. He's a man of character and integrity who continues to serve the American people well. While it's important to take the views of the Senate into consideration, I would like to emphasize that the decision of Attorney General Gonzales's continuance in the position is one I will make after careful evaluation of all the circumstances presented. At this moment, I am committed to supporting him and have not made any final decisions or intentions regarding his role for the remainder of my administration.

As for the report of civilian deaths in Afghanistan, I recognize the seriousness of the situation and the need to ensure that the United States and our NATO allies maintain the trust and support of the Afghan people. The tragic deaths of civilians are of great concern to all of us and must be addressed with the utmost seriousness and attention. Transparency and accountability in this regard are paramount to maintaining the mission's legitimacy and the support of the international community. We are committed to conducting thorough investigations, making appropriate adjustments to military operations, and ensuring that the Afghan people are treated with the respect and care they deserve.

We are working closely with our NATO partners to address this issue, as our ultimate goal is to bring stability and security to Afghanistan, and to support the Afghan government in its efforts to build a peaceful and democratic future for its citizens.

Thank you for your question. The United States and France definitely have common interests in promoting peace and stability around the world. We're working together in various areas including the fight against terrorism and the reconstruction efforts it requires, but the dynamics of interactions on Iraq reflect past differences. While those differences were significant during the Iraq War, there has been continued cooperation and reconciliation since then on various fronts.

Regarding Iraq, the path to peace and democracy remains a top priority for our administration. We're committed to supporting the Iraqi government and its people as they strive to build a stable, free, and democratic society. As for a timetable for withdrawing troops, I believe making decisions about troop levels and timelines should be based on the security and stability conditions on the ground, as well as the advice and assessments of our military leaders. Our commitment remains to leave Iraq to Iraqis but only when they are ready to provide for their own security and hold accountable national elections to determine their political future. We're neither longing for nor rushing into a departure; rather, we are guided by the interests of a stable, self-reliant Iraq.

Thank you for your questions.

First, I'll address the issue of America's obligations in the face of genocide, drawing from my own experiences and observations during my tenure as President. Preventing and intervening in instances of genocide is one of the gravest responsibilities of any American leader. It requires a clear and determined commitment to international justice and human rights.

We must remain vigilant, for the lessons of history, such as what occurred in Rwanda and elsewhere, can provide important guidance for the future. America's role in the world must reflect our values and our commitment to protecting the innocent. Diplomacy, military readiness, and a willingness to act when needed are all part of that responsibility.

To my successor, I would encourage them to support international organizations that have been established to prevent atrocities, like the International Criminal Court. But also, I would emphasize that the United States must have the capability to act swiftly and decisively when the international community falls short.

Regarding the situation of Darfur, when I was in charge, we did raise the issue and actively worked to address the crisis there. In 2006, for instance, the United States Congress passed the Darfur Peace and Accountability Act, which was designed to support a peaceful solution to the conflict and to protect those who were suffering.

We also took action to hold Sudan accountable for the violence that was being committed, which included targeted sanctions against individuals and the government for their involvement in the atrocities. However, I understand that more could be done and that ensuring such a tragedy does not occur again is an ongoing challenge.

In summary, my message to the successor would be to emphasize the importance of building international coalitions, leveraging our diplomatic assets, and using America's leadership to encourage peace and stability where it is most needed. Preventing genocide is a complex task that requires patience, persistence, and a readiness to engage with any tools at our disposal, but it is a mission we must accept and strive to fulfill.

Thank you for your question. The policy of the United States remains committed to seeking significant reductions in both strategic and tactical nuclear weapons as well as weapons-usable materials. We are working with Russia to achieve this through negotiations and joint efforts to enhance security and stability.

As for our missile defense system, our view is that it's essential to have a robust missile defense capability to protect the American people from the growing threat of long-range missiles being developed by rogue regimes. We are committed to our strategy of building this necessary capability while engaging in dialogue with Russia about strategic stability. We seek to do both things simultaneously, recognizing the importance of missile defense for our national security and our desire to continue reductions in nuclear arsenals.

I hope that clarifies our position. We value our relationship with Russia and are working towards constructive dialogue on these issues.

Thank you for your question. The United States has been deeply involved in the peace process in the Middle East since the inception of the current cycle of negotiations, and we will continue our efforts to support a negotiated peace agreement.

I understand the concerns about the recent escalations and the difficulties in restarting the peace talks. The death of Yasser Arafat, the former chairman of the PLO, created a period of uncertainty in the Palestinian leadership. However, that's not an excuse for inaction, and I believe it's crucial that we continue to work towards a peaceful resolution.
