Our diplomatic efforts include facilitating dialogue between Israeli and Palestinian leaders, providing security assistance to Palestinian areas, and working through our close friendship with Israel, as well as our relationships with Egypt, Jordan, and other regional counterparts to ensure that both Israel and the Palestinians take steps to secure and sustain the peace.

We are calling on all parties to refrain from violence and to engage constructively in the peace process. The United States under my administration has been proactive in engaging both sides and regional actors to help advance the prospects for a lasting peace in the region. We will continue to use our good offices, as well as leverage our influence to bring about peace and stability.

Peace in the Middle East is a complex issue that requires the commitment of all involved parties. We are committed to doing everything in our power to work towards a peaceful resolution, but it will require cooperation from all sides, and unwavering leadership from Israeli and Palestinian leaders to make important decisions and concessions for the sake of peace.

The question you're raising is certainly pertinent in the context of a proposed resolution regarding Iraq and its missile capabilities at that time. The administration was concerned about Iraq's development and deployment of weapons of mass destruction, including the al-Samoud 2 missiles, as well as efforts to acquire materials related to nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons programs.

Our proposed resolution was going to be framed as a clear and enforceable set of standards that Iraq must meet in order to comply with previous resolutions and international demands. It would likely include language about the destruction of prohibited weapons, the establishment of rigorous inspection and monitoring mandates under the United Nations, and probably a clear and unequivocal message to Iraq that the international community would take appropriate action if non-compliance persisted.

Regarding the ultimatum, deadline, or threat of force, it would have reflected the strong stance that maintaining international peace and security required. The Bush Administration sought to outline the consequences of continued non-compliance through a resolution that would leave little ambiguity about the collective resolve of the international community not to allow Iraq to threaten neighbors or the world with weapons of mass destruction.

I would emphasize in this context that the goal of the resolution was not merely punitive, but also preventive to protect regional stability and ensure global safety by eliminating these threats once and for all.

Good question. I want to thank you for the opportunity to address this important issue as it pertains to the global impact of the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime.

While the intelligence regarding Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction was reviewed by multiple government agencies, it was a consensus judgment at the time that Iraq continued to possess and develop an arsenal of weapons of mass destruction. We believed that these weapons posed a serious threat to the national security of the United States, and were working to give those weapons to terrorists. The decision to go to war was made based on this intelligence and the actions taken by Saddam Hussein, which included the violation of United Nations resolutions and a refusal to disarm.

As events have unfolded, the intelligence provided prior to the war has proven to be incorrect. However, our decision to remove Saddam Hussein and his regime was well-founded based on the information and the assessments available at the time.

We made it clear that Saddam Hussein's Iraq was a threat to the freedom and security of the United States and the world. When given an opportunity, we sought to peacefully disarm Saddam Hussein's regime, yet our allies, including France and Russia, would not enforce the United Nations resolutions that they had voted for, so the United States took military action to enforce the U.N. resolutions.

In the aftermath of the Iraq War, the United States and its coalition partners have worked to bring stability to the region, foster democracy, and ensure that the people of Iraq would live in a free and peaceful nation. Saddam Hussein is no longer a threat to his own people or others. While the events in Iraq post-war have been challenging, the United States remains committed to helping build a peaceful and prosperous Iraq for its citizens.

In terms of credibility, the United States will continue to carefully assess and gather information to make informed decisions that protect the nation's security interests. We recognize the importance of ensuring our actions are based on the best available intelligence and evidence.

Thank you for your question, and I encourage an open dialogue about these significant challenges facing our nation and the world.

Good morning. The governor of California, Gray Davis, is a Democrat, and I have spoken to him about his ability to continue to lead the state out of its budget difficulties and I believe that’s what the citizens of California want. They want strong leadership out of Sacramento. That’s what I told Governor Davis, is that I believe he needs to continue to work with the Legislature, work with the citizens – reach across the aisle and come up with solutions.

As far as the recall process, it is a legitimate democratic exercise in the state of California. It’s not something that I initiated, it’s not a process that was called for here at the federal level. It is a state law, and it’s something that citizens of the state of California will ultimately decide. They’ll decide if they want to remove their governor and they’ll decide whether or not to support any of the replacements.

Let me be clear that I’ve not voiced a preference for any particular candidate. That’s a matter to be determined by the citizens. I would urge all citizens who are interested in participating in this process, to get themselves familiar with the candidates, and to participate in the process, whether it’s the recall or whether it’s the election following.

Thank you for the question.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding your first point, I have always said that we're respectful of our differences in this country, but we are united in a common goal: to make America safer and to defeat the enemy. I believe that we need to work more effectively together in a spirit of civility and resolution. I want our conversations about how to win the war on terror and advance freedom to be vigorous and open but also responsible. That's what I mean by saying we will change the tone. The stakes are high, and I know that my fellow Americans expect us to work together and to put partisanship aside. We have an obligation to do so for our troops, for our families, and for future generations.

As for your second question, the Congress has an important role to play, and I believe that all branches of government have a duty to ensure that the country's resources are used effectively and efficiently in the war against terrorism. Working together with the oversight committees, we are committed to making sure that the oversight process is orderly and that the workings of our government's actions in the War on Terror are transparent to the American people. I will work with the Congress to make sure that we can accomplish our goals in this vital national mission, maintaining the security of our country and the advancement of freedom and democracy around the world.

Thank you for your question. It's a fair one. We believe the terrorists and insurgents should not set the terms and conditions for the United States of America. We've got a strategy to succeed, and we've got a strategy to win in Iraq.

The phased redeployment, which General Petraeus will be recommending, gives us an opportunity to set conditions, as opposed to deadlines. The enemy does not know what those conditions are. The public does not know, which is as it should be. The enemy understands the conditions surrounding the size of safe havens, levels of violence, whether they've broken the will of the United States, and the capacity and capability of the Iraqis for taking charge of their own security. Setting an outside deadline gives the enemy the ability to, you know, regroup and plan and, like I say, not let them set the conditions for us.

I have said, Mr. Independent, that this is a different configuration compared to the deployment in the past. But the name for the strategy is "success," not “Plan B” or "Plan A." It's a strategy that results in a stable Iraq, which is obviously in our nation's interests.

The phased redeployment based on the President's conditions will have a different configuration of troops in the field. It will leave them in areas where the enemy still remains strong and the Iraqis need help. At the same time, you'll be able to keep areas where the Iraqis are in charge from being overrun. The goal is a stable democracy in Iraq, putting pressure on Iran and al-Qaeda, as well as making sure that our troops are not overcommitted and exhausted as they return home to their loved ones.

Would you like to follow up or see if others have questions?

Thank you for your questions. Let me address each part of your inquiry.

Firstly, regarding Dmitry Medvedev, it's important to understand the situation from a strategic perspective. Medvedev was elected president in 2008, and at the same time, Vladimir Putin became the Prime Minister of Russia. Their roles were described as a "tandem" or "dual leadership," but the specifics of their collaboration were indeed complex and somewhat opaque.

Medvedev came to power with a reformist agenda, labeling himself as a "modernizer" for Russia. He emphasized areas such as civil society, the rule of law, and anti-corruption efforts. However, his ability to implement these reforms was limited by various factors, including political opposition and the entrenched interests of those close to Putin.

As for the power dynamic between Medvedev and Putin, while Medvedev held the office of President, the practical influence often seemed to revert back to Putin. This is because Putin wielded significant power as the head of the United Russia party, controlled key security and military services, and had a tight grip on the levers of power within the Russian system.

The cautionary tale I would provide to my successor is this: dealing with Russia requires a nuanced approach that recognizes the potency of its strategic interests, its significant nuclear arsenal, and its role as a permanent member of the UN Security Council. My administration did not misjudge Putin's intentions; however, the complexity of the Russian landscape presented challenges that were not always foreseen, especially as Moscow chose to engage in actions that undermined international norms and stability.

In terms of dealing with Russia today and moving forward, it is essential for the United States to robustly address Russian aggression, whether it be in cyberspace, in Europe, or in the Middle East. We must also work to strengthen our alliances and partnerships, reinforcing NATO and defending Article 5 of the treaty, which commits members to collective defense. Meanwhile, it's important to maintain channels of communication, seeking to de-escalate tensions while holding Russia accountable for its actions that contravene international agreements and principles.

We have to be vigilant and adaptive, remembering that the world is constantly changing, and Russia's role in it will continue to evolve. By keeping a watchful eye and taking a principled yet pragmatic stance, we can navigate the complexities of dealing with Russia more effectively in the future.

Thank you for your questions.

On the matter of clarity regarding our plans for Iraq, I want to reassure you and the German people that my administration has been clear in its intentions regarding Iraq. The ultimate objective of our efforts is to disarm Saddam Hussein of his weapons of mass destruction and to free the Iraqi people from the grip of a brutal dictator. We have been and continue to work with our allies to achieve these goals. We have expressed our willingness to exhaust all diplomatic measures, such as working through the United Nations, before considering military action. Our sensitivity towards the views of our allies is important, and we are committed to discussing these issues seriously.

Regarding Germany's contributions to the fight against terrorism, Germany has indeed taken on a significant role within our coalition of the willing. The solidarity and cooperation we have received, including support from German intelligence, have been crucial. I acknowledge the substantial burden that Germany has undertaken. I value our partnership in the war on terrorism and the effort that Germany has made. However, like with all our allies, we always encourage and seek further contributions that will strengthen our common resolve to eliminate terrorism. But it's important to recognize what each nation is capable of as they respond to requests for assistance.

I am grateful for Germany's efforts and for Chancellor Schröder's leadership. We will continue to work together to ensure the security and peace of our citizens.

Thank you for the question. The Jackson-Vanik amendment is indeed a Cold War relic, and steps have been taken to update the U.S.-Russia economic relationship to reflect the changed nature of our relations since that time. There have been discussions in the U.S. Congress about how best to address Russia's trading status and the applicability of Jackson-Vanik in light of Russia fully recognizing the rights of emigration for its citizens.

Regarding the future of Jackson-Vanik, the executive branch has worked closely with the Congress to find a resolution that is consistent with the spirit of Jackson-Vanik while also acknowledging the progress Russia has made in terms of human rights and economic freedoms since the early '70s. As for the specific question about when it would be rescinded, it was a complex issue at the time involving both legislative efforts and official state actions to update the trade relationship.

On the prospect of Russia joining the World Trade Organization (WTO), the U.S. has supported Russia's accession to the WTO based on the condition that Russia meets the necessary economic reforms and trading practices expected of WTO members. The U.S. views Russia's WTO entry as beneficial for global commerce and economic growth.

As for the idea of U.S. Boeings in Russian civil aviation, we continue to encourage trade and economic cooperation between our two nations, which includes promoting the interests of American companies in the Russian market. U.S. Boeings offer state-of-the-art technology and support systems, which can enhance the efficiency and safety of Russian civil aviation.

We are committed to the partnership with Russia on a wide range of issues, as well as promoting the mutual benefits that can come from closer economic ties.

Good question. The situation in the Middle East continues to be complex and difficult, but the commitment of the United States to a permanent status agreement that leads to two states living side by side in peace and security has not changed. As I mentioned in my previous address, Israel's long-term security depends on its withdrawal to indefensible positions. We continue to work with the parties to achieve a lasting peace. The United States will continue to engage actively with both sides and the wider international community to encourage them to make the hard choices that are necessary to achieve a just and lasting settlement. It is my hope that through diplomacy and by taking the steps required by the road map, both Israelis and Palestinians can move forward to achieve a future of peace and security for both peoples.

Thank you for your question. When we talk about reconstruction aid, it's important to understand that this is an investment in our national security and in a more stable, peaceful world. The funds that we are proposing to allocate towards the reconstruction of Iraq are part of our commitment to assist Iraqis as they stabilize their country and build a better future. 

We are also cognizant of the concerns about the financial impact on the American taxpayer. That's why we've been working closely with Congress to ensure that we have a responsible plan for both the timing and the structuring of any spending. It's not an exorbitant or disproportionate amount when you consider the broader context of our national security and interests overseas.

As for why this aid should be viewed as an investment rather than a burden on future generations, it's because stabilizing Iraq can prevent further instability and terrorist threats from emerging in that part of the world. It's an upfront cost to prevent the potential for much greater costs down the line, whether financially or in terms of our national security.

Moreover, I'm confident that the Congress will take the appropriate measures to ensure that this aid is well-planned and managed to benefit both the Iraqi people and the American taxpayer. Our objective is to work together to find a balance that supports our national interests and those of the Iraqi people.

Our coalition forces have been working tirelessly to stabilize Iraq and bring the perpetrators of violence to justice. The situation in Iraq is complex, and the insurgency has exploited the chaos to carry out their attacks. Despite the efforts of our military, capturing or killing Zarqawi and other terrorist leaders has proven challenging due to their ability to blend in and operate within a civilian population, as well as their use of tactics to avoid detection and engage in guerrilla warfare.

Regarding the need for additional forces, our military continues to assess and adapt to the evolving security situation. We do not make the decision lightly to commit more troops; it is a serious consideration that involves evaluating both the mission requirements and the availability of resources. The needs of coalition forces are continually reviewed with President Bush and his advisors. If it's determined that more troops are needed to accomplish the mission, we will not hesitate to make that commitment. The safety of our troops and the stability of Iraq are our primary concerns.

Thank you for your question. First and foremost, it's important that we have a president that stands with our troops and the people in Iraq as we work to take the fight to the terrorists and to bring security to a whole part of the world. A president has got to be strong and resolve, and I believe that John Kerry has sent mixed signals.

Now, with respect to your question about current messages potentially having consequences on the effort in Iraq, I would say that it's not just about the current messages, but also about the confidence and morale of our troops and the Iraqi people. The confidence in the mission is important for the war on terror. We have an obligation to stay until the job is done, and that's why I've been saying that the commander-in-chief needs to be focused and resolve, someone who understands that we must stay the course in Iraq.

The last part of your question asks if using the war in Iraq as part of a campaign has consequences on the situation there. Well, it's the duty of all candidates to explain their position on all issues, including Iraq. However, I believe that at a time when young Americans have set aside comforts of home so that others can be free, how we talk about the sacrifices we're asking our troops to make matters to our men and women in uniform. I will not do anything to undermine the morale of our troops, nor would I do anything abroad that would embolden the enemy. That's part of my job as commander-in-chief.

As for immediate consequences, a commander in chief communicates with a clear, confident voice. And that's what our troops deserve, and that's what the American people deserve. That's how I try to conduct this campaign, and that's how I'm going to be a commander-in-chief.

As you've heard, some of the Senate's Democratic leaders have been using hyperbolic language to describe the state of our economy, comparing our current economic conditions to the dire circumstances of the Great Depression. In contrast, they suggest that there's no issue with Social Security at all.

I believe in working constructively with people from both parties to find solutions for the American people. It's important to maintain composure and keep the focus on the facts. Accusations of being out of touch do not contribute to addressing genuine issues. Instead, let's talk about the economic policies that we can agree on improving the economy, whether it's investing in American workers, supporting small businesses, or overcoming the challenges that Social Security faces.

Democrats and Republicans can agree on the need for sound fiscal policy, responsible budgeting, and free-enterprise programs that can create jobs, grow the economy, and address our challenges in a responsible way. So, we will reach out with solutions that can command bipartisan support and take positive action for our fellow citizens. Let's work together to understand the complex realities of the economy and work toward solutions that address the challenges while ensuring the future security of programs like Social Security.

Thank you for your question. While I understand the important nature of your inquiry, I want to stress that the men and women of our armed forces are committed, capable, and proud to defend freedom and serve their country. They understand the vital nature of their mission and the importance of their work in Iraq.

Regarding morale, it is a concern we take very seriously. We do have a strong military today. We've been reminded recently of the professionalism and courage of our troops -- not just in Iraq; they've come through challenging and tough missions in other areas of the world. And our job is to support them, whether it's providing them the resources they need, the mentally and the spiritually, and the thanks of the country.

I do not have specific statistics to share about the frequency of tours or current morale figures at hand in this press conference, but I understand that you may be concerned about deterioration over time. We work closely with the Department of Defense and military leadership to ensure that our troops are supported in every way possible, including through adequate rest between deployments and ensuring that they receive the morale-boosting activities that are important.

It is not uncommon for soldiers to engage in discussions and to reflect upon their mission. Asking questions is a sign of thoughtful service and reflection, and it's important that as leaders and as a country, we are always listening to our troops to better understand how we can continue to support them and their families. We are deeply committed to ensuring every person who wears the uniform of the United States is treated with respect and honor.

The decision to send our troops into harm's way is made with the utmost seriousness and I am committed to ensuring that our military personnel receive everything they need to make them as successful and safe as possible under the tough conditions they face. We owe every one of our service members our gratitude and support.

Thank you for your question, and I recognize that this is a complex issue that involves a range of challenges and considerations. The surge was designed to provide a window of opportunity for the Iraqi government to make progress on national reconciliation and political accountability. While our military achievements were clear, and the situation in parts of Iraq improved, it is also true that political reconciliation has been slow.

To address the benchmarks you mentioned, we have defined several critical steps that the Iraqi government could take to make progress on national reconciliation, security, and political unity. These include:

1. Reconciliation between Sunni and Shi'a communities to address the sectarian divide and promote national unity.
2. Critical benchmarks for the Iraqi political process such as electoral reform, a revised permanent constitution, and national reconciliation.
3. Effective implementation of de-Ba'athification to ensure some fair treatment of former Ba'athists and encourage moderation.
4. Disbandment of sectarian militias and ensuring the Iraqi security forces are inclusive and representative of all communities in Iraq.
5. Provisions for equitable oil revenues distribution and management, as sharing resources fairly is essential for political stability.

These actions are crucial for creating a viable government that can command the support of different communities and provide a sense of security and fairness to the Iraqi people. With clear political progress from the Iraqi government and continued U.S. support, conditions can be established for our troops to responsibly and confidently move towards redeployment as Iraq's security situation improves.

It's important to maintain engagement with the Iraqi government, continue providing military support, and work with them to achieve these benchmarks, even as we look towards the day when our troops can return home. The Iraqi people must also take responsibility for the future of their country, and it is their leadership that will ultimately determine the success of the government.

Our goal has always been a stable, self-reliant Iraq at peace with its neighbors, and these benchmarks represent the necessary steps towards that goal. While it is understandable that some may be skeptical, it's in the best interest of the Iraqi people and the world to continue this process and monitor progress closely.

Good morning. I appreciate your interest in this critical matter. Let me be clear that any decisions regarding our troops will be deliberate and made with the utmost seriousness. I've previously stated that our troops in Afghanistan are engaged in a critical mission to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a terrorist sanctuary, and we are doing everything within our capability to ensure that country does not become a base for al Qaeda or other extremist elements.

We are conducting a thorough review of our Afghanistan policies in order to determine what elements of our strategy need to be adjusted or revised. This review will take into account the advice of our military leaders, our diplomats, regional analysts, and others to make sure that we are responding effectively to the situation on the ground. Our commitment is to make sure that America remains safe and that we stay focused on the mission.

Regarding the involvement of our NATO allies, it is important to remember that their contributions are critical. We appreciate the sacrifices made by our allies, including their contributions of troops, funds, and political support. While some allies have not been as engaged as others, this does not diminish the importance of the collective effort to bring about a stable and secure Afghanistan. We are working with our NATO partners to improve their efforts and to ensure that we have the best possible coalition response to the challenge we face.

Ultimately, the success of our mission in Afghanistan is in everyone's national interest, and the United States, along with our allies, will continue to work together to achieve our shared goals. As part of this effort, we will continue to hold discussions with our partners and will keep the American people informed of any steps we take regarding our strategy and troop levels.

I appreciate the question. The United States, along with our partners from South Korea and China, continues to engage with North Korea to address their nuclear weapons program. We've emphasized the importance of full disclosure in the context of the Six-Party Talks, and the fact that we are still awaiting North Korea's complete and accurate declaration does concern us. 

It's important to approach this situation with a thorough and deliberate process. We have had diplomatic channels open, and we've been working diligently to achieve complete and accurate declarations from North Korea regarding their nuclear programs. The upcoming round of talks offers another opportunity to push for these declarations and to further discuss the steps North Korea needs to take to dismantle its nuclear capabilities under international verification standards.

We are committed to a peaceful resolution and strongly believe that North Korea's compliance with the Six-Party agreement is critical for stability on the Korean Peninsula and in the broader region. We will continue to engage North Korea with a firm but patient approach, working to achieve the goals we established at the Six-Party Talks.

Thank you for your questions. The situation with Iran remains a significant concern for the United States and our allies, including Germany and the European Union.

Regarding the European Union's offer, as presented by Javier Solana, we have been working closely with our partners in the E3+3 (China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States) in an effort to address Iran's nuclear program. We've sought diplomatic means to encourage Iran to meet its international obligations and to cooperate more transparently with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

If Iran does reject the offer, we are prepared to consider a range of measures with our allies, including additional sanctions that would aim to increase pressure on the Iranian regime to comply with United Nations Security Council resolutions and other international demands. These sanctions have already been operating to limit Iran's ability to develop its nuclear program.

In terms of Germany's role, Chancellor Merkel and other German leaders share our commitment to a non-proliferation agenda. Germany has been a strong partner in enforcing economic sanctions on Iran and has been involved in diplomatic efforts to curb Iran's nuclear ambitions. As for specific actions, Germany, along with other EU members, has implemented a number of financial and trade restrictions targeting Iran's oil and banking sectors, as well as measures aimed at individuals and entities linked to Iran's nuclear program.

Our goal remains to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons and to ensure that all countries meet their international obligations. We will continue to coordinate with our European and global partners to achieve these ends and are prepared to take further steps as necessary.

Thank you for your question. The visit here to Northern Ireland is an opportunity for us to build stronger ties and address critical issues such as the peace process and reconciliation. I appreciate the progress that has been made since the Good Friday Agreement in 1998, and it is important that we continue to support the efforts toward a peaceful resolution to all conflicts.

Regarding my meetings, every leader I meet with is important for the dialogue that is necessary to progress peace and stability. Meetings with leaders from various factions, including those from Sinn Féin, are part of a broader strategy to engage in discussions that foster understanding and cooperation. It's crucial to include those who have been part of the political process and have committed to the path of peace, as well as those who continue to oppose violence and extremism.

It's also true that I will meet with a range of voices and representatives, some of whom might express views different from my own or from the official policies of the United States. However, the Republican leaders I meet with are committed to political progress through non-violent means, and that is a major step toward moving past the past.

I understand that symbols and appearances are important, especially in a place as sensitive as Northern Ireland. It is my intention to respect the process that has been established and to support those who work for peace and unity in this region. Our commitment is to support the peace process and to encourage dialogue among all parties, all while respecting the sovereignty and democratic processes of the United Kingdom.

Well, first of all, on the question of weapons of mass destruction or weapons of mass destruction programs in Iraq, my judgment was informed. We were dealing with someone who had used weapons of mass destruction to attack his neighbors. We were dealing with a person who had used chemical weapons on his own people. We were dealing with a person who was willing to threaten his neighbors. And I believe that the world was right to act when we did to deal with Saddam Hussein.

Now, concerning postwar planning, all wars are difficult and all wars are tragic. And yes, we were slow to help the Iraqi people deal with the fact that they were being attacked by a former regime that was sending out remnants for retribution. That's a regret and I don't defend that. I wish I had done more. I've asked others in our government who are responsible to do a better job in helping Iraqis come to grips with their own security situation.

Regarding the September 11th attacks, I think that in the intelligence community, which traverses many different points of government, it's my assessment that we did not share information sufficiently. There's an important lesson to be learned, and that's why we created the Terrorist Threat Integration Center and the Director of National Intelligence to make sure that the information we need to protect America was being shared effectively. And it's a lesson I've learned personally. Had I known something was going to happen on September the 11th, I would have acted to make sure it didn't take place. But as the president, as commander in chief, those decisions are now mine.

Finally, on never admitting mistakes, I believe that given the nature and the dangers that our country faces, there is a responsibility on the part of the president to defend the country, to be decisive, and to do what is in the country's best interest and best to uphold the principles of the country. There are going to be people who will find fault with decisions. That's a part of the nature in which we operate. But, the United States of America has an obligation to lead and to help others.

I'm aware that being decisive can lead to mistakes, and it's important for leaders to learn and adapt from those mistakes. However, in decision-making of matters of security and foreign policy, I've always made the best choice I could for the American people at the time. And I have sought to learn from those experiences.

Thank you for the question. The principles of freedom and democracy have always been core to American values. However, taking office after the tragedy of September 11th, 2001, highlighted the direct link between freedom and the national security of the United States and the world. It became even clearer that in order to make America and the world safer, we must work to defeat the ideologies that promote oppression and foster acts of terror against free peoples.

Before September 11th, the fight against terrorism was a priority but perhaps not the sole focus of our foreign policy. After September 11th, our understanding was that freedom and democracy are critical to defeating tyrants and the ideologies that they promote. When people are free and economies are open, the chances that people may try to attack America from outside our borders decreases.

Therefore, what changed was the context in which we viewed the promotion of democracy. It was not that the commitment to freedom and liberty was less important before, but the nature of the threats facing our nation transformed. The strategic imperative to address and remove the root causes of such threats brought a heightened emphasis on promoting democracy as a fundamental way to achieve long-term peace and stability.

We understood that to fight a war on terror effectively, we needed to change regimes that foster and harbor the terrorists, and this goes beyond military action. It includes promoting the values of freedom and liberty as a foundation to build stable societies that offer hope to their people, reducing the appeal of extremism.

Our vision for a Free Iraq, as it proudly flew over the White House, was more than a symbol: it was a statement of our commitment to the fundamental principle that a free Iraq goes beyond just the interests of the Iraqi people but is also vital to the greater peace of the region and to America's security.

So, in sum, while the core belief in freedom did not change, the events of September 11th brought a renewed and strategic commitment to spreading democratic influence as a means to secure our nation and promote peace in the world.

Thank you for your question.

I appreciate your interest in the legislative process, but I don't view this as a split within the party. The resolution that was passed emphasizes the need to stay focused on the mission of victory in Iraq and underscores our commitment to American troops. It also reaffirms the vital partnership between the United States and Iraq as they work together toward a secure and stable democracy.

The resolution's passage reflects a constructive and responsible approach to providing oversight on our policy in Iraq, which is in line with my administration's commitment to keeping the American people informed about our goals and progress in that theater. This spirit of accountability is an important part of our democracy, and I welcome the opportunity to work with members of Congress to ensure we are charting a course that supports our interests and the interests of the Iraqi people.

As for the specific emphasis on more information and potential changes to our policy, I welcome the dialogue and believe that communication and cooperation between the White House and Congress strengthen our efforts to accomplish our objectives in Iraq.

Finally, I do not view this as an embarrassing situation while traveling abroad. We present a united front when we represent the interests of the United States on the world stage. Our coalition partners appreciate the robust discussion taking place within our political system and understand that a strong and informed Congress is an integral part of our efforts to stabilize Iraq and achieve a lasting peace in the Middle East.

Thank you for the opportunity to clarify, and I look forward to continuing our work together toward those objectives.

Thank you for your question and the kind words. It's important to reaffirm our support for Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity as well as the unity and independence of all the countries in the region. The United States has and will continue to work with our allies, including countries like Estonia, to help Georgia navigate the challenges it faces. We can do this through a variety of tools, including diplomatic engagement to de-escalate tensions, promotion of economic development, which can help provide a more prosperous future for the Georgian people, and reinforcing our commitment to the security of Georgia and its neighbors.

It's vital that we support efforts aimed at peaceful resolution of disputes, and we must remain committed to the goal of a stable and secure Caucasus region. The United States will also work with our international partners to ensure that Georgia can continue to grow and thrive, despite the geopolitical challenges around it. We are deeply concerned about the situation in Georgia and we will continue to stand for the principles of international law and the peaceful resolution of conflicts.

Thank you for your question. It's important to consider the complexities and realities of nation-building and the global fight against terrorism. Our presence in Iraq is part of a larger strategy to confront threats that endanger American security. As President, my responsibility is to ensure the safety and security of the American people.

While I take all public opinion polls into account, ultimately, my primary duty is to make decisions based on what I believe is most prudent for the security and well-being of our nation. The survey you mentioned reflects the public's sentiment regarding a specific aspect of our involvement, but the commitment to defend our country against terrorist threats and work toward stability in Iraq remains firm.

We are committed to working with the new Iraqi government, strengthening the capacity of Iraqi security forces, and supporting national reconciliation. These efforts are critical for the long-term stability of the Middle East and security of the United States. 

It's worth noting that what we're doing in Iraq is part of a larger, comprehensive strategy to ensure world peace. We will continue to adapt our strategies, if necessary, to manage the situation responsibly. Our military leaders, including General David Petraeus, have provided detailed operational assessments aimed at achieving stability in Iraq. Comparisons of Iraq to Vietnam are inaccurate; each nation and situation presents its own unique challenges and opportunities.

I respect the opinions of the American people and the complex scenarios we face, and I will remain focused on ensuring the safety and security of our homeland. We recognize that our service members and their families sacrifice greatly in pursuit of these goals. It is our duty to complete the mission and pave the way for a peaceful and democratic Iraq.

Well, first of all, I’m pleased the microphone is being used, and I’m proud of the fact that we’ve got an engaged public audience regarding these issues. People across the country are participating in town hall meetings. And the reason why I think it's really important to continue to engage is because we’re talking about some fundamental issues that are going to affect the quality of life here at home.

As far as the Congress is concerned, I'm engaged with the Democratic leadership, and we are talking about both Social Security reform and immigration reform. And as we enter into discussions, my tone will be one of comity; my interest is to do what’s right for America.

I believe deeply in Social Security. I also know that the current benefit formula eventually will lead to bankruptcy of the system. And rather than allow seniors to lose anything in terms of their benefits, I want to work with leaders in Congress to make sure there are personal accounts, to make sure that younger workers have got a better deal and to extend the solvency of the Social Security system.

On immigration reform, I’m a strong believer that we have to secure our borders first. And when Congress established legalization programs in the past, they weren't effective because the border was not secure. And my hope is that we can work together to get a comprehensive approach to solving this issue, by making sure no amnesty is involved until we’ve got a secure border and making sure that we can effect an earned legalization idea that actually works, that allows people to fill the quotas, if you will, that we need in order for a vibrant work force to continue.

So the microphone, so to speak—the Presidential bully pulpit—is still going to be used, and I appreciate the fact that there’s a receptive audience to talk about these important issues. I will do everything in my power to work with a bipartisan Congress to achieve solutions that are in the best interests of the American people.

I appreciate you asking that question in both Pashto and English for clarity. While President Hamid Karzai was a leader of Afghanistan that I have worked closely with and respected, any comments he made about the Taliban before might differ from the realities that have unfolded since. The nature of the threat posed by the Taliban has changed over time, alongside the evolving geopolitical conditions of Afghanistan.

The Taliban have continued to pose a threat to the Afghan people through their activities, including kidnappings and attacks on government officials and civilians. These actions are supported by a range of factors, including extremist ideologies, regional support, and the exploitation of local grievances.

Here in the United States, we have steadfastly supported the Afghan government in efforts to combat the Taliban and restore stability to Afghanistan. I've worked with leaders like President Karzai to improve security and establish a more stable and prosperous future for the Afghan people.

The challenges in Afghanistan are complex, and the situation has evolved as both national and international efforts have targeted the Taliban's leadership and their networks. Our goal has always been peace and stability in Afghanistan, but it's clear that achieving this requires a multifaceted approach with international support.

I appreciate the opportunity to address this topic, and let me say that I understand the importance of bipartisanship and working together for the good of the country. I've made it a priority to reach across the aisle and to find common ground where we can. 

In my report card, I mentioned some areas where we've made progress, such as education reform and the recent tax cut action, which was a bipartisan effort in the Senate. These are areas where we've been able to work together. However, I also mentioned issues where we haven't seen as much cooperation, like with the Medicare prescription drug benefit, which I believe is one of the most significant pieces of social legislation ever in this country. Congress, including some Democrats, did not support the legislation.

That being said, I do believe that there are many issues where we can find common ground and make progress. We have ongoing discussions about energy policy, immigration reform, and other important topics where the administration is ready to work with members of both parties. We haven't given up on finding common ground, and I'm committed to continuing those discussions.

In terms of my own assessment, I would say that finding common ground is an ongoing process, and while we've had successes, we still have work to do. My job is to lead this country, to set an agenda, and to call upon members of both parties to work together to achieve our goals. We can never underestimate the importance of collaboration in this great republic of ours.

First of all, I want to thank you for the question. The people of Venezuela have spoken, and the Venezuelan people will make the decisions about their future. The commitment of the United States has always been to democracy in the Western Hemisphere -- that's very important. You asked me about Hugo Chavez, and how I would assess his tenure as president. Here is what I told him in 2007, after a meeting we had in Mar-a-Lago: "I hope you know that I hold you in great disdain. The United States looks like a lone ranger in the world because, well, you're not helping much. You're taking the side of some of the biggest enemies of the United States, and you are not standing with the victims of tyranny."

Given that context, the reaction of the United States is one of encouragement and support for the democratic process wherever it unfolds. We believe in free and fair elections as a way to resolve political differences, and we are encouraged that the Venezuelan people were able to cast their votes as they saw fit. Our focus is on promoting stability, prosperity, and freedom -- those are the values we stand for. We hope that the new leadership in Venezuela will align itself more closely with the principles that are the cornerstone of our bilateral relations.

Thank you for asking that question. As you know, I believe in transparency and accountability not only for corporate America, but also for the government. Transparency is an important step in rebuilding trust and ensuring that businesses operate with integrity.

Regarding Harken Energy Corporation, it was my decision and responsibility at the time; however, as President, I do not hold the same disclosures and transparency requirements on my past business dealings that current companies or individuals under investigation might have. The SEC is a professional, independent agency responsible for conducting investigations and making the appropriate disclosures once the necessary legal procedures have been completed.

In the U.S., the principle of separation of powers means that executive branch officials should not have undue influence over the regulatory agencies, like the SEC. Releasing documents prematurely or as a request from an individual could undermine the SEC's independence and its ability to follow the proper legal processes.

Regarding the Vice President, I can say that his role with Halliburton is his own matter and should be taken up appropriately within the proper channels, just like the processes with any other individual. The Vice President and I have encouraged openness and honesty, and I trust him to provide accurate information.

If you have specific questions about the Vice President's or my own dealings, they should be addressed to the independent agencies responsible for investigating such matters. We will continue to support such investigations and will adhere to any recommendations or decisions that are made.

First, regarding the State of the Union address, I stand by the intelligence that was provided to me and the British Government at the time. The comment in the State of the Union regarding Iraq attempting to purchase nuclear material from Africa was based on the best available intelligence at the time. The intention was to provide clarity and urgency to the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime. When intelligence is updated or reevaluated, as it often is in the complexities of foreign policy and national security, we must be willing to acknowledge and adapt our understanding accordingly.

As for any claims of misleading the public, it is imperative to remember that the information was presented to Congress and the American people in a way that we believed to be accurate at the time. Of course, continuous review of intelligence is standard practice, and both the U.S. and U.K. Governments have been committed to thorough investigations into the intelligence gathering process and its evaluation.

Secondly, concerning Zimbabwe and the opposition leader's delegation, our commitment to promoting democracy and human rights is a cornerstone of U.S. foreign policy. It would certainly be appropriate for a representative from our administration to meet with representatives of the opposition party in Zimbabwe if it advances our goals to support the people of Zimbabwe and to press for genuine democratic reforms. While South African President Thabo Mbeki has been involved in mediation efforts, we recognize that the situation is complex and requires thorough dialogue to address the concerns and aspirations of the Zimbabwean people. We will consider all avenues to support a peaceful and just resolution in Zimbabwe that respects the will of its citizens.

The proposal by Senator Pat Roberts to restructure the intelligence community is an important matter that would impact the effectiveness of our intelligence apparatus. While I support the efforts to improve our intelligence capabilities, it is essential to evaluate any major legislative changes thoroughly, ensuring they do not dilute the effectiveness or integrity of our intelligence operations, which are critical to our national security. 

At the White House, we are working closely with intelligence community leaders and Members of Congress, including Senator Roberts, to refine the approach to intelligence reform. We aim to create institutions that are agile, effective, and responsive to the evolving global threats we face today. It is vital that any restructuring maintains the strong oversight that the intelligence community has always had in Congress, while also ensuring operational flexibility.

As of the current status, we are reviewing various proposals, including Senator Roberts', and are involved in discussions across the government to formulate a cohesive and comprehensive approach to intelligence reform. Our goal is to keep our nation safe while enhancing the intelligence community's capacity to anticipate and counter emerging threats. 

It's a balanced approach that seeks to foster a strong, efficient, and innovative intelligence community, ready to meet the challenges of the 21st century. We will continue to engage with Congress and other stakeholders to ensure the best outcomes for our national security.

Thank you for your question. Our efforts in Iraq, particularly in Baghdad, have been focused on improving security conditions and creating the stability necessary for the Iraqi government to manage its affairs. We work closely with Iraqi security forces to ensure that they are capable and willing to take the lead in securing their cities.

Changes to the security status and conditions are continually being evaluated and adjustments are made whenever possible. This includes shifting resources, troops, and tactics to address the evolving threats and challenges in Baghdad and other parts of Iraq. Our approach often involves a mix of military operations, partnerships with local security forces, and support for civil administration efforts that improve governance and services.

In the political aspect of the security, we have been stressing the importance of the Iraqi government's political reconciliation process, which is aimed at creating a unified national movement that can help restore peace and cohesion in the country. We have encouraged political leaders to reach out across ethnic and sectarian lines in order to form a government that enjoys broader support of the Iraqi people.

The situation in Baghdad and throughout Iraq remains complex, but we are committed to working with the Iraqi government, security forces, and the international community to address these issues. It is crucial that the Iraqi people see progress and improvements in their daily lives as part of broader efforts to achieve long-term stability and security in the region.

Your second question, please.

Thank you for your questions. Let me address each one.

First, regarding the issue of terrorism as a crime or a law enforcement concern, I would say that while terrorism can certainly involve criminal acts, the scope and nature of terrorism demand a more comprehensive response than any single law enforcement action can provide. This is because terrorism is often rooted in ideological and often religious zealotry, aimed at creating a state of fear and instability, and disrupts not just one country but an entire region or the world order. For that reason, it is imperative that we treat terrorism as a complex strategic challenge that demands a multifaceted approach involving military action, intelligence gathering, diplomacy, economic sanctions, and law enforcement cooperation.

Secondly, to the Prime Minister, I would say that while it's true that any cooperation between our nations should be based on the strong foundation laid by your predecessor and the United States, it's also important to recognize that every partnership can benefit from a fresh perspective and new ideas. As leaders, we have an opportunity to build upon the progress made by our predecessors while also addressing the new challenges that arise, particularly in a rapidly changing world. Continuous dialogue and a willingness to adapt our policies will be key moving forward.

During our visit here, we've had productive talks, and I'm confident we will work together to strengthen our partnership and confront the shared challenges we face.

Thank you for your questions, and let me address them in order.

First, regarding housing prices, the market is currently in a period of adjustment after a period of significant housing demand. It's clear that falling home prices and rising foreclosures are contributing to a broader economic slowdown. While there's no easy crystal ball to predict future housing prices, we must anticipate that the housing market is in a process of correction, and that stabilization may take time.

Second, the credit freeze we've seen is a serious matter and is affecting the ability of many Americans to access home mortgages and other types of loans. This financial constricting can indeed have a broader impact on economic growth, consumer spending, and job creation. It's a vital concern that the administration is working to address.

As for what we're prepared to do, we are working closely with the Federal Reserve and Congress to pursue measures that could help stabilize the financial markets. We are actively discussing legislative measures that may be necessary to ensure our financial institutions are sound and assist families and communities that are being impacted by this difficult situation.

Specifically, about a government bailout for homeowners, the administration is exploring various policy initiatives that could help mitigate the effects of foreclosures and ensure stability in the housing market. These could include programs that provide relief to borrowers facing foreclosure, measures to improve mortgage financing, and efforts to address the broader systemic issues. Actions will be taken to protect the taxpayer investment, encourage responsible behavior among lenders and borrowers alike, and streamline the process for resolving the current crisis.

We're also working to ensure that the lenders who have acted responsibly and the creditors who have played a role in the current financial challenges receive a fair shake as we craft solutions that can stem the broader economic impact of the current crisis. We've seen commitments from key institutions, and our commitment is to help take bold measures to help our economy recover from the current challenges.

Thank you for the question. Canada has been a valued ally and a strong partner in the mission to assist the people of Afghanistan and to promote stability in that country. Canadian troops have played a critical role in the operations in Kandahar and have made significant sacrifices to help the Afghan people and promote peace and security.

While it's true that Canada has been a key contributor and has taken on a substantial burden, the overall mission in Afghanistan requires the sustained commitment of the international community. The success of our efforts is dependent upon the collaboration and dedication of all coalition partners. As the mission progresses and transitions, it is important for all nations involved to continue to support the Afghan government's efforts to gain control and sovereignty over its own security.

We value the partnership with Canada and hope that regardless of the specific mission Canada chooses to maintain, they will continue to support the broader goals of our efforts in Afghanistan. Cooperation with our partners will continue to be essential as we work towards a secure and stable Afghanistan.

Thank you for your question. To address the first part, I made it clear that Iraq was not an endless war because we went into Iraq with a clear mission: to disarm Saddam Hussein of weapons of mass destruction, and to bring democracy to Iraq. Our coalition took Saddam Hussein out of power, and we delivered a message to the world that women and men will not be brutalized by a dictator any more than they will be intimidated by a terrorist.

The mission in Iraq is a serious undertaking. We must continue to help the Iraqi people maintain an opportunity to determine their own future. Progress has been steady. We're training Iraqi security forces, and Iraqi units are now in the fight with American and coalition forces. We have good leaders in interim Prime Minister Allawi and President Jalal Talabani who have helped rally their countrymen to the cause of peace and freedom. And I believe that Iraqis will eventually be able to take control of their own security and protect their own institutions, and with that in mind, I made it very clear that it won't be an endless war.

Regarding your question to the Prime Minister, as for the meetings with candidates to succeed me, the candidates shared their vision for the future of the United States and their commitment to global leadership and alliances. The Prime Minister is aware of the importance of the transatlantic relationship and the deep ties that bind Europe and the United States. The next President will have to work towards maintaining these ties and ensuring that the relationship continues to be strong and cooperative. The policies that come from Washington are important, and I’m confident that whoever follows me will work with allies like the UK to uphold these vital relationships.

Thank you for your question. Let me address the two parts of your inquiry.

Regarding the Middle East conference, our priority is to secure stability and peace in the region. The United States is working closely with our partners to create a framework that is conducive to meaningful peace talks. We are committed to the principles of the Middle East Quartet, which include a vision of two states living side by side in peace and security. The success of any conference would depend on the willingness of all parties to engage in honest and constructive dialogue towards a peaceful solution. We are hopeful that with the right circumstances and a commitment to peace from all involved, a conference can take place. However, we must be realistic about the challenges and the need for all parties, including President Arafat, to be ready to take the steps necessary for a just and lasting peace.

As for your question about Iraq, the regime of Saddam Hussein has been a threat to the peace and security of the Middle East, and the international community has repeatedly expressed its concern over his weapons of mass destruction programs, his defiance of United Nations resolutions, and his brutal repression of his own people. The aim is to disarm Iraq of weapons of mass destruction and to promote the emergence of a democratic Iraq that will never again pose a serious threat to its neighbors or the world. The United States has tried to work within the United Nations system to compel Iraq to comply with its obligations under numerous Security Council resolutions. We will continue to work with our allies and the international community to achieve a peaceful resolution, but we have also not ruled out the option of military action as the last resort to deal with a threat that cannot be contained within the confines of international diplomacy. Our aim is to promote a world where all nations, including those of the Middle East, can live in peace and freedom.

Thank you for the question. Keeping America safe is always my top priority, and finding the right balance to enhance our security and preserve the effectiveness of our law enforcement agencies is critical.

Regarding the recommendations for intelligence reform, I am committed to ensuring that our efforts are focused on protecting the American people and our interests at home and abroad. This includes strengthening our intelligence community and making sure that all relevant agencies are well-coordinated and effective in their work.

I will work closely with members of Congress and leaders from the various agencies to consider thoughtful, comprehensive reforms based on a careful analysis of what's required to ensure our country remains secure. This process will include thoughtful discussions with professionals like the FBI agents and other members of the intelligence community, as well as oversight bodies.

Any proposal that comes forward will strive to balance the need for effective counterterrorism measures with the necessity of maintaining civil liberties. I will also seek input from the public and bipartisan support from both the legislative and executive branches to ensure that the reforms are well-considered and effective.

It is indeed the role of the White House to provide strong leadership in such matters. This will involve cooperation with key stakeholders to implement common-sense reforms that improve coordination and enhance our nation's security posture.

Well, first of all, I appreciate the question. I made my judgment on Vladimir Putin based on my conscience, looking into his eyes and my gut, and there was an inherent goodness in the Russian leader at that time. I believe that some of the decisions he's made since to support regimes like Syria and Iran's nuclear programs are inconsistent with the principles of freedom and stability that we in the West hold dear. It is concerning that Russia would consider supplying weapons and nuclear components to these regimes, because they are outlaws that are sworn enemies of freedom and stability.

During our upcoming meeting, my goal will be to discuss strategies to ensure peace and stability in the Middle East, and to encourage Russia to engage productively in resolving regional conflicts. We will also be making it very clear that we believe a regime like Iran's does not deserve nuclear capabilities, and that providing nuclear components to that regime would be contrary to global security.

Our approach with Russia remains constructive yet firm, working to align our shared interests where possible and addressing differences openly and responsibly. It is essential that we continue to hold Russia accountable to international norms, and to work towards a peaceful and secure world for all.

Thank you for your question. The protocols in place are designed to ensure the safety and security of the United States, including the President and our nation's capital. On that particular day, there was a situation involving a small aircraft that inadvertently entered restricted airspace. The military responded appropriately and effectively to secure our skies.

In the context of that specific incident, I was not notified because it quickly became clear that there was not an imminent threat to the White House or my safety. The authorities were able to address the situation swiftly, and the protocols were in place to allow them to maintain security without interrupting my recreational activities.

However, I understand the importance of being informed on matters of national security, and the protocols are reviewed and adjusted as necessary to reflect evolving circumstances and threats. Going forward, it is my intention to ensure that I am fully informed of any potential threats, directly or through my team, and that the balance between maintaining security while ensuring that the President is kept aware of significant situation developments is achieved. If an incident were to occur that did pose a credible threat to me, the White House, or national security, I would expect and demand to be notified immediately.

Thank you for your question. The goal of the "standing up" the Iraqi forces has been a central pillar of our strategy in Iraq. We have indeed made significant progress in training and equipping Iraqi security forces. This is a key component of our efforts to ensure stability in Iraq and transition responsibility off our shoulders to those who are capable of maintaining peace and security in their own country.

Iraqi forces have grown in both numbers and capability. They now encompass the Iraqi Army, National Police, Border Enforcement Units, and local police forces, all of whom have taken on a larger and more active role in counterterrorism operations, humanitarian missions, and elections support. These forces are more capable of securing their own nation and are becoming more experienced in doing so.

However, it's important to note that the stabilization and security situation in Iraq is complex and requires continued effort, both from Iraqi forces and coalition support. The enemy we face is trying to instill an atmosphere of terror and undermine the progress Iraq has made towards a stable and democratic society. This requires a continued coalition presence, which provides Iraqi forces with expertise and direct support as they tackle security challenges.

The drawdown of U.S. forces is based on ongoing assessments of the security situation on the ground and the readiness of our Iraqi partners to take the lead in maintaining order and combating terrorism. The figures on Iraqi troops continue to be significant, but the capability and readiness to lead operations is even more critical. As Iraqis become more capable, we will be able to further adjust our forces and continue the drawdown in accordance with how the situation evolves.

We remain committed to helping Iraq become a stable and secure nation that can protect its citizens and contribute to regional stability. The progress is there, but caution and vigilance are warranted to ensure that the security improvements are sustainable and lead to a more peaceful and democratic Iraq.

Thank you for the question. As president, I appreciate the insights provided by former United Nations Ambassador John Bolton as well as other members of our international community who bring their expertise and perspectives. However, we took the step of engaging with North Korea to halt their nuclear weapons capabilities and to try to achieve nuclear non-proliferation in the region, goals that align with our national security interests and those of our allies.

Concerning the deal and the lifting of sanctions, we believe that carefully calibrated financial pressure helped bring North Korea to the negotiating table. It was important to ease that pressure in exchange for concrete steps toward denuclearization, which North Korea committed to do in our Singapore joint statement and subsequent commitments. The deal seeks to verify and implement those commitments. We remain vigilant to ensure that North Korea follows through on its promises and that the commitments made are honored.

We also maintain the flexibility to reimpose sanctions or take other measures in coordination with our allies if North Korea fails to live up to its responsibilities under the agreement. Our goals are to achieve a different future for North Korea and the Korean Peninsula, one where peace and security prevail, and where we can build a relationship founded on trust and mutual interests. We believe that by working closely with our partners and maintaining a firm stance, we can achieve real progress in this critical endeavor.

Thank you for the question. The selection of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is a significant decision and one that is always made with the best interests of our national security in mind. General Pace, as you rightly pointed out, has provided extraordinary service to our country throughout his distinguished career. I personally valued his counsel and his devotion to duty, and it was not an easy decision to see him leave.

As for the dynamics between the White House, the Military, and the Congress, I believe we have a strong relationship built on mutual respect and the common goal of supporting our troops and defending our nation. It's important to note that the confirmation process is not solely about politics. It's about ensuring that the person in this critical role has the full confidence of both the President and members of Congress. It's a joint effort to identify a qualified leader who can represent the Joint Chiefs to the administration and to Congress effectively.

General Pace faced no opposition that would be characterized as a "bruising battle" and I think his departure is mostly from reaching the end of his term of service, which is actually in line with the tradition of military appointments and the practice of bringing new leadership in from time to time. This change presents an opportunity to bring in fresh perspectives and new ideas, while still maintaining continuity of leadership. Our Armed Forces are strong and the transition to a new Chairman is one that will continue to support our military's mission to protect and defend our nation.

Firstly, the United States is not involved in the day-to-day decisions and policies of companies operating in Iraq or other countries. Decisions about contracts and international business dealings are between the companies themselves and the host countries or regions. The Hunt Oil deal in Iraq you mentioned is a matter for Iraqi parties to resolve, as the Iraqis hold the primacy in such matters. The central government and the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) are the right parties to negotiate and resolve such issues based on mutual benefit and respect for existing laws and agreements.

As for the broader topic of oil revenue sharing, I continue to support an arrangement that ensures equitable distribution and management of Iraq's vast resources, which would be beneficial to the country's stability and progress. The U.S. encourages all parties in Iraq to reach a consensus on oil legislation that respects the law and benefits all the Iraqi people.

Regarding your mention of criticism from Baghdad, I believe it is necessary for all parties in Iraq to engage in constructive dialogue to resolve any disputes over these matters in a manner that is equitable and just. We urge the Iraqi leadership to focus on national unity and prosperity as they continue to seek resolution in ongoing negotiations.

Mr. Bongiorno, the issue of troop withdrawals is one that I take very seriously. Each country must consider the best course of action for their own national security and commitments. Australia's commitment to democratic efforts in Iraq is appreciated. While I expressed concerns about the timing of withdrawals, I respect the decision made by Prime Minister Rudd's government. My comments about past Prime Ministers were meant to reflect the solid commitment that Australia has shown in the global fight for freedom. As for Prime Minister Rudd, it is clear that he also possesses a strong sense of responsibility for Australia's interests.

Well, first of all, the peace process between the Israelis and Palestinians has always faced challenges and obstacles, and it's the job of leaders to work to overcome those obstacles in pursuit of a just and lasting peace. The situation can be complex, and we need to support our Israeli allies and others who are working towards a peaceful coexistence.

Regarding the settlements in the West Bank and Jerusalem, my administration made it clear that the settlement issue is an important element in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and we have encouraged Israel to find ways to help advance the peace process despite these challenges. The continued growth of settlements has been a point of contention and a hindrance to the peace process; therefore, it remains crucial for all parties involved to address these issues constructively as part of any comprehensive peace deal.

We have consistently called on both sides to take meaningful steps towards reconciliation and to avoid actions that could undermine peace efforts, as well as to engage in direct negotiations that lead to the resolution of core issues such as security, borders, Jerusalem, and refugees. Achieving peace requires the commitment of all parties and the international community to support efforts conducive to a peaceful, stable, and secure Middle East.

As we approach the end of my administration, we remain hopeful that we can contribute positively to the pursuit of a negotiated solution that addresses the needs of both Israelis and Palestinians, fulfilling our aspirations for peace and security in the region.

Thank you for your question. The issue of whether or not to remove North Korea from the list of State Sponsors of Terrorism is a serious and complex matter. It involves a thorough review of the status and activities of North Korea to ensure that they meet the criteria for removal as laid out by the laws of the United States. This review takes into account various factors, including steps taken by the North Korean regime toward international nonproliferation goals and the cessation of activities that contributed to their designation as a State Sponsor of Terrorism.

The path to removal also requires a commitment to the complete, verifiable, and irreversible dismantlement of their nuclear program in accordance with the 2005 Joint Statement of the Six-Party Talks. Additionally, the designation removal process must be supported by cooperating nations and be reflective of United States foreign policy objectives in the region.

There has been progress with North Korea in some areas, leading to diplomatic initiatives, but the removal from the terrorism list cannot be done in a vacuum. The conditions laid out in the legislation governing the State Sponsors of Terrorism list—12 USC §2551 et seq.—must be fully satisfied, and we must also consider the safety and security interests of the United States and our allies, especially given the threats posed by North Korea's weaponry programs.

Our administration is committed to advancing peace in the region and ensuring that North Korea abides by its commitments. We will continue to work with international partners to ensure that any changes in status align with our national security interests and are supported by concrete actions from North Korea. We will keep the American people informed as developments occur and decisions are made regarding North Korea's status on the State Sponsors of Terrorism list.

Thank you for your questions.

Firstly, regarding the deployment of defensive technologies that have not been fully tested, I understand the concerns from some folks in the U.S. and around the world. However, we have to move with urgency in light of the threats that our country and our allies face - the need to protect the American people and our friends and allies is a vital part of my leadership and, if I have to act to deploy these systems, I will.

As for the second part, my commitment is to the security of the American people and ensuring that we maintain robust missile defense capabilities. The Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (ABM Treaty) was an important agreement in its time, but the world has changed since its signing. We must keep abreast of these changes and adapt our defenses and agreements accordingly.

To address threats, we need to explore and develop effective missile defense technologies. The limitations imposed by the ABM Treaty could hinder our ability to do so; therefore, I will work to ensure that America can pursue these advancements without unnecessary constraints. When it comes to missile defense, the urgency of the issue requires us to act in a way that ensures our security and that of our allies, even if that means working within or revising the current framework of treaties and agreements.

Thank you for your question, and I look forward to continuing our efforts to enhance our security in a thoughtful and responsible manner.

Thank you, Nihal, for your question. It is important to remember the historical context and the United States' long-standing position on this issue. The United States has consistently maintained that Israeli settlement activity is inconsistent with previous agreements and is misguided, and that it is a tragic mistake. We oppose the construction of Israeli settlements because it is bad for peace.

Israel has suffered a severe and understandable security concern emanating from the Palestinians in the territories, and that's why Palestinians need to understand that they must fill their obligation to act against terror.
