Palestinian leadership has to fulfill its obligation to act against terror, and at the same time, Israel agrees to refrain from actions that harm the peace process and that undermines confidence in reaching peace.

Therefore, our administration reiterates that we support Israel's right to defend itself and its citizens, while also calling on Israel to refrain from actions that could prejudge the outcome of final status negotiations or undermine the two-state solution. As President, I encourage both sides to return to the negotiating table with a renewed sense of purpose and a commitment to achieve a lasting peace based on two democratic states, Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace and security.

During discussions with Prime Minister Berlusconi and other allied leaders, the issue of the international community taking the lead in Iraq's reconstruction and security was indeed a point of conversation. Italy played a significant role in the coalition efforts, and we discussed the various responsibilities different countries could take on as we transitioned to a more international-led approach in Iraq.

Our administration believes that countries that may not have participated in the military coalition can still play a vital role in the reconstruction of Iraq and should be able to contribute to the peacekeeping efforts and rebuilding process. The President was committed to fostering international cooperation to ensure the stability and prosperity of Iraq. We worked with our NATO allies and others to develop a multinational force that would help stabilize Iraq after we reduced our military presence there.

The overall objective was to establish a secure and stable environment in which the Iraqi people could rebuild their country. This would require contributions from numerous nations, highlighting the importance of wide-ranging cooperation and partnership between different countries around the world in supporting Iraq through its reconstruction and transition to self-governance.

Good afternoon. Thank you for your questions.

Regarding the groups we have labeled as terrorists in Colombia, our commitment to security in Colombia is unwavering. We will continue to support the Colombian government in its efforts to combat terrorism and violence, including those groups that threaten the stability and sovereignty of Colombia. We stand firm against any individuals and organizations that resort to violence to achieve their political goals.

The peace process underway in Colombia is a crucial step toward lasting peace and prosperity. As we have seen with similar efforts in other countries, a comprehensive approach that includes addressing the root causes of conflict, providing economic opportunities, and guaranteeing security is essential. We support efforts that promote justice and reconciliation to ensure the sustainable peace in Colombia.

President Uribe and I have discussed the Free Trade Agreement (FTA) several times. I want to be clear that our commitment to strengthening the strategic partnership between the United States and Colombia is strong. We believe that a ratified FTA will provide significant benefits for both countries, especially for our farmers by opening up new opportunities in the Colombian market. We are committed to working together, including addressing farmers' concerns, to find solutions that strengthen our economic ties.

We appreciate the support of Congress in considering the FTA and look forward to continuing our discussions on this and other issues as we work together to promote prosperity and security in the region.

Well, first of all, I welcome the dialogue. And I think it's important for the American people to understand that filibustering judges is a new phenomenon. It is a significant change in the way the Senate has traditionally confirmed judges. And I do believe, if there is a change in the way judges are confirmed, it's the Democrats who brought about that change.

Now, as to the nominees themselves, we've put some very fine people forward to serve in the federal courts. It's a very important part of the agenda, because you see, the courts will set policy when the legislative body is not acting -- that's what they do. If you look at the history of our country, you can see many different policy issues that have been determined in courtrooms rather than in Congress.

And therefore, it is vital for me to put people in judgeships that understand that their job is to interpret law and Constitution, not to legislate from the bench. And I'm optimistic that many of the nominees who have been held up in the Senate will be confirmed.

As to which is more important, judges or my agenda, they are both important. I believe in an agenda that expands freedom, that encourages economic growth, that proactively deals with the nation's needs on energy, on defense, and of course, education and health care. It's also important for folks to understand that the legislative agenda and the judicial agenda, while both important, they hold different responsibilities when it comes to the courts. The courts are, again, the ones that have set policy when the legislative body is not acting.

And for that reason, it's extremely important to have judges that reflect the Constitution and the laws, not personal agendas. I want to work with Democrats to get judges confirmed, and I urge them to reexamine their position on filibustering federal judges. I'm pleased that there is an opportunity for dialogue, but the American people expect us to do our duty. They expect us to put aside politics and do what's right, and that is to confirm the excellent people we've put forward to serve in the federal bench.

First of the matter, the question of a left-leaning leader in Mexico: Mexico is a sovereign nation, and like any democratic society, its people have the right to elect a leader of any political persuasion. Mexico's electoral outcomes reflect the will of its citizens. As for the broader implications of left-leaning leadership in Latin America, the United States has worked and continues to work with a variety of governments in the region to foster stability, economic opportunities, and cooperation against common threats.

Regarding the second part of your question, managing the southern border and ensuring national security is indeed a complex and multi-faceted challenge. The United States has taken steps to improve the security of our borders, and cooperative efforts with Mexico have been a crucial part of this. Illicit activities, including the movement of individuals attempting to cross the border illegally or the trafficking of contraband and drug smuggling, pose significant security concerns.

We have made progress through programs like Operation Rio Grande, reinforcing our border security, and partnering with Mexico to address shared security challenges. We firmly believe that a secure and well-managed border is in the national interest of both the U.S. and Mexico.

We continue to support a smart, coordinated approach that balances the need for security with a humane and effective immigration system. We have also emphasized the importance of addressing the root causes of migration through economic development, political stability, and tackling corruption in Mexico and Central America.

Do you have any further questions on these topics or others related to the region and our foreign policy?

Thank you for your questions, and I appreciate your thoughtfulness in bringing this up. From the very first day in office, I made it clear that I wanted to work across the aisle, to work together, to find common ground, and to show the American people that we could rise above partisanship and work for the good of the country. And there are many examples of where we've done that. We passed a jobs bill -- a jobs and trade bill that had bipartisan support. We've also won approval for a Medicare prescription drug benefit, which became law with vast majorities from both political parties.

Regarding the issues you've mentioned, it's important to understand the dynamics of our political system. I respect the opinions of Democrats and have had many conversations with them to reach compromises and achieve productive legislation. That said, there are times when, as President, I must stand firm for my convictions and work to secure my agenda, which is grounded in bipartisan principles.

John Bolton's confirmation as Ambassador to the United Nations was a matter of foreign policy and the statement of our values in the world. I believe that he is the right person for the job and I'm confident that he will be confirmed by the Senate. As for Tom DeLay, I'm not going to weigh in on legal matters or issues being handled by the Justice Department, but I believe in the rule of law and that any American who has a disagreement with an accusation should have their day in court.

On the matter of federal judges, it's been important for me that we have judges that are fair and not politicized. We've signed on bipartisan efforts to confirm judicial nominees, but I will not back down from my duty to nominate judges who I believe will interpret the Constitution, not legislate from the bench.

Regarding Social Security and energy legislation, I want to remind you that this Administration has a track record of working with Congress to pass important, bipartisan legislation. My plan for Social Security reform is aimed at preserving the program for future generations, and the energy bill will help reduce our dependence on foreign oil and promote clean, modern technologies.

In conclusion, while disagreements can arise, the goal of any President must be to work with all members of Congress to achieve what's best for the American people. We're committed to a positive working relationship while standing firm on our principles. Thank you for your questions, and I hope you can see the Administration's commitment to bridging divides and accomplishing our agenda.

Well, you know, I'm someone who takes these matters very seriously. I campaigned on the promise to improve the integrity of the White House, to demand high standards and to set the right example. I have directed my staff and the White House counsel to fully cooperate with any investigation into these matters.

We've got one of the finest ethics officers we've ever had in our administration, and I have zero tolerance for misconduct. I've asked my staff to do the right thing, to cooperate fully, and I've asked the ethics officer and the inspector general to investigate these matters. If anyone has done anything wrong, they will be held accountable.

As far as throwing open the books, we've encouraged full transparency. We want to accommodate the investigations to the best of our ability. But ultimately, this is a matter for Congress to investigate. We will provide the necessary information to the authorities as they collaborate and look into these issues. However, I will not compromise our constitutional separation of powers between the legislative and executive branches of government.

This is a complex situation. We're committed to getting to the bottom of it and ensuring that even the appearance of impropriety is not tolerated within our administration. I deeply care about the trust of the American people and the integrity of the White House, and we are actively working to maintain and restore that.

Thank you for the questions. Yes, I have been briefed on the incident involving unauthorized access by a foreign government to networks within the Department of Defense. These actions are very serious, and I have no doubt that Chinese officials know better than to attempt such things. I will raise this issue with President Hu Jintao in our discussions, emphasizing that we expect every nation to respect the sovereignty of others, including in the realm of cyber security. This incident does add to the complexity of our relationship, but it doesn't change the need for cooperation between our two countries on issues like global security, economic trends, and climate change. We remain committed to peaceful and constructive relations, yet we will also be clear about the consequences of actions that undermine the mutual trust necessary for such a relationship.

Thank you for the question. As I mentioned earlier, maintaining stability in financial markets and ensuring that the economic foundations remain solid are critical. In discussing specific entities such as General Motors, the approach really depends on the unique circumstances and challenges that they face.

When we're talking about systemically important financial institutions that are also operating in the real economy like GM, the government's role must be focused on promoting responsible lending and borrowing and ensuring that the institutions themselves take action to strengthen their balance sheets and business models. Government intervention in the form of direct support or investment is generally considered only under extreme circumstances where failure of such an entity could have widespread negative economic impacts.

We are determined to help American companies make adjustments and remain competitive in the global market. Government and private sector must work together to find solutions whenever possible, but our ultimate goal is to have businesses that can thrive independently without government support. We are encouraging constructive adjustments within the auto industry, including promoting research and development in alternative technologies, which not only enhances competitiveness but also helps to secure America’s energy future. We want to see the auto sector continue to serve as a cornerstone of our economy, but under sustainable conditions.

In the meantime, we continue to monitor the situation closely and will take necessary actions to maintain stability and foster continued recovery of our economy.

Thank you for the question. I understand that many Americans are concerned about what the future holds and how we will respond to this national tragedy. We certainly ask for the nation to go back to business in a practical sense, which means our economy must continue to function, government services must be maintained, and schools must remain open.

However, we are certainly facing a new reality. It's not a return to life as it was on September 10th; we've experienced a tragic and transformative incident that will affect us for a long time. The courage and unity we saw over the past weeks are a sign of the strength and resolve of the American people. It is through this unity that we will move forward and protect the future of our country.

This is a time for resolve, not panic. It is a time for courage, not fear. As President, I have called upon the American people to continue their lives and routines not out of a belief that everything is back to normal, but out of a determination to face this challenge together. We've asked for assistance from law enforcement, which requires an effort from many, and we've called upon the American people to watch for suspicious activities and report them to the authorities.

In the meantime, we will continue to engage the enemy overseas in the war and protect the homeland as necessary. We do not anticipate needing to call for sacrifices beyond the efforts already being made. For now, I ask for the people of the United States to join me in prayer for those who have suffered and those who have the difficult jobs of protecting our country and defending freedom.

We will get through this time together, as a strong and united nation. America will, in this dark hour, emerge stronger and more confident than ever.

Thank you for your question. The relationship between the United States and Europe is founded on shared values, democratic institutions, and a common commitment to freedom and security. While there are certainly honest differences of opinion on the best approach to certain global challenges such as terrorism, our nations share a goal of promoting peace and stability around the world.

As you pointed out, the transatlantic community has had debates about the best way to address political and economic issues that contribute to global instability. The United States believes that addressing the underlying conditions that give rise to terrorism is important, as we work alongside our European allies in promoting democracy and economic prosperity in troubled regions.

Regarding military solutions, the United States occasionally takes a leadership role in the defense of freedom when international consensus doesn't immediately form. For example, in Iraq, we worked hard to build an international coalition, and we have found strong support from many European partners and countries like Poland.

Trade is another area where we see ongoing dialogue and strong cooperation with our European partners. We are committed to balanced economic policies and trade agreements that promote growth and competitiveness for both the United States and the global economy.

Regarding Poland's potential EU membership, we are pleased to see the progress they have made in aligning with European norms and standards. Poland's entry into the European Union is a positive development for both Poland and the European Union. It will further strengthen the transatlantic alliance by bringing a reliable and strong partner into the European community. We have every confidence that Poland's membership will complement and enhance the United States' relationship with Poland, not complicate it.

The United States and Poland have enjoyed a strong and important relationship, and we believe that Poland's membership in the EU will only serve to deepen and broaden our shared interests in the world. We are committed to working closely with Poland and the European Union to ensure these relationships continue to flourish and contribute to a more secure and prosperous world.

Mr. Robinson, I’d like to address the difficult emotions and concerns that you've raised. We are here today, alongside our British friends and allies, to reiterate the firm global partnership and the shared commitment to the security and prosperity of our people. America and Britain have stood side by side shouldering challenges together through the ages, and we will continue to work together to ensure that the values we hold dear, such as democracy and freedom, prevail.

As for the protests, I understand that in a free society, citizens have the right to assemble and express their views. This is part of the democratic process that we uphold and encourage around the world. For those who have concerns about my visit, I hope they understand that our visit was aimed at addressing serious issues about the world's security and stability and that we share the goal of a safer and more peaceful world for all people.

It’s important to acknowledge that opinions will vary, and that's a natural part of a free society. As for why some may feel opposed to America or me personally, it's a complex issue that often arises from misunderstandings, differing views, and sometimes the aggressive actions of extremists who use violence to draw attention to their causes.

My message to all the people of Britain is clear: we value the friendship between our nations, and America is committed to Britain's well-being and the safety of our citizens. We are here as friends and allies, and we will continue to work together for the common good.

Thank you for your question. As we work towards peace in the Middle East, my administration values our close ties with the government of Israel. We have been clear that we support a two-state solution where Israelis and Palestinians can live side by side in peace and security.

Regarding settlements, the United States has always recognized the importance of the settlement issue as a matter of negotiation between the Israelis and the Palestinians. We believe that direct negotiations between the parties are the best way to resolve such issues, on the basis of the Roadmap for peace and the long-standing principles of the international community.

As to your question regarding the Ariel settlement, the United States has made no final decisions on the borders or status of Ariel. We believe these issues need to be resolved through direct negotiations. Our policy has been to urge all parties to continue good-faith negotiations aimed at reaching a final and comprehensive settlement that addresses the interests and concerns of both sides.

It's important to recognize that the peace process is complex and involves many parties with differing perspectives. We have supported steps that bring Israelis and Palestinians closer to a peaceful resolution while acknowledging that compromises will be necessary from all sides. Our objective remains a lasting peace agreement that will ensure the security, prosperity, and dignity of both Israelis and Palestinians.

Thank you for your question, and I hope this clarifies our position on this important issue.

Thank you for your question. The relationship between the United States and the European Union is indeed an important bilateral dynamic and one that we continue to build and strengthen. The summit between the U.S. and the EU is part of ongoing efforts to enhance cooperation in areas of common interest, including foreign policy and security.

While NATO remains the primary forum for transatlantic security cooperation, the EU-U.S. partnership does offer a valuable platform for addressing a broad range of issues, from trade and climate to foreign policy and defense. This partnership supplements NATO's mission, rather than replacing it. We value the unique contributions that both NATO and EU-U.S. cooperation make to our shared security and stability.

The meetings and dialogues that take place between the U.S. and the EU are not meant to undermine or replace NATO; rather, they aim to enhance our ability to address the full spectrum of challenges we face in a rapidly changing global environment. The U.S. and the EU work together bilaterally and multilaterally to advance our common interests and uphold our shared values.

I believe this summit has reinforced our commitment to maintaining a strong and resilient alliance that reflects the evolving security landscape and the interdependence of our nations in the 21st century. While history marks many important milestones, our focus remains on the present and the future, ensuring that we effectively address the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead.

Thank you for your question. The United States has long held the position that it is essential for all parties to exercise restraint and work toward a peaceful resolution of the Kashmir dispute. While I cannot unilaterally make declarations on the Line of Control or restate specific policies, I would affirm the general principle that each side must respect the sanctity of the Line of Control and refrain from actions that could escalate tensions or violate agreements.

The United States has been and continues to be committed to the promotion of peace and stability in South Asia. U.S. policy supports a negotiated and peaceful resolution to disputes in the region, which includes the concerns regarding the Line of Control. We hope and encourage dialogue and cooperation between all relevant parties to achieve lasting peace and security for the people of Kashmir and South Asia as a whole.

Thank you for your question. Reflecting on my time as President, I believe in giving credit where credit is due, and taking personal responsibility for mistakes. When it comes to the Iraq War, I have often spoken about the decision to go to war with Iraq in 2003, which was one of the most significant and consequential actions of my presidency. While I was convinced that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and posed a threat to the United States and its allies, subsequent intelligence revealed that was not the case. It is clear that I made a decision based on the best information available to me at the time, but I have learned that there's no substitute for having accurate and complete information.

From this experience, I have learned that making decisions with imperfect information can have serious consequences. It's essential to continuously gather and reassess intelligence and be open to new evidence as it comes to light. Additionally, it highlighted the importance of diplomatic efforts and ensuring broad support from the international community before taking military action.

Throughout my presidency, I have tried my best to serve the American people with integrity and a strong sense of responsibility. I have worked hard to learn from my experiences and to draw lessons that would help me be a better leader. We can never let go of the lessons we learn, as they serve to shape our future choices and actions.

Thank you for your question. I've always expressed that the United States desires to keep the peace and is a force for good in the world. We are concerned about the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and we've acted to prevent rogue regimes from having the ability to harm the American people or our allies.

Regarding the perception in Europe, I believe there can be a disconnect at times in how our decisions are perceived and what the actual intentions behind them are. Our intentions have been to strengthen international security and to prevent those who seek to do us and our friends harm from gaining dangerous weapons. We have worked through various international mechanisms and treaties to achieve these goals, recognizing the importance of global cooperation.

In all actions taken by the United States, we strive for consultation and alliances when possible. The American people and our government understand the importance of standing with our allies and upholding international law. We have sought to lead by example, pushing for democracy and respect for human rights.

If there are any regrets, my administration would reflect on how we can better communicate our actions and intentions to our friends and partners around the world, including Europe, to ensure a clearer understanding of our role and purpose. We want to continue to work towards a more stable and peaceful world, and cooperation is key to achieving that goal.

In addressing the matters of Iran, North Korea, and our relations with Russia, I would respond as follows:

On Iran, we have taken steps to address the issue of their nuclear program, which we are deeply concerned about. It's imperative that Iran does not develop nuclear weapons, as such a capability would be a dangerous threat to the security of the world, including Russia. We have engaged in diplomatic efforts, and I discussed the matter with President Putin at the G8 meeting earlier this week. The United States believes that the UN Security Council bears the responsibility to work to apply the necessary pressure. We will continue to work with our friends and allies, including Russia, to mobilize the international community against a nuclear-armed Iran. Should Iran fail to address international concerns, we would pursue additional steps and coordinate with other nations on options available, including working through the UN Security Council.

Regarding North Korea, we have also worked on the denuclearization of that region. North Korea's nuclear program is no less of a threat. We continue to press for their adherence to the denuclearization commitments made in the Six-Party Talks, and we actively pursue conversations with Russia, among others, to align efforts and urge North Korea to cease its provocative behavior.

President Putin and I discussed a range of issues pertaining to these and other global challenges. Russia has indicated its commitment to cooperation on these matters, and they have joined us in calling for Iran to address international concerns over its nuclear program in a transparent manner. As for the specific commitment on sanctions, Russia has demonstrated flexibility when it comes to dealing with countries of proliferation concern. However, it is our collective responsibility to ensure that these nations act in accordance with international norms and the Security Council's resolutions.

We will continue to work with Russia and other nations to find peaceful and cooperative solutions that address these issues, uphold the integrity of the non-proliferation regime, and maintain stability and peace in the region and around the world.

Thank you for your question. It's important to note that the United States continues to have serious concerns about Iran's activities in Iraq and elsewhere in the region. Our intelligence assessments and information are continually evaluated as new facts come to light. It's possible that some of the disparity you're seeing is the result of ongoing intelligence operations and the analysis of information as it becomes available.

The statements that you're referring to, ranging from the ones made by U.S. officials in Baghdad to my own or those of my administration, all reflect where our understanding stands at that particular moment. It's not uncommon for details and our assessments to evolve as we gather more data and intelligence.

We will continue to seek hard evidence and make clear our concerns to the Iranian government about their activities in Iraq and the broader region. We have not ruled out the possibility that senior Iranian officials could be involved in these activities, but it's also clear that we cannot take any action based on speculation alone. Our goal remains to counter any external influence that might undermine the sovereignty and security of Iraq.

Good morning. First, let me thank you for the opportunity to discuss these important matters. As for Hugo Chavez's suggestion, I will continue to speak about our concerns regarding Venezuela and his government. Being direct and straightforward in our interactions is how we build a positive relationship that protects American interests.

As for how much of a threat Hugo Chavez is to U.S. interests in the hemisphere, I believe that having a neighbor who funds terrorist organizations, helps the leaders of Cuba resist reforms, and is a negative force in terms of spreading democracy and freedom is a cause for us to speak clearly.

Regarding President Vazquez's situation in Uruguay, I appreciate him trying to broaden ties to the United States through trade, and I understand the delicate position that he is in as he seeks to balance his interests with those of his South American neighbors. I believe it's important that we continue to work together, to support democratic institutions and economic freedom in the Western Hemisphere.

Trade is not just about trade pacts; it's about sharing the spirit of freedom and democracy. We want to build ties with leaders who endorse change, democracy, and an environment for enterprise to flourish. Uruguayan leaders, like President Vazquez, are making a positive difference in their region by working towards these values.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address these serious concerns.

First, let me reaffirm that we are committed to working with Russia and President Putin in those areas where our interests align. However, we also recognize that there are serious concerns regarding the transparency and accountability of Russia's management of sensitive materials. We take these concerns seriously and will continue to work with international partners to ensure that proliferation does not occur. We need to maintain vigilance in global efforts to monitor and control the spread of weapons of mass destruction and the materials needed to produce them.

Regarding the commitment to democracy, we acknowledge that there are concerns about the overall trajectory of democracy and the rule of law in Russia under President Putin's leadership. We believe that the development of freedom and democracy is important for Russia's future, as well as for the stability and prosperity of the global community. While we have engaged in dialogue with Russia about these issues, we also make clear that upholding democratic values and human rights is essential for a constructive partnership and for international respect.

As we continue to engage with Russia, we will advocate for policies that encourage transparency, accountability, and democratic governance, while also working collaboratively on common goals that can benefit both our nations and the world at large. This includes maintaining strong channels of communication and cooperation on a range of international issues, while speaking out explicitly about our concerns when necessary.

I appreciate the question, but I would assert that our trade policies are not driven by election strategy but rather by our commitment to both the economic prosperity of the American people and the principles of fair and reciprocal trade with our partners around the world. The decisions we make regarding trade with China, the value of the dollar, and our stance on the steel industry are part of a broader approach to ensuring that the United States remains competitive in the global marketplace.

Firstly, on the China trade quotas, these measures have been taken to address unfair trade practices and to protect American jobs, rather than being aimed at boosting election prospects. It is important to recognize that trade should be fair and mutually beneficial for all parties involved.

Secondly, the value of the dollar can be influenced by a wide array of economic factors including supply and demand dynamics in foreign exchange markets, interest rates, inflation expectations, and other macroeconomic conditions rather than being solely controlled for political purposes.

Regarding our disagreement with the WTO on the steel issue, we acted to protect an important U.S. industry from overwhelming imports that were being sold below fair market value, which threatened jobs and businesses across the country. The safeguards put in place were designed to ensure that domestic manufacturers could compete on a level playing field and did not represent a departure from our commitment to free trade.

Overall, my administration's policies aim to support a robust U.S. economy and ensure that international trade rules are fair and reflect the needs and interests of the American people. Our goal is to strengthen the economic foundation of our country and ensure that all Americans have the opportunity to prosper in a globalized world.

Thank you for your questions. We've worked closely with Iraq's interim government in its efforts to stand up a transitional government that was representative and inclusive of all Iraqis. The letter exchange between the Coalition Provisional Authority and the new Iraqi Transitional Government was a significant step towards sovereignty, as it established the framework for the transfer of authority.

The Iraqi people are taking responsibility for their country's destiny, and we commend their leadership for their efforts to establish a new government. This is an important step forward as we continue to work together to build a free, prosperous, and peaceful Iraq that is an example for the rest of the Middle East.

As for President Chirac's views on full sovereignty and the new U.N. resolution, I would defer to him for his direct response, but I would refer you to our ongoing discussions and efforts in the international community to support Iraq's path to democratic governance and stability.

Efforts are underway to develop policies and work through the United Nations to ensure a constructive relationship between Iraq and the international community as the Iraqi people move towards their promised elections.

I appreciate the question, and I believe it's important for us to consider the moral and legal implications of these issues. Our nation has made it very clear that the United States does not torture. We adhere to the rule of law and to our country's values. I signed Executive Order 13491 [it's important to note here that George W. Bush left office on January 20, 2009, so as the former president, this EO wouldn't have been signed by him, but in addressing the hypothetical question as if it were during his presidency, he might have referenced previous policies], which explicitly prohibited "cruel, inhuman, and degrading treatment or punishment" of any individual in U.S. custody.

It's important that we protect our citizens from harm, and that's our fundamental duty as we engage in the war on terror. To protect the American people, we must confront the enemy effectively. However, this does not mean we justify actions that compromise our moral values and our respect for the rule of law.

Regarding the question of whether torture can ever be justified, it's worth noting that the legal definition and acceptable practices are set by laws and treaties that our country adheres to. Torture is not an appropriate means to obtain information, and any information obtained through torture is, in any case, inherently unreliable. I believe we must uphold the highest moral standards in our fight against terrorism, and this includes upholding the fundamental rights and dignity of every individual, even those who threaten our nation.

The actions that were discussed in the memos you mentioned were to ensure compliance with the law while dealing effectively with the serious threats against our country. It's critical that we respect and maintain the integrity of our laws while protecting our people. I understand that this is a complex and deeply ethical issue, and we must address it with care and a commitment to our shared values as a nation.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this with you. As you noted, in my speech to the German Parliament and in my broader diplomatic efforts, I have sought to reaffirm our commitment to the transatlantic relationship and build on the strong foundation of friendship and cooperation between the United States and Europe.

Regarding taking into account the perspectives of our European allies on international matters, this is indeed a priority for my administration. I believe that consultation, cooperation, and partnership are key to addressing the significant challenges that we face in today's world, from terrorism to nuclear proliferation. We have and will continue to seek their input and support.

On the specific issue of military action, particularly concerning sovereign nations like Iran, it is critical to underscore that the United States operates within the framework of international laws and norms. This includes our commitment to the United Nations Charter and the specific role of the United Nations Security Council in matters of international peace and security. Any actions by the United States would be consistent with our obligations under international law, including the important role of the Security Council.

It's also important to note that direct military strikes are not an automatic course of action, and we often pursue diplomacy, economic sanctions, and multilateral approaches as means of addressing international crises and security concerns. Engaging with our allies, including European nations, is a critical part of this process. We value the relationship with our allies and recognize that their views and contributions to addressing global challenges are vital.

Ultimately, our goal is to ensure a safer and more secure world, and we are committed to working with our friends and allies, including European nations, to achieve this objective through pragmatic and effective approaches to foreign policy.

I appreciate the question. I deeply respect the service of Major General Paul Eaton in our Armed Forces. I want to thank people who have served this country, and I will always do so.

With respect to the position of Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, I've had confidence in him. I've named him the Secretary of Defense because I believe in his abilities to carry out our strategy to defeat the terrorists and bring freedom to the greater Middle East. I am committed to the strategy of victory in Iraq, which is a key part of that broader strategy. We will defeat these terrorists, and we will pass the responsibility to the Iraqis, much as we have in Afghanistan to the Afghans.

We are making progress in Iraq. Progress can seem slow, but it is real. We're helping train Iraqi security forces so they can secure their own country. We're helping the Iraqi people on the path towards democracy.

My administration has a lot of advice to consider. I've asked others for their counsel, as well. I trust Donald Rumsfeld, I trust General David Petraeus, and I trust the men and women in the U.S. military to carry out our mission. The success in the region with the terrorists being on the run is the ultimate evidence that the strategy we have is working and that our military is superb. I don't think turning the strategy based on political advice is the right thing to do. We must see our mission through, and with continuing efforts we'll succeed in Iraq.

Thank you for your question. I understand the concerns that people have about Iraq and the broader war on terror. One of the challenges we faced in the lead-up to Operation Iraqi Freedom was the threat of weapons of mass destruction being in the hands of Saddam Hussein. We thought that he had those weapons and was not cooperating fully with the United Nations.

Yesterday, I was addressing the threat that remains from Al-Qaeda in Iraq, which is related to our ongoing efforts in the region. As Commander-in-Chief, it is my responsibility to provide the American people and our allies with accurate and timely information about these threats. We're dealing with a very complex situation, and it's important that we continue to address it with the seriousness it demands.

I believe I am a credible messenger because of my commitment to the security of our nation and to the accomplishments we've achieved in the war on terror thus far. The efforts we've made have disrupted terrorist networks, and we've kept the American people safe following the September 11th attacks. It's clear that there are skeptics and differing viewpoints, but my decisions are guided by what I believe is necessary to defend America.

We must continue to work together as a country to address the challenges we face and to support our troops who are working tirelessly to bring stability to Iraq and the broader region. Our goal remains to defeat our enemies and to leave a stable Iraq for a peaceful world.

Thank you for your question. Let me address both parts of it.

In terms of President Karzai's assessment of Iran's role in Afghanistan, I would note that our concerns about Iran's activities go beyond just those in Afghanistan. We are concerned about Iran's support for extremist groups, their proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and their sponsorship of terrorism. Our policy is clear: we are going to continue to press Iran to live up to its international obligations and to fulfill the commitments it has made. That being said, we are working with all nations, including our ally Afghanistan, to find ways to address these challenges.

Regarding the efforts to reduce civilian casualties in Afghanistan, we deeply appreciate President Karzai's commitment to minimizing harm to civilians. In our discussions, I expressed appreciation for his leadership and reinforced our commitment to take all steps necessary to protect civilians and abide by the laws of armed conflict. We have worked closely with the Afghan government to better target operations and reduce the risk to civilians. We will continue to address these sensitive issues in a constructive and cooperative way with the Afghan government to support the safety and security of all Afghan citizens.

I also would like to personally thank President Karzai for his partnership, and I look forward to continuing to work with him as we both focus on achieving a stable, prosperous, and peaceful Afghanistan.

I believe you've addressed a question more relevant to Mr. Putin. However, I'll address the aspect related to missile defense and the involvement of Poland and the Czech Republic. This missile defense system is about defending our allies and ourselves from long-range ballistic missiles -- it's not directed at any country. It's in keeping with our commitment to transparency to share information about the system with our allies and with the Russian Federation. We will continue to discuss the system with both Poland and the Czech Republic, aiming to ensure that they understand its purpose and benefits, just as we continue discussions with Russia to address any concerns they have about the system. It's important that all parties involved are informed and that we work towards a mutual understanding regarding this issue.

Thank you for your questions.

Firstly, we are pleased with the progress made in the ceasefire negotiations. Our goal is to ensure that agreements are upheld, and peace can be maintained in the region. We believe that diplomatic efforts are crucial in sustaining any progress made towards a peaceful resolution, and we are committed to supporting our allies and partners in the Middle East.

Regarding the involvement of Secretary of State Colin Powell, we will be considering our options and the needs of the situation. The Secretary of State plays a key role in our diplomacy and may travel to the region as necessary to support diplomatic efforts and ensure that all parties adhere to the terms of the ceasefire.

As for me traveling to the region, that would depend on several factors, including the stability of the situation, the prospects for further progress, and advice from my advisors. My commitment is to peace and security, and I would be ready to travel should it serve to advance those interests effectively.

We will continue to evaluate the situation and may make decisions on further involvement as circumstances evolve. Our ultimate objective is to promote long-term stability and cooperation in the interest of the United States, our partners, and the people of the Middle East.

Thank you for your question. We fully support the right of Israel – and all nations – to defend themselves from terror. The fence has been effective in preventing terror attacks in Israel, and that is something that we understand and respect.

However, when the fence runs inside Palestinian lands, it can complicate things and unfairly restrict the lives of Palestinians, including farmers, village leaders, and community members. We believe that Israel can use methods like roadblocks and checkpoints as a form of defense, maintaining security while still allowing people basic freedom of movement.

The United States is committed to working with all parties to find a way to help the Palestinians live in peace, while at the same time ensuring that Israel has the tools to protect its citizens from terror. We are not opposed to the concept of a separation fence per se, but we are concerned about its route and its impact on the Palestinian population.

We are working with each side to arrive at an agreement that respects the security needs of Israel and the rights of Palestinians. We are in consultations with Prime Minister Sharon, among others, to seek a viable resolution that balances these important considerations.

I appreciate the question on a topic that is of concern to many Americans and others around the world. In making the decision to remove Saddam Hussein from power, our administration acted based on the information and intelligence available to us at the time. The United States and its allies, including Nations of the United Nations, worked to eliminate Saddam Hussein's capacity to produce and use weapons of mass destruction, which posed a serious threat to the region and the broader international community.

We believed that Saddam Hussein was in possession of both chemical and biological weapons. This assessment was supported by a range of national intelligence services, not just those of the United States. We believed that our actions were necessary to protect the world from the threat that Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction posed. In the spring of 2003, after the major fighting had ended, inspectors were to more thoroughly examine Iraq for weapons of mass destruction. While to date they have not found weapons in stockpiles, our efforts to free Iraq from Saddam Hussein's tyranny — tyranny based on the will to possess and potentially use weapons of mass destruction — were all justified.

I understand that the absence of weapon stockpiles has raised questions and concerns. The intelligence community, as with any organization of its type, often deals with incomplete information and makes assessments based on the intelligence on hand — intelligence that is often hard to verify before it is acted upon. While it's not the result that was hoped for, our commitment to stopping the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction remains steadfast.

As we look to the future, the primary focus is on building a free and democratic Iraq, where the Iraqi people can determine their own destiny without the threat of weapons of mass destruction. This is in the best interest not only of Iraq but also of global peace and stability.

Regarding the credibility of my administration, it is important to note that the decision to go to war was made after careful deliberation and with the full support of Congress. The administration's commitment is to serve the American people and to uphold our national security. Challenges like these can be addressed by continuing to work together towards the goals we have set for Iraq and ensuring that the lessons learned from this experience are applied to future decisions.

Thank you for the opportunity to address these concerns. Our commitment to the Iraqi people and to the larger goal of a safer and more prosperous world continues.

Thank you for your question. The intelligence reports that we received prior to September 11th certainly were taken very seriously by our administration. As I mentioned at Fort Hood, the August 6th Presidential Daily Briefing warned of potential terrorist attacks in the United States. The briefers did not, however, connect the report to hijackings, which is certainly critical context to keep in mind.

Following that briefing, we initiated various actions to strengthen security measures. For example, following an intelligence update in the summer of 2001, we issued a National Security Directive that heightened security at various points, including airports, and we tasked the intelligence community to pay more attention to Al-Qaeda networks in the U.S. This directive did not specifically address the scenario of hijackings as a form of attack, but it did emphasize the need for heightened awareness across multiple sectors.

It's important to note that while we responded to the known threats and raised our overall alert level, no one in the federal government at the time, including me, could have anticipated aircraft being turned into weapons. The nature of the threat was unprecedented and our ability to predict exactly how it would unfold was limited.

We were working tirelessly to prevent any sort of attack against our nation and its citizens, and the National Security Council met frequently to review all threats and the measures in place to address them. Sadly, we did not intercept the specific plot that led to the attacks on September 11th.

The events of September 11th highlighted the need for a complete transformation of our intelligence community, and soon after those tragic attacks, we enacted comprehensive reforms to strengthen our homeland security and better prevent future acts of terrorism.

Thank you for the question. When it comes to fiscal responsibility, the administration has consistently advocated for responsible budgeting and fiscal restraint. I understand the importance of managing taxpayer dollars wisely and ensuring that government spending does not go unchecked. 

During my first term, there was indeed a focus on balancing the budget and ensuring that we lived within our means as a nation. While I did not veto any bills, it was also important to note that we achieved the first surplus in over 30 years in fiscal year 2000 and we were on a path to pay off the national debt in a decade. However, certain events, such as the economic downturn that followed the dot-com crash, and later the events of September 11th, impacted our ability to continue this trajectory easily.

For my second term, I am committed to fiscal discipline and reducing the deficit, while still funding the priorities of the American people and tackling the challenges our country faces. The administration will work closely with Congress to identify and implement budget savings wherever possible, and I believe a collaborative effort between the executive and legislative branches is essential.

As for vetoes, I will look at each bill carefully and make my decisions based on what best serves the American taxpayer and the principles of fiscal responsibility. I am committed to maintaining a strong defense and advancing other priorities, but every dollar must be accounted for and spent wisely.

It is important to note that trust funds are real money and have to be reported in a sensible way for accountability to the American people. I believe that with a strong commitment to reform and an open dialogue with Congress, we can make the tough decisions necessary to achieve a more responsible budget for the American people. Thank you for your question.

First off, I want to reaffirm my commitment to addressing the long-term challenges that Social Security faces while ensuring that we fulfill the benefit promises we have made to our seniors and to future generations. On Social Security reform, I've said that no options are off the table, and I've outlined a concept for personal retirement accounts that I believe is a constructive and responsible way to help keep Social Security solvent. 

Regarding the idea of possibly raising the cap on payroll taxes, I've indeed expressed that as one of the components we're considering in achieving long-term sustainability. However, it's important to understand that this is part of a larger discussion about addressing the insolvency issue. Unlike recent tax increases, such a change would be part of a comprehensive reform effort and not a tax hike in isolation.

I've pledged to uphold the principle of not raising taxes, but we're talking about structuring a more sustainable system for the future—there's a key difference there. The intention isn't to increase the overall tax burden, but to reform the system so that future generations will have the same promise of the Social Security system that we've enjoyed. This is about ensuring the economic security of America's senior citizens not just for today, but for tomorrow as well.

The option to raise the payroll tax cap to ensure the solvency of the program could be seen as a necessary compromise within a broader reform package, one that aims to safeguard the integrity of Social Security for an aging population and one where benefits are paid in full. We have to consider the implications for the long-term prosperity and financial security of Americans, and working toward the long-term solution of Social Security reform encompasses a variety of approaches that need to be balanced.

Thank you for your question. Maintaining the solidarity and commitment of the coalition in Iraq is a priority. The decrease in troop-contributing countries is a concern, but we appreciate the continued support of those who remain and are working together to build the capacity of Iraq to secure itself.

We've made significant progress with the recent creation of the Iraqi Transitional Government and the seating of the Iraqi Council of Representatives. Promoting further progress towards security and stability in Iraq is important, and as part of our strategy, we are building the capacity of the Iraqi Security Forces so that they can shoulder the responsibility for their own security.

We have long stated that as the Iraqis stand up, we will stand down. The progress we have seen in training and equipping Iraqi Security Forces and other steps towards a stable political process provides a foundation on which we will make decisions about the pace of the transition of security responsibilities to Iraqis. However, it's important to make these decisions in consultation with our coalition partners and according to specific benchmarks that we've laid out.

The Iraqi people are entitled to security in their own country, and the United States, along with our coalition partners, will continue to work alongside the new Iraqi government to achieve that security. The ultimate goal is to create a stable and sovereign Iraq capable of protecting its citizens and serving as a constructive member of the international community. We are in a long-term commitment with the people of Iraq, and our coalition partners remain as committed as ever to this shared goal.

Thank you for that question. Good economic policy and fiscal responsibility are very important to putting our country’s finances on a sustainable path. The tax relief that we put in place was a crucial economic stimulus. To address your particular point about making the tax cuts permanent, I strongly believe in making them permanent. I’ve said this a lot for the past six years: tax relief is here to stay.

But it is important for members of Congress to be fiscally responsible, which is why I've been urging Members of Congress to be in a comprehensive budget resolution that will help set spending priorities and discipline discretionary spending. It requires serious choices on both sides of the budget ledger, especially since we're dealing with a deficit that's running at over $400 billion a year.

Balancing our desire to give tax relief to people with fiscal responsibility is the challenge before the Congress and the administration. We cannot be short-sighted with our nation's finances, but nor should we sacrifice growing the economy and providing economic opportunity for our citizens. That's really what our tax cuts have been about – ensuring that America continues to be the most competitive economy in the world. So rest assured, I will keep the tax cuts that we have put in place at the forefront of the economic agenda. 

Thank you for your question.

Thank you for your question. The idea of a rapid pullout from Iraq without a clear plan to secure the country and dismantle the capabilities of any terrorist organizations, including Al Qaeda, would certainly put the United States at risk. We have been working diligently to stabilize Iraq, ensure basic services are provided to the Iraqi people, and train Iraqi forces to take over the security of their own country. It’s a significant task that has made progress, but there is still work to be done.

If we were to pull out too quickly, without ensuring that the situation within Iraq is stable and that we’ve prevented any resurgence of terrorist activities within the country, we could create a vacuum that terrorist organizations could exploit. This might lead to a situation where they could reconstitute and plot against the United States and our allies.

In a statement made by Senator Obama, I understand he indicated a willingness to act if such a situation were to arise. This reflects an important fact – our national security strategy must be flexible and able to respond to changing circumstances that could pose threats, such as the formation of a terrorist base. The overarching principle is to protect American lives and our way of life, which is why our foreign policy decisions must be guided by the possibility of both short-term and long-term threats.

Ensuring that Iraq becomes a peaceful and stable nation is crucial not only for the Iraqi people but also for regional stability, global security, and preventing the reemergence of Al Qaeda's presence and its ability to plan and execute attacks.

Thank you for the question. In our discussions with European leaders, the mergers between companies are often brought up as part of broader trade and economic discussions. While I can't go into specific details about private conversations, it's important to note that when such matters are discussed, they typically involve conversations about fair competition, regulatory standards, and the impact on international markets.

Regarding the specific case of the potential merger between General Electric and Honeywell, my administration has certainly been paying close attention to the implications here. However, it's not within my role to intervene directly in merger discussions or decisions that are handled by regulators and company executives. What is within my administration's purview is to ensure the integrity of the relationship between our countries and to uphold the principles of free and fair trade.

If the European Union were to reject the deal based on the findings of their regulatory review and concerns about competition, my administration would respect their decision. At the same time, it's crucial for both parties to continue working together to resolve any issues that may arise from such decisions in a way that upholds the spirit of the transatlantic relationship.

It's also important to keep in mind that the United States and Europe share a strong partnership. Our economies are intertwined, and our relationship is built on more than just mergers and acquisitions. We will continue to foster open dialogue and cooperation to address any concerns and ensure mutual prosperity and stability.

Thank you for your question. When it comes to the economic forecasts and the budget, one of the most important aspects is basing these projections on widely accepted economic trends and conditions. Our administration's budget projections, like those of the Congressional Budget Office, take into account a range of factors, including economic growth, inflation, and employment.

The forecast for 3.2% growth next year is based on a number of key indicators that suggest continued economic expansion. We've seen steady job growth and strong consumer confidence, which are important drivers of economic activity. Home sales are indeed up, indicating stability in a sector that is crucial to the overall health of the economy.

We have to remember that the economy operates in cycles. Our tax relief plan, aimed at putting money back in the pockets of American workers and families, is designed to foster an environment conducive to sustained growth. We're working on a fiscally responsible budget that supports initiatives like missile defense while managing spending.

It's true that some economists may have differing views on the exact growth projections. However, we're making a forecast that we believe is reasonable and achievable. We're mindful of the signposts provided by economic indicators, such as durable goods orders, recognizing that every little part of our economy contributes to the overall picture. The fluctuations you mentioned can be normal and manageable in the context of a broadly healthy economy.

In putting together the budget, we take into account the full range of economic factors and trends, while also being cautious managers of the taxpayers' resources. We'll continue to work closely with Congress to deliver the best possible economic climate for the American people, ensuring that the country remains prosperous and secure.

Thank you for your questions. First, let me address our commitment in Afghanistan. The United States is fully committed to the security and stability of Afghanistan, and we are working diligently alongside our international partners to defeat the Taliban and secure our common interest in a peaceful Afghanistan. This is a complex conflict that requires a comprehensive approach, encompassing military efforts, as well as political and economic support.

Regarding the Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty, I have met with President Putin to discuss our concerns and to explore ways to adapt to the changing global security environment since September 11th. It's important to recognize that the security threats of today are not the same as they were when the ABM Treaty was signed. Countries like Iran and North Korea are developing weapons of mass destruction and theater-range missiles that pose a direct threat to our troops and to allies in the region. This is a significant shift in the strategic landscape.

Our goal is to protect not only our own nation but also our friends and allies. The United States is looking for a cooperative approach in dealing with these modern threats through various means including missile defense systems and stringent non-proliferation policies. We are open to working with Russia to ensure that any changes to the ABM Treaty or its successor frameworks are to the benefit of international security and stability.

I would prefer not to scrap the ABM Treaty outright, but rather to reevaluate and modify it as necessary to reflect today's realities. We believe that by working together with strategic partners like Russia, we can address emerging threats effectively while maintaining global peace and cooperation.

I did not ask the Prime Minister to pursue specific actions regarding the Japanese economy. However, it's important that Japan, like many nations, works towards economic stability and growth. We had a productive conversation with Prime Minister Koizumi where we stressed the importance of the bilateral relationship between the United States and Japan, and discussed the challenges facing various economies in the region.

When it comes to the Japanese economy, it's clear that addressing structural reforms and taking antideflation measures are both critical. The balance between these two areas should be one that fosters long-term economic health while also providing immediate relief to the economy. Japan has made progress on reforms, but more can be done, and we support efforts aimed at making the economy more flexible and competitive. Any actions taken by Prime Minister Koizumi and his government should focus on strengthening the economy in a way that benefits the people of Japan and supports the economic partnership between our two countries.

Prime Minister Koizumi is in the best position to decide the balance that works best for Japan, but we trust that he will consider all the aspects necessary to ensure Japan's economic recovery and continued prosperity.

Good evening. I appreciate your question. You're correct; I do believe in the wisdom of the American people and I also appreciate the need for transparency on matters of national significance such as the costs of war.

In regards to the financial costs of the war, it's important to understand that these can vary widely based on a number of factors, including the length of the conflict, the types of operations undertaken, and the international support we might receive.

We have worked closely with analysts and experts to estimate the potential costs, but these are indeed estimates. The Pentagon has provided cost projections, but the reality is that the future is inherently unpredictable, and the cost can escalate or decrease based on how events unfold on the ground.

What we can offer is a commitment to be as transparent as possible about the funds we allocate and how they are spent, ensuring accountability to the American people. Our goal is to win the war decisively and swiftly to minimize the costs, both human and financial. We've worked hard to ensure that any cost associated with the war is carefully assessed to align with our broader security interests.

I understand your point about presenting these estimates to the American people, and we will continue to do so to the best of our ability. However, we must balance full disclosure with the reality that sharing exact numbers could have strategic implications for our operations and could provide sensitive information to our adversaries. Our focus, however, remains on escalating the necessary funds to support our military and win the war effectively.

Thank you for your question and for your keen interest in these critical matters.

Thank you for your question. The surge in violence is a prime example of the desperation of those who oppose a free Iraq and a free future. They use women and children and innocent civilians as pawns to try to terrorize Iraq and terrorize the American people. The attacks are a sign, Mr. Qurdasi, that they're desperate. They're in the business of killing innocent people to try to shake our will. And it's not going to work. We're not going to be swayed by such tactics. 

Our coalition forces continue to work closely with Iraqi forces and our international partners to identify the perpetrators and dismantle their networks. Intelligence agencies from around the world are collaborating to gather the necessary information to combat these threats. While the full scope and breadth of these operations remain classified to preserve their effectiveness, we are taking the necessary measures to address these terrorist attacks and the individuals behind them.

We're making progress towards restoring security and stability in Iraq. It's a long process, but the Iraqi people are stepping forward, embracing their future with liberty and hope, despite the few who try to encourage the opposite with violence. We honor the bravery of the Iraqis and the coalition forces who are working to defeat these murderers and are grateful for the contributions of the Red Cross and others who continue to support the Iraqi people regardless of this ongoing campaign of terror.

The "Mission Accomplished" banner was about the end of major combat operations, as I said in my speech that day. We liberated Iraq's people from a brutal dictator. I was not premature in declaring major combat operations over, for that was a fact. After major combat, the coalition continued to pursue the remaining Baathists, Fedayeen, and terrorists who were left in Iraq.

My commitment to Iraq’s people and our troops was always my top priority, and we have adjusted our approach as needed since that time. The challenges faced in Iraq after the removal of Saddam Hussein's regime were significant, and the ongoing struggle against remnants of the former regime, as well as the rise of new threats, required perseverance and adaptation of our strategy. We continued to work towards stability and democracy in Iraq for the long term, understanding that the mission to restore peace and security in the region remained a complex, multi-faceted endeavor.

Well, thank you for the question. The American people have to understand that there is a vast difference between genuine security concerns, real issues facing our nation's safety, and partisanship or political motivations. When we talk about the serious subject of protecting our homeland from emerging threats and the dangers of terrorism, it is absolutely essential that everyone be on the same page, and we cannot allow divisions sown by politics to interfere with our ability to keep America safe.

Campaigns are about winning elections, but our national security is about saving lives and securing freedom. The amounts of money raised for a campaign are not indicative of the severity of the issues we face or the steps we take to address them. The frustration felt by some in the media over the course of our response to security concerns is not reflective of the gravity of our mission. It's vital that we continue to focus on what we must do to protect the American people, not on the political dimensions that could detract from that important work.

There will always be a debate about the right approach to national security, and I understand that. However, I call upon the American people to stay focused on what is truly important: defending our nation from violent extremist threats, strengthening our alliances, and working towards a safer world. That is our top priority, not the debates that might occur during a political season.

Thank you for your question. In my second term, we have a number of significant priorities that we want to address domestically, and we're committed to making real progress in these areas. Social Security reform, tax reform, and education are some of the key issues that we will focus on.

Regarding tax reform, we are committed to simplifying the tax code, reducing complexity, and increasing fairness for all Americans. We believe that a reformed tax system should encourage growth, job creation, and economic prosperity, and it should be designed so that taxpayers understand what they owe with minimal confusion and hassle.

As I mentioned, we are looking to make the tax code simpler. This will involve not only simplifying the tax forms and reducing the number of pages required to file income taxes, but also reducing or eliminating certain tax provisions that create complexity and confusion.

On the subject of revenue neutrality, we understand that significant tax reform will involve discussions about revenue, but our primary goal is to ensure that our tax system promotes growth and opportunity without creating additional burdens on the American taxpayer. It is important that any reforms we make are carefully considered and evaluated to ensure that they produce the desired economic outcomes for American families and businesses.

Additionally, tax reform must be part of an overall economic strategy that supports job creation and fosters a thriving business environment. We believe that good tax policy can play a crucial role in promoting these goals and we are committed to working with Congress to achieve sensible, pro-growth reforms.

Regarding education, we are committed to ensuring that every child has access to a quality education that prepares them for success in college and careers. Our priorities in education include increasing parental choice, promoting accountability, and ensuring that schools are safe and effective learning environments. We are also focused on providing teachers with the necessary tools and support to elevate the outcomes in our classrooms and to reward the best educators.

These are complex issues, and we understand the depth and breadth of the challenges we face in addressing them. However, with a collaborative effort and a commitment to reform, we are confident that together, we can create a brighter, more prosperous future for all Americans.

Thank you for that question. As you know, immigration reform is an important issue that touches millions of people's lives here in America. During my meetings with President Fox, we discussed the need for comprehensive immigration reform that takes into account the economic realities of our nation and the humanitarian aspects of those seeking a better life for themselves and their families.

When I speak of political capital, I mean the willingness to engage in the political process to achieve what I believe is right for America—legislation that offers a legal and compassionate way to allow hardworking people to remain in this country so long as they're willing to earn their citizenship and pay their taxes. This is not only a compassionate policy, but also one that aligns with the values of this country—rewarding work and rewarding responsibility.

To sell the guest-worker program to the Congress, I plan to engage closely with members on both sides of the aisle to address their concerns and continue to build support from those across the nation who believe in fair and effective immigration policies. We'll listen to constructive criticism and work to refine the proposal to ensure it meets the needs of our economy, our national security, and our humane values.

We'll also make the case that a reasonable guest-worker program will help businesses get the workers they need, strengthen our economy, and help ensure that the workers themselves are treated fairly. We will continue to cooperate with Congress to develop a system that is secure and effective, not a system that exploits the people doing the hard work of building our nation.

Ultimately, this issue is about national unity. We are a nation of immigrants, and we must act thoughtfully, respecting both the rule of law and the hearts of good people who are seeking better lives. Working together, I am confident we can find a solution that reflects both the best of our laws and the best of our hearts.

Thank you for your questions.

The United States has long supported the rights of individuals to express themselves and to participate in free and fair elections. We believe that open and accountable governments are critical to peace, freedom, and stability worldwide. That's why we advocate for the universal rights of human beings to be free from fear and want, with respect for democratic principles.

Regarding Uzbekistan, it is important to recognize that our cooperation with countries like Uzbekistan is multi-faceted. While the central government in Uzbekistan has its challenges, we have found areas of mutual interest where we work closely together, particularly in the war on terror. We appreciate the valuable support Uzbekistan has provided in the fight against terrorism and have attempted to navigate the complexities of our relationship by balancing the need for regional stability with our advocacy for human rights and democracy.

As for Egypt, the United States has a deep and complex relationship with Egypt, which includes a strong partnership in maintaining regional stability and peace. We recognize that Egypt has been undergoing significant political changes in recent years. The concerns raised about the elections and the restrictions on freedom of expression are noted, and we have continually encouraged the government of Egypt to take steps toward more democratic governance, including holding inclusive and competitive elections, as well as freedoms of expression and assembly. We have called on Egyptian authorities to respect the freedoms and rights of all Egyptians.

The United States will continue to urge all countries to respect the universal human rights of their citizens and to work towards democratic governance. But our approach also must balance these efforts with broader strategic interests and the need to address regional challenges. We are committed to working with our partners in the region to support the aspirations of all people for freedom, justice, and dignity.

The use of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) courts is important, and I want to reinforce the fact that we're abiding by the law. The FISA process is indeed a strong tool against terrorism, and many of the terrorist-related investigations that we've conducted have been based on FISA court orders. However, the threats of the 21st century demanded new thinking and quicker response times.

In the context of the post-9/11 environment, the Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF), which was passed by the United States Congress shortly after the attacks, gave the President the authority to use "all necessary and appropriate force" against those he determined were responsible for the attacks and those who harbored such organizations or persons.

Post-9/11, as the country faced the urgent threat that we did, Congress provided me with authorization to conduct the military operations deemed necessary and appropriate to combat terrorism.
