It was within this context that I found it necessary to act, and I did so with the authorization from the congressional resolution and under my constitutional authority as Commander-in-Chief.

Regarding the specific actions related to the Domestic Surveillance program, I can assure you that they were not designed to circumvent FISA but rather to operate in a different legal sphere as authorized by the AUMF. I made a decision that I thought was necessary and supportive of the national security of the country, and I was not alone in my decision. I received legal advice from my top national security advisers to guide and justify these actions.

I continue to believe that these actions were essential to the national security of the United States, in a unique and grave period in our nation's history. We acted responsibly with the aim of defending our citizens.

First off, I appreciate your questions. As for the situation in Lebanon, the United States has been consistent in calling for an immediate cessation of hostilities. We have also been working closely with our allies and partners to facilitate humanitarian aid for all civilians affected by the conflict and to support the Lebanese government as it seeks to secure stability. Our plan to rebuild houses and communities is contingent upon a ceasefire being maintained so that recovery and reconstruction can commence.

Regarding the broader context, it is important to emphasize that the United States has always been and continues to be committed to a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. Our policies are focused on achieving that goal through dialogue, diplomacy, and security cooperation. The involvement of the United States aims to support actions that will lead to long-term security and prosperity for all parties in the region. While we support our ally Israel, we also believe that all parties must take steps towards peace and we are working towards that end.

The engagement of both Israel and Lebanon is critical in this process, as is the desire to see them minimize conflict and move towards a peaceful resolution based on mutual respect and the principles laid out in international law.

Good afternoon, thank you for your questions.

Regarding the economic recession in the United States, it is a complex issue with multifaceted causes, and I want to stress that predicting the exact depth and duration is challenging due to many factors at play. The recent economic downturn is affecting many parts of the world, including Mexico. Our two nations are closely linked through trade and commerce, and an economic setback in the U.S. will undeniably impact Mexico, but we are committed to working together through these difficult times to support job creation, maintain trade stability, and ensure economic security for our citizens.

As for the reform presented by President Calderón, I appreciate Mexico's efforts to modernize its system to promote more robust and sustainable economic progress for the benefit of all Mexicans. The reforms are fundamental, addressing fiscal, energy, and labor issues, which are vital for Mexico's future growth and prosperity.

Turning to the security situation and the context of NAFTA and the FTA with Colombia, our countries share a commitment to security and free trade. The military action in Ecuador by Colombia highlights the ongoing threats posed by transnational criminal organizations and terrorists, which we all must address together to safeguard our borders, citizens, and the environment of trade that NAFTA and other agreements provide.

It is essential for regional partners to maintain dialogue on these matters to ensure that disagreements are handled constructively without compromising our shared goals of security and economic prosperity for the North American and broader Western Hemisphere regions. We stand committed to maintaining the spirit and purpose of these trade agreements in fostering cooperation and stability among our countries.

Thank you for your question. The relationship between President Tony Blair and myself is strong and built on mutual respect and shared values. We have faced challenges together and taken decisive actions for the security and freedom of our nations. As we move forward, we are committed to maintaining that close relationship, which has been a cornerstone of our efforts in areas like counterterrorism and in fostering peace and stability around the world.

Regarding Europe, the United States and the European Union share many common interests and we continue to cooperate in numerous areas, including economic ties, global security, and international institutions such as NATO. While there may be differences on certain specific issues, our track record of working together on critical matters is a testament to the strength of our alliance.

Our focus will always be on the need for security and stability both at home and abroad. President Blair's role as a mediator and partner is appreciated, and together we are striving to ensure that our nations and the broader international community work through differences and continue to advance shared goals and interests. We value the relationships we have with our European allies and are committed to strengthening and advancing them in the best interests of our countries and the world.

Thank you for your question. Our commitment to regional stability and the security of our allies remains a top priority. The vice president's message during his recent trip was clear: any actions we take will be done in consultation with our partners, and we value their perspective and support.

Regarding Saddam Hussein, the United States remains deeply concerned about Iraq's possession of weapons of mass destruction and its potential to threaten not only its neighbors but international peace and security as well. Our policy is clear: we will not tolerate the threat posed by Saddam Hussein, including the specter of weapons of mass destruction, and we will work with our allies to address this issue.

The removal of Saddam Hussein has been and continues to be an objective of the administration, paralleling our commitment towards the removal of the Taliban in Afghanistan. This objective stems from the need to secure the world from the dangers of terrorism and from regimes that support terror.

We have taken an approach that seeks to resolve international disputes through the United Nations and diplomacy, while leaving all options open. It's important to note that we are committed to a process of engagement that involves our allies and the international community. We believe that a comprehensive strategy involving various elements of national power is the best way to deal with rogue states like Iraq under Saddam's rule and their potential to harm the world.

We are dedicated to building a coalition in which all nations who love freedom and understand the stakes can work together toward justice and peace. Thank you for your attention.

Thank you, Andy, for your question. The situation in Iraq is certainly complex, but we have a clear and achievable strategy to stabilize the country and enable the Iraqi people to take control of their own security and governance.

Firstly, what we're pursuing is a transfer of responsibility for security to the Iraqi government and security forces. We've been training and equipping the Iraqi forces, and they're now ready to take on more responsibility for providing security within their own country. This process is not about giving up or leaving – it's about ensuring a capable and sustainable Iraqi force that can protect their own democracy.

We recognize that a full military solution is not the only answer. We need to stand alongside the Iraqi government to see it through a political transition and foster economic opportunities for the Iraqi people. As we've said from the outset, this mission is about more than removing Saddam Hussein – it's about ensuring a free and democratic Iraq that can be a leader in the region for peace and stability.

Regarding the security situation, we've made significant progress in reducing the insurgency and improving stability in Iraq. While there is still work to be done and challenges ahead, the Iraqi forces are becoming more capable and are taking the lead in major operations. We've seen setbacks from time to time, as expected in a conflict of this nature, but we will persevere and continue to make progress toward our goals.

Lastly, I want to stress that getting out of Iraq is not our departure plan – it's a part of our exit strategy that includes the eventual withdrawal of American forces as Iraq becomes increasingly capable of defending itself. This process will be measured and conditioned based on progress made in training the Iraqi security forces and ensuring stability. We are committed to a responsible transition while striving for a long-term, free, and secure Iraq.

Thank you for the question.

First, let me say that in the state of Texas, we took steps to make sure that penalties were administered fairly. We have an effective justice system that upholds the rule of law, including capital punishment as a sentencing option for aggravated murders. When I was governor of Texas, we worked to ensure that the legal system worked effectively, and that was part of the fabric my administration worked to uphold.

Regarding the statements I made in the State of the Union, it is important to reiterate that I am committed to ensure death penalty cases are treated justly and fairly upheld. The inclusion of discussions on DNA evidence and inadequate legal representation of death row inmates in my speech showed that while controversy surrounds capital punishment, ensuring that innocent people are not wrongfully convicted is a critical responsibility. It isn't about my personal feelings or a change in stance; it's about maintaining the integrity of our justice system.

When it comes to considering a moratorium on the death penalty, as President, my duty is to follow through with the current laws on the books as established by Congress. Any call for a moratorium would be subject to legislative process reflecting the sentiments of the American people. My position on the death penalty remains the same: it should be reserved as a punishment only for the worst of the worst crimes and carried out in a way that is consistent with our values of justice and fairness.

We continually work to find ways to strengthen our justice system, ensuring that it is a fair and reliable institution that serves and protects all Americans.

I appreciate the opportunity to address these concerns.

Firstly, let me speak to the idea that the size, power, and cost of government increased under my administration. While the Medicaid and Medicare costs did increase under my presidency, the federal workforce during my tenure was actually smaller than it was in 2001 due to a focus on efficiency and technology in the way government services were delivered. To my administration's credit, we emphasized a core philosophy of empowerment of individuals and support for local government initiatives.

I have always believed in a conservative philosophy that emphasizes limited government, fiscal responsibility, and strong national defense. We sought to enforce tax cuts that, by promoting an environment in which individuals and businesses could succeed, lead to a growing economy which could shoulder spending costs more effectively. By removing the unfair tax burden and creating a more equitable tax code, we sought to place less dependency on the growth of the federal government.

It's true that factors such as military action and natural disasters have significant impacts on the budget, and the budget deficits during my administration were high. To address the budget deficit and pay for increased costs, we have worked to streamline programs and began to see progress. In 2006, we went from projected annual deficits in the trillions to projections of deficits in the low hundreds of billions. We also took steps to cut wasteful spending and demonstrated a five-year span of fiscal restraint unseen since the era of President Reagan.

Specifically, in terms of program cuts, we sought to consolidate federal agencies and eliminate duplicative programs, aiming to find efficiencies and savings wherever they could be found. Additionally, we made tough decisions such as the proposed Social Security reform, which, while ultimately not realized during our term, was intended to address long-term sustainability issues. The goal was to build a foundation of fiscal responsibility that could allow for both strong national defense and continued investments in areas like education and security.

I understand that an answer about specific revenue measures or cuts to programs isn't sufficient without being highly specific to a program. Here's an example: One area we targeted was unnecessary spending in agricultural subsidies, where we reduced waste and overspending. We were also successful in reducing fraud and abuse, particularly in the Medicare system.

Our administration was dedicated to providing a government that is compassionate but responsible in its spending and committed to a balanced budget over the long term. While I acknowledge that there are challenges ahead, we believed that our approach of economic growth and limited government would be the best path forward for the American people.

Good morning. The situation in Iraq remains a serious matter of concern for our nation and the region. It's important to remember that Iraq is a country that has faced significant challenges since the removal of Saddam Hussein's regime. While we understand the serious conditions facing the Iraqi people, we continue to support the Iraqi government and the Iraqi people because we believe in their future.

Our commitment to helping Iraq achieve a stable and democratic government that respects the rights of all its citizens remains firm. This is not just a matter of American interests but also one of the moral imperative to support a people who are striving for a better future.

The term "civil war" is a term that different people define in different ways. However, what I can tell you is that our strategy in Iraq is to help build a government that can defend its own borders, protect its people, and provide security for all. We're working with the Iraqi government, helping them to create structures that build up the rule of law.

The threshold of "civil war" often refers to a situation where there is armed conflict between parties, well-organized as well as a significant departure from normal law and order. The Iraqi government is working to bring stability and security to its own country, and we're providing them with support to do so. We remain engaged with international partners and Iraqi authorities to ensure that all parties are moving towards a more peaceful and unified Iraq.

Our soldiers are over there fighting side by side with Iraqi troops; they're doing a fantastic job. We're also working with our international partners to help train Iraqi security forces and build national reconciliation. We believe that by working together, Iraq can overcome the challenges it faces and the country can avoid the pitfalls of fragmentation and civil unrest.

We will continue to do what is necessary to support a free Iraq, and we will continue to work with our Iraqi friends to overcome this adversity together.

Thank you for your question. Indeed, one of my administrations' principles was the importance of measured success and accountability. These benchmarks are designed to ensure that the Iraqi government is moving in the right direction towards stability, sovereignty, and democracy. We have a vested interest in ensuring that the United States' efforts and the sacrifices made by our troops and coalition partners result in a stable and democratic Iraq that can stand on its own.

To measure the success, we will look at several key areas that the Iraqi government has committed to. These include the establishment of a more inclusive government focused on the will of the Iraqi people, the passing of key legislation that strengthens the rule of law and supports national reconciliation, the implementation of a program to absorb Sunni fighters into public works projects, and the establishment of the rule of law to protect the liberties of all Iraqis.

We will continue to work closely with our Iraqi partners to chart progress in these areas. If the Maliki government does not meet these benchmarks, we will have a conversation with our Iraqi partners to determine what adjustments are necessary to ensure we are making progress towards our mutual goals. We're committed to the success of the Iraqi people, and if the Iraqi government is not willing to take the steps necessary for success, we will work to find a solution in the best interests of Iraq and the broader regional stability.

Thank you for your question. We have indeed reached out to a variety of political and religious leaders in Iraq as part of our efforts to help the people of Iraq enhance stability and freedom. In the case of Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, his views and support for a moderate coalition are significant, as he is a revered and respected figure in the Shi'a community, and thus his endorsement can have a stabilizing effect on the political climate.

His involvement and support can serve as a moderating influence, especially in relation to the governance and actions of the Iraqi government. If his endorsement can help Iraqis work together in a spirit of unity to build a free and democratic society, then it is of great importance.

Regarding the call for more troops, I understand the concern about sectarian tensions. However, the presence of our troops has played a stabilizing role, helping to protect Iraqis from violence while improving security, liberating hostages, and enabling Iraqis to form a democratic government. Our plan is not to stay in Iraq forever but to help the Iraqis secure their interests, restoring stability and fighting those who want to intimidate other nations from supporting democratic movements.

In the case of needing additional troops, it is to ensure the ongoing progress in Iraq, and our benchmarking process is key to transitioning more responsibilities to the Iraqis so that we can begin the transition of power. We will keep the goal in mind of a self-reliant Iraq, free from tyranny, and a country that is not a safe haven for killers and not a threat to the civilized world.

Thank you for that important question. Five years ago, the idea that Usama bin Laden would still be at large planning attacks against the United States and targeting Iraq as a potential terrorist safe haven would have been a source of great concern and urgency for me and certainly for our entire nation. Clearly, the al Qaeda threat and combating terrorism were top priorities for my administration. We understood the gravity of the situation and we acted decisively to protect our country by going on the offensive against terrorists at home and abroad.

We recognized that al Qaeda and its affiliates had the ability to find sanctuary in failed states or ungoverned territories, and one of our strategic objectives was to prevent the establishment of such a terrorist safe haven in Iraq. We took immediate action to remove Saddam Hussein's regime and prevent the reconstitution of al Qaeda's operational capability within Iraq.

However, we were up against a highly adaptive and resilient enemy. Bin Laden and his network did their best to stay hidden and use the chaos of war to their advantage. The terrain and the complexity of the situation in Iraq made it a difficult challenge to track down individual operatives, especially an individual as high-value as Usama bin Laden.

We executed a multi-faceted approach, which included combining intelligence gathering with military operations, strengthening our diplomatic efforts with partner nations, and improving our homeland security measures. Our dedication remained steadfast in seeking out the whereabouts of Usama bin Laden and dismantling al Qaeda's capability to launch attacks against the United States.

Ultimately, the pursuit of Usama bin Laden and dismantling the al Qaeda network was a significant challenge that required continuous effort and cooperation with our allies. While the road was full of obstacles, our commitment to ensure the safety of the American people remained unwavering.

Good question. I appreciate you asking the question, and I'm glad you bring up the subject of a multilateral approach. The United States has always worked within a multilateral framework, and we have sought the support of our friends and allies in addressing global challenges, including Iran's nuclear program. We've often worked within international institutions like the United Nations, where we have been able to build consensus for robust sanctions against Iran to pressure them to comply with their international obligations.

Regarding Iran, my Administration had been pushing a policy of patient pressure aimed at convincing Iran to abandon its nuclear weapons aspirations. We made it clear to Iran that their continued defiance of UN resolutions and IAEA demands would have consequences. Over the years, we've seen a growing number of countries recognize the threat posed by Iran's nuclear ambitions and have come to support the international sanctions imposed on Iran.

But patience isn't infinite. We've always made it clear that Iran must comply with international obligations, and we've worked to persuade other nations, including China and Russia, to join us in holding Iran accountable. While we have seen some progress with the stance of China and Russia, there is a growing consensus that international sanctions and pressure on Iran need to be maintained and even increased if Iran does not change course. If Iran does not respond to these international efforts through diplomatic channels, then we and our allies will have to look at other options, including the potential for all options to remain on the table.

Thank you for your question, and I hope this gives you some insight into our approach.

Thank you for your question. Protecting the privacy and security of the American people is a critical responsibility that I take very seriously. The legislation I'm proposing, the Protect America Act, includes provisions to protect the civil liberties of our citizens while we ensure the safety of our country. If we do not take action, we will leave our nation vulnerable to attack. It's important to understand that the protections we're enacting are aimed at ensuring our enemies overseas cannot turn the laws meant to protect Americans' privacy against us. We're working to strike a balance between security and the rights of our citizens.

Regarding the telecoms, legal protections are needed to ensure they can support the intelligence community in gathering potential terrorist-related information without fear of lawsuits. The purpose is to ensure that businesses can assist the government without undue risk. We're taking action to protect the companies that have cooperated with law enforcement and intelligence agencies in the past because I believe we need their cooperation now and in the future.

When it comes to the concerns that some might feel their privacy was compromised in the name of security, this issue needs to be part of an ongoing dialogue. We will continue to work with Congress to find ways to protect both the safety of our nation and the rights of its citizens. That's why I also support the establishment of an independent panel of experts to review the Terrorist Surveillance Program, ensuring that it is conducted lawfully and that there is transparency as necessary. This is a complex issue, and we will work to address the concerns and privacy issues as we seek to keep our country safe.

Well, thanks for the question, and I appreciate you bringing up Charles Krauthammer, who I have often had a good discussion with, and respect his opinion about these matters.

I think that throughout the campaign and subsequent years in leadership, I brought a different perspective to the White House, and I know that some folks weren't entirely comfortable with that change. President Clinton and President Reagan were different from one another, as they very well should be. Each comes in with his own set of values and ideas that he seeks to bring forth into the country.

As for "Bush derangement syndrome," some people use that term to talk about those who seemed to have an irrational or overly negative reaction to my presidency. This can happen when emotions run high, and the stakes are perceived to be great. From my perspective, it's important to be true to one's beliefs while also respecting those who may hold differing views. In a democracy, we need to be able to listen and to find common ground where we can.

To those who are critics, I would encourage them to continue voicing their thoughts and opinions. It's through healthy debate and discussion that we make progress as a nation. Whether someone agreed or disagreed with me, I think it's important for the American people to have confidence that we were always working toward the best interests of the nation, and to do so, we must be open to good-faith discussions.

Throughout the time I was in the White House, I worked diligently to bring my vision for America into reality, and that sometimes meant policies that not everyone agreed with. But let's remember, that's how it works in a free society — disagreement and debate are part of healthy dialogue. I am always proud to represent the values of the American people, to the best of my ability, and I do think that we have come up with a strategy and a set of actions that have stood the test of time and have led positively for the future of our country.

Thank you for the question. The FBI is one of our nation's premier law enforcement agencies, and its national security importance is unmatched. We want to ensure that the agency continues to meet the highest standards of professionalism, accountability, and efficiency. During my presidency, we have taken steps to ensure that the FBI continues to uphold the trust the American people have placed in it.

Regarding the suggestions for tighter oversight, we must always seek to improve and maintain the integrity and effectiveness of the FBI. This is something that we do consistently. The Justice Department and the FBI itself already conduct internal reviews and assessments to identify areas for improvement and to address any issues that arise. Moreover, the Department of Justice Inspector General also plays an important role in providing oversight of the FBI.

What we want to make sure we avoid is creating an environment of bureaucracy that thwarts the ability of the FBI to protect our nation and catch those who seek to do us harm. The FBI must be agile and adept at investigating threats, and not be hindered by overly restrictive oversight that would hamper their capabilities and their work.

That said, I do believe it's always important to listen to the voices of respected members of Congress, such as Senator Patrick Leahy, and to consider their perspectives on how to keep the FBI operating at the peak of its ability to safeguard the country’s security. We appreciate the sentiments of those who are concerned about maintaining the highest standards at the FBI, and we remain committed to that objective.

We stay focused on ensuring that America's law enforcement and intelligence agencies are well-equipped and effective in confronting the ever-evolving global threats to our nation. Thank you for raising this important topic.

Thank you for your questions. Regarding the global climate change initiative, America welcomes the world's views on how to fight global warming. As we have done in the past, we will continue to lead the world to confront the serious challenges of climate change. Our plan is ambitious. It is strong. And it will keep America -- America on track to reduce our economy's emissions significantly -- by three percentage points to meet the requirements of the Kyoto Protocol, but in a practical way that is not harmful to our long-term economic growth.

Since the Bush administration took office, we have reduced our economy's emissions by ten percent -- faster than we would have had we ratified Kyoto. The 2002 climate action report shows that we have reduced sulfur dioxide emissions by almost forty percent, carbon monoxide by fifty percent, nitrous oxide by thirty percent, and lead by almost ninety-five percent.

We're a leader in the world. We're a leader. We have a real difference. The short of the answer is the following: We think we ought to work together. I'm not trying to go it alone; I'm trying to lead. And you'll find my administration always willing to work with others to achieve our national and global goals.

As for the EU's concerns over my missile defense proposal, we believe a missile defense system would add to the security of the United States and our friends and allies. We are working diligently to find grounds for mutual understanding and to strengthen our partnership. I think the conviction is -- and history shows that without unity of our friends and allies, our security will be less secure. And as a result, we will continue to work with our European friends and others to find common ground on this vital matter of the common defense.

Thank you for your question. The Saudi initiative outlines a comprehensive vision for Arab-Israeli normalization and is a significant milestone toward achieving long-term peace and prosperity in the Middle East. While there have been some discussions and statements, the core of the plan remains to promote peace and stability in the region.

The specifics of normalization are ongoing conversations that involve Israel, the Arab League nations, and other nearby countries. The essence of the Saudi initiative is to provide a framework for peaceful coexistence and mutual recognition. As leaders continue to engage in dialogue, adjustments and clarifications might be made, but the overarching goal of peace remains the foundation of any efforts moving forward. I believe the right approach is to keep the channels of communication open and to work toward the common goal of peace, security, and normalization between all parties involved.

Well, thank you for that question. When I set a goal of two states living side by side in peace and security, that was based on the belief that it's the right thing to do and that it's doable. The road map set a period for achieving that vision, recognizing that achieving peace would take commitment and hard work from both sides.

Certainly, the path of peace is not an easy one, and we face significant challenges. The construction of security barriers and the ongoing violence and lack of trust between the Palestinians and Israelis have been obstacles to peace. However, I continue to believe that the goal is achievable with persistence, continued engagement, and clear accountability of both sides to fulfill their responsibilities.

It's important that we hold each side to its commitments and work with them to address the concerns that prevent them from moving forward. We must continue to promote policies that enable both parties to make the hard choices necessary for a lasting peace. While the goal may seem distant at times, I remain committed to pursuing it because it is in the security interests of our country and the region, and because it's the right thing to do for the people of Israel and Palestine who deserve a chance at a better future.

Thank you for your question. First of all, I want to thank the American people for their resolve and their strength during this time.

Regarding the sentiments expressed by some Americans and candidates, I understand that people have different views. The important thing is to stay focused on the mission at hand, which is to finish the job we were called to do by our friends, by the countries that have joined us, and by the United Nations. The mission is to defeat the terrorists, to protect our nation, and to make the world a safer place.

Regarding thoughts that maybe we should be leaving Iraq, all I can say is that I think we must accomplish the mission. The cost of leaving prematurely would be far greater than the cost of seeing this mission through. The great objectives of liberty advanced will be worth the effort, and it's absolutely essential that we finish the job.

The capture of Saddam Hussein is a significant step forward, and I believe it's an important event that will give some people hope that the end of the Saddam Hussein regime will bring peace and stability to Iraq. However, as the Iraqi people work toward building a democracy, it's important for them to know that we will stay, that we will support their sovereignty, that we will help them build the institutions necessary to fight terrorism and to help the Iraqi people live in freedom.

Therefore, I don't think Saddam's capture changes our thinking; it enhances our resolve to complete the mission we were called to do by our own citizens, by our coalition, by the Iraqi people who want a better day, and by our friends around the world. We will do what is necessary to make sure that Saddam Hussein's regime is no longer a threat to the United States or the rest of the world. We will stay our course.

Thank you for your question. Despite the challenges Iraq has faced, including those you mentioned, the handover of sovereignty is a critical step in the establishment of a new, democratic government. It's important to recognize that our goal is not just to secure Iraq but to build a self-reliant nation amongst the Iraqi people and their security forces. The handover signifies that Iraq is now on its own path toward self-governance, with the support of the international community. We have expanded and enhanced the Iraqi security forces, and we are committed to helping them build the capacity and will to maintain their own security.

While there have been setbacks and challenges, our efforts have been focused on preparing the Iraqi people to take the lead in their security. The U.S. and coalition forces will continue to support Iraq's new leaders, but our role is changing as we work towards a transition where Iraqis are more capable of handling their nation's defense and internal security. This is a crucial phase in the reconstruction of Iraq and a long-term commitment to ensuring that Iraq can stand on its own.

Thank you for your question. First of all, I want to express my confidence in John Bolton. He's a man of strong principles and convictions, and his dedication to public service is unparalleled. I have appointed him as our nominee for U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations because I firmly believe he has both the knowledge and the strength of character to stand up for America's interests at the United Nations. 

Regarding the filibuster in the Senate, it is unfortunate when we do not have support for an important nominee who is well-qualified for the job. However, we respect the process and are working through all the options available to us, including the possibility of a recess appointment. A recess appointment would allow John Bolton to serve temporarily, enabling him to begin the work we believe is necessary to strengthen the role of the United Nations and focus it on its core purposes, which are maintaining international peace and security, promoting friendly relations among nations, and being a forum for bringing nations together to encourage the attainment of peaceful solutions of disputes.

It is true that we would have limited time to effect long-term changes if the appointment were made during the remaining recess period, but we would certainly make the most of the time available to start the process of reform and engagement that we believe is essential for the United Nations to fulfill its potential. We value Secretary Rice's wisdom and advice in all situations, and I can assure you that we are considering all our options carefully to serve the best interests of our country and the world.

We will continue to make the case for John Bolton's confirmation as our Ambassador to the United Nations, and I believe he has the support he needs. We ask the Senate to work with us to ensure that this talented, committed public servant can take his rightful place serving our nation on the world stage.

Thank you for the questions. Let me address each in turn.

First, regarding mainland China's participation in the widening of the Panama Canal, the United States expresses a strong belief in promoting greater transparency and accountability in large infrastructure projects, such as the expansion and operation of the Panama Canal. As you know, the Canal is a central artery of global commerce, and therefore, it is essential that any investment or participation in such a significant project is conducted in a manner that respects the democratic principles and the laws of Panama.

The United States welcomes investment and involvement from any country that respects these principles, supports the Panamanian government's vision, and adheres to international standards. As such, China's potential participation would be viewed positively if it aligns with these standards and does not compromise the strategic interests of Panama or impede the flow of goods and services through the Canal.

Turning to the FTAA summit and the divisions among countries, particularly those within MERCOSUR, it is important to recognize that economic integration and cooperation are challenging endeavors. They can often intersect with a variety of national interests and perceptions, particularly those that may be rooted in differing political ideologies or historical experiences.

What we've seen in recent FTAA summits, including those in South America, is a reflection of the complex and varied economic, social, and political landscapes of the Western Hemisphere's nations. The disagreements can sometimes stem from perspectives on labor standards, environmental regulations, intellectual property rights, and the pace and methods of economic liberalization.

The United States remains committed to fostering an environment where all nations can participate in a manner that respects their unique circumstances and advances their economic interests within a broader framework of free trade. Open dialogue, respect for sovereignty, and a willingness to find common ground are essential to resolving the ideological and practical issues that may arise. We hope that through continuing negotiations and demonstrating the mutual benefits of free trade, the participating countries can continue to build a prosperous and integrated region.

I appreciate you asking these questions. They highlight the importance of open communication and respect for sovereignty as we seek to address issues of commerce and international relations.

Thank you for the question. The United States has a strong commitment to supporting democratic elections and processes around the world, and our efforts in the Palestinian territories are no exception. The assistance provided by the U.S. is aimed at supporting the Palestinian people in their democratic aspirations and ensuring that the elections are free, fair, and transparent. 

Our goal is to help create a peaceful, prosperous, and democratic Palestine that lives side by side with Israel in peace. It is important that the Palestinian people have a voice in their own future and that the elected officials truly represent the will of the people. By working to ensure the integrity of the election process, we are not only supporting democracy but also laying the groundwork for a more stable and peaceful Middle East.

Regarding the balance between promoting democratic processes and managing security concerns, these are indeed complex issues. The United States seeks to address both democratic aspirations and legitimate security concerns. We encourage all parties to engage in dialogue and reconciliation while firmly opposing any form of violence or terrorism. Our commitment is to empower the Palestinian people through democratic means, while working with our allies to address the challenges posed by terrorist threats.

It's a delicate balance, but one that we believe is necessary to achieve a lasting peace in the Middle East.

I want to thank the reporter for the question. We had a good working relationship with the Armed Services Committee. Senator Warner, Senator Levin, and Senator McCain have been very respectful of the process and they are men of great integrity and I have a great deal of respect for them. We worked actively over the summer. It was my hope at one time to address the concerns by strengthening the bill in such a way that it would be consistent with American values, with the Constitution, and also provide the folks on the front lines the ability to do their job and to protect the American people.

Let me be clear. I respect the ability of the Congress to pass legislation. I respect the intelligence and the honesty of their motives in looking out for the safety of our country. I think it's important for the American people to know how serious this decision is, as it's been briefed to me, that to send people back to a country where they'll be tortured would be against our values and against American law.

Let me be very clear. I'm the commander in chief. I lead this country through these difficult times. And I will adhere to the following principles: if there's an open rebellion on Capitol Hill -- I don't quite use that term -- but if there is a bill that gets past the executive branch that would not adequately protect American people, it'll come to me in some form or another and I will review it, as I would any bill. And based upon the concerns I've outlined, my request is that we be able to finalize a bill that will protect Americans, that is consistent with our laws, and that treats people humanely.

With respect to the question of a veto, the Congress will consider the matter. We hope to work cooperatively with them so the bill that comes to my desk is the kind of bill we can feel good about signing. We had hoped to mark up a bill that would work within the Constitution of the United States, treat people humanely, and also keep the American homeland safe. We're actively working toward that goal.

Thank you for the question. I understand that as a parent, especially when welcoming a new child into the family, you want to make sure that all the necessary legal and social scaffolding is in place to help care for and support that child. In terms of the way the country is structured, my administration believes in the sanctity of marriage as an institution between one man and one woman. I support that definition, as did the U.S. Congress when they defined marriage that way.  

However, it’s also important to ensure that families, including situations like Mary Cheney’s, have the appropriate legal protections and rights that any parent would want. While I believe in the definition of marriage as being between a man and a woman, we can, through practical measures, ensure there is stability and support for all Americans, including those in committed relationships outside of marriage. 

My administration has supported measures such as civil unions or domestic partnerships, which can provide legal rights and protections in areas like hospital visits, inheritance, and more without redefining marriage itself. In this way, we can help ensure that families like Mary Cheney’s have the legal and familial support they need, even as we hold to the definition of marriage that we believe is important for our culture and society.

Good afternoon. As for the situation regarding drug trafficking and the paramilitaries in Colombia, the United States has been deeply involved in supporting the efforts to maintain stability and enhance security in the region. President Uribe has been a key partner in our shared commitment to tackle the issues of narco-terrorism and combat organized crime. 

The U.S. continues to offer assistance to Colombia, including military and law enforcement training, as well as intelligence sharing, aimed at combating these threats. It is essential that justice is served, and accountability is maintained, therefore we support the Colombian government in its efforts to identify, prosecute, and punish individuals involved in the drug trade and paramilitary activities. 

Extradition is a crucial aspect of ensuring that those who commit crimes under the law of one country are held accountable in a jurisdiction where appropriate. We have emphasized the importance of extraditing individuals involved in these activities to face the justice they deserve. Such actions align with our principles and help to reinforce the rule of law in Colombia and throughout the region. 

It's important to continue urging resolution and justice, while reinforcing our commitment to partnering with Colombia and other countries in the fight against drug-related crime and organized crime groups. We will work together to ensure that those responsible for the suffering of the Colombian people and the destabilization of the region are brought to justice.

Thank you for the question. I'm mindful of the situation in Pakistan and understand the challenges that President Musharraf faces. It's important that Pakistan continue to work with the United States and the international community to combat the threat of extremism and terrorism. Pakistan's stability is critical to our efforts, and we've been working closely with the Musharraf government to help it strengthen its capacity to deal with these threats.

We have been encouraging efforts to promote democracy and reform in Pakistan, as we believe that a stable, democratic Pakistan is in the best interest of both the Pakistani people and the broader global community. While I don't want to comment on specific actions that President Musharraf might take, I do know that we are committed to working with Pakistan on the path toward a more stable and secure future.

We believe that the struggle against terrorism is a long-term effort. Therefore, ensuring that Pakistan remains a key partner in this struggle is a priority for us. We will continue to work closely with Pakistan to address any instability and to support its efforts in this critical fight.

Good morning. I appreciate that question. I want to share with you that we have not given up on the diplomatic efforts to address the serious threat of Iran's nuclear ambitions. We strongly believe that a peaceful resolution to this issue is possible and preferable to military action or other more confrontational measures. That is why we continue to push for the universal application of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, to ensure that countries like Iran do not develop weapons of mass destruction.

We work closely with our international partners, including the UK and other members of the UN Security Council, to impose necessary sanctions and to pressure Iran to comply with international demands regarding its nuclear program. We have also reached out to the international community to condemn Iran’s continued defiance of UN Security Council resolutions and to impose tougher sanctions on the regime until they comply with their international obligations.

It’s important that we draw clear lines and ensure that Iran respects international norms and agreements. Iran seems to be testing the patience of the international community, but we continue to work diligently to send a strong message that non-compliance will have serious consequences.

We must remain united in the international community in our approach to Iran, sending a consistent and clear message that the pursuit of nuclear weapons is unacceptable. It's important that nations like Iran learn from the experiences of other nations and adhere to the rules that are vital for maintaining international peace and security.

I appreciate your question. The issue of the tax cut that we're talking about is an issue that affects the average person. It's an issue of whether or not we're going to show the American people we trust our economy. And the answer to that question for me is to show confidence in the American people by sending them their money back.

With regard to the budget surpluses and the fact that they won't appear or could disappear, there's no question we've got to be wise stewards of the people's money. And that's why it's very important for us to uphold the basic traditions of how to keep the budget balanced. We must start with a budget process that creates discipline. We must make sure Congress uses the reconciliation process. It's a process that I'm familiar with from my time in Congress, and it does create discipline in Washington.

Secondly, we have various options to deal with the Congress as they move forward with spending programs. I would work diligently with members of Congress to make sure that the budget does not get out of whack. But, also, in terms of the tax relief plan, it's on a schedule, and the schedule is a series of triggers that would start to pull back on the tax relief if revenues do not materialize.

So there are mechanisms in the Congress and mechanisms in the tax cuts themselves to help prevent these things from getting out of hand. We must also, however, recognize that the best way to cure a lot of the spending issues is to have a vibrant and growing economy, and tax cuts are an important part of making sure the economy grows.

It's also important for me to say that it's really important to trust the American people. I don't believe we should make an issue out of tax cuts; I believe we should trust American workers and American families to spend their money. And one of the best ways to align interest between the people's interests, the people in the Congress, is to trust the people by sending them their money back.

This tax cut I've proposed does just that. It affects mostly the working folks. If you make 40,000 a year, you pay no marriage penalty. If you're a new parent, you get a child credit. If you're a small business person, you don't have to pay the death tax.

This tax cut I've proposed affects mostly the working folks. And my concern and worry is that Washington elitists not get in the way of good tax policy that is giving the American people decisions about how to spend their own money. That's what this tax cut does. It trusts the people. That's my philosophy on taxes.

Thank you for that question.

Collaborating with Senator John McCain and members of Congress, including Democrats, to pass meaningful legislation that benefits Americans has been a priority of mine since the beginning of my administration. Regarding the campaign finance reform bill and other proposals, it's important to understand that the legislative process involves much negotiation and compromise, and differences in opinion can arise.

As for campaign finance reform, we have reached a crucial point where we need to ensure that we address the concerns of both parties and constituents to make progress. We only have one more opportunity in front of us to get it right. That's why discussions continue, and we are working diligently to find common ground that will satisfy both the administration's goals and the concerns of our legislative partners.

In the case of the Patients' Bill of Rights, it's crucial to remember that there are competing versions and ideas on the table, and it's our job to come up with a comprehensive and workable plan that genuinely protects and improves healthcare access for all Americans. We have been and will continue to be in discussions with Senator McCain and others to ensure that whatever is passed is both comprehensive and effective.

As for the idea of signing a bill with someone's name on it, that is simply not the case in our legislative process. All pieces of legislation have to pass through Congress with the support of the necessary votes, and then the President signs the bill into law. The ultimate goal is to make sound decisions that improve the quality of life for the American people, regardless of party affiliation or individuals involved. We seek reforms that have bipartisan support and can muster the necessary legislative votes to become law.

I would also like to emphasize that there has been a good relationship between Senator McCain and my administration on various issues. We have worked together on a range of subjects for the benefit of the American people, and that cooperation will continue, focused on finding solutions that work in the country's best interest.

Thank you for the question. The Saudi initiative reflects the region's desire for peace and represents an important step forward in the Middle East peace process. It's an opportunity for all parties involved to engage in constructive dialogue and move towards a lasting resolution. While the details and specifics of the proposal are still being considered carefully, the framework it outlines is one that could contribute to ending the conflict and achieving peace.

It's natural for Israeli officials to express a willingness to discuss the initiative; the desire for peace must be reciprocal. While it's positive that interest in these discussions is strong, it's also important for all parties to approach these talks with a sense of responsibility and commitment to reaching a fair and peaceful resolution. The diplomatic process must be handled carefully and thoughtfully, with close consultation with all stakeholders involved, including our partners in the region, to ensure productive outcomes.

The United States is committed to supporting all efforts that can help move the Middle East peace process forward and achieve a peaceful settlement. We will continue to work closely with all parties interested in peace to help guide these discussions and address the issues concerning the Israeli people as well as the Palestinian people.

We encourage dialogue and exploration of all avenues that can contribute to the establishment of a comprehensive, just, and lasting peace in the Middle East.

Thank you for your question. John Bolton has been a seasoned diplomat and a respected figure in Washington, and I believe that his talent and experience will be a valuable asset in the work that needs to be done at the United Nations. The Democrats' demand for more documents does not alter the conviction I have in his qualifications, nor does it undermine the process of his nomination. 

As you mentioned, some Republicans have criticized the tactic of filibustering, and I understand that point. It is important that we work in a cooperative manner in our government system. However, these are different times, and sometimes nominees can be subject to extensive scrutiny by the Senate, which is their right. Our administration will strive to work with the Senate to find a compromise, but when it comes to critical appointments, such as this one, I am committed to standing by my nominations. 

We are in the process of providing documents and answering questions to the best of our ability. I will, of course, continue to work closely with both the Senate and my administration to ensure that the process moves as smoothly as possible to confirm qualified individuals like John Bolton, who will speak for American values and interests on the world stage. Thank you for your understanding.

I understand that there are differing opinions about the nomination, but ultimately, I feel confident that Judge Harriet Miers is someone who will interpret the Constitution according to its original meaning. She has a strong legal background and has been a leader in the legal community. Her dedication to the law and her ability to analyze complex legal questions will serve the Court well.

While some may have had different expectations, I made the nomination with the belief that Judge Miers is an excellent candidate who can carry on the conservative jurisprudence and uphold the Constitution. It's important to recognize that a person's temperament, intellect, and dedication to the law are crucial in the role of a Supreme Court Justice. I have worked closely with Judge Miers and have the utmost confidence in her abilities. I hope that those who are skeptical will give her a fair chance to present herself before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Well, first of all, let me say that I appreciate the question. It's an important one. The United States is working tirelessly to defeat global terrorism, and part of that strategy involves working with other nations, even those that have, in the past, supported terrorist activities, provided they fully and honestly renounce these activities and demonstrate their commitment to fighting terrorism.

We have seen this approach work in some cases. When a country shifts its stance from supporting terrorism to opposing it, it can be beneficial to international security. This does not mean a blanket amnesty; it means that nations must take verifiable actions and policies that demonstrate a commitment to the principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law.

However, let me be clear: there is no place for terrorists or those who harbor them under any circumstances. A change of heart must be proven through action, not just words. We need tangible evidence that such nations are acting in good faith to combat terrorism. If they do not, there will be consequences.

Our aim is to make the world a safer place and to prevent future attacks. We are working closely with our allies and partners to ensure that those who are turned towards peace and cooperation are reliable partners in the fight against global terrorism.

Thank you for your question. We take intelligence seriously, and when the FBI determines that there's a potential threat, it's important that we communicate that to the American people. The concern of another retaliatory attack is real, and this warning is just another measure we're taking to keep citizens informed and safe.

The warning should not prevent people from going about their daily lives, but rather serve as an increased awareness to stay vigilant. It doesn't mean that everyone should stay at home, but it does mean that we need to be careful, watchful, and ready to report any suspicious activity to authorities. We've seen previously that public awareness and reporting can help stop threats before they escalate into danger.

Regarding whether I personally approved this warning, that's a bit more detailed and would be better answered by the FBI, who are responsible for issuing these types of alerts. However, it's part of our ongoing effort to keep the public informed about potential security concerns as they arise. 

We're all in this together, and the best way to combat these threats is through cooperation between the government and the public. Keep living your lives and support one another, but do not hesitate to take heed of the signals that come our way.

Thank you for your question. Let me be very clear: we are dealing with a difficult situation in Iraq. The commitment made by our military men and women is challenging, and America is proud of their service and sacrifice. Our nation does not lose in war; we rarely see our goals fully realized on schedule, but we are exhibiting resilience in the face of adversity.

The enemy in Iraq is trying to stop us, but we will not be deterred. It is not an easy battle; we are dealing with individuals who are spreading murder and destruction. Our mission is tough, but it's also a noble one. We must defend our nation and help the Iraqis, who want to live in freedom, secure their nation and form a democracy. We've made progress, and we will continue to work with our allies and coalition members to stabilize the region.

Transparency is important to this administration, and I can assure you that we are providing as accurate a picture as we can while also maintaining the security and operational integrity of our forces on the ground. We recognize and acknowledge the difficulties we face but remain confident in the ultimate purpose of our efforts -- to secure a safer world for the American people and to promote freedom and democracy where they have been suppressed.

I understand the concern you and others have about the timeframe and the challenges that lie ahead. But I also believe in the heart of the American people and know that we will rise to this challenge just as we have risen to countless others throughout our history. Our troops, diplomats, and the American people will persevere and succeed in Iraq and in the broader war on terror.

Thank you for your question. The concept of unacceptable weapons development applies to all nations, and the United States remains committed to preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) around the world. Our approach, however, does not dictate the same path for each nation.

In the case of Iraq, the intelligence community believed that Saddam Hussein possessed and was developing weapons of mass destruction. When this intelligence turned out to be incorrect, it underscored the difficulty in assessing such matters with complete certainty and the importance of verifying information through continuous intelligence gathering and international collaboration.

Regarding Iran and North Korea, the regimes in those nations have demonstrated hostile intentions and have engaged in activities that are of serious concern to the international community. Both countries have pursued and, in some cases, are known to possess nuclear weapons technology or are suspected of seeking such capabilities, which raises legitimate concerns about regional and global stability.

The United States has sought diplomatic resolutions and worked with allies to address these issues through a variety of means, including sanctions, efforts to negotiate, and, in the case of North Korea, direct dialogue when possible. We continue to engage in a comprehensive approach that includes diplomatic efforts and the strengthening of international partnerships to ensure that all nations comply with nonproliferation commitments and understand that they cannot threaten others with weapons of mass destruction with impunity.

It's important for the American people and the global community to understand that the decision-making process is thorough and based on the best available intelligence at any given moment. We take steps to mitigate threats in a way that reflects our values and efforts to achieve lasting peace, stability, and security for all nations involved.

Good evening. Thank you for the question. While I understand the frustration many Americans are feeling about the high price of gasoline, it's important to recognize that the price of oil and gasoline is influenced by a variety of factors in the global market, including supply and demand, geopolitical tensions, the strength of the dollar, and speculation.

The energy legislation that we've advocated for, which is now pending in Congress, would help address our long-term energy supply concerns by reducing our dependence on foreign oil, increasing domestic production through innovative and environmentally responsible means, and promoting alternative energy sources. It would also offer some short-term relief measures, such as loan guarantees for refineries to expand production, which could help increase our refining capacity and potentially ease supply pressures that contribute to high prices.

However, it's also true that enacting this legislation won't result in immediate changes in the price of oil or gasoline. The legislative process can be lengthy, the measures proposed in the bill would take time to implement, and the full impact of these measures would take years to be realized.

In the meantime, my administration is taking steps to address the short-term issues. For example, I've directed my Department of Energy to continue to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve if necessary to help stabilize the market. We're also working to ensure that our current refineries are operating at their full capacity and exploring ways to get gasoline to the market more efficiently.

I want to be clear that we cannot control the global price of oil, but we can work to reduce our reliance on it and build a better, more secure energy future that puts downward pressure on prices over the long term. Thank you for your continued support in these efforts.

I understand your comparison but it's important to clarify that no president has the authority to act in a way that is illegal. The Constitution and the rule of law are indeed paramount in the United States, and my administration is committed to both. The program I've discussed is conducted in a manner consistent with authorities I’ve been given by the Congress and in a way that is reviewed by the courts, such as the FISA court.

The Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) passed shortly after 9/11 vests the President with the authority to use all necessary and appropriate force against those he determines planned, authorized, committed, or aided the terrorist attacks that occurred on September 11, 2001, and any person who aided, harbored, or concealed such terrorists. This authorization was enacted by the legislative branch of our government and signed into law, thus providing the necessary legal framework to authorize the measures we've taken in the name of national security.

The quote you attribute to President Nixon refers to a period of political controversy unrelated to the legal framework for wartime powers I operate under. My administration works within the Constitution, legal statutes, and ensures oversight to stay within the legal boundaries while conducting the war on terror. We have sought and obtained the Congress's consent for these actions, and our program undergoes judicial oversight to ensure that it complies with the law and preserves our freedoms.

Thank you for your question, and I understand why this is a serious concern for many Americans and fellow Republicans. Our priorities have been focused on several key areas since I took office, including national security, tax relief to stimulate economic growth, education, and healthcare. These areas are important for the wellbeing and prosperity of all Americans, and they require investment, particularly after some of the economic conditions we faced in the early years of my administration.

Regarding the national debt, I agree that it is a matter of great importance. While the numbers you cited may lead to concern, it is also important to highlight the context of our approach. We've been working to promote economic growth through a series of tax cuts to encourage individuals and businesses to be more productive and innovative. The tax cuts were designed not just to give immediate relief to those who needed it, but to create a more flexible and resilient economy that would generate more revenue for the federal government over time due to increased economic activity.

In terms of the appropriations process and other spending decisions, we're making sure to find ways to control spending. The budget I proposed included sensible limits on domestic spending to ensure that we do not exacerbate the situation. It's a delicate balance between investing in priorities that matter for America's future and ensuring that we are fiscally responsible, including working to address long-term fiscal risks like entitlement spending.

I haven't vetoed any bills because those that have come to my desk did not include items that were contrary to my policy priorities and principles. My Administration works closely with Congress to ensure that legislation aligns with the goals of economic growth and fiscal responsibility.

Ultimately, my goal is to ensure that our children and grandchildren do not have to face an even more difficult inheritance, but a future filled with opportunity and security. We must continue to work towards that future, balancing our needs today with the needs of future generations.

I appreciate your question, and I understand that there are ongoing discussions about the outcomes and the timeline of the events following the ousting of Saddam Hussein's regime.

As the Prime Minister mentioned, we both anticipated a relatively quick transition to a democratic government in Iraq. However, we also recognized early on that creating a durable democracy in Iraq would not happen overnight, and both of us continued to affirm our commitment to the process despite the challenges.

We've seen progress in Iraq, and creating a new political system is complex and requires time from any nation emerging from dictatorship to authoritarianism. While our initial expectations may not have been fully met, our goals have remained steadfast: to help Iraq achieve a stable and democratic future, and to ensure that it no longer represents a threat to its neighbors or to the broader interests of the United States and our allies.

It's important to keep in mind that the path of any nation toward democracy often involves setbacks and requires ongoing support and assistance. We've worked diligently, and will continue to work, to support the Iraqi people as they build a free and democratic nation that can serve as a model for others in the region.

Thank you for your question. Let me assure you that we are working tirelessly to address the situation in Iraq. As you mentioned, Prime Minister Maliki's visit was an important moment that reinforced the importance of fostering relations between the Iraqi government and the coalition forces.

The term "nimble and facile" was used to describe the flexible approach we need to take in order to respond effectively to the evolving security situation on the ground. The Combined Forces Command, under General George Casey, and Multinational Force Iraq are made up of very capable leaders, and I have full confidence in their recommendations and the strategies they're implementing.

While I understand your concern about the rising violence, remember that our goal is not only to provide security but also to support the transition to a stable and sovereign Iraq. This requires difficult and often slow progress, as we work through tribal, sectarian, and governance issues that have plagued Iraq for decades.

I can assure you that our commitment to supporting the government of Iraq in its fight against terrorism remains strong. We are working closely with Prime Minister Maliki and his government to boost their capacity, and we are doing so according to the conditions set out in the UN Security Council’s resolution authorizing our presence in Iraq.

We will continue to evaluate all actions taken and ensure that we are taking the appropriate measures to improve the security situation and move Iraq towards a peaceful and stable future.

Thank you for your questions. Let me address each one individually.

First, in the three years since the conflict in Iraq began, we have made significant strides. Saddam Hussein's regime, which posed a unique danger due to its possession of weapons of mass destruction and its support for terrorism, no longer exists. The fall of Saddam's regime is an important milestone in the effort to keep the world a safer place, and it is a testament to a cooperative international effort to combat global terrorism.

Coalitions of countries have partnered with the United States in Iraq and Afghanistan to uphold a vision of peace globally. While the challenges are significant, we have made progress in rebuilding Iraq as a democracy. Freedom is inherently contagious, and the spread of democracy is an important strategy for the long-term destruction of terrorism.

Regarding the accusation that the United States is bringing terrorism to Iraq, it is unfortunate that some individuals might believe this. The truth is that Iraq is a country where extremism was allowed to thrive under Saddam Hussein. The toppling of Saddam's regime did not create terrorism; rather, it set the conditions for the Iraqi people to eventually reject extremism.

Furthermore, it is a fact that there have been tremendous improvements in Iraq in providing free elections, human rights, and a functioning, free civil society. However, the transition from tyranny to a democratic government never happens overnight. It is a long and challenging process that requires the involvement and patience of the international community.

As for the Iraqi citizens, they are at the heart of what we are trying to accomplish. The citizens of Iraq deserve a chance to live in a free society. The Iraqi people have suffered under a brutal dictatorship, far more than Iraqis have suffered at the hands of American military personnel. Today, a liberated Iraq is helping to lead the world toward peace and opportunity.

We remain committed to our goal of helping Iraq stabilize and democratically govern itself. The United States and its partners will continue to work tirelessly to support the Iraqi people in their pursuit of a peaceful and prosperous future.

To address the first part of your question, I appreciate the concerns raised. However, it is important to understand that the border security fence was not about denying Latin Americans or any other group entry to the United States. It was about ensuring that our borders are secure and to enforce our laws. We love immigrants who come here legally; immigrants start businesses and play important roles in American life. But we also must uphold the rule of law, and this includes securing our borders so that individuals are entering the United States in a safe and orderly manner.

Our intentions are to secure our nation’s borders, enforce our laws, and ensure safety and order. The fence represents one component of a larger border security strategy that includes physical barriers, additional personnel, and better technology.

For the second part of your question, I believe you meant to ask about President Fox of Mexico, as President Berger is from Costa Rica. In conversations with President Fox, he has expressed his concern about illegal immigration and sees the importance of addressing the issue responsibly. We have worked closely with the Mexican government to find ways to strengthen our border security while also improving economic opportunities in Mexico to encourage lawful entry and discouraged illegal immigration.

Our goal is to respect the sovereignty of both nations, to secure the border and improve the quality of life for our citizens on both sides of the border. We share a common desire to enhance the security of both our nations.

Thank you for your questions. First, regarding the missile defense system and my upcoming talks with President Putin, I can say that I enter these discussions with the hope of finding a common ground and addressing the concerns of both our countries. It's essential for the United States and Russia to have a robust dialogue and build mutual trust, ensuring our security and that of our allies. We need to address the challenges of the modern world together, and missile defense is an issue that can be resolved through diplomatic means.

Secondly, regarding NATO Membership Action Plans for Ukraine and Georgia, the United States firmly supports the sovereignty and territorial integrity of both countries, and we believe in the principles of the North Atlantic Treaty and its Article 5, which extends security guarantees to member states. Ukraine and Georgia have expressed a strong desire to join NATO, and the Membership Action Plans reflect our support for their aspirations to enhance their security and their commitment to democratic and institutional reforms.

I believe in engaging in fair and productive discussions that can lead to diplomatic solutions and agreements. Any tradeoffs should not come at the cost of our principles and the security of our allies. We will continue to work closely with our NATO partners to ensure a balanced and secure environment for all nations in the European-Atlantic area.

First of all, I want to thank everyone for coming and I want to make it clear that our position on Iraq has been very clear. The United States of America respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Iraq. Saddam Hussein, the dictator of Iraq, is not what we want to control. We want to control weapons of mass destruction that are inside of Iraq.

I will repeat what I've previously said: The United States respects the territorial integrity of Iraq. This action we took today is specifically under United Nations Security Council resolutions to see to it that we maintain the principle that no nation can threaten their neighbors with weapons of mass destruction.

We are putting Saddam Hussein on notice that America is going to do whatever it takes to keep the peace. It is in his interest to comply with the demands of the international community. It is also my hope that if America takes the lead, other countries will begin to take a more active role in making sure the peace is maintained in that part of the world.

To specifically answer your question whether or not it signals a hardening of our position, it signals the fulfillment of our position. It's a position I have made very clear: We will enforce existing United Nations Security Council resolutions, and we will promote American interests in that part of the world.

And for the future, you asked whether or not actions will be more frequent or forceful – I would hope not, but I can't say for sure. I can tell you that we expect Saddam Hussein to comply. And when others do see the opportunity to keep the peace, I believe it will be less likely that the United States will have to take preventive actions. But we'll do what is necessary to protect American interests as we look at the world.

Thank you for your questions. We take these matters very seriously, and I want to assure you that we are committed to the safety of our troops and to mission success.

Regarding the airstrikes in Iraq, while it is true that some bombs may not have hit their intended targets, we are constantly evaluating the success of our operations. Precision in these military strikes is crucial, and we are committed to ensuring that our operations are as accurate as possible. Every effort is made to mitigate any unintended consequences and ensure that the targets have a significant military value and pose a threat to coalition forces.

The assessment of the danger posed by any missed targets would be conducted by our military commanders on the ground. They are best positioned to evaluate the risks involved and will continue to provide the operational guidance for future actions.

If our commanders determine that additional strikes are necessary for the protection of our forces and to achieve our objectives, we will authorize them as required. The welfare of our troops is our utmost concern, and we will take all necessary military actions to ensure their safety and to protect our national interests.

Thank you for your question. The situation that we are addressing is a matter of intelligence reports that suggest the Chinese government may have provided material support to Iraqi air defense systems. These allegations are serious and, if proven, would be a violation of the UN resolutions that prohibit the possession and enhancement of weapons of mass destruction and the missiles capable of delivering them by Iraq.
