Regarding the first question, putting Dr. Rice in charge of the management of our Iraq policy reflects our commitment to ensure that the decision-making process at the highest levels remains strong, focused, and effective. Dr. Rice brings a wealth of experience and expertise to this role, and her leadership will enhance our capacity to carefully consider the options available for achieving our goals in Iraq. We remain committed to crafting a responsible plan that will enable Iraq to govern itself, sustain its own economy, and defend its own future.

As for your second question, I appreciate your concern about the current situation and the American troops stationed in Iraq. We are focused on supporting the sovereignty and stability of a democratic Iraq. That said, a specific timetable for troop reduction is not something we are going to commit to publicly, as it would be premature and could undermine our efforts. The conditions on the ground, our success in stabilizing the region, and the ability of the Iraqi Security Forces to take the lead in their nation's security will all be factors we evaluate as we make decisions about the levels of coalition forces in Iraq. Our goal is to work with the Iraqi government to ensure that they are in a position to sustain their own security and that we can responsibly bring our troops home.

Thank you for your question. The mission in Iraq is about making the world a better place and keeping the American people safe. We've freed 25 million people from the clutches of Saddam Hussein. It was the right decision then, and it is the right decision now. The Iraqi people are starting to take responsibility for their future, and it's important for all of us to stay the course in order to help this new democracy take root.

As for the political consequences, I've always been clear that leading the country isn't about personal politics; it's about doing what's right for the future. I've had a strong mandate from the American people, and I'm committed to carrying out the responsibilities given to me. The outcome of any election is never certain, but the commitment to the security and prosperity of our nation will always be paramount.

Thank you for your question. I want to be very clear about the United States' commitment to the sovereignty of Iraq and its people. Our goal in Iraq has always been to support the emergence of a stable, democratic, and self-reliant Iraq that is capable of safeguarding its own sovereignty and security.

As for the imposition of martial law, which is a significant decision for any government to make, it is ultimately for the elected leaders of Iraq to determine their own path forward, guided by their constitution and the needs of their people. We have been encouraging a political process that represents all Iraqis and respects the rule of law.

While the Iraqi Government has our full support in efforts to combat terrorism and restore security, the role of U.S. forces is to enable Iraqis to take the lead in their own security and stabilization. This includes training and equipping Iraqi security forces so that they can take over all responsibilities. 

We will continue to work closely with the Iraqi Government to find ways to support their efforts towards stability and security that are consistent with the principles of democracy and the rule of law. The United States is committed to supporting the Iraqi people as they seek to build a secure and prosperous nation.

The objective of the planned offensive in Fallujah is to secure the city and remove the insurgents who have been using it as a base of operations to attack Iraqi civilians and U.S. and Iraqi forces. This operation is a continuation of our mission to establish and extend the authority of the Iraqi interim government throughout all of Iraq. 

The stakes are high for our coalition, for the Iraqi government, and for the Iraqi people. Insurgents based in Fallujah have hindered reconstruction efforts, threatened regional stability, and have prevented the return of thousands of refugees to their homes. Clearing Fallujah is crucial to providing a measure of safety to the Iraqi people in that region, as well as securing the roads leading to Baghdad. This will help support the upcoming elections, including a secure environment that allows Iraqis in Anbar province to participate safely.

By working together with the interim government of Iraq and the multinational force, we are committed to promoting a safer and more stable Iraq where free and fair elections can be held. We believe that as Iraqis take more responsibility for their own security and governance, they will be better positioned to resist the violent actions of the insurgents and their supporters. This is a key phase in the effort to hand over security responsibilities from the coalition forces to the capable and growing Iraqi security forces.

I appreciate the question on the Secretary of Defense's responsibilities. The Secretary of Defense has a lot of duties to carry out as part of his role in successfully defending our country. I believe that he has an obligation to make sure that the families of fallen troops are treated with respect and compassion, and that the process for sending them a message of condolence from the Department of Defense is effectively carried out.

It's important to note that the Secretary of Defense's role includes many critical functions, such as strategic planning, managing military resources, and ensuring that our forces are well-trained and prepared to defend our nation. Ensuring that the process for conveying condolences is in place and carried out effectively is also a part of that role. If there are concerns about how that process is being handled, the best approach is to work with the leadership to ensure that the families of our fallen service members are given the respect and care they deserve.

As for whether my view of this particular issue matches up with other considerations I have as President, my priority is achieving all aspects of national security and bringing stability to our nation, while also providing the military families with the support and care they need. I'll work closely with the Department of Defense to ensure that everyone involved in this solemn duty is doing their job properly.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding Social Security reform, my Administration wants to replace a problem of the past with a solution for the future. We need a solution that strengthens the system for today's workers, protects the benefits for those who are currently retired, and guarantees benefits that are there for our younger generation. The debate on this subject has become one of a moral obligation to future generations. We must speak with a sense of clarity and urgency about the need to act on this, because we owe our kids and grandkids the opportunity to earn their own retirement benefits.

As for the timeline, I believe it is important to get the debate going so that we can pass meaningful reform in 2005. We've already begun working with members in the Senate, and we look forward to serious hearings in the House. There will be up-or-down votes, as promised. But there will be a period of discussion, and there will be compromise. It's imperative that we come together and make Social Security a reality for our younger generation.

Now, the willingness to drop personal accounts is a serious matter to discuss, but it’s important to understand that personal accounts are integral to our proposal. They serve not only as a way to boost retirement security but also as a means to empower individuals to make decisions about their own financial future. Personal accounts encourage ownership and responsibility. They would operate side by side with the Social Security system to ensure its long-term solvency. While I'm open to compromise and collaboration, the core principles of our reform plan, including personal accounts, should not be entirely dismissed.

Let me be clear, however: The goal is not just a bill, but a bill that can restore confidence in the system and secure the future of America's workers and retirees. We believe strongly in this issue and are committed to working through any challenges to achieve a fair and viable solution.

I appreciate your question. History has indeed shown that the decision to act in Iraq was the right one. The Iraqi people have worked tirelessly to seize their future by exercising their right to choose leaders democratically, and they wrote a constitution that recognizes the rights and aspirations of all their citizens.

The progress we are seeing in Iraq—with elections taking place, a constitution being drafted and ratified, and a democratic government being formed—is a significant achievement. It is an inspiration to people throughout the broader Middle East who have been living under tyrannical regimes for far too long.

The examples set by the Iraqi people and by others who have followed their lead—such as in Lebanon and Afghanistan—are stirring aspirations for freedom across the region. The despots and dictators now worry about the growing demand for liberty and justice. When given the chance, men and women choose freedom. And the advance of democracy in a region of the world filled with so much potential is of critical importance to our nation’s security and the peace of the world.

While we understand there is much work still to be done in Iraq and the broader Middle East, we recognize that any sharing of burdens in the war against terror is important. And as we continue to face future challenges, I take confidence knowing that brave men and women from many nations are unified in the cause of freedom.

Thank you for that question. I have deep respect for Mahmoud Abbas and the decisions that he is making to advance the cause of peace in the Middle East. While we discuss the issues of terror with him, and we share our concerns regarding the necessity of combating and eliminating terrorist groups, President Abbas is working on his own terms and within the framework of his political realities.

Israel's security is paramount, and we have consistent discussions with both the Israelis and Palestinians about the urgent need to close terrorist organizations. Hamas and other such organizations pose a significant threat to the peace process and the security of Israeli citizens. We support Israel's right to protect itself but also believe that a political solution, one where terrorism is renounced and dismantled, is key to a lasting peace.

President Abbas understands the importance of these measures, and we're continuing to work with him to find equitable yet enforceable solutions that bring about safety and stability for all involved. We want to see the Palestinian Authority succeed in its efforts to create a more peaceful environment and champion peace for their people and the region.

Thank you for that question. For the record, I'm confident that the people responsible for leaking classified information will be found, and I support a complete and thorough investigation to get to the truth of the CIA leak.

Regarding the concerns raised about my former nominee for the Supreme Court, I believe Harriet Miers to be a private citizen now and will defer to her and her counsel. It was important to have a confirmation process where nominees can speak freely about their legal philosophy without having to cave to pressure to say what some in Congress want to hear. While the process can be tough sometimes, I must stand by my decisions and trust in the abilities of the dedicated individuals I nominee for important positions.

I understand the public expects me to keep the focus on the duties of the Office of the President, and that is what I will continue to do. My team and I are committed to the agenda we have laid out to enhance our national security, preserve economic freedom, and improve the quality of life for all Americans. These are long-term goals that require constant effort and attention. I have every confidence in my administration and in the American people to push through these challenges.

We must stay focused on the main challenges we face: defending freedom, protecting our nation against terror, and spreading freedom to those who yearn for it. I will continue to work every day to keep our country safe, prosperous, and free. I'll deal with every issue that's in front of me, and will do my very best for the American people.

With regards to the investigations of Republican leaders in Congress, I can say that I have every confidence in the integrity and commitment of the Republican leadership. The rule of law applies to all, and it's important that any allegations are fully investigated. My focus is on the agenda that will serve the long-term interests of the United States and its citizens.

To address your concerns directly: I believe the actions taken by the National Security Agency to surveil the communications of suspected terrorists were legal and necessary to protect the American people. This program was conducted with the advice of our Justice Department's top lawyers and was within the four corners of the Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists (AUMF) that was passed by Congress shortly after September 11, 2001. It has also been reviewed and supported by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, a court that was established precisely for these types of matters when they concern national security.

Regarding the call for congressional hearings and an independent investigation, I believe that the policies and actions taken by this administration have been made in the interests of our national security. As for going before Congress to discuss this program, we have already shared a significant amount of information with select members of Congress and briefed them on the legality and the procedures of the program. I believe the American people need to trust their elected leaders, especially when it comes to matters involving national security and the defense of our nation.

The need to have a genuinely independent counsel was a concept during the Clinton administration that I think was once an appropriate legal process in a previous time. However, in this day and age, I believe it is more important for the Congress and the executive branch to work together to promote our common interests in protecting our country. I will continue to work with Congress to address any concerns they might have, and together, we will protect this country from further terrorist attacks.

I appreciate your question, and it's important we are clear on the status of our military and the challenges our troops face. The Pentagon study you are referring to likely pertains to a broader look at the readiness of our military services. It's accurate to say that our forces, because of the demands of the War on Terror and the deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan, are indeed strained.

Secretary Rumsfeld, who was in office at the time, used the term "overwhelmed" and then clarified this to mean that while the military was stretched, it could handle the current demands. However, it's also correct that General Casey, as the Commander in Iraq, noted the strain on forces in the context of the mission there. He accurately reflected the operational challenges U.S. forces faced at that time.

The point is that our military is tough and capable, but no military can deal with constant deployments without replenishing its forces and ensuring adequate time for rest, recovery, and necessary training. We were, and are, committed to winning the war on terror, but we are also mindful about the long-term readiness and sustainability of our armed forces.

As president, my focus has always been on using our military prowess wisely, both in ensuring mission success and in looking after the needs and well-being of our troops. We've taken steps to increase the size of the Army and the Marine Corps, augmenting the number of available soldiers and marines for deployment, as well as fighting for pay raises and benefits that help our soldiers and their families.

Thank you for your question. The success of the Iraqi people in taking control of their government is a vindication of our coalition's efforts, and it is certainly cause for celebration. The Iraqi people have shown courage and determination in the face of great adversity. They have stood up for their freedom, despite the challenges and violence they have faced. This is a victory for the cause of human freedom.

As for the political realities, leading in the face of difficult challenges is part of the responsibility of leadership. While we are mindful of the challenges and the sacrifices that our nation has made, we continue to remain committed to the values of freedom and peace. The relationship between political standing and our efforts to support and defend those values is complex and multi-faceted. The mission to defend the security of our country and the world from threats of terror remains a top priority, and we will continue to work towards that end with the strength and resolve that defines our nation.

The American people know that when we stand up for freedom, we do so for a cause bigger and more important than our own political gains. We do this because it is right, and because our founders endowed us with the unalienable rights of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. This leadership is vital not only for our security and prosperity but also for the world's. The freedom that we defend is a powerful and compelling force for good in the world, and we will continue to advocate for it.

Thank you for your question. The world should care about North Korea's missile tests because they pose a direct threat to global peace and security. Long-range missile tests by North Korea increase regional tensions, particularly for countries in the Asia-Pacific region, and challenge international norms and commitments to disarmament and non-proliferation. These actions also demonstrate North Korea's unwillingness to engage in serious dialogue and diplomacy towards resolving nuclear disarmament.

Regarding penalties for such actions, the international community has implemented a range of measures under the auspices of the United Nations Security Council, including sanctions aimed at restricting North Korea's ability to fund and develop its missile and nuclear programs. These sanctions include restrictions on financial transactions, trade, and travel related to the regime’s prohibited activities.

The European Union has been an active supporter of the international sanctions regime concerning North Korea. The EU also considers additional autonomous measures to complement these sanctions, often in response to new provocations or as part of a broader diplomatic strategy to address the North Korean nuclear issue.

It is crucial that any penalties are carefully coordinated with our international partners to ensure a unified and effective approach to addressing North Korea's actions. We continue to urge for a peaceful resolution through dialogue and diplomacy, emphasizing the importance of maintaining international solidarity in the face of North Korea's provocations.

I understand your concern. It's important to note that while federal support is crucial, we're dealing with a situation that involves multiple levels of government, as well as private organizations and volunteer groups, all working to help those affected by the hurricane.

The Department of Homeland Security is coordinating the federal response and recovery efforts, and our goal is to provide support where it's needed most. In the case of New Orleans, that means collaborating closely with state and local leaders to address their specific needs and challenges.

We've also recognized that the local government needs resources and support to rebuild and recover. That's why we're pushing forward with plans to assist with debris removal, water and power restoration, and other critical services. And while the local government has an important role to play, federal agencies are there to stand alongside them and help wherever they can.

As the recovery process moves forward, we will continue to assess the situation and ensure that federal resources are used effectively to help bring New Orleans back, and to aid other affected communities in the Gulf Coast region. Thank you for your interest in this important issue.

Thank you for your question. The Mark Foley situation has been a troubling affair, and it's truly unfortunate that it has come to light in this manner. It's clear that members of Congress have a responsibility to maintain high ethical standards, and any violations of these standards or cover-ups are unacceptable.

Regarding Speaker Hastert's position, he has taken steps to investigate the matter thoroughly and to ensure that the appropriate authorities are informed. I have confidence in his ability to lead this investigation with the seriousness it deserves. It's important, however, that the House of Representatives maintains the integrity that is expected of it in the eyes of the public. The allegations against Representative Foley are very serious, and they must be addressed with the utmost seriousness and transparency.

As for the impact on the midterm elections and party control, I would say that the American people will ultimately make their decision based on a variety of factors, including the overall performance of their government and representatives over an extended period. Individual incidents, while significant, should be considered in the broader context of the work being done to advance the country's interests.

It's a serious situation, and we must ensure that all appropriate authorities are involved, and that justice is served. The wellbeing of our youngest citizens is paramount, and we must do everything we can to protect them.

Thank you for your question. I can understand why such news would generate questions. As the commander-in-chief, I hold Attorney General Alberto Gonzales in high regard. However, it's also my job to expect full transparency and honest disclosure from all members of my Administration, including the Attorney General.

The Attorney General is a critical member of the Cabinet and must have the full and absolute trust of the American people. I have directed the Office of Counsel to Congress to provide the full scope of information behind the U.S. Attorney decisions. Those U.S. Attorneys were serving political appointees and the Attorney General made his decision based on a variety of standard criteria, such as performance and leadership. I've asked for a full accounting to be made public so there's transparency and accountability.

I understand the concern about accountability and transparency, and the Attorney General has been directed to provide a detailed explanation to clarify the situation. The damage to trust can be repaired through transparency and through the Attorney General's willingness to fully disclose all relevant facts about the U.S. Attorney decisions. The bottom line is that the Attorney General will regain the respect of the American people to the degree that he is open and honest in answering questions about this matter.

The most important thing is to provide the facts so that the American people can judge him based on that. As the President, I've taken the steps to ensure that this process is thoroughly investigated and that the results are made public to rebuild the trust between the Attorney General and the American public.

Thank you for your question. As we approach the final stages of my presidency, there are a few key priorities that still hold importance for me. I remain committed to the war on terror and the safety of our nation, continuing to ensure that everything possible is being done to locate and eliminate terrorists and their networks. This includes further strengthening our security at home and abroad, as well as supporting our troops who continue to serve in harm's way.

Additionally, I'm focused on education reform, with the No Child Left Behind Act being a significant part of my legacy and an area where I believe we can continue to make improvements to ensure that every child receives a quality education.

Regarding immigration, it is indeed one of the most challenging issues facing the country, and I believe a comprehensive solution is needed. My administration has proposed an immigration bill that addresses the humanitarian needs of the undocumented workers, the need for skilled workers in our economy, and of course, the matter of national security. I am concerned that the bill might become embroiled in electoral politics. However, it is imperative that we work through any political differences to address this important issue in a way that is fair to both the immigrants and the American people.

I also want to ensure that my administration's record on the environment, space exploration, and economic growth is well recognized and appreciated. We have worked to ensure that we balance economic growth with responsible stewardship of our natural resources, and we have expanded our presence in space with the Vision for Space Exploration.

In discussing these priorities with Congress and the public, I continue to emphasize the importance of bipartisanship and working together to move America forward in a way that will benefit future generations. It is my hope that efforts like the immigration bill can transcend partisan differences to become good policy that serves the American people.

Thank you for your time and for giving me an opportunity to outline some of my remaining goals and concerns as we approach the conclusion of my term as President.

Thank you for your question. First and foremost, the decision to liberate Iraq and remove Saddam Hussein from power was not one I undertook lightly. It was made after careful consideration of the very real threats that existed at the time - threats of weapons of mass destruction and the potential for Saddam Hussein to align with terrorist organizations.

Regarding your suggestion about peacekeepers, I believe that the stabilization and peacekeeping efforts in Iraq are already well underway through the multinational force that is working with the Iraqi government to establish security and foster the growth of democratic institutions. The United Nations and our coalition partners have been involved in assisting Iraq as it builds a more prosperous and free nation.

While I acknowledge that the conflict has led to challenges, including the displacement and loss of life you mentioned, it is also important to note the sacrifices of our servicemen and women, their families, and our coalition partners. We must also recognize the progress made in Iraq: free elections, a new and democratic government, and the empowerment of Iraq's people to determine their own future.

It is true that terrorist organizations have taken advantage of the chaos and instability, and that is why the coalition has been working diligently to combat these threats, and providing the Iraqi security forces with the training and support they need to maintain their own security.

Ultimately, it is the Iraqi people who will determine the future of their country. The United States and our coalition partners have been committed to helping Iraqis build on the progress that has been made, and we will continue to work towards a peaceful and prosperous Iraq that is an ally in the war against terror and a model of freedom in the Middle East.

Well, thank you for that question. It's important for us to remember that the Department of Homeland Security is responsible for the safety and security of our country, and that means they are constantly monitoring for threats and working to protect our nation. Secretary Ridge's comments are a reflection of the ongoing vigilance we must maintain and the responsibility we have to our fellow citizens to ensure their safety.

Regarding the specifics, Secretary Ridge and I are in constant communication. There is no room for complacency when it comes to homeland security, and I trust that all the agencies involved are relying not just on intuition but on the best intelligence and information available to assess potential threats. We've increased our awareness levels to help our first responders and law enforcement officials be extra vigilant during this time.

As for my gut, while I take the concerns of our national security officials very seriously, it's also essential to make decisions based on all the facts and available intelligence. We're taking all reasonable precautions, but I'm confident in the work that our homeland security team is doing to keep us informed and protected.

Thank you for the question. First, let me express my concern for the American families who are enduring hardship as a result of record-high gas prices. We want to make sure our citizens are getting a fair deal as they fill up their cars and as they are concerned about the economy in general.

In the short term, we're determined to take action on the energy front. We're looking at the increased use of ethanol, natural gas, clean coal, and renewables like wind and solar. Additionally, I put forth an initiative to reduce gasoline consumption in the United States by 20 percent over the next ten years. The initiative includes supporting scientific research and development of hydrogen-powered vehicles, which could provide an alternative and possibly fuel the cars of the future.

Our National Energy Policy will address these issues comprehensively. It will propose to Congress legislation to reduce America's dependence on foreign sources of oil, diversify our energy supply, and encourage the development and use of advanced technologies. We believe that a diversified approach is necessary to truly address the challenges affecting the entire energy spectrum facing our nation.

Regarding the role of OPEC, my Energy Secretary Randy E. Lee has emphasized the influence of OPEC in keeping prices high and their responsibility to address the situation and provide sufficient supply to the market to reflect the demand. We believe that a sufficient supply should be available to meet economic conditions and we're watching the situation closely with OPEC.

Ultimately, as President, my goal is to work with Congress to enact policies that will lower energy prices and make us less dependent on foreign oil in the long term. We are coordinating our efforts globally, talking with our friends and allies about how we can work together to reduce the pain at the pump and secure the nation's energy future.

Thank you for your questions, which address the evolving relationship between the United States and the European Union. The United States welcomes the European Union as a steadfast partner and one of our most important allies. The strength of the transatlantic bond has been a cornerstone of international stability and security for decades, and I believe it will continue to be so.

A strong, united Europe is not a threat to the United States; rather, it is an opportunity for enhanced cooperation in addressing global challenges, promoting democratic values, and fostering economic prosperity. Both our nations and the EU member states share values such as freedom, democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. These shared values are the foundation of our partnership and should always confirm that we aim to work together to achieve common goals.

As for the prospect of the EU becoming the world's leading economy, that is not a concern for the United States. Instead, it is an opportunity for mutually beneficial trade and economic policies that benefit the citizens of both regions. Economic strength on one side does not mean economic weakness on the other; we can compete and collaborate to grow together and ensure that our economies remain vibrant and innovative.

Regarding the engagement of the United States in Europe, I am committed to maintaining and strengthening this relationship. The U.S. engagement in Europe is not a function of the economic stature of other regions, but rather a reflection of our commitment to the shared interests and the security architecture of the Euro-Atlantic area. We continue to support NATO and look forward to a Europe where all nations, through the institutions of NATO and the EU, work together for our common security and prosperity.

In sum, I believe the partnership between the United States and Europe must remain strong and unshaken. We are committed to working closely with the European Union on a range of issues from economic development to democratic governance and security cooperation. This is a testament to the enduring importance of transatlantic relations.

Thank you for your question, Nick. I understand the speculation and questions that can arise in the aftermath of such a devastating event as 9/11, but I want to be very clear about our country's response and approach to dealing with the threats posed by Iraq.

It is not accurate to say that I had already made the decision to invade Iraq just six days after 9/11. In fact, my immediate focus was on responding to the attacks themselves, which required us to mobilize a comprehensive and robust campaign against the perpetrators of that heinous act. The responsibility for 9/11 lay squarely with Osama Bin Laden and the al-Qaeda organization, which is why we moved swiftly to form a coalition to respond to these terrorist attacks.

The threat posed by Iraq, however, was separate and distinct from the initial fight against al-Qaeda. Our administration did begin to explore options to deal with Iraq over time, recognizing that Saddam Hussein had a history of aggression and a willingness to use weapons of mass destruction. We also had concerns about his possible connections to terrorist groups and the need to ensure weapons of mass destruction weren't finding their way into the hands of terrorists.

We engaged in diplomacy and sought international support for addressing Iraq's ongoing violations of United Nations resolutions and its refusal to comply with weapons inspections. This was not a charade. Diplomacy was a crucial part of our efforts to find a solution that could disarm Iraq and stabilize the region without resorting to military action.

When it became evident that Saddam Hussein would not give up his weapons of mass destruction voluntarily, we presented the case for disarming Iraq to the international community, including the United Nations Security Council. The inspections process continued, but unfortunately, it became apparent that Saddam was not cooperating as required.

Our decisions relating to Iraq were guided by the need to uphold international law and safeguard the interests of the United States and its allies. It was a decision based on the gravest of circumstances and the threat posed to our country and the global community.

In summary, our actions were proportionate to the threat we faced, and we took every possible diplomatic avenue before taking the step of going to war. The plans for Iraq were not preordained nor were they a substitute for a genuine and thorough diplomatic effort to solve the problem.

Thank you for your question. It is our intention to protect the lives of innocent civilians and to minimize harm wherever possible. However, the terms of any military operations, including the safety of inspectors, humanitarian workers, and journalists, would be carefully planned to balance these considerations with the effectiveness and success of the mission. Our priority is to ensure that the inspectors, humanitarian workers, and journalists can leave Iraq safely while we take necessary actions to address the serious threats posed by Saddam Hussein. I cannot go into details about our specific military plans, but I can assure you that the safety and lives of these individuals are of paramount concern to us as we proceed.

To address the first part of your question regarding the relationship between Russia and the United States, differences in political systems, strategic goals, and historical context certainly contribute to the challenges we face in maintaining a strong bilateral relationship. However, it's important to recognize that throughout history, despite these differences, the United States and Russia have been able to cooperate on matters of mutual interest. For example, even during the height of the Cold War, we found ways to work together to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and manage crises where our interests overlapped.

As for the second part of the question directed specifically at me, the United States acts in accordance with its Constitution and international law. We do work with the United Nations in many instances to achieve our foreign policy objectives, but when we believe that there is a critical matter requiring action to protect U.S. national security or regional stability and waiting would be disastrous, we have felt it necessary to act. This was the case with Iraq, where intelligence pointed to Saddam Hussein's possession of weapons of mass destruction and a direct threat to our security. After international efforts to persuade Saddam to disarm failed, and with his repeated violations of UN resolutions, the United States, with a coalition of nations, acted to disarm Iraq and liberate its people from a brutal regime.

In the future, the U.S. will continue to work with international bodies and seek the support of allies for common goals. However, we will also act decisively when we believe it is necessary to do so to protect the lives and interests of our citizens.

Thank you for your question. When it comes to the 9/11 attacks, my Administration was faced with an unprecedented terrorism threat that we did not fully understand or anticipate, and we're deeply committed to ensuring that never happens again. We have been focused on improving intelligence sharing and enhancing our understanding of potential threats across the government.

Regarding the Iraq threat, our intelligence community assessed that Saddam Hussein posed a serious threat, both to regional stability and to the United States, in part because of concerns of weapons of mass destruction. The intelligence was publicly presented to the international community and to the United States Congress, which authorized the use of force. The decision to go to war in Iraq was made after careful deliberation, and we believed the potential threat required swift action.

The appropriate threat level to justify action in future situations is a matter that will be determined on a case-by-case basis. Just as an immediate response was needed to the attacks of 9/11, and sometimes swift action is necessary to pre-empt urgent threats, our decisions about future actions will be based on the specific circumstances and the best intelligence we have available. It is our responsibility to protect this great nation and our friends and allies from terrorist threats. We will continue to monitor threats and take appropriate measures to prevent attacks, employing every tool at our disposal to ensure the safety and security of the American people.

Thank you for your question. Our commitment in Iraq was to help the Iraqi people liberate themselves from the brutal rule of Saddam Hussein. We acknowledged that we faced many challenges as we helped the Iraqi people build a new government that respects the rule of law, and protects the freedom and rights of all its citizens.

Transitions to democracy are never easy, and it's important to remember the significant progress Iraq has made since the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime. Iraqis have now been able to vote in free elections, have a democratically elected government, and have representatives in an elected parliament. The Iraqi people have shown tremendous courage and determination in the face of great challenges and violence.

We worked closely with the Iraqi government and were focused on building the capacity of that government to maintain security and stability in the country. We have had a robust military and civilian effort to train Iraqi security forces and enable them to take the lead in securing their own country. Of course, much has been difficult and mistakes were made, which we have acknowledged. However, the Iraqi people, with the support of the United States and other coalition partners, have made significant progress toward building a future of hope in a free and democratic Iraq.

It's important to look at the outcomes and the historical context of the situation in Iraq. While we did face challenges, we also saw the Iraqi people rise up to establish a new democracy in the heart of the Middle East, a feat that would bring hope and possibilities for peace and cooperation in the region.

To address your question directly, we have informed you that Saddam Hussein and his regime had long-standing ties to Al Qaida. We're dealing with an enemy that we understand shares certain objectives with Al Qaida, they both want to hurt the United States, and they both hold a common enemy.

Now, as for the qualifiers, it is important to understand the context and the complexity of the situation. Our government carefully evaluates intelligence to make diplomatic and military decisions, and we base these evaluations on the best information available to us. In the case of Saddam Hussein, his regime provided safe haven and support to terrorist groups like Abu Nidal, which were considered part of the broader terrorist network.

Regarding the best evidence of ties, we based our assessments on intelligence that included interactions between senior members of the Saddam Hussein regime and Al Qaida operatives. This would include things like financial assistance, sharing of intelligence, and training of terrorists in various techniques. It is also important to point out that even as the U.S. intelligence community assesses the nature and extent of the ties, the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime to our country was clear and present, warranting the actions we took.

Again, it's important to recognize that statements about the links between Saddam Hussein's regime and terrorist organizations are indeed matters of serious intelligence that must be handled with prudence and care to ensure the safety and security of both the United States and our allies.

Thank you for your questions. The United States and the Afghan Government work closely together to address the challenges posed by terrorism and insurgency in Afghanistan. We have a strong partnership with the Karzai Government, and the issue of prisoner custody and related matters is an integral part of that cooperation and trust-building.

Regarding your first question, the treatment of detainees is a matter of utmost importance to us, and we follow strict guidelines to ensure the humane and legal treatment of all individuals in our care. We are committed to working with our Afghan partners to ensure that due process is followed and that detainees are treated fairly and justly. As for transferring custody to the Afghan Government, we continue to work in consultation with the Afghan authorities under the auspices of the bilateral security agreement to ensure the process is carried out responsibly and respects the security and interests of both countries.

In answer to your second question, it is important to support the sovereignty and government-led efforts in Afghanistan. We are dedicated to coordinating closely with the Afghan Government on matters related to military activities, respecting the Afghans' leadership in their own country, and supporting their government's authority.

With respect to your final question on the discussions with President Karzai about the prisoner abuse issue at Bagram, yes, President Karzai and I discussed these matters during our meetings. Transparency and accountability were, and continue to be, of paramount importance to us. We have taken steps to investigate and, where appropriate, address the allegations of abuse rigorously and with transparency. It's a part of our ongoing commitment to upholding our values and working collaboratively with our allies, including the Afghan Government, to maintain the highest standards of conduct and ethical behavior.

Thank you for your question. We are in close consultations with our European allies about Iran's provocative decision to resume its uranium conversion activities in direct violation of its obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the requirements of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). It is clear that Iran's actions are unacceptable and intended to deceive the international community about the true nature of its nuclear program.

We will continue to work closely with our European allies to resolve this issue through diplomatic efforts. However, if Iran does not choose to comply with the demands of the international community, we will have no choice but to pursue a robust response in the United Nations Security Council for punitive measures against Iran. The nature and extent of these measures would be determined in cooperation and consultation with our partners, but they must effectively convey the seriousness of the situation to the Iranian leadership and demonstrate that the international community will not tolerate such threats to global security and stability. Sanctions could include economic measures, travel restrictions, and other punitive actions designed to pressure Iran into compliance with its international obligations.

Thank you for your question. Dealing with the crisis in Darfur is indeed one of the critical issues we are focusing on as a part of our foreign policy. The Sudanese government has not always cooperated with efforts to bring stabilization and security to the region. We will continue to work with our international partners, such as the United Nations, African Union, and European Union, to apply diplomatic and economic pressures as necessary to ensure that the Sudanese government fulfills its responsibility to protect its citizens.

My message to the Sudanese government is clear: there must be a commitment to ending the violence and ensuring that humanitarian aid reaches those in need. We will support efforts that lead to a lasting peace and stability, and hold accountable those who continue to obstruct the path to peace. The tragedy in Darfur continues to be a grave human rights issue, and the United States will continue to advocate for peace, justice, and the alleviation of suffering in the region.

Thank you for your question. In terms of any flights for rendition, the Department of Justice has put out a letter confirming that the federal policy against overseas rendition to torture does not violate U.S. obligations under the Convention Against Torture. I have not received specific intelligence briefings regarding the flights you're asking about.

The Department of Justice has fully investigated any claims of CIA flights, and I have spoken — the Director of the CIA, Leon Panetta, has spoken on this issue as well. We're not going to discuss any ongoing investigations or interrogations. The European Council's report is a matter of concern to the United States, and we've made clear that any allegations of wrongdoing will receive appropriate scrutiny and that transparency is an important part of maintaining our relationships with international partners. 

As for my meetings today, I cannot go into specific details of the discussions or any agreements reached, but I can say we had productive and frank discussions with our European partners about a variety of international issues. Anyone with more specific questions about CIA operations or any flights should speak with the Department of Justice or the CIA directly for clarification on the stance of the United States government.

I understand your question, and first, let me say that the war on terror is a test of our will. We must not waiver; we must stay strong and stay focused. Saddam Hussein was a tyrant, and he had weapons of mass destruction. He murdered many people. I understand this can be an each day, grueling fight for our troops and for our country, but it is important that we face the terrorists and those that support them head-on and bring them to justice.

As for moments of doubt, I would say that every commander in chief has moments of reflection and concern for the well-being of our troops. There's no question the situation in Iraq has been challenging, and we've faced difficult, unexpected challenges along the way. But we knew it would be tough, and we have a responsibility to bring peace and freedom to that part of the world. We're laying a foundation for democracy and creating space for others to live freely. We're helping future generations of Iraqis live in a more hopeful and free society. This is the right mission, and it's essential that we see it through with perseverance. We will not waver. We will not tire. We will not give up.

Listen, I understand the allegations the media is putting out there. But let me be very clear, I never used, nor did I ever authorize anyone else to use partisan politics in making personnel decisions at the United States Department States Department of Justice. I expect that, not only did I do that, but I expect exactly that from all appointments I make in my administration. The service to the United States of America is a noble one, and I expect our public servants to be above reproach. I expect people to uphold the law, and they must not engage in anything but the most ethical way of acting while doing their job.

Now, as far as instructions to the Attorney General, I have spoken with the Attorney General regarding personnel decisions that were to be made, but I do not recall specific instructions at this moment. I did ask him to make sure he followed the procedures and rules of the Department of Justice, and to make decisions based on the law and merit. I expected the people serving in these roles to uphold the rule of law and to serve their country well.

In response to any rumors or allegations, I believe the Attorney General has informed you of his side of the story. I urge everyone to consider the integrity of the public servants in our justice system, for they are essential to upholding our democracy. If there are concerns, by all means, investigate them. But I urge you to keep in mind the integrity of our judicial and law enforcement officials and not to question their motives unfairly.

I understand that it can appear that there are frustrations and challenges in working with Congress, but I approach our relationships with a desire for collaboration and progress. I believe in the democratic process where we can often find common ground despite differences. Sometimes it takes time, and sometimes you must give direction, as you see in my State of the Union address.

Regarding specific issues like the economic agenda, the trade agreement with Colombia, and the FISA legislation, I've taken actions that I believe are best for the United States. I have called for Congress to support these initiatives and presented my case to the American people. I remain committed to achieving our goals through dialogue, leadership, and working with both Republicans and Democrats where we can find areas of agreement.

I don't spend my time being angry, but rather focused on the American people's needs. As president, my responsibility is to lead and to set the course for what I believe is best for the country. I have a positive outlook and hope to see progress in working with Congress on a range of matters this year. Together, we can make the United States a stronger, safer, and more prosperous nation.

First, let me address your question about American oil producers. The United States has been working to increase energy security and reduce our dependence on foreign oil. This includes exploring and developing domestic energy sources, including offshore drilling. Regulations, technological advancements, and the current economic climate all impact the decisions made by American oil producers. It's my hope that as we balance environmental stewardship with energy needs, we can achieve a secure and sustainable energy future.

Regarding your second question about Iraq and an agreement with Prime Minister Maliki, it's true that we've been working on transitional arrangements with the Iraqi government. We've made significant progress in our relationship with Iraq, helping them establish a democratic system and ensuring security and stability in the region. Any agreements related to American operations, specifically on our active presence and programs in Iraq, are complex and would need careful consideration to ensure they respect Iraqi sovereignty and our commitment to the security and stability of the region.

As for the future, decisions about such agreements would need to be made in consultation with the Iraqi government and would respect the coming change in the U.S. administration. It's not my intention to bind my successor with long-term agreements that would not yet be ready to be signed. If there's a need for an interim framework, it would be designed to ensure a smooth transition and not set definitive policies for the next Administration to follow but to provide a pathway to such policies.

Thank you for the question. When the policy on stem cell research was announced, the information on the state of the 60 cell lines was based on what was known at the time. The science is constantly evolving, and new data can emerge that changes our understanding of any given research field.

The intent behind the policy was to support stem cell research while respecting the sanctity of human life. At the time, we believed that there were eligible stem cell lines available for research. Since then, advancements in the field have provided new insights.

To address the points you raised, it's important to clarify that we did not have immediate, precise knowledge of every technical detail about the cell lines at the time the policy was set. However, the policy was intended to follow ethical guidelines and our understanding of science as of that period. 

It's also important to note that the FDA guidelines are crucial in ensuring the safety and efficacy of biomedical products. The integration of cells with other tissues could indeed affect their practicality for therapeutic use, which is why ongoing research and strict adherence to regulatory standards are so important.

In light of the evolving nature of scientific knowledge, we continue to evaluate the regulations and approaches to ensure they meet the goals of advancing medical research while upholding our values.

Thank you for your question. This is a very serious issue that has caused great pain and suffering to the victims and their families. It is not the time for finger-pointing; it is the time for action.

I have great respect for Cardinal Law and the Catholic Church. However, the question raised by the allegations in Boston is one of the highest moral and ethical responsibilities in leadership, which is to act in the best interest of the community and protect the vulnerable. The Church must take immediate and diligent action to address this crisis, bring healing to the victims, and prevent these acts from occurring again.

I urge the Boston Archdiocese and all institutions to respond swiftly in investigating and addressing the charges. Victims must feel that justice is being served, and I know that all right-thinking people agree that protecting the vulnerable, especially children, is absolutely critical. The institution must also demonstrate a clear commitment to reforms that ensure the trust of the people in religious leadership is restored.

The issue at hand is about ensuring that we have the appropriate resources to tackle corporate wrongdoing effectively. I appreciate your interest in this, and I'd like to clarify a few points based on the information you've provided.

Firstly, let me emphasize that we are committed to holding wrongdoers accountable, and we are working to empower our enforcement agencies to achieve this goal. The changes we proposed last week are designed to give the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) more robust tools in the fight against fraud.

I understand the viewpoint expressed by some Republicans in Congress and our own SEC Chairman regarding the need for additional funding. We are certainly open to constructive conversations and are evaluating all options to ensure that the SEC has the support it needs to operate effectively.

It's important that we strike the right balance between empowering our enforcement agencies and ensuring fiscal responsibility. We will work closely with Congress to align our efforts and resources towards achieving comprehensive reform while maintaining public confidence in our capital markets.

Thank you for bringing this up, and rest assured that our Administration is dedicated to making the necessary adjustments to address the concerns expressed by various stakeholders in this process.

Good evening. The issue of immigration is one that we take very seriously. The United States is, and will always remain, a nation of immigrants. We respect the essential contribution that immigrants, both legal and illegal, have made in growing our economy. However, it is also true that, to address the issue effectively, we need to ensure a system that is orderly, legal, and secure.

Regarding the migratory agreement with Mexico, I can tell you that the administration is committed to working with our neighbor, Mexico, to create a system that helps secure our borders while also addressing the demand for labor from both countries. Both nations have a shared interest in combating the criminals and smugglers that prey on vulnerable migrants.

As for your question about former President Carter’s suggestion for amnesty, the stance of our administration has been clear. We believe in a three-step approach that involves securing our borders, enforcing the law, and creating a temporary worker program. Comprehensive immigration reform should not include amnesty for those who enter the country illegally. Instead, we favor a rational and just approach that respects the law and does right by workers and their employers. 

However, we are open to discussing all proposals that aim to improve the current system and address the needs of all parties involved. Thank you for the question.

Good afternoon to the representative from TVN Polish Network. I appreciate the opportunity to address Poland's role in Central and Eastern Europe and its relationship within the context of enhanced relations between the United States and Russia.

Poland plays a significant role in the security and stability of Central and Eastern Europe, and as a valued partner of the United States, its contributions are vital. Poland's leadership during the Solidarity movement and its transition from a communist state to a thriving democracy serve as an inspiration to other nations in the region and beyond.

In the context of a new era of enhanced relations between the United States and Russia, Poland's position remains steadfast in promoting democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. Poland, as part of the NATO Alliance, continues to support collective defense and to promote regional stability.

Poland's role in this region includes:

1. **Contributions to NATO Missions**: Poland continues to support NATO's security missions, ensuring the collective defense of our Alliance members. This commitment aligns with the principles of strengthening mutual defense and promoting regional security.

2. **Leadership in the European Union**: Poland is an active member of the European Union, contributing to its growth and strengthening European integration. Leading by example in areas such as economic development, social cohesion, and political reforms, Poland is an important model for other nations.

3. **Promotional of Stability and Prosperity**: Through economic development initiatives and regional cooperation, Poland fosters stability and prosperity in Central and Eastern Europe. This includes supporting the integration of neighboring states and working towards the economic and political development of the region.

4. **Diplomatic Engagement**: Poland is involved in diplomatic efforts within the United Nations, the OSCE, and other international organizations, advocating for democracy and human rights, as well as for a stable and secure Europe.

While the United States works towards improved relations with Russia, we also uphold our commitments to our NATO allies, including Poland, and will continue to support and cooperate with Poland in enhancing stability, security, and prosperity in Europe. Poland's actions align with both its national interests and our collective pursuit of peace and security.

Thank you for highlighting this important subject, and I hope this answers your question.

Thank you for your question. As we approach our visit to Europe, it's important to recognize the role the United States has played in helping to bring about a new, independent government in Iraq, one that is now more capable of taking control of its own destiny. We are committed to supporting Iraq as it strives for sovereignty and security, and this visit is an opportunity to emphasize that commitment and underscore the importance of a strong partnership moving forward.

We believe in the sovereignty of Iraq and will continue to advocate for its interests and security. This support will take many forms, from our cooperation with Iraqi security forces to ensure stability and combat against terrorism, to our diplomatic efforts aimed at fostering peace and prosperity in the region.

Our goal is to ensure that Iraq is a stable and prosperous country that contributes positively to the Middle East and global peace. By working together with European allies and other partners, we can support Iraq's transition to a responsible nation and help shape a future that benefits not only the Iraqi people but the international community at large.

Thank you for your question.

Good morning, Dennis. I appreciate the question, and it's important to recognize the significant commitment we've received from our close allies, such as Australia, in the fight against extremism. Prime Minister Howard, his government, and the Australian people have been steadfast supporters in the global war on terror.

The duration of our troops' deployments in Iraq and Afghanistan is primarily determined by the progress made on the ground, as well as the strategic assessments of what's necessary to ensure stability in these regions and protect both allied and local populations. We are continuously evaluating and adjusting our strategies based on the changing circumstances and the cooperation of local forces and populations.

We've seen significant progress and are dedicated to ensuring that the sacrifices of Australian and other coalition forces result in a safer and more secure Middle East. Our goal is to establish conditions in Iraq and Afghanistan that allow for the withdrawal of our troops as soon as it is safe and responsible to do so. However, the timeline is not set or measured in convenient time periods such as months or years; it's measured by the criteria that ensure enduring peace and security.

It's not my intention to give a specific timeline without a clear picture of what the future holds, particularly given the unpredictability of the situation on the ground. However, rest assured, the safety and support of our allies, including Australia, continue to be of the utmost importance. We will work closely with the Australian government to provide them with regular updates and assessments. Thank you.

First and foremost, I want to express my profound sympathy and support for those affected by the hurricanes. As we focus on the immediate relief efforts and recovery for the affected communities, it's vital that we balance the need for compassion and recovery with fiscal responsibility. That's why we're working in a bipartisan fashion to craft legislation that will provide the necessary support for the affected areas without jeopardizing our economic health or fiscal stability.

It is our priority to ensure that the money is used efficiently. We will be very careful with the allocation of funds, focusing not only on immediate needs such as food, water, and shelter but also on long-term recovery planning. This involves rebuilding infrastructure and supporting communities so they can get back on their feet.

Regarding the national debt, we remain committed to addressing it over the long term. While it's understandable that any significant expenditure can impact our fiscal balance in the short term, the longer-term health of our economy still rests on maintaining a responsible approach to spending, investing in growth, and promoting policies that foster economic stability and prosperity for all Americans.

We believe that by prioritizing and coordinating efforts effectively, we can minimize the long-term financial strain while ensuring that the people in the affected areas receive the support they need to recover. We will also look to find ways to fund these efforts without increasing the overall burden on future taxpayers, but rather through targeted and responsible measures.

Well, thank you for your question. The international community, led by the United Nations Security Council, has a critical role in bringing about a durable cease-fire and a lasting peace in Lebanon. We support efforts aimed at bringing a comprehensive and sustained resolution to this conflict.

The Security Council has passed Resolution 1701, which calls for a full cessation of hostilities and outlines measures to achieve a durable cessation of hostilities, in coordination with Lebanese governmental authorities. This resolution puts forth a plan that includes the full withdrawal of Hezbollah's fighters from south Lebanon, the disarmament of all non-state actors, and the full deployment of the Lebanese army and UNIFIL to the south of Lebanon to maintain peace and security.

Pressing Hezbollah to comply with this resolution, as well as diplomatic engagement from both regional and world powers, will be crucial. It is important for Hezbollah to understand that their actions have consequences and that continuing to fuel conflict will only lead to further pressure and isolation. The international community must also address the concerns and interests of all parties involved carefully, to ensure the long-term stability and security of the region.

Ultimately, it is in the interest of all concerned to stop the cycle of violence and to move towards a peaceful and stable resolution, ensuring the sovereignty of Lebanon and the safety of its citizens.

Thank you for your question. The anniversary of Hurricane Katrina serves as a poignant reminder of the challenges that our fellow citizens faced, and how as a nation, we came together to help our brothers and sisters in need. The levee breaks in New Orleans and the severe flooding in Mississippi and Alabama brought significant devastation, and recovery has been a critical and ongoing process.

Since Katrina struck, my administration has remained committed to aiding the recovery in the Gulf Coast region. We've taken an active role in working with state and local leaders to rebuild communities through various initiatives such as:

1. A comprehensive recovery plan allowing funds from the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Housing and Urban Development to support efforts in Mississippi and Louisiana.
2. Investments in new rebuilding designs for our levee systems to enhance the safety of New Orleans.
3. Revamping emergency response measures at the federal, state, and local levels to ensure a more effective management of future disasters.

The commitment to recovery and rebuilding remains steadfast. But we acknowledge that there are still a number of challenges ahead. These include long-term housing solutions, restoring economic opportunity in the region, and fostering the return of displaced residents. Education and health care are other critical areas needing attention to support the renewed vitality of these communities.

The work is not yet done, and, as President, I will continue to push for the recovery and rebuilding of the Gulf Coast, ensuring the resilience of the people who have shown such remarkable strength and determination in the face of unimaginable adversity.

I appreciate your follow-up on this, and I will be as clear as I can. We're dealing with a dangerous regime that has threatened the United States. We're dealing with a regime that is trying to develop capabilities to deliver weapons that could be devastating for our country.

I strongly support the work of Secretary Baker. Secretary Baker's work is primarily involved in helping me to conduct foreign policy, from which I derive the diplomatic efforts as I see fit. Our policy is outlined. We have a comprehensive strategy to fight the war on terror. And a part of that strategy is to isolate this dangerous regime, to warn the world about the dangers of that regime. And I'll continue doing so.

In one of the speeches I gave in Cincinnati, I recognized that we need to be working with ally nations -- like Saudi Arabia -- on the diplomatic front to encourage a diplomatic solution. So in other words, that's part of our diplomatic efforts in conducting a foreign policy, which is to engage other nations in diplomatic efforts here.

But at the end of the day, Iran is a dangerous regime. They're trying to develop a nuclear weapon capability, and we need to warn the world about it. And I appreciate the suggestions my colleagues bring to the table, but my words are clear, my policies are clear, and we are going to continue to conduct foreign policy here to make our country secure.

Thank you for your question. As President, it's important to acknowledge that all policies are results-oriented and our approach to Iraq has been about achieving stability, freedom, and security for both the Iraqi people and our nation. While the report by the Iraq Study Group, also known as the Baker-Hamilton Commission, offers valuable insights, I am committed to remaining focused on the goal of a free and democratic Iraq.

Let me be clear: Our strategy in Iraq rests on a foundation of support from the Iraqi government and the support of our coalition partners. This involves a comprehensive approach that includes training Iraqi forces and implementing political reconciliation. The status of forces agreement that we are negotiating with the Iraqi government is also critical in shaping our partnership with the new government that will be formed.

Regarding your question about direct engagement with Syria and Iran, our approach to these matters has been guided by one principle: working together to find solutions to the challenges we face, with an emphasis on concrete actions that will support our objectives in Iraq. We have been persistent in our dialogue with Syria and Iran, but it's crucial for them to take meaningful actions that contribute to the stability and security in Iraq.

As for the timeline for troop withdrawal, as the President, I do not favor a rigid timetable for withdrawing forces as it could have a destabilizing effect if not carefully considered. Our commitment to Iraq remains steadfast, and we will follow through with a responsible strategy that ensures the security of our forces and supports the emergence of a stable democratic Iraq capable of sovereignty.

We will continue to work closely with our commanders and will make decisions based on the best available information and the judgments of our military leaders on the ground. Our commitments to our troops and to the people of Iraq remain unwavering.

Thank you for your question, and I look forward to addressing any more issues regarding our national security or the efforts towards peace and stability in the region.

Thank you for your question. I would like to express my confidence in General Musharraf and the assurance that he has provided us. Pakistan is a valued ally in the global war on terror, and we continue to have a positive and constructive relationship with them.

Regarding General Musharraf's commitment, I believe that, as a leader, he understands the stakes involved and is committed to the partnership against terrorism. He has made clear his determination to combat the terrorist threat, and we will work closely with him to achieve our shared goals.

As for the internal turmoil in Pakistan, we recognize that this is a complex situation with serious and potential implications. Secretary Gates has articulated the Secretary of Defense's perspective on this significant issue. We are aware that the stability and effectiveness of the Pakistani government are crucial for our collective efforts against terrorism, particularly in supporting actions in Afghanistan. However, we are working actively with Pakistan's leadership to manage these challenges and ensure that the focus remains on the security and stability of both countries, and the broader region.

Thank you for your questions. I appreciate the interest that our friends in the media have in this matter. It is our hope and our expectation that Turkey will bring its incursion into northern Iraq to a rapid close. We understand Turkey's concerns regarding security threats from PKK terrorists. However, we have been in regular contact with Turkey, offering our support in addressing these terrorist threats while avoiding undue harm to the people in the region and ensuring the territorial integrity of Iraq.

We are working closely with our Turkish ally and with Iraqi officials to bring this to a resolution that addresses security concerns without undermining the sovereignty of Iraq or the regional stability that we're all committed to maintaining.

Our principal concern remains the potential for further destabilization, whether resulting from prolonged military operations or the possible disruption of our ongoing efforts to build a stable Iraq. We have emphasized to Turkey the importance of minimizing any negative impact on the broader region, and we are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts to facilitate the swift resolution of the situation.

Mr. President, I appreciate the question. Our first priority is to protect the American people from further attacks by al Qaeda and other terrorists. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act was crafted in the Cold War era and did not anticipate the kind of threats we face today. The FISA Court plays a crucial role in helping us stay ahead of these evolving dangers by providing judicial oversight over the targeted terrorist surveillance activities that the Congress approved in 2001.

We have seen firsthand the devastating effects of terrorist attacks, and I believe we must remain vigilant against the threats that could result in the death of Americans on American soil. We have worked very closely with Congress to ensure that we have a legal framework which allows us to defend our nation with the tools necessary to gather necessary intelligence while respecting constitutional requirements and the rule of law.

The measures we are taking are done with clarity of purpose and after extensive consultation and legislation with Congress, ensuring that our national security is not compromised and Americans can be confident that we are doing everything in our power to prevent another 9/11. I urge the House to remain focused on this mission and understand the urgency of it. We cannot afford to be passive in the face of a determined enemy.

Certainly, the Iraq war presented many challenges, and we faced situations that were complex and at times difficult to predict. In reflecting on the decision to go to war in Iraq in 2003, we took action based on the information we had and the intelligence provided to us by our government agencies and our allies.

If I were asked if I would have done anything differently based on what we know now, I would say that no administration can foresee every outcome or consequence of military action. Throughout the war in Iraq, the goal was always the safety and security of the American people and the hope for a peaceful, liberated Iraq.

We made decisions with the best information available at the time, and we committed deeply to helping Iraqis build a free, stable, and sovereign democratic nation. While the path was harder and lengthier than we initially envisioned, the sacrifice of the coalition forces and the resilience of the Iraqi people were critical to bringing about a peaceful and freer Iraq. We will always be proud of our men and women in uniform and the service they provided, and we are committed to supporting the new government of Iraq as it grows into its role as a stable, democratic ally.

Thank you for your question. First and foremost, we take any allegations of wrongdoing extremely seriously. Regarding the CIA leak case, the Department of Justice investigated the matter thoroughly and conducted a lengthy investigation, as they are required to do under the law. Special Counsel Patrick Fitzgerald was appointed, and he followed all the proper protocols to ensure a fair and just outcome.

I have always believed in the integrity of the institutions that serve this nation, and I have full confidence in the Justice Department's thoroughness. The results of the investigation are a matter of public record, and with respect to any individuals involved within the administration, we also held a separate and distinct internal investigation. As President, I take responsibility for protecting our country's national security while also ensuring that we follow the rule of law. That's exactly what was done in this case.

Regarding critics who suggest that the administration retaliates against naysayers, I categorically reject that notion. We believe in fostering an open and honest dialogue where people can express their views and concerns. That being said, we also have a responsibility to protect sensitive information that can compromise the safety of our nation and our people. It is essential to balance the need for transparency with the need to secure our national security.

Our commitment to upholding the law and the Constitution remains unwavering. We appreciate the scrutiny of the press and the people in ensuring our government functions as it should. While there may be disagreements on specific issues, I hope we can come together to focus on the greater good of our country.

Thank you for your question. We are gathering all the necessary information about Saddam Hussein and the actions that will follow his capture. The coalition will be considering all the options on the table regarding his fate, including the possibility of a trial. We are committed to making sure that any process involving him is fair, and we are working closely with coalition partners to determine the appropriate steps. The graves of thousands of innocent Iraqis are a stark reminder of the brutality of Saddam Hussein's regime, and we will proceed wisely to ensure justice is served. As far as execution being an option, that is not something I would like to speculate on at this point; however, accountability will be a priority. We will ensure that Saddam Hussein faces the consequences of his actions appropriately and transparently.

Thank you for your question. The situation in Northern Ireland has been a significant issue for the United States and for myself, and it is one that I take seriously as President.
