One of our strategies involves working closely with the Iraqi government to streamline bureaucratic processes and ensure that projects can be implemented more swiftly. We are also focusing on training and capacity-building to help the Iraqi institutions manage these funds effectively and to foster a climate that encourages private sector investment.

We understand that high unemployment is a major concern, and it is imperative that these reconstruction efforts create jobs and improve the economy. To this end, we are prioritizing projects that can provide immediate employment opportunities and support the growth of small and medium enterprises.

In terms of accelerating fund arrivals, we are currently communicating with donor nations to expedite the disbursement of committed funds. We are also clarifying project plans and timetables to provide clearer guidance to donors about the specific projects and infrastructure needs in Iraq.

We believe that by working together with our international partners, the Iraqi government, and the private sector, we can not only meet our goals for the reconstruction of Iraq but also lay a solid foundation for a prosperous and stable future for the Iraqi people.

Yes, the timetable that I laid out depends upon our troops and upon the Iraqis. And we will be able to withdraw our troops as necessary. We will do so with — but we are going to do so in a way that is going to protect the American people. My fundamental decision is to defeat the enemy over there so we don't have to face them here.

The Iraqis, in collaboration with our forces, are developing plans to secure their cities, their neighborhoods, and their country. We will adjust our troop levels based on the success of this Iraqi government in securing and stabilizing the country. We're laying down the benchmarks, as you call them, and we're going to expect the Iraqis to meet these benchmarks. And as they do, we'll be able to draw down our troops, and my objective is to keep the peace and defeat any enemy.

I understand the desire for a precise timeline. But a strict timeline that doesn't take into account Iraq's progress would remove a key incentive for the Iraqis to build the security forces needed to maintain their own stability and for our troops to defeat the enemy. And so as you can see, this is a very complex issue, and it requires a strategy that is flexible enough to adapt to the circumstances on the ground, yet also firm in its goal of putting the Iraqis in charge of their own security.

Thank you for asking that question. I'm aware of the allegations that have been made regarding Ambassador Bolton's conduct. I take any accusations of improper behavior seriously and, like you, have been monitoring these allegations closely.

However, I must also emphasize that Ambassador Bolton has not been found guilty of any wrongdoing, and until he has had an opportunity to respond, I will refrain from commenting further on specific allegations. 

Ambassador Bolton has a strong record of service, both in private practice and in public service. He is respected for his expertise and commitment to advancing American interests around the world. It is important to thoroughly investigate such matters, but as I mentioned, he is still presumed innocent until proven otherwise.

I believe Ambassador Bolton understands my personal standards of conduct and would act accordingly. If, after a thorough process, an investigation is required or warranted, we will act appropriately and follow the necessary protocols. My administration values integrity, and ensures that those we place in positions like the UN Ambassadorship uphold the highest ethical standards.

Thank you for the question. I want to commend the Prime Minister for his courage and leadership. He is a strong ally in the effort to fight terrorism. He’s been a leader in recognizing the danger of Hezbollah, which is an anti-Semitic terrorist organization.

To address your question about Arab nations and applying pressure to cease the ongoing conflict, it will ultimately take the commitment of leaders in the region to make concrete steps towards peace. We need to work collectively, leveraging the diplomatic efforts and dialogue with all nations involved, to create a unified front against terrorism and in support of peace. It is crucial for all parties to engage in negotiations and express a clear stance against the use of violence and terrorism as a means to political ends.

The Prime Minister and I share a commitment to fighting terrorism and standing up for the principles of freedom and democracy. We will continue to work with our allies and friends in the region to promote stability and peace.

Mr. President, the Iraq Study Group report is an important contribution to the ongoing discussion about the way forward in Iraq. I've made it very clear that the Iraq Study Group's ideas will be studied very carefully. As for your question on admitting failures, it's a responsibility of leadership to identify areas where progress isn't being made and to take the appropriate action.

Regarding our efforts in Iraq, we've made much progress since 2003, but there's still much work to be done. Our focus remains on helping the Iraqis assume more responsibility for their own security and for providing the kind of services that their citizens need. This is the way in which we're executing our strategy, and as General Petraeus, our current commander, and Ambassador Crocker have made clear, changes will be made based on facts on the ground and the assessment of our military leaders and diplomats.

So yes, it's absolutely important for a leader to be candid and open to changing course as circumstances require. That's what we're doing, and our commitment is to find the best path forward to protect our nation and bring about a stable and peaceful Iraq.

Thank you for your question. I understand and respect the perspectives of those in Congress, even as we have our differences. The security and interests of the American people are always my top priority. Regarding Iraq and our responsibilities in the region, I will continue to work closely with Congress and our military leaders to make decisions that ensure the long-term security of the United States and promote stability in Iraq.

When it comes to elections, senators and representatives must answer to their constituents. However, I believe that leadership in times of uncertainty and challenges is crucial. I am confident that the majority of Americans understand the importance of our efforts in Iraq to protect our homeland and advance the cause of freedom in the world. We have made significant progress, but we know there is still much work to be done to ensure a stable Iraq that can govern and sustain itself.

I am committed to working with members of my own party as well as those across the aisle to find the best course of action. I believe the American people will appreciate candor, leadership, and a focus on the long-term strategy for both the wellbeing of our nation and our troops. It's vital to continue supporting our troops and helping to build a stable and democratic Iraq, despite the challenges we face.

It's no secret that the war in Iraq faced skepticism and criticism from the moment it began. The test of leadership often requires making decisions that are not universally popular, especially during times of conflict. As President, I am acutely aware of the democratic process and the importance of the will of the people. However, it is also my responsibility to consider the national interest and the security of the American people.

Balancing the interests of democracy and the responsibility of leading a nation through conflict can be challenging. I understand and respect the value of a robust debate about our policies and actions. However, in matters of national security, the President must often make decisions based on what he believes is necessary to protect the country and its citizens, even if those decisions are not supported by every single American.

In the case of Iraq, my administration's position was that Saddam Hussein posed a threat to the United States and our coalition partners, and that his regime was harboring weapons of mass destruction and supporting terrorism. We also believed that by ending his rule, we could bring about a more peaceful and stable region.

The Congress authorized the use of force against Iraq based on the intelligence available at the time, and I took those responsibilities of office very seriously. Although the war has been a complex and difficult undertaking, I believe it was an action we had to take for the security of the American people and regional stability.

At the same time, it's important for the administration to engage with the American people, be open about the challenges faced, and continuously strive to gain support for our work and reflect the changing opinions and needs of the public. We've held many town hall meetings and provided information to keep Americans informed about the progress being made. It's crucial to be transparent and accountable, especially in times of great national importance.

Throughout my presidency, I've tried to uphold this responsibility and to lead with both determination and humility. It's a delicate balance, but one that I took very seriously as Commander-in-Chief.

Thank you for the question. Climate change is an important issue, and President Howard and our other allies from around the world are working together to address it. Unfortunately, the Kyoto Protocol is not the right way to solve this very serious problem. It is a flawed treaty that exempts 80 percent of the world's nations, including developing countries like China and India. It will have little, if any, impact on the environment and it doesn't reflect sound science.

In Washington, we will have an effective meeting with leaders to discuss various ways to address climate change. Our goal is to reduce emissions and help meet the needs of our citizens through technology, innovation, and international cooperation. We believe in a better way to address climate change, and I'm proud of my administration's efforts through the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate, which brings countries together to develop and deploy clean technologies.

The Kyoto Protocol isn't the right approach, and I regret that my trip to Washington meant that I couldn't attend the APEC meeting in full, but I was able to participate in many of the discussions by phone and will continue these efforts to improve the environment and address climate change constructively with our APEC partners.

Thank you for your question. That's an important topic, and I appreciate the national interest in ensuring that our children have access to quality healthcare. On this issue, I think the SCHIP [State Children's Health Insurance Program] reauthorization was presented in a way that would have expanded the program well beyond its original intention, going well beyond covering children in families earning up to twice the poverty level, which is the fallback point that I supported.

It was my belief that the legislation adopted by the Senate and by the House went too far, potentially reaching to provide coverage to individuals earning far more than the target group originally intended. Moreover, the plan proposed would have funded coverage expansions not just through traditional mechanisms like new fees or taxes, but by undermining the very accessibility of coverage under Medicare.

It's crucial for us to abide by our priorities and preserve the principles not only for fiscal responsibility but also to protect existing programs designed to take care of our senior citizens. I believed that an approach needed to be balanced and that both parties had a responsibility to consider common ground and the sustainability of healthcare programs for our nation's future.

That's why I called for a different approach to funding which would emphasize real reforms. I also called for an increase in funding for those who truly need assistance, which I believe would meet the needs of the children and families in a responsible manner. In the end, it was my Constitutional duty to put a hold on legislation that expanded government health care past what was agreed in the original purpose of SCHIP.

I am committed to working with Congress to find a responsible long-term solution that would continue to provide access to quality healthcare for our children while also ensuring that we respect the program's original intent and importantly, the fiscal responsibility and integrity of our nation.

Thank you for the questions. Regarding the state of the economy and the terminology used to describe it, I want to be clear about a few points. When I made statements about the economy, I was looking at the trends and data available at the time. The economy was facing challenges, and while we faced rising costs in areas such as food and energy, the term "recession" is a specific economic definition that requires a decline in Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for two consecutive quarters.

I was also clear that I wanted to speak about hope and possibilities for recovery and growth rather than get bogged down in negative economic terms. The country was going through uncertain times, and leadership is about seeing the future and working to build a better tomorrow for all Americans.

Regarding Saudi Arabia, my upcoming visit to that country is an opportunity to engage in direct dialogue with oil-producing nations about global energy security. I will be discussing with them the importance of stable economic growth and the role that their energy production plays in achieving that. It is a fact that increased oil production can help reduce prices at the pump, and I will be addressing this issue directly with Saudi officials.

It's a complex global market, and while ensuring economic stability is a priority, the relationships between nations and the cooperation among allies are vital to securing the energy needs of our citizens and fueling economic recovery.

Thank you for the question. My administration is committed to addressing the economic challenges facing America, including high energy prices and the overall state of the economy. We have a comprehensive plan to promote economic growth, enhance energy security, and improve the situation for the American people.

As part of our agenda, we will work to reform the tax code, streamline regulations that hinder business, and take steps to increase domestic energy production while considering the environmental impacts. Our objective is to create an environment where businesses can grow and succeed, leading to more jobs and higher wages for the American people.

It's important to note that economic conditions are influenced by a multitude of factors, many of which are outside of my administration's immediate control, including global economic trends and geopolitical events. However, I am confident that as we implement our agenda, the American people will see tangible benefits.

As for responsibility, the overall improvement of people's lives is indeed a responsibility that I take seriously. If at the end of my term it is found that our policies did not lead to better economic conditions for Americans, we will have a conversation about what could have been done differently. Throughout my tenure, I will be accountable for the actions of my administration and open to constructive criticism. However, I believe in the strength and resilience of the American people and the economy, and I am optimistic about our future.

Thank you for the question.

We are working closely with Spain on a number of issues, including defense cooperation. The agreement that you're referring to is the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) which outlines the terms under which U.S. forces can be stationed in Spain. We are indeed working towards the renewal of this agreement.

As far as the presence of U.S. military in bases, we understand and respect Spain's sovereign right to make decisions regarding the location of our troops on its soil. Any adjustments to our military presence would be made in consultation with Spain to ensure that our partnership remains strong and that the mutual security interests of both countries are upheld.

We are committed to maintaining a positive and productive relationship with Spain, and I am hopeful that we will be able to reach an agreement that both nations can support.

We're considering a range of options to ensure our military has the flexibility and capability to address the broad spectrum of threats we face, including those posed by the countries you've mentioned. The development of low-yield nuclear weapons would fall under this framework and is aimed at maintaining a credible nuclear deterrent that is flexible, adaptable, and consistent with the strong tradition of nuclear employment strategies set forth by my Administration.

This is not about the war on terrorism specifically, but rather about the broader security environment in which the United States operates. The security challenges of the post-Cold War era continue to evolve, and new ones are emerging. We must adjust our capabilities so we can respond effectively to these challenges.

The assessment considers the options available should a country cross a line and use weapons of mass destruction against us or our allies, and these options should also be available in the event of an extreme scenario where we may need to deal with these nations' strategic weapons that could be used in a less-than-total conflict.

It's important to remember that this approach is not about the first use of nuclear weapons, but rather about maintaining a strong and flexible deterrent. Our goal is to prevent our enemies from even considering taking such a disastrous step.

We will also consult with our allies and work closely with Congress to ensure they understand the need for a modern and adaptable nuclear triad. Our ultimate priority is to keep the American people safe and to protect the security and interests of the United States.

The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians is a complex issue that does indeed impact the broader geopolitical landscape, including our efforts in Iraq. The increased violence between the two does present a challenge for the kind of stability and cooperation that we are working toward in the Middle East. When there is heightened tension in the region, it can make some Arab leaders and peoples leery of supporting significant changes in the status quo, such as regime change in Iraq.

Nevertheless, Vice President Cheney and our administration's other senior officials are working tirelessly to convey the necessity and urgency of ensuring a region free from weapons of mass destruction and the threat of terrorism. We believe that the case for allowing UN weapons inspectors unconditional access to Iraq is critical to maintaining international security and peace.

We also recognize that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict cannot be ignored. The United States has consistently been committed to achieving a peaceful and just resolution, and we work closely with our partners in the Middle East to find a way forward that would allow both Israelis and Palestinians to live in peace and security. Nonetheless, the security of the United States and global peace remain paramount as we address these challenges.

The intelligence we receive is constantly analyzed and evaluated as we make decisions for the safety and security of our country. The reality is that Saddam Hussein posed a serious threat to the stability of the region and potentially to the United States. His refusal to disarm, his defiance of international law and multiple Security Council resolutions, and his continued efforts to develop weapons of mass destruction created a dangerous situation that had to be addressed.

The possibility that Saddam Hussein would become less constrained after an attack is an important consideration, but it is just one aspect of dealing with the myriad threats he posed. Our approach was aimed at ensuring that a dangerous leader who had used weapons of mass destruction against his own people and had connections to terrorist networks would no longer be in a position to do so.

We acted not just based on one piece of intelligence but on a broader assessment of the situation and the potential long-term implications for global security. We believed that by removing Saddam Hussein from power, we would be diminishing the threat he had posed for years and working towards a future where the region would be more stable and secure.

This was a complex issue, and it was addressed with the seriousness it demanded, using all the information available to us to make decisions that we believed would protect our nation and our interests.

Thank you for the question. The initial evidence we are gathering strongly suggests that Saddam Hussein was involved in directing attacks against coalition forces. The Iraqi regime has used a variety of weapons, including improvised explosive devices and other means, to harm our troops and their allies. 

As intelligence is gathered and analyzed, our expectation is to identify more specific and direct links between the regime and these attacks. However, the nature of the threats faced by our troops can be complex, and we are committed to ensuring our forces have the support they need to confront and neutralize these threats.

In terms of whether these attacks might decrease or get worse in the short term, there are several factors to consider. Defeat of Saddam's regime can lead to a temporary escalation in resistance from those loyal to him, as well as from foreign fighters opposed to the coalition's presence. But our strategy includes not only immediate military responses but also working with Iraqi people to build a future for Iraq that does not involve terror and violence. 

We are taking comprehensive steps to ensure security and stability, and as the situation evolves, so will our response. It is impossible to predict with certainty what the future holds, but we remain focused on achieving a secure Iraq—one where the Iraqi people can live in freedom from fear. 

Americans can be assured that their military and their government are doing everything possible to protect the troops and to protect the Iraqi people from the violence of Saddam Hussein's remnants and from other terrorists.

I appreciate the question. First of all, Mr. Brahimi, as the United Nations' Special Envoy, worked diligently and with a great deal of resolution to bring together the interim government that's now sworn in. This government is broadly representative, and I believe it has significant legitimacy, not just in the eyes of the international community, but also among the Iraqi people.

Secondly, we recognize the importance of ensuring that this interim government holds together and works effectively to serve the needs of all Iraqis, including those who feel disenfranchised. That's why the Coalition and the international community are committed to supporting the government as it takes on these challenges.

The transition of power from the Coalition Provisional Authority to the Iraqi Interim Government is an important step in the sovereignty and democratic self-governance processes for the Iraqi people. We are confident that as this government operates, it will gain further legitimacy from Iraqis and enable the country to move towards national elections.

Thank you for your questions. As we work towards peace in the Middle East, it is important that any discussions are productive and lead to a durable solution that respects the rights and needs of both Israelis and Palestinians. The establishment of an international conference on the Middle East would need to be in support of these efforts, with clear objectives and the involvement of key parties to ensure it is meaningful.

Prime Minister Tony Blair and I have had discussions about convening such a conference. Before moving forward, we would need to ensure that the conditions are right for such a gathering. This means creating an environment where all parties can engage in constructive dialogue, and that all sides are willing to work towards a peaceful resolution. The basic framework for these discussions must be based on the principles supported by the international community. We will continue to consult closely with our allies and other interested parties to determine the most effective way to move the peace process forward.

Regarding the nomination of a U.S. envoy, the situation calls for strategic and careful diplomacy. We will consider all options, including appointing an envoy, as we continue to work towards bringing about progress in the Middle East. The individual selected would need to have the skills and the ability to navigate the complex politics of the region in service of peace.

Looking ahead to my upcoming trip to Europe, the primary goal of the trip would be to strengthen alliances and promote global stability. Given the current state of affairs in the world, it's crucial for the United States to work closely with our European allies on a wide range of issues including security, economic growth, and the promotion of democracy. I will be meeting with leaders of various countries to discuss shared priorities and build a cohesive approach to addressing challenges such as the situation in the Middle East, the threat of terrorism, and economic recovery.

Thank you for your question. The United States has and will continue to support the expansion of freedom and democracy globally, including on the African continent. We have seen significant steps toward democracy and good governance in many African countries. The U.S. can assist in this process through a combination of diplomacy, development assistance, economic engagement, and support for civil society in Africa.

Whenever the U.S. is involved in nation-building or promoting democracy outside our borders, including in Africa, we prefer to work through multilateral institutions like the United Nations and regional organizations like the African Union and NEPAD. We encourage regional partnerships and the strengthening of peaceful, democratic institutions.

Our traditional military power is only one tool in a comprehensive toolbox for advancing these goals. Often, it is more effective to support democracy through economic empowerment, education, and by fostering environments where free and fair elections can take place.

Regarding military action or the involvement of a new coalition, the United States would only consider such measures as a last resort and only if regional and international partners agreed that it was necessary to address a critical threat. We are open to coordinating with partners, including Denmark, to achieve these objectives, but it is essential that any such coalition be built upon the support and consent of the affected nations, regional partners, and the international community.

I would invite the Prime Minister to address how Denmark might be involved in supporting these efforts.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding the first part of your inquiry, concerning the potential greater federal involvement and troops in future disasters, let me clarify. In times of national emergencies of catastrophic proportions, like the Katrina disaster, the federal government's role as the provider of last resort is absolutely necessary. We are working on strategies to improve our disaster response mechanisms, to improve coordination and communications at all levels of government. That means working with states and local communities as well as the private sector to ensure that critical services such as search and rescue, water and food distribution, and health care can be provided effectively.

As for the military aspect, the National Guard plays a vital role in disaster response and recovery. There may be a need for federal troops to assist in such situations, but it's essential that this happens under the direction of the proper authorities and with the cooperation of local, state, and federal officials. We are looking at options like ensuring better training, adequate equipment, and robust logistics for when federal troops are called in to assist.

As for the second question about convincing President Putin on the need to send Iran to the Security Council, our discussions covered a wide range of topics regarding national security and the fight against terrorism. The situation in Iran is a matter of serious concern, given their efforts to acquire weapons of mass destruction and support for hostile terrorist organizations throughout the world. It's always preferable to resolve such matters diplomatically, and we continue to engage our international partners, including Russia, to address this issue. The United States will continue to work with our allies to ensure that Iran does not pose a threat to the world.

We are committed to working closely with other nations to ensure global peace and security, and we are exploring all options in the framework of our international commitments.

Thank you for your question. I understand the frustration and the urgency in the aftermath of natural disasters like Hurricane Katrina. In the immediate wake of the storm, we did encounter significant challenges in coordinating and expediting aid to those in need in the Gulf Coast region. We recognized that we had to do better and have since taken steps to improve our disaster response capabilities and speed of aid delivery.

The government has implemented post-disaster reforms, learning from Katrina and subsequent disasters, to ensure quicker response times and more effective aid distribution. We've worked to improve communication between federal and local authorities, strengthen infrastructure, and ensure that our aid organizations have the flexibility and resources necessary to respond effectively to large-scale disasters.

However, it is important to acknowledge that recovery from such tragic events is a lengthy process. Our goal has always been to provide for the immediate needs of those affected and guide them through the broader process of recovery. We have ongoing programs in place to assist those recovering from Hurricane Katrina, and we remain committed to helping individuals and communities rebuild their lives and homes.

I hope this response addresses your concern and provides insight into the progress made in disaster response since Hurricane Katrina. If there are specific areas of concern or further questions, I am here to try to clarify or provide additional information.

I disagree with Mr. Allawi's characterization of the situation in Iraq as a civil war. What we're seeing is the culmination of Saddam Hussein's hatred and his desire to destroy the fabric of society in Iraq. There are terrorists and insurgents who are trying to derail the process of the Iraqi people building a free society. We are helping the Iraqi government to put out the fires of the insurgency and to deal with the murderers and thugs that are trying to prevent democracy from taking hold in Iraq. We're making great progress with provincial elections taking place in Iraq. The Iraqi government is taking steps to protect its citizens, and we're going to continue to support them as they proceed down the road of democracy.

Thank you for your question. As I discussed yesterday, the removal of U.S. troops from Iraq to meet an arbitrary timetable is simply irresponsible. It's important to have a timeline that is based on conditions on the ground and the recognition that Iraq's progress is dependent on our support – particularly in the area of security.

Regarding your specific question about a reduction in violence: We should continue to use benchmarks to determine the progress of the Iraqi government in areas such as security, politics, and economics. The reduction in violence is certainly a key indicator of that progress. As the Iraqis improve their ability to provide a safe and secure environment for their people, we are prepared to transition to a smaller, residual force focused on training and providing support to Iraqi forces.

It's difficult to specify a quantitative reduction in violence because the nature and extent of the violence have fluctuated greatly over time. We are aiming for a situation where Iraqi security forces can effectively take the lead in providing security, including patrolling the streets, securing borders, and conducting operations against terrorists and insurgents. When we reach the point where these forces are fully capable and operational, it will be a clear sign that a drawdown can begin, not because of a fixed numerical reduction in violence, but as part of a broader successful strategy that includes effective governance and economic growth.

Thank you for your interest in this critical mission. We remain committed to a responsible approach in Iraq that supports the Iraqi people and ensures the safety of our troops.

Thank you for your questions.

Regarding amnesty for insurgents in the new Iraqi Government, it is important to recognize that we are talking about a sovereign nation making its own decisions. The process of reconciliation following a period of conflict is complex and requires careful consideration. Amnesty discussions can be a part of a broader reconciliation process, but any such measures must be carefully tailored to maintain the security and stability of the country, as well as to ensure justice for those who have lost loved ones to insurgent violence. The Iraqi government should take into account the needs and views of all Iraqi communities when considering such amnesty programs.

Turning to the issue of oil resources in Iraq, it is crucial for the well-being and economic future of all Iraqis that the oil resources are managed fairly and distributively. The Iraqi government has the responsibility to address the economic needs of all its citizens, including the Sunni population, which has historically had significant representation in Iraq's oil-producing regions. An equitable distribution of oil revenues should be a priority, and it's good to see that the Iraqi people are having these discussions themselves.

As for whether I support a constitutional provision or new law guaranteeing Sunnis a percentage of the oil profits, the legitimacy of such provisions would come from the Iraqi constitution and the democratic process within Iraq. The Iraqi people should ensure that any laws or constitutional amendments reflect their will and promote unity and stability within the country. It's important that these discussions are transparent and inclusive, ensuring that all Iraqi communities see a bright economic future ahead of them.

Yes, I understand that support for the war in Iraq can fluctuate as a result of ongoing events and the challenges involved in nation-building and peacekeeping. It's natural to see shifts in public opinion as the situation evolves, including reports of casualties, the length of deployment, and the progress being made in Iraq.

I also understand that the American people want to see the mission succeed, and they have high expectations for the Iraqi people and their government to take control of their own security and governance. As the President, I have a responsibility to lead and to follow through on what I believe is the right course of action.

The challenges we face are significant, but I believe they are manageable as long as we stay the course and continue to work with our coalition partners and the Iraqi people. I've outlined our strategy as a comprehensive plan that includes security, democracy, and economics: to help Iraq develop the capacity to provide for its own freedom and security. It's a long-term commitment, but one that I believe is necessary for the safety and security of both Iraq and America.

I can understand why questions arise about the support for the strategy, but I firmly believe that we are on the right path and that our coalition and the Iraqi government will ultimately succeed in bringing freedom and security to Iraq. We will continue to work diligently to achieve these goals.

Good question. When you look at Iraq, you see sectarian violence that is challenging the lives of innocent men, women, and children, you see the attacks by al Qaeda and other extremists against the Iraqi people, and you see the Iraqi Government taking steps to unify and bring hope to the people.

While there are a lot of honest disagreements over the terminology to describe the situation in Iraq, I think it's more important to understand that Iraq is dealing with the aftermath of a brutal dictator, Saddam Hussein, who had a policy of divide and conquer in order to keep people from coming together.

The Iraqi government is currently working with coalition forces to bring about stability, deliver services that had been denied to the people under Saddam Hussein, and, most importantly, to help create a democratic system that can unify the country. The goal remains to help Iraqis build a peaceful and prosperous society that is an ally in the war on terror and an example to others in the region.

I do understand the concern about how the term "civil war" might be perceived, and that is why we continue to focus on the successes and progress being made by the Iraqi government and the coalition forces working to defeat the extremists and bring peace to Iraq. We are committed to supporting the Iraqi people in this endeavor.

As President, I believe that supporting the service members of our military and acknowledging their incredible sacrifices in defense of our country is an obligation we all share. The warriors who put their lives on the line for freedom deserve the recognition, support, and gratitude of all Americans.

It's important to distinguish between support for the troops and support for the particular decisions that lead us into conflicts. Just as the Constitution grants the President the authority to lead military force, Americans also reserve the right to debate the wisdom of these decisions. A healthy democracy requires open dialogue about our policies, including military policies.

However, discourse about those decisions should not undermine the morale of the troops or the sacrifices they make. Speaking out against a policy, as long as it is done respectfully and does not disparage the troops, does not equate to undermining the military. We honor our service members not only by supporting them in their mission but also by ensuring that the discussions about sending them into harm's way are grounded in a commitment to defending their welfare and the nation's best interests.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this. I want to ensure the American people that I am committed to working with Democrats and others I disagree with to make sure that we can move this country forward.

As we've begun addressing the challenges before us and have started working together on issues like education reform, tax relief, and Medicare reform, I've found Democrats to be committed to public service and willing to listen to ideas and proposals. We've had our differences, but I believe that with goodwill and common sense, we can work together to accomplish what is best for the American people. Our debates are fundamental to the democratic process, and it's a testament to the strength of our democracy that we can debate complex issues and work toward finding the best solutions.

I do not see this as a time for "divorce." Rather, it's a time for "marriage," to work together more closely on behalf of the American people. Divorce was one of those issues Mr. Clinton addressed in his last State of the Union, and I just hope all of us will work together to make sure that this great nation is a land that understands we must work together for the common good, for a better, stronger America.

Thank you for your question. I understand that the war in Iraq has been a difficult, challenging time for the American people and for the troops and their families who have served, including those who have made the ultimate sacrifice. The costs have been significant, and I carry the weight of those who have lost their lives and been injured deeply.

When we made the decision to remove Saddam Hussein from power, it was because we believed that his weapons of mass destruction posed a real and serious threat to the security of the United States and the world. Saddam Hussein was a danger—destabilizing the region, supporting terrorism, and using weapons of mass destruction against his own people.

While initial intelligence about weapons of mass destruction was unfortunately incorrect, the broader decision to remove Saddam Hussein was in service of a long-term goal to bring security and stability to a region that had been ravaged by conflict and tyranny. It's true that the aftermath of the war did not unfold as smoothly as we had hoped, but America's ability to face challenges and overcome adversity is part of our character and our history.

As the situation in Iraq evolved, so did our strategy. We focused on building the capacity of the Iraqi government and security forces to take charge of their nation’s future, while working with our coalition partners and regional allies to address the growing challenges posed by regional threats and insurgent groups.

It is certainly realistic to conclude that the challenges have been complex and the costs significant. However, as Commander-in-Chief, my mindset has always been that of taking responsibility for making the decisions necessary to ensure the future safety and freedom of the American people. I trust that future historians will judge the decisions made with the information available at the time and the actions taken in the context of the times.

Let me be clear: the American people deserve an administration that will tell them the truth, defend freedom, and do what is best for our nation. We faced the challenge of Saddam Hussein, and the world is a better place for his removal, but there is much left to do to ensure the future security of the Middle East and to remember those who have fought and sacrificed there.

Thank you for your question.

Addressing climate change effectively requires international cooperation and engagement with emerging economies, which are increasingly significant contributors to global emissions. The outlook for reaching an agreement that limits emissions meaningfully involves acknowledging the roles of all major economies, along with the historical responsibilities each country bears.

In the midterm and beyond, it's critical that all parties commit to climate action in a way that is both ambitious and achievable. This means working toward a balanced approach that accounts for the varying economic stages of development and for the individual countries' needs. Fairness is a cornerstone of how we construct these agreements. Nations must find a pathway that enables them to grow their economies while also mitigating environmental impact.

Getting emerging economies to come around involves various strategies, such as:

1. Encouraging transparent dialogues through international forums like the G20 and the Major Economies Forum on Energy and Climate.
2. Creating incentives for investment in renewable energy, including public-private partnerships and green financing mechanisms.
3. Providing access to clean technologies through capacity-building programs and knowledge-sharing initiatives.
4. Offering technical assistance and financial support, particularly to developing nations, to help them transition to more sustainable energy practices.
5. Highlighting the opportunities that arise from a green economy, including job creation and enhanced energy security.

At the same time, it's important not to lose sight of the progress we are already making. The United States has taken significant steps domestically to reduce emissions through policies like the Clear Skies Act and the Hydrogen Fuel Initiative, which promote energy innovation and cleaner energy production. We are also engaging with our partners around the world, recognizing that addressing climate change is a global challenge that demands a global solution.

The United States stands ready to work with all partners, including emerging economies, to bridge the gap between current emissions and a future that is more sustainable for all. Our goal is to achieve an agreement that not only addresses the urgent need for climate action but also fosters positive, long-term relationships and global stability.

Thank you for the question. As we've seen in the past, oil prices are subject to fluctuation based on a variety of factors — supply and demand, geopolitical events, natural disasters, and economic cycles, among others. It's true that when prices spike, there have been periods of decline that subsequently followed, as you mentioned.

Our administration has worked closely with our allies and key producers to address oil prices and their impact on consumers and the economy. We've emphasized the importance of a stable and secure energy supply, and we've encouraged the need for diverse and robust energy policies, which include exploring more domestic production, investing in alternative energy, and maintaining strategic reserves.

However, making specific predictions about the future prices of oil relies on a complex set of variables that are difficult to predict with certainty. While our goal remains to promote stability and to address the issues that can impact oil prices, we cannot with certainty say that oil prices will drop in the future. Our focus is on creating an environment that fosters security and economic prosperity, and that includes working to stabilize and manage the impact of energy price fluctuations on American families and businesses.

Thank you for your question.

We are working closely with Poland and our other coalition partners to ensure that the entire world is safer from the threat of terrorism. Poland has made significant contributions to the global coalition against terror, both in Afghanistan and in other areas vital to our joint security interests. Poland's commitment and steadfastness have been a source of encouragement and strength.

As we move forward, the challenges remain significant, and it is clear that unity among our allies will be crucial in shaping the next phase of the war on terrorism. Poland's leadership and contributions are greatly appreciated, and we remain confident in Poland's ability to meet its obligations as the situation requires.

We believe that a collective response, rooted in strong alliances, is the most effective way to address these threats. The successful continuation of our coalition depends on the shared resolve and continued commitment of each member state. Poland's proactive stance in both diplomatic and operational contexts demonstrates its readiness to contribute effectively to these efforts.

Therefore, I expect Poland to continue to play a vital role in the anti-terrorist coalition moving forward. Poland's readiness and resolve have proven to be exceptional, and we hold high expectations for Poland's ongoing participation in the mission to combat terrorism around the world.

The recent attacks, including those in Morocco and Saudi Arabia, do reflect the grim reality that terrorist organizations are still active and pose a continuing threat to global security. While the September 11 attacks significantly disrupted Al-Qaeda's operations and capabilities, it's clear that they have not been completely eradicated.

We must remain vigilant and ensure our counterterrorism efforts are robust. Intelligence agencies and military forces continue to work diligently to dismantle the networks and prevent attacks before they occur. We are also working closely with international partners to combat this global threat.

These events serve as a reminder that the fight against terrorism is an ongoing challenge, and it's crucial that we stay focused on our mission to protect our citizens and the international community from these dangerous actors. We have to stay engaged and not underestimate the resilience of terrorist organizations like Al-Qaeda.

Thank you for your question. The situation with North Korea's nuclear program and missiles is indeed a serious matter of international security. We are closely monitoring North Korea's actions and are engaging with our allies, including South Korea and Japan, to come up with a diplomatic, but also a firm, stance on their continued pursuit of these weapons.

The United States will not accept a nuclear-armed North Korea, and we will continue to work with our friends and allies to demand that North Korea live up to its international obligations and commitments to denuclearize. We have a range of options—from diplomatic measures to economic sanctions to enhanced defense capabilities for our allies—that we are prepared to use as necessary.

If North Korea continues its provocative actions or escalates its nuclear activities, we will consider enforcing tougher measures. We are focused on peaceful resolution through dialogue but are also resolute in ensuring that all options remain on the table to protect the American people and our allies in the region.

Thank you for your question. Economic growth is critical to generating revenues for the government, and that is part of our plan to address the deficit. We believe in a strong, growing economy as the foundation for sustaining fiscal health. We are committed to keeping taxes low to ensure that people have more money to save and spend, and more jobs are created as a result. Higher economic growth will increase tax revenues and contribute to reducing the deficit. Additionally, we are also focused on reducing government spending and making tough budgetary decisions where necessary to ensure responsible fiscal management while still investing in security, education, health care, and other priorities.

The previous Administration had left us with a large deficit, and we've worked diligently to get our fiscal house in order while also responding to the challenges of a global economy and international conflicts. Growth-based policies and responsible spending are key components of our overall approach to improving the fiscal situation of our nation.

First of all, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to address your question in this setting. During my time as President, I have always made sure to communicate my vision and address the concerns of the American people, whether it was about security, the economy, education, or healthcare.

I don't believe in the concept of "failing" in an absolute sense because the role of the President is to try to do what's right for the country and to serve American interests with the best of my judgment and ability. I have worked hard to fulfill the duties of my office and to uphold the values that we as Americans hold dear.

In terms of engaging the American public, I have done so through various methods, including press conferences, town hall meetings, public speeches, and through my legislative initiatives. While we never live up to everything we hope to achieve, I've strived to inform and engage the American people about the issues facing our nation and to explain my policies and the rationale behind them.

Setting aside political perspectives and views, I truly believe that we have made progress in many areas, including strengthening our national security, improving education through the No Child Left Behind Act, and advancing economic policies to foster job growth and economic recovery.

Communication is an ongoing process, and I have always sought to be as open and direct as possible with the American people. I remain committed to working for the betterment of our country and to ensuring that the legacy of my administration contributes positively to the future of America.

It’s important to maintain perspective when considering statistics regarding terrorist activities. While it is true that terrorism remains a serious issue, we must recognize that our efforts to combat terrorism have disrupted many plots and weakened terrorist networks. The Democratic national security leadership's portrayal of negotiated sanctions and a "global conversation" as the solution to global terrorism is overly simplistic and does not fully acknowledge the threat we face from these violent organizations.

The increase in reported terrorist activity can partly be attributed to increased reporting and better tracking mechanisms, as well as the fluid nature of modern terrorist groups. They adapt to the countermeasures we take, which can sometimes mean that their activity appears to increase. However, we are also seeing instances where regimes such as Saddam Hussein's fall, leading to increased stability in regions that were previously under the grip of oppressive dictatorships that in some cases were partly responsible for sponsoring terrorism.

Our policy involves a comprehensive approach to battling terrorism, which includes disrupting terrorist cells, dismantling networks, and addressing the root causes of terrorism. We're making progress, but it is a long-term effort. We must remain vigilant and steadfast in our commitment to the war on terrorism. Our renewed focus on non-proliferation and the network of alliances we have forged across the world presents a strong bulwark against further terrorist activity.

The United States is leading a coalition of nations in a global fight against terrorism, and we will not rest until terrorists are no longer able to threaten the lives and freedom of people around the world.

Thank you for your question. The No Child Left Behind Act is an important part of our commitment to ensuring that all students have access to a quality education, regardless of their background. This legislation is about raising standards and holding schools accountable.

I understand the concerns about funding, but the goal of No Child Left Behind is to improve education through improved teaching, higher standards, and more flexibility for states and communities to meet those standards. It's about parental involvement and choice for parents who don't find the adequate quality of education for their children. No Child Left Behind is also about ensuring that every child can read and do math at grade level. 

Regarding the lawsuit, I have some thoughts:

- We remain committed to the principles of No Child Left Behind, including accountability for the achievement of all students and the use of evidence-based teaching methods.
- While we understand that there are funding concerns, we believe that with existing resources, schools can still make progress towards meeting the goals set forth in the act. However, we've worked across party lines on a bipartisan basis to work with Congress to provide more resources for education so teachers have the tools and support they need to succeed with our children.
- The adequacy and the quality of education for children is far more important than the quantity of dollars provided to bureaucracies. We're focused on making sure that we're getting results, and one of the reasons I think No Child Left Behind is so commonsense is, if you're not teaching a child, you're going to be called to account for it.

As for whether No Child Left Behind is working, we are already seeing positive results:
- More children are being taught to read and do math at grade level compared with just a few years ago. 
- More districts are receiving adequate yearly progress (AYP) scores, meaning they're making progress towards meeting the standards set by the legislation.
- More states have implemented their accountability systems and are now identifying areas where they need to improve.

These are important measures, and we will continue to assess the impact and effectiveness of No Child Left Behind to ensure that it is making the best possible difference in our children's education.

Thank you for your question. I believe it's crucial to fill vacancies on the federal bench with qualified nominees who understand the Constitution and the role of an impartial judiciary. It is within the constitutional responsibility of the President to make judicial nominations, and it is the duty of the Senate to give those nominees fair hearings and consider their qualifications.

Critics who suggest that stonewalling or playing politics with judicial nominations is acceptable miss the point of the judicial process. Appointing fair-minded, competent judges to federal courts ensures that citizens receive fair trials and that the law is faithfully interpreted as written. Courts play a critical role in our system of checks and balances. Without sufficient personnel, we risk arbitrary decisions being made by federal courts, which affects the rights of citizens.

Regarding the comparison to President Clinton's nominees, every administration faces challenges in getting its nominees confirmed. However, the context is often different. We work with the Senate to find common ground and pass nominees who are well-qualified, unlike some of President Clinton's nominees who may not have known the law, and their nominations were on a much smaller scale compared to the backlog that was present at the start of my administration.

I hope to work with the Senate in both chambers under whatever circumstances necessary to ensure that I can meet my obligation of提名官员，同时也要尊重参议院的角色和责任。

对于批评者提到的共和党在克林顿总统提名法官时所做的事情，那是在不同的情况下发生的。我相信如果双方能够保持对话并寻找共识，我们就能够解决这些问题。我的目标是建立一支有能力且公正的司法队伍，而不是仅仅为了通过提名而牺牲质量或原则。

如果您还有其他的问题，我很乐意继续回答。

Certainly. The selection process for the next Chairman of the Federal Reserve is a very important responsibility for me and the Administration. The Chair of the Federal Reserve plays a critical role in managing the U.S. economy, and the person I choose will help shape our nation's future.

My criteria for selecting someone to fill this position will involve assessing a candidate's experience, judgment, and commitment to sound monetary policy. I am looking for an individual who understands the complexities of the global economy and has a proven record of success in navigating these challenges. While the current Federal Reserve Chairman, Ben Bernanke, has skillfully managed the economy during the tenure of the Bush Administration, it's now time to consider new leadership as his term approaches its conclusion.

I believe in a diversified pool of candidates, including both current members of the Federal Reserve and outside candidates who have expertise in the financial sector and a deep understanding of economic policy. Before making my decision, I plan to consult potential candidates and gather feedback from congressional leaders and other stakeholders.

The American people expect leadership that will perpetuate the Fed's independence and continue promoting economic stability and growth. I will be making my choice based on the best interests of the American people and the future of our economy.

Good question. My top commanders and I have been monitoring the situation closely since the operation that led to the death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. The initial assessment is that this is a significant blow to al-Qaeda in Iraq, and we hope it will diminish their ability to carry out attacks.

Zarqawi was an orchestrator of sectarian violence and was responsible for countless instances of brutality against civilians, both Sunni and Shia Iraqis. With him removed from the picture, we see a brief window of opportunity for increasing cooperation among the different factions in Iraq to build a stable, representative government that serves all of Iraq's people.

This development will be an important point of discussion during our strategy meetings at Camp David. We will be considering how best to leverage this momentum to push forward with our broader goals of promoting democracy and stability in the region. It is an encouraging development, but we know that the fight ahead will still be challenging. It is our hope that the Iraqi government and security forces will continue to work toward a peaceful and secure environment for all Iraqis.

Thank you for the question.

Regarding the need for permission to strike inside Pakistan, the United States respects the territorial integrity of nations. However, in the context of a potential strike against Usama bin Laden, if we have intelligence that leads us to believe he is inside Pakistan and poses a direct threat to the United States, we would consider all options to protect our national security. Such actions would be contemplated with great care and consideration of our relationship with Pakistan.

It's important to maintain the integrity and strength of our alliances, and we would always seek to act responsibly, while understanding the complexities of the situation, especially given Pakistan's own fight against extremism on their soil.

As for the assurances on the tribal deal, I'd prefer not to go into specifics of diplomatic negotiations at this moment. However, I can say that we are working closely with Pakistan to address our shared concerns about terrorist safe havens within their borders. Our objectives are aligned, and we are committed to continuing conversations to improve security and stability in the region.

Thank you for the question, and we will continue to work with our partners to achieve a safer world for everyone.

Well, first of all, I have to say that I hold no ill will toward Matthew. My relationship with Matthew has been defined by strong points, and while there have been some tough moments, I have great respect for him and what he's done in our administration. 

As for his critique, I have to differentiate between my own personal feelings and the role I have as President of the United States. My job is to focus on the best interests of Americans and making smart, informed decisions that will lead this nation to a better and brighter future. I will always welcome constructive criticism because I want to do what's best for our country. But with that said, if somebody feels free to criticize, I also feel free to let their words not affect me personally and not influence my decision-making.

Regarding the support of those who might hold the same view as Matthew, our administration continuously aims to be inclusive of all Americans and their ideas. Our goal is not to pander to any one group or individual, but to govern in a way that strengthens our nation and benefits the American people as a whole. I believe that if the policies we implement prove successful, people regardless of their initial perspectives will come to see the wisdom behind them.

I appreciate the concern, but I am confident in the team we have and the decisions we are making for America.

Good question. Let me just step back and say that, first and foremost, our troops need to hear that this Congress believes in them and that the American people will stand by our troops. That's the message they need to hear, not the undermining that's taken place.

The American people sent a message to Washington in November. They said that they expect us to work together. Moderation, bipartisanship, common sense ought to prevail in Washington. And what the American people are discovering is that there are some in Washington who said one thing during the election, but act another way once they get to Washington.

The tone that I set with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle is one of respectful dialogue. And my attitude toward those who may have different points of view is to listen respectfully but present my point of view. And I believe the American people expect a bit of common sense in Washington and a bit of civility.

So yes, the American people expect us to find common ground. And I'm going to work regularly with the Congress, both Republicans and Democrats, to get our priorities met for the benefit of the American people.

Thank you for your question. The United States and Poland have indeed enjoyed a strong partnership in various realms, including security and defense. The cooperation on strategic initiatives such as the missile defense system has been a significant highlight of our security relationship.

Regarding anti-missile defense, the United States is committed to ensuring the security of our allies and friends against regional threats, and we see Poland as an integral partner in this effort. The deployment of parts of the Ground-based Midcourse Defense system to Poland underscores our shared commitment to deterrence and protection. This system serves as a potent symbol of our mutual resolve and commitment to each other's security.

In terms of site cooperation, we have worked closely with Poland to operationalize these sites, which are critical for joint security measures. It's also important to note that we see this as part of a larger Euro-Atlantic defense posture, including our NATO commitments, which form a solid foundation for our cooperation.

The realm of trade and investment is equally important to the robust relationship between our two countries. Through the United States' support for free trade initiatives and our focus on fostering economic ties, we aim to create a more prosperous and economically resilient partnership. We continue to encourage American businesses to invest in Poland, recognizing the abundant opportunities for growth and mutual benefit.

I am confident that as we continue to work together on both these fronts—security and economic cooperation—our bilateral relations will continue to flourish and serve as a model for international collaboration.

Thank you for your question. When I look back at my time as President, I've certainly learned from a variety of experiences, some of which were more challenging than others. Throughout my time in office, I've always sought to do what I believed was best for our country, even if others might disagree with the course of action taken.

If I had to identify a mistake, I might say that not all aspects of my Administration's initial approach to post-war Iraq were as effective as we would have liked. Our original plan underestimated the complexities of the situation on the ground, leading to a period of instability and violence that was difficult for the Iraqi people and costly for our coalition.

However, it's also important to note that the lessons learned from that period influenced the changes we implemented over the following years. The surge of U.S. forces, which began in 2007, was a difficult but necessary decision that ultimately helped to stabilize Iraq and set the conditions for it to take control of its own security. 

The broader point is that leadership often requires making tough decisions and being willing to reassess and adjust strategies when circumstances change. As President, I always aimed to make choices that would protect our national security, enhance American interests, and uphold our values. That being said, I acknowledge that not every decision proved to be as effective as we hoped, and there's always room for improvement.

Thank you for the question. I would like to express my deepest sympathy for the family and friends of the victims in both tragic cases. Every innocent life is precious and filled with potential. The death of the baby in Gaza is horrific, and I condemn the use of force that results in the loss of any innocent life, including children.

The brutal murders of the young Jewish boys are heinous acts that shock the conscience. The perpetrators of such violent crimes must be held accountable and brought to justice. This tragedy highlights the vulnerability of civilians and underscores the urgent need to address the underlying tensions and violence in the region. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of both victims, and we call for an end to such senseless acts of violence.

Thank you for your question. The expansion of NATO is indeed a question of when and how, rather than whether. It's a strategic decision that requires careful consideration to ensure that it's done in a way that strengthens the alliance's cohesion and enhances the security of all our members.

Regarding your second question, tomorrow, I will be addressing the leaders of NATO to reaffirm America's commitment to the alliance and our shared goals. We will discuss a comprehensive approach to Eastern and Southern NATO, which includes a balance between the adaptation of the Alliance and the expansion of it. The expansion of NATO must be in accord with the vision laid out in the Founding Act and Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council. That means considering NATO's relationship with Russia, as well as the importance of our partnerships with Ukraine and other European nations.

As for the timing and the specific countries that may be considered first, these are subjects of ongoing consultations that will continue at the NATO summit. The Balkan States and other countries that have expressed interest in joining NATO will be part of these discussions. However, the process is not solely about geographical proximity; it's also about the willingness and ability of aspirant countries to contribute to the security of the alliance and to meet the political, economic, and defense requirements of membership.

We will proceed in a deliberate, consistent, and fair manner, ensuring that every step we take reinforces the foundation of collective security that NATO stands for.

Thank you for your question. The efficacy of getting a budget that reflects our national defense priorities, as well as other national priorities, is a matter of leadership and clear communication of the values and risks at stake for our nation. Congress plays a crucial role in this process, and it's important to maintain a partnership with them, recognizing that they represent the interests of their constituents.

I'll remind you that we are committed to fiscal responsibility and ensuring that we allocate our resources wisely. However, the defense budget is a critical investment in the security of our nation and the safety of its citizens. We must balance our defense needs with the need to fund essential domestic programs, and this requires thorough planning and negotiation.

While it is true that Social Security is a significant part of our federal budget, it is not the entirety of our fiscal landscape. There are a number of revenue streams and ways to fund our defense priorities, including defense-related legislation, reallocation within the budget, and, if necessary, tax policy reforms that may increase the funds available. It is also true that Congress has a range of priorities, but I believe that with the proper leadership and bipartisan cooperation, we can address these issues effectively.

I do not believe it is naive to have this expectation of Congress. I am confident in the ability of Congress to take the necessary steps to ensure our nation's safety, which is a core priority that should unite us all. We will continue to make the case for the importance of our defense priorities, and we will work together to find solutions that reflect our shared values and the security of our nation.

Terima kasih untuk pertanyaannya. Saya menghargai kehadiran saya di Indonesia mungkin telah menimbulkan beberapa perdebatan, namun rencana pertemuan saya dengan rakyat Indonesia adalah bagian penting dari upaya Amerika Serikat untuk memperkuat hubungan di seluruh dunia. Kami percaya bahwa dialog dan interaksi langsung penting untuk memahami satu sama lain dan membentuk ikatan yang lebih kuat.

Saya percaya bahwa kebijakan luar negeri kami mengakui dan menghargai peran berbagai negara dan masyarakat di seluruh dunia, termasuk di wilayah Timur Tengah dan Asia Tenggara. Kontribusi dari berbagai orang dan negara serta langganan nilai-nilai yang sama semakin ditekankan oleh pemerintah Amerika. Kami akan terus bekerja untuk membangun dan mempertahankan hubungan yang sehat dan saling menguntungkan dengan negara-negara di seluruh masyarakat internasional, termasuk Indonesia.

Perubahan di dalam kebijakan luar negeri dapat dan biasanya dilakukan berdasarkan dinamika dunia yang berubah-ubah dan munculnya tantangan baru. Kami akan terus mengevaluasi dan mengubah kebijakan sesuai situasi yang ada untuk memastikan keamanan dan stabilitas global.

Harap maklum bahwa saya berbicara dalam bahasa Inggris dan terjemahan ini mungkin tidak sempurna, namun saya berusaha untuk memberikan jawaban yang jelas dan informatif sesuai dengan pertanyaan yang diajukan.

Thank you for your question. We, the United States, remain committed to supporting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine. We respect all countries' right to follow their own path, but at the same time, we believe it is important that all nations, including Ukraine, adhere to international norms of behavior, including respect for democratic principles, human rights, and the rule of law. We have consistently called for calm and dialogue in Ukraine to address legitimate concerns and to resolve differences peacefully. As for President Putin's statements, to achieve stability, it is crucial that all parties involved engage in constructive dialogue and work towards a peaceful resolution that respects the rights and aspirations of the Ukrainian people, without external interference that undermines sovereignty and the will of the Ukrainian people.

In response to your question, I appreciate the opportunity to address these concerns. First and foremost, our administration values the importance of democracy and human rights around the world, and we believe that when the people of a country freely express their will through the ballot box, it can lead to positive changes.

Regarding President Hosni Mubarak's efforts toward political reform, the United States has consistently encouraged the Egyptian government to take steps that would allow for more open and competitive elections. The support expressed for Mubarak's steps towards direct presidential elections was in the context of recognizing that the movement toward democratic elections was a significant development for the Egyptian people.

However, it is vital that such steps are accompanied by a commitment to uphold the rights of all citizens, to allow for the peaceful expression of dissent, and to protect the freedoms of the press and assembly. It is also critical that there is no intimidation or violence against opponents or supporters of the government. The United States condemns any and all attacks against civilians, regardless of their political affiliation.

My message to President Mubarak and to all Egyptians is that the United States stands for freedom and democracy. We encourage the Egyptian people and government to continue to move forward, but in a manner that is peaceful and ensures freedom and democracy for all. We believe in the power of self-determination and the capacity of the Egyptian people to choose their leaders in a peaceful and transparent process.

We hope that all parties involved in the political process will act responsibly and uphold the peaceful transfer of power, respecting the rights of all citizens and ensuring that the Egyptian people can freely exercise their democratic rights.

The situation with Mr. Khodorkovsky is indeed a matter of great concern, and I spoke to President Putin last night about it. The case has raised significant issues about the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary in Russia. While I don't want to speculate about Mr. Khodorkovsky's motives or his intentions, it is a fact that he was a vocal critic of the Russian government.

The United States values its relationship with Russia and wants to see Russia emerge as a strong and democratic country. We've communicated to the Russian government that we believe their legal system should operate independently and in accordance with internationally accepted norms. We've urged them to respect the rule of law at home and around the world.

As for the implications for U.S.-Russian relations, it is important for us to maintain a constructive and strategic dialogue with Russia on a variety of issues, including security,经贸关系、防扩散、打击恐怖主义等。我们对俄罗斯的期望是他们能够成为一个强大而民主的国家。我们会继续监测事态发展，并在我们认为必要时与俄罗斯政府进行沟通。我们的目标是促进两国之间的建设性和战略性的关系。

Thank you for your question. The process for selecting a Supreme Court Justice is a critical matter and one that I take very seriously. As the President of the United States, my role is to nominate a candidate who I believe would be a stellar addition to the Supreme Court, someone who has a deep respect for the Constitution and the rule of law.

The selection process typically begins with seeking advice from individuals who understand the significance of the position and its impact on our society. This includes consultation with Senators, both from my own party and across the aisle, as well as legal experts and other stakeholders.

As for the agreement reached between 14 Republicans and Democrats on judicial nominations, while it certainly is an important development in the oversight and confirmation process for judicial nominees, it does not directly affect the nomination process itself. I aim to nominate a candidate who is highly qualified, has a strong judicial philosophy, and can garner support from a bipartisan group of Senators for confirmation. It is within a nominee's path to go through the Senate confirmation process, which, under this agreement, would aim to provide a fair and efficient review period for nominees.

In essence, the nomination process remains the responsibility of the Executive Branch. However, the legislative process for confirmation, which now benefits from a structured timeline, as agreed upon by a bipartisan group of Senators, serves to minimize delays and expedite the confirmation process, thereby ensuring that the judiciary receives the attention it deserves.

Thank you for your question on this important issue. Looking back on our response to Hurricane Katrina, there are several areas where I believe we could have improved our efforts. Initially, we focused on the federal response and coordinating with the other levels of government, both state and local, to better support the people in the affected regions. 

As President, I took responsibility for the overall federal response, and I could have been more assertive in ensuring all agencies were operating effectively and efficiently. We learned important lessons from this experience, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was restructured to be better equipped and more responsive in future emergency situations.

Additionally, ensuring clear communication channels and more robust coordination among all branches of government during an immediate crisis would be critical improvements. I also believe that improving transparency and providing clearer, more frequent updates to the American people during a crisis would help in fostering accountability and maintaining public trust. 

The federal response to natural disasters has been strengthened in the years following Katrina, and these improvements would not have been achieved if we had not faced the significant challenges that came with the storm. We worked hard to ensure that our country was better prepared for the next time it faced a disaster of this magnitude.

I appreciate the opportunity to address the questions surrounding the nomination of Harriet Miers. The process of nominating a Supreme Court Justice is a serious matter that requires a thorough and careful consideration of the nominee's qualifications, experience, and judicial philosophy.
